fields.body:
Luc Ladmiral was awakened shortly after 4am on the morning of Monday, January 11, 1993, by a telephone call. His friends the Romands' house was on fire; he should come. When Luc arrived, the firefighters were bringing out the bodies. All his life he will remember the sealed grey plastic bags into which they had put the children: too horrible to look at. Florence, Mrs Romand, had simply been covered with a coat. Her face, blackened by the smoke, was unmarked. Smoothing her hair in a desolate gesture of farewell, Luc's fingers encountered something strange. He felt around, carefully tilting the young woman's head to one side, then called over a firefighter to show him, at the base of the skull, an open wound. It must have been from a beam that fell on her, the firefighter said; part of the attic had collapsed. Luc then clambered into the red vehicle where the rescuers had placed Jean-Claude, Florence's husband, the only one of the family who was still alive. His pulse was weak. He was in pyjamas, unconscious, burned yet already as cold as a corpse.

Luc and Jean-Claude had been friends ever since medical school in Lyon. They'd got married almost at the same time; their children had grown up together. Each knew everything about the other's life - the public image, but also the secrets, the secrets of honest, reliable men who were all the more vulnerable to temptation. When Jean-Claude had confided in him about an affair, talked about chucking everything in, Luc had made him listen to reason. Their lives were very similar, even if they hadn't succeeded in the same way. Jean-Claude had become a leading figure in the world of medical research, hobnobbing with government ministers, always off at international conferences, while Luc was a GP in Ferney-Voltaire, a town on the French side of the Swiss border, just a few miles north of Geneva. The Romands lived in the nearby village of Prévessin.

Later that Monday morning, Luc phoned the casualty department in Geneva: Jean-Claude, who was 38, had been placed in a hyperbaric oxygen chamber; the prognosis was guarded. Luc prayed with his wife Cécile and the children that he would never regain consciousness.

When Luc went to his office, two policemen were waiting for him. Their questions seemed odd. They wanted to know if the Romands had any enemies, if they'd been involved in any suspicious activities... Seeing Luc's astonishment, the police told him the truth. An initial examination of the bodies revealed that the victims had died before the fire, Florence from head injuries inflicted by a blunt instrument, the children - five-year-old Antoine and seven-year-old Caroline - from bullet wounds.

That wasn't all. In Clairvaux-les-Lacs, in the Jura Mountains some 50 miles to the north-west of Ferney, Jean-Claude's uncle had been delegated to break the tragic news to the injured man's parents, a frail elderly couple. Accompanied by their doctor, he had found the house locked, the dog mysteriously silent. Worried, the uncle had broken open the door to discover his brother, his sister-in-law and the dog lying in their own blood. They, too, had been shot.

Murdered. The Romands had been murdered. The word echoed through Luc's brain, stunning him. "Was it a robbery?" he asked, as if that word might somehow reduce the horror. The officers asked again about possible enemies, and Luc, at a loss, shook his head. Enemies? The Romands? Everyone loved them. The police needed to find out exactly what Jean-Claude did for a living. A doctor, the neighbours had said, but he didn't have a surgery. Luc explained that he was a researcher at the World Health Organisation (WHO), in Geneva. One of the officers telephoned, asking to speak to someone who worked with Dr Romand. The receptionist did not know any Dr Romand. She connected the officer to the personnel director, who consulted his files and confirmed: there was no Dr Romand at WHO.

In the course of that day, reality became even more nightmarish. Summoned to the police station in the afternoon, Luc learned that a note in Jean-Claude's handwriting confessing to the crimes had been found in his car and that everything people thought they knew about his career and professional activities was a sham. The WHO? No one there had ever heard of him. The national registry of physicians? He wasn't listed. The hospitals in Paris where he was said to be on the medical staff? He was not accredited there, nor was he a graduate of the medical school in Lyon where Luc himself, and several others, swore nevertheless to have been students with him. He had begun his studies, yes, but had stopped taking his exams at the end of the second year; from then on, it was all false. Latterly, Jean-Claude had confessed to Luc that he was suffering from cancer, for which he said he was being treated in Paris by the eminent oncologist Léon Schwartzenberg. Also false. Dr Schwartzenberg had no record of Jean-Claude Romand, nor had the oncology department of any other hospital in France.

At first, Luc simply refused to believe this. When someone tells you that your best friend, your daughter's godfather, the most respectable man you know has killed his wife, his children, his parents, and that in addition he has been lying to you about everything for years, isn't it normal to go on believing in him, even in the face of overwhelming proof?

It soon came out that Jean-Claude had an on-off relationship with a woman called Corinne Hourtin - a child psychologist, now divorced, who had once lived in Ferney with her husband Rémi. She had handed over to Jean-Claude 900,000 francs (about £90,000) in savings that he was to have invested for her in Switzerland. He had embezzled it instead. Other revelations came from Florence's family, the Crolets. They, too, had entrusted money to Jean-Claude: first the father's retirement bonus, and then, after his death, a million francs netted from the sale of his house. Their grief was compounded by an agonising suspicion: M Crolet had died in a fall on a staircase when he was alone with Jean-Claude. Had he been yet another victim of his son-in-law?

Everyone was wondering: how could we have lived beside this man for so long without suspecting a thing? Everyone tried to remember a moment when some suspicion had crossed their minds. Luc himself remembered that he'd been struck by something a few months earlier, after learning from Florence that Jean-Claude had ranked fifth in all of Paris in his finals. What astonished Luc wasn't this achievement but the fact that he hadn't learned of it at the time. Why hadn't Jean-Claude mentioned it? Questioned, accused of being secretive, Jean-Claude had shrugged, said he didn't want to make a big deal of it, and changed the subject. It was extraordinary, this ability to deflect conversation whenever it turned to him. Thinking back on it, you ended up admiring his discretion, his modesty, his desire to show others to advantage. Yet Luc had felt vaguely that there was something not quite right in what Jean-Claude said about his career. He'd considered calling WHO to discover exactly what it was he did there - but had decided the whole thing was absurd. And now he kept telling himself that if he'd gone through with it, maybe things would have turned out differently.

"Perhaps," said Cécile when he told her of his remorse, "... perhaps he would have killed you as well."

Three days after the fire, the Ladmirals learned that Jean-Claude was going to live.

Jean-Claude Romand's early childhood was spent in a small village in the Jura where his father ran a farm. Neighbours, cousins, schoolteachers all remember a well-behaved little boy, quiet and sweet, whom some are tempted to describe as too well-behaved, too quiet, too sweet. An only child, perhaps somewhat overprotected by his mother. A child who never got up to any mischief, more respectable - if one can say that about a child - than truly lovable, but even so a child whom no one imagined to be unhappy. He says that his mother worried all the time and that he learned early on to mislead her so that she wouldn't worry even more. He admired his father for never showing his feelings and tried to imitate him. It was better to conceal them. On the one hand, he had been taught not to lie, and that was absolute dogma: a Romand was as good as his word, a Romand told the truth and shamed the Devil. On the other hand, there were certain things you shouldn't say, even if they were true. You had to avoid upsetting anyone, or boasting about your success or your good qualities.

Romand achieves good grades at school. He originally plans to become a forester, but then changes his mind and decides to study medicine instead at Lyon. At the end of his second year, in 1975, he needs to resit one exam. He fails to turn up, but he tells no one, and no one notices.

Three weeks went by between the day of the examination and the posting of the results. There was still time for him to admit that he had lied. It would have been hard for him, naturally. To this serious young man, it must have seemed impossibly painful to admit a whopping error, a childish blunder like that of Antoine Doinel in Les Quatre-Cent Coups, who extricates himself from a sticky situation at school by blurting out that his mother has just died, and who then must deal with the inevitable consequences of his lies and the certainty that the truth will come out. The most baffling thing, in Romand's case, is that he committed his folly in two stages, like the computer user who, having accidentally typed the command for erasing a valuable file, when asked by the program whether he's sure he wants to delete the file, carefully considers the pros and cons - then goes ahead and destroys it anyway. Rationally speaking, anything would have been better than what Jean-Claude did: he waited for the day the results were posted and then announced that he had passed, that he'd been accepted as a third-year medical student.

How could he have foreseen that there was something worse than being quickly unmasked, which was not to be unmasked; how could he have suspected that this childish lie would lead him 18 years later to murder his parents, Florence, and the children he did not yet have?

While still ostensibly studying medicine, Jean-Claude marries Florence Crolet, a fellow student at Lyon. He supposedly passes his medical board exam and becomes first a research assistant in a medical research institution and then a research scientist at the World Health Organisation in Geneva.

Romand was always, as Florence put it, "very compartmentalised", strictly separating his personal and professional relations, never inviting colleagues from WHO to his house, refusing to allow himself to be disturbed at home by anyone from his office, or at work by any of his family or friends. Moreover, nobody had his office phone number, not even his wife, who contacted him through an answering service: you left a message in a voice mailbox, which sent him a signal on the bleeper he always carried with him, and then he quickly called back. Neither his wife nor anyone else found the arrangement strange. It was one of his personality traits, like his gruffness, which she often joked about: "One of these days, I'm going to find out my husband's a communist spy."

In the mornings, he was the one who drove the children to the Ecole Saint-Vincent. He would accompany them into the courtyard, exchange a few words with the teachers or the pupils' mothers, then drive off towards Geneva. More often than not he ended up in the car park of WHO. Entering with a visitor's badge, carrying a briefcase, he followed a familiar orbit, going from the ground-floor library to the conference rooms and the publications office, where he systematically swept up anything printed and free: his house and car overflowed with papers bearing the letterhead or stamp of WHO. He used all the services offered by the organisation - a post office where he sent his mail, a bank where he made most of his withdrawals, a travel agency through which he planned the family holidays - but did not risk going upstairs, where security guards might have asked him what he was looking for. His mother-in-law remembers that one Sunday when the whole family had gone to Switzerland, the children had wanted to see Papa's office, so Papa had agreed to the detour. They'd pulled into the car park, he'd pointed out the window. And that's all.

At first he went to WHO every day, later less regularly. He'd stop at a news-stand to buy an armful of papers: dailies, magazines, scientific journals. Then he'd go and read them, either in a cafe - he was careful to change cafes often and to choose them far enough from home - or in his car. He would park in a car park or at a service station and stay there for hours, reading, taking notes, dozing. He'd have a sandwich for lunch and continue reading throughout the afternoon in a different cafe, at a different service station. Other days, he needed open air and nature, and would drive into the Jura Mountains.

Lastly, there were the trips - conferences, seminars, symposiums, all over the world. He would buy a guide to the country; Florence would pack his suitcase. He'd drive off in his car, which he would supposedly leave in the long-term car park at Geneva airport. In a comfortable hotel room, often near the airport, he would take off his shoes, stretch out on the bed, spend three or four days watching television and the planes taking off and landing outside his window. He studied the guide books so he wouldn't make any mistakes in his stories when he got home. He telephoned his family every day to tell them what time it was and what the weather was like in Sao Paulo or Tokyo. He'd tell his wife, his children, his parents that he missed them, was thinking of them, sent them a big kiss. After a few days, he went home with presents bought in an airport gift shop. Everyone made a fuss of him. He was tired from jet lag.

Indirectly it was WHO that provided Jean-Claude with a source of income. He said or let it be understood that as an international civil servant he was in a position to make extremely advantageous investments at a rate of 18%, an opportunity he could share with his family. Jean-Claude's parents were not the kind of people to cheat on their taxes by putting their savings into Swiss banks, but as it was their son's idea that was enough for them. Romand lived on their nest egg at the beginning of his marriage. Florence declared to the income tax authorities the very modest salary she earned by temporarily filling in for pharmacists in the area, and he declared no income because, since he worked in Switzerland, he had - he said - no taxes to pay.

The year Antoine was born, Florence's father retired from his job in Annecy. A disguised redundancy, his retirement brought him a bonus of 400,000 francs. Jean-Claude agreed to do his father-in-law a favour by investing 378,000 francs for him at a Geneva bank. This sum was deposited in an account in Jean-Claude's name, since he was the one whose position entitled him to make such an investment. But one day Jean-Claude's father-in-law told him he wanted to withdraw part of his capital to buy a Mercedes. A few weeks later, on October 23, 1988, Pierre Crolet fell on the stairs of his home where he was alone with his son-in-law and died just before the arrival of the paramedics.

After the fire, a new investigation was ordered at the request of the Crolet family. Of course, it uncovered nothing. At the end of the proceedings, Jean-Claude insisted on telling the Crolet family, as God was his witness, that he had had no hand in his father-in-law's death. Short of a confession on his part some day, we will never learn any more.

What is indisputable is that the death of his father-in-law was providential for Romand. There was no longer any question of touching the money in the Swiss account. Then Mme Crolet decided to sell the house, now too large for her on her own, and handed over to her son-in-law the proceeds of the sale, which amounted to 1.3million francs.

Romand had become enraptured with Corinne Hourtin and they begin an affair when she moves to Paris. But she soon decides that she could never love him. He confides in her, as he he did to Luc Ladmiral, that he is suffering from cancer. They remain friends, and she turns to him when she had money to invest, handing over 900,000 francs in cash. He flies from Paris with a small suitcase stuffed with notes. Soon after, Corinne decides she wants some of her money back, but finds Romand evasive.

Just before the 1992 Christmas holidays, the president of the school board wanted to talk to Jean-Claude on the subject of a demoted head. The president did not know Jean-Claude well enough to be aware that one didn't call him at his office, and he had his secretary look up Jean-Claude's number in the WHO directory. Puzzled at not finding him anywhere, he imagined there must be some explanation, and he didn't think about it again until one day after the holiday when he ran into Florence in the main street of Ferney and told her about it. His tone wasn't that of a man who had suspicions but that of someone who was curious to find out the real story behind an odd mystery, and Florence reacted equally mildly. It was strange, yes, there was obviously a reason, and she'd speak to her husband about it. Florence and the man did not see each other again. One week later she was dead, and no one will ever know if she brought it up with Jean-Claude. He says she didn't.

Although he was unsure where the first blow would come from, he knew that the hounds were closing in. His various bank accounts would soon be overdrawn, and he had no means of replenishing them. People were talking about him, and talking about coming after him. Hands were flipping through directories. The look in Florence's eyes had changed. He was scared.

In the run-up to Christmas, he flew to Paris and took Corinne to dinner at the Restaurant Michel Rostang. Corinne told him that she had made up her mind and she wanted all of her money back. Instead of trying to wriggle out of it, he opened his diary to set up a meeting when he would hand over the funds. Turning the pages, he had an idea: he had agreed to have dinner at the start of the new year with his friend Bernard Kouchner, illustrious co-founder of Médecins Sans Frontières. Would Corinne like to join them? Of course Corinne would like that. Before then, though, he would be dead.

On the flight home, he continued to study his diary. Christmas wasn't a good day, that would be too cruel for the children. Caroline was going to play Mary and Antoine one of the shepherds in the Nativity play at the church. So, right after New Year?

Jean-Claude did not go to work on the Tuesday after the New Year. Florence and he ran errands in Ferney. She insisted that he buy a new suit; he let himself be tempted by a parka for 3,200 francs. The saleswoman thought they seemed a couple who were at leisure, well-off, and getting along fine.

Jean-Claude had spent the morning studying books such as the Vidal pharmacological dictionary; he rejected drugs that caused instantaneous death in favour of barbiturates with a rapid serum peak for a comfortable lapse into unconsciousness. Everything would be ready by Friday, January 8, said the pharmacist, would that do? It would do.

That evening, Romand read a story to the children. He left for Lyon on Wednesday morning. At 2.08pm he obtained 1,000 francs from the cashpoint, and another 1,000 francs at 2.45pm. Between the two withdrawals, he says, he gave a 500-franc note to a homeless person. Then, in a gun shop, he bought a stun wand, two tear gas canisters, a box of cartridges and a silencer for a .22 calibre rifle.

"So," the judge pointed out, "you weren't thinking only of killing yourself. You were living with your wife and children while you were planning to kill them."

"That idea did surface... but it was immediately masked by other false plans, other false ideas. It was as though the idea didn't exist... I pretended... I told myself I was doing something else, that it was for a different reason, and at the same time... at the same time I was buying the bullets that would pierce my children's hearts."

He sobbed.

On the Thursday, Jean-Claude went to visit his parents in Clairvaux. The next day, after the children had gone to bed, Florence had a long phone conversation with her mother. Mme Crolet complained bitterly about being a widow, about growing old, about being neglected by her children. Her unhappiness affected Florence, who began crying after she hung up. Jean-Claude joined her on the sofa. That is the last image he has. He is sitting next to her, he has taken her in his arms, he is trying to comfort her.

"I don't remember her last words." He went on: "I am unable to say what happened between the time when I was consoling Florence on the sofa and the moment I woke up holding the rolling pin stained with blood."

Early that Saturday morning, the telephone rang, which woke the children. They were always quicker to bounce out of bed on days when they didn't have school. Jean-Claude told them that Mama was still sleeping, and the three of them went downstairs to the living room. He put a tape of The Three Little Pigs in the video, prepared bowls of Coco Pops with milk. With him in the middle, they settled themselves on the sofa to watch the cartoon while they ate their cereal.

"I knew after having killed Florence that I was also going to kill Antoine and Caroline and that those moments in front of the television were the last that we would spend together. I cuddled them. I must have said sweet things to them, like, 'I love you.' "

"We stayed like that for perhaps an hour... Caroline saw that I was cold, she wanted to go upstairs to get my dressing gown... I said that I thought they seemed rather hot, that perhaps they had a fever and I was going to take their temperature. Caroline went upstairs with me, I had her lie down on her bed... I went to get the rifle ..."

"What did you say to Caroline?" asked the judge.

"I don't know any more... She'd lain down on her stomach... That's when I shot her."

"Go on..."

He sobbed. "I shot Caroline the first time... She had a pillow over her head... I must have been pretending it was a game." Here he moaned, his eyes closed. "I pulled the trigger... I put the rifle somewhere in the room... I called Antoine... and I did it again."

"Perhaps I should help you a bit, because the jury needs details and you're not being specific enough."

"Caroline, when she was born, it was the most wonderful day of my life... She was beautiful" - he moaned - "in my arms... for her first bath." A spasm shook his body. "I'm the one who killed her... I'm the one who killed her."

The policemen, appalled, held him gently by the arms.

"Don't you think Antoine could have heard the gunshots? Had you attached the silencer? Did you call him upstairs on the same pretext? To take his temperature? He didn't find that strange?"

"I don't have an image of that precise moment. It was still them, but it couldn't be Caroline... it couldn't be Antoine..."

The prosecutor spoke up. Afterwards, he said, Romand went out to buy the local paper and a sports daily, L'Equipe, and the newspaper seller thought he looked completely normal.

"Were you trying to behave as if nothing had happened, as if life was going on as usual?"

"I couldn't have bought L'Equipe. I never read it."

"Neighbours saw you cross the street to check your postbox."

"Did I do it to deny reality, to pretend?"

"Why did you wrap up the rifle and carefully put it away before you left for Clairvaux?"

"In reality, to kill them, of course, but I must have told myself that it was to return it to my father."

Jean-Claude does not remember the drive to his parents' home later on the Saturday morning. We know the three of them had lunch together. Dishes were still on the table when Uncle Claude entered the house two days later, and the postmortem examination revealed that the stomachs of Aimé and Anne-Marie Romand were full. Did Jean-Claude eat anything? Did his mother urge him to have something? What did they talk about?

First he lured his father upstairs with the excuse of examining a malodorous air vent the old man had complained about. The old man, who couldn't bend over because of back trouble, must have knelt down to point out the defective vent, which was set into the skirting-board. That was when he received two bullets in the back. His son covered him with a wine-coloured corduroy bedspread that had been in the room since Jean-Claude's childhood. Then he went to get his mother. She hadn't heard the gunshots, fired with a silencer. He made her go into the sitting room, which they never used. She was the only one who was shot from the front.

He carefully closed up the house and drove off at around two o'clock. He was heading for Paris where he was to meet Corinne.

 Read the second part of the story here.

 Taken from the book The Adversary by Emmanuel Carrére and translated by Linda Coverdale to be published by Bloomsbury on 22 January 2001 at 14.99

In Clairvaux-les-Lacs, in the Jura Mountains some 50 miles to the north-west of Ferney, Jean-Claude's uncle had been delegated to break the tragic news to the injured man's parents, a frail elderly couple. Accompanied by their doctor, he had found the house locked, the dog mysteriously silent. Worried, the uncle had broken open the door to discover his brother, his sister-in-law and the dog lying in their own blood. They, too, had been shot. Murdered. The Romands had been murdered. The word echoed through Luc's brain, stunning him. "Was it a robbery?" he asked, as if that word might somehow reduce the horror. The officers asked again about possible enemies, and Luc, at a loss, shook his head. Enemies? The Romands? Everyone loved them. The police needed to find out exactly what Jean-Claude did for a living. A doctor, the neighbours had said, but he didn't have a surgery. Luc explained that he was a researcher at the World Health Organisation (WHO), in Geneva. One of the officers telephoned, asking to speak to someone who worked with Dr Romand. The receptionist did not know any Dr Romand. She connected the officer to the personnel director, who consulted his files and confirmed: there was no Dr Romand at WHO. In the course of that day, reality became even more nightmarish. Summoned to the police station in the afternoon, Luc learned that a note in Jean-Claude's handwriting confessing to the crimes had been found in his car and that everything people thought they knew about his career and professional activities was a sham. The WHO? No one there had ever heard of him. The national registry of physicians? He wasn't listed. The hospitals in Paris where he was said to be on the medical staff? He was not accredited there, nor was he a graduate of the medical school in Lyon where Luc himself, and several others, swore nevertheless to have been students with him. He had begun his studies, yes, but had stopped taking his exams at the end of the second year; from then on, it was all false. Latterly, Jean-Claude had confessed to Luc that he was suffering from cancer, for which he said he was being treated in Paris by the eminent oncologist Léon Schwartzenberg. Also false. Dr Schwartzenberg had no record of Jean-Claude Romand, nor had the oncology department of any other hospital in France. At first, Luc simply refused to believe this. When someone tells you that your best friend, your daughter's godfather, the most respectable man you know has killed his wife, his children, his parents, and that in addition he has been lying to you about everything for years, isn't it normal to go on believing in him, even in the face of overwhelming proof? It soon came out that Jean-Claude had an on-off relationship with a woman called Corinne Hourtin - a child psychologist, now divorced, who had once lived in Ferney with her husband Rémi. She had handed over to Jean-Claude 900,000 francs (about £90,000) in savings that he was to have invested for her in Switzerland. He had embezzled it instead. Other revelations came from Florence's family, the Crolets. They, too, had entrusted money to Jean-Claude: first the father's retirement bonus, and then, after his death, a million francs netted from the sale of his house. Their grief was compounded by an agonising suspicion: M Crolet had died in a fall on a staircase when he was alone with Jean-Claude. Had he been yet another victim of his son-in-law? Everyone was wondering: how could we have lived beside this man for so long without suspecting a thing? Everyone tried to remember a moment when some suspicion had crossed their minds. Luc himself remembered that he'd been struck by something a few months earlier, after learning from Florence that Jean-Claude had ranked fifth in all of Paris in his finals. What astonished Luc wasn't this achievement but the fact that he hadn't learned of it at the time. Why hadn't Jean-Claude mentioned it? Questioned, accused of being secretive, Jean-Claude had shrugged, said he didn't want to make a big deal of it, and changed the subject. It was extraordinary, this ability to deflect conversation whenever it turned to him. Thinking back on it, you ended up admiring his discretion, his modesty, his desire to show others to advantage. Yet Luc had felt vaguely that there was something not quite right in what Jean-Claude said about his career. He'd considered calling WHO to discover exactly what it was he did there - but had decided the whole thing was absurd. And now he kept telling himself that if he'd gone through with it, maybe things would have turned out differently. "Perhaps," said Cécile when he told her of his remorse, "... perhaps he would have killed you as well." Three days after the fire, the Ladmirals learned that Jean-Claude was going to live. Jean-Claude Romand's early childhood was spent in a small village in the Jura where his father ran a farm. Neighbours, cousins, schoolteachers all remember a well-behaved little boy, quiet and sweet, whom some are tempted to describe as too well-behaved, too quiet, too sweet. An only child, perhaps somewhat overprotected by his mother. A child who never got up to any mischief, more respectable - if one can say that about a child - than truly lovable, but even so a child whom no one imagined to be unhappy. He says that his mother worried all the time and that he learned early on to mislead her so that she wouldn't worry even more. He admired his father for never showing his feelings and tried to imitate him. It was better to conceal them. On the one hand, he had been taught not to lie, and that was absolute dogma: a Romand was as good as his word, a Romand told the truth and shamed the Devil. On the other hand, there were certain things you shouldn't say, even if they were true. You had to avoid upsetting anyone, or boasting about your success or your good qualities. Romand achieves good grades at school. He originally plans to become a forester, but then changes his mind and decides to study medicine instead at Lyon. At the end of his second year, in 1975, he needs to resit one exam. He fails to turn up, but he tells no one, and no one notices. Three weeks went by between the day of the examination and the posting of the results. There was still time for him to admit that he had lied. It would have been hard for him, naturally. To this serious young man, it must have seemed impossibly painful to admit a whopping error, a childish blunder like that of Antoine Doinel in Les Quatre-Cent Coups, who extricates himself from a sticky situation at school by blurting out that his mother has just died, and who then must deal with the inevitable consequences of his lies and the certainty that the truth will come out. The most baffling thing, in Romand's case, is that he committed his folly in two stages, like the computer user who, having accidentally typed the command for erasing a valuable file, when asked by the program whether he's sure he wants to delete the file, carefully considers the pros and cons - then goes ahead and destroys it anyway. Rationally speaking, anything would have been better than what Jean-Claude did: he waited for the day the results were posted and then announced that he had passed, that he'd been accepted as a third-year medical student. How could he have foreseen that there was something worse than being quickly unmasked, which was not to be unmasked; how could he have suspected that this childish lie would lead him 18 years later to murder his parents, Florence, and the children he did not yet have? While still ostensibly studying medicine, Jean-Claude marries Florence Crolet, a fellow student at Lyon. He supposedly passes his medical board exam and becomes first a research assistant in a medical research institution and then a research scientist at the World Health Organisation in Geneva. Romand was always, as Florence put it, "very compartmentalised", strictly separating his personal and professional relations, never inviting colleagues from WHO to his house, refusing to allow himself to be disturbed at home by anyone from his office, or at work by any of his family or friends. Moreover, nobody had his office phone number, not even his wife, who contacted him through an answering service: you left a message in a voice mailbox, which sent him a signal on the bleeper he always carried with him, and then he quickly called back. Neither his wife nor anyone else found the arrangement strange. It was one of his personality traits, like his gruffness, which she often joked about: "One of these days, I'm going to find out my husband's a communist spy." In the mornings, he was the one who drove the children to the Ecole Saint-Vincent. He would accompany them into the courtyard, exchange a few words with the teachers or the pupils' mothers, then drive off towards Geneva. More often than not he ended up in the car park of WHO. Entering with a visitor's badge, carrying a briefcase, he followed a familiar orbit, going from the ground-floor library to the conference rooms and the publications office, where he systematically swept up anything printed and free: his house and car overflowed with papers bearing the letterhead or stamp of WHO. He used all the services offered by the organisation - a post office where he sent his mail, a bank where he made most of his withdrawals, a travel agency through which he planned the family holidays - but did not risk going upstairs, where security guards might have asked him what he was looking for. His mother-in-law remembers that one Sunday when the whole family had gone to Switzerland, the children had wanted to see Papa's office, so Papa had agreed to the detour. They'd pulled into the car park, he'd pointed out the window. And that's all. At first he went to WHO every day, later less regularly. He'd stop at a news-stand to buy an armful of papers: dailies, magazines, scientific journals. Then he'd go and read them, either in a cafe - he was careful to change cafes often and to choose them far enough from home - or in his car. He would park in a car park or at a service station and stay there for hours, reading, taking notes, dozing. He'd have a sandwich for lunch and continue reading throughout the afternoon in a different cafe, at a different service station. Other days, he needed open air and nature, and would drive into the Jura Mountains. Lastly, there were the trips - conferences, seminars, symposiums, all over the world. He would buy a guide to the country; Florence would pack his suitcase. He'd drive off in his car, which he would supposedly leave in the long-term car park at Geneva airport. In a comfortable hotel room, often near the airport, he would take off his shoes, stretch out on the bed, spend three or four days watching television and the planes taking off and landing outside his window. He studied the guide books so he wouldn't make any mistakes in his stories when he got home. He telephoned his family every day to tell them what time it was and what the weather was like in Sao Paulo or Tokyo. He'd tell his wife, his children, his parents that he missed them, was thinking of them, sent them a big kiss. After a few days, he went home with presents bought in an airport gift shop. Everyone made a fuss of him. He was tired from jet lag. Indirectly it was WHO that provided Jean-Claude with a source of income. He said or let it be understood that as an international civil servant he was in a position to make extremely advantageous investments at a rate of 18%, an opportunity he could share with his family. Jean-Claude's parents were not the kind of people to cheat on their taxes by putting their savings into Swiss banks, but as it was their son's idea that was enough for them. Romand lived on their nest egg at the beginning of his marriage. Florence declared to the income tax authorities the very modest salary she earned by temporarily filling in for pharmacists in the area, and he declared no income because, since he worked in Switzerland, he had - he said - no taxes to pay. The year Antoine was born, Florence's father retired from his job in Annecy. A disguised redundancy, his retirement brought him a bonus of 400,000 francs. Jean-Claude agreed to do his father-in-law a favour by investing 378,000 francs for him at a Geneva bank. This sum was deposited in an account in Jean-Claude's name, since he was the one whose position entitled him to make such an investment. But one day Jean-Claude's father-in-law told him he wanted to withdraw part of his capital to buy a Mercedes. A few weeks later, on October 23, 1988, Pierre Crolet fell on the stairs of his home where he was alone with his son-in-law and died just before the arrival of the paramedics. After the fire, a new investigation was ordered at the request of the Crolet family. Of course, it uncovered nothing. At the end of the proceedings, Jean-Claude insisted on telling the Crolet family, as God was his witness, that he had had no hand in his father-in-law's death. Short of a confession on his part some day, we will never learn any more. What is indisputable is that the death of his father-in-law was providential for Romand. There was no longer any question of touching the money in the Swiss account. Then Mme Crolet decided to sell the house, now too large for her on her own, and handed over to her son-in-law the proceeds of the sale, which amounted to 1.3million francs. Romand had become enraptured with Corinne Hourtin and they begin an affair when she moves to Paris. But she soon decides that she could never love him. He confides in her, as he he did to Luc Ladmiral, that he is suffering from cancer. They remain friends, and she turns to him when she had money to invest, handing over 900,000 francs in cash. He flies from Paris with a small suitcase stuffed with notes. Soon after, Corinne decides she wants some of her money back, but finds Romand evasive. Just before the 1992 Christmas holidays, the president of the school board wanted to talk to Jean-Claude on the subject of a demoted head. The president did not know Jean-Claude well enough to be aware that one didn't call him at his office, and he had his secretary look up Jean-Claude's number in the WHO directory. Puzzled at not finding him anywhere, he imagined there must be some explanation, and he didn't think about it again until one day after the holiday when he ran into Florence in the main street of Ferney and told her about it. His tone wasn't that of a man who had suspicions but that of someone who was curious to find out the real story behind an odd mystery, and Florence reacted equally mildly. It was strange, yes, there was obviously a reason, and she'd speak to her husband about it. Florence and the man did not see each other again. One week later she was dead, and no one will ever know if she brought it up with Jean-Claude. He says she didn't. Although he was unsure where the first blow would come from, he knew that the hounds were closing in. His various bank accounts would soon be overdrawn, and he had no means of replenishing them. People were talking about him, and talking about coming after him. Hands were flipping through directories. The look in Florence's eyes had changed. He was scared. In the run-up to Christmas, he flew to Paris and took Corinne to dinner at the Restaurant Michel Rostang. Corinne told him that she had made up her mind and she wanted all of her money back. Instead of trying to wriggle out of it, he opened his diary to set up a meeting when he would hand over the funds. Turning the pages, he had an idea: he had agreed to have dinner at the start of the new year with his friend Bernard Kouchner, illustrious co-founder of Médecins Sans Frontières. Would Corinne like to join them? Of course Corinne would like that. Before then, though, he would be dead. On the flight home, he continued to study his diary. Christmas wasn't a good day, that would be too cruel for the children. Caroline was going to play Mary and Antoine one of the shepherds in the Nativity play at the church. So, right after New Year? Jean-Claude did not go to work on the Tuesday after the New Year. Florence and he ran errands in Ferney. She insisted that he buy a new suit; he let himself be tempted by a parka for 3,200 francs. The saleswoman thought they seemed a couple who were at leisure, well-off, and getting along fine. Jean-Claude had spent the morning studying books such as the Vidal pharmacological dictionary; he rejected drugs that caused instantaneous death in favour of barbiturates with a rapid serum peak for a comfortable lapse into unconsciousness. Everything would be ready by Friday, January 8, said the pharmacist, would that do? It would do. That evening, Romand read a story to the children. He left for Lyon on Wednesday morning. At 2.08pm he obtained 1,000 francs from the cashpoint, and another 1,000 francs at 2.45pm. Between the two withdrawals, he says, he gave a 500-franc note to a homeless person. Then, in a gun shop, he bought a stun wand, two tear gas canisters, a box of cartridges and a silencer for a .22 calibre rifle. "So," the judge pointed out, "you weren't thinking only of killing yourself. You were living with your wife and children while you were planning to kill them." "That idea did surface... but it was immediately masked by other false plans, other false ideas. It was as though the idea didn't exist... I pretended... I told myself I was doing something else, that it was for a different reason, and at the same time... at the same time I was buying the bullets that would pierce my children's hearts." He sobbed. On the Thursday, Jean-Claude went to visit his parents in Clairvaux. The next day, after the children had gone to bed, Florence had a long phone conversation with her mother. Mme Crolet complained bitterly about being a widow, about growing old, about being neglected by her children. Her unhappiness affected Florence, who began crying after she hung up. Jean-Claude joined her on the sofa. That is the last image he has. He is sitting next to her, he has taken her in his arms, he is trying to comfort her. "I don't remember her last words." He went on: "I am unable to say what happened between the time when I was consoling Florence on the sofa and the moment I woke up holding the rolling pin stained with blood." Early that Saturday morning, the telephone rang, which woke the children. They were always quicker to bounce out of bed on days when they didn't have school. Jean-Claude told them that Mama was still sleeping, and the three of them went downstairs to the living room. He put a tape of The Three Little Pigs in the video, prepared bowls of Coco Pops with milk. With him in the middle, they settled themselves on the sofa to watch the cartoon while they ate their cereal. "I knew after having killed Florence that I was also going to kill Antoine and Caroline and that those moments in front of the television were the last that we would spend together. I cuddled them. I must have said sweet things to them, like, 'I love you.' " "We stayed like that for perhaps an hour... Caroline saw that I was cold, she wanted to go upstairs to get my dressing gown... I said that I thought they seemed rather hot, that perhaps they had a fever and I was going to take their temperature. Caroline went upstairs with me, I had her lie down on her bed... I went to get the rifle ..." "What did you say to Caroline?" asked the judge. "I don't know any more... She'd lain down on her stomach... That's when I shot her." "Go on..." He sobbed. "I shot Caroline the first time... She had a pillow over her head... I must have been pretending it was a game." Here he moaned, his eyes closed. "I pulled the trigger... I put the rifle somewhere in the room... I called Antoine... and I did it again." "Perhaps I should help you a bit, because the jury needs details and you're not being specific enough." "Caroline, when she was born, it was the most wonderful day of my life... She was beautiful" - he moaned - "in my arms... for her first bath." A spasm shook his body. "I'm the one who killed her... I'm the one who killed her." The policemen, appalled, held him gently by the arms. "Don't you think Antoine could have heard the gunshots? Had you attached the silencer? Did you call him upstairs on the same pretext? To take his temperature? He didn't find that strange?" "I don't have an image of that precise moment. It was still them, but it couldn't be Caroline... it couldn't be Antoine..." The prosecutor spoke up. Afterwards, he said, Romand went out to buy the local paper and a sports daily, L'Equipe, and the newspaper seller thought he looked completely normal. "Were you trying to behave as if nothing had happened, as if life was going on as usual?" "I couldn't have bought L'Equipe. I never read it." "Neighbours saw you cross the street to check your postbox." "Did I do it to deny reality, to pretend?" "Why did you wrap up the rifle and carefully put it away before you left for Clairvaux?" "In reality, to kill them, of course, but I must have told myself that it was to return it to my father." Jean-Claude does not remember the drive to his parents' home later on the Saturday morning. We know the three of them had lunch together. Dishes were still on the table when Uncle Claude entered the house two days later, and the postmortem examination revealed that the stomachs of Aimé and Anne-Marie Romand were full. Did Jean-Claude eat anything? Did his mother urge him to have something? What did they talk about? First he lured his father upstairs with the excuse of examining a malodorous air vent the old man had complained about. The old man, who couldn't bend over because of back trouble, must have knelt down to point out the defective vent, which was set into the skirting-board. That was when he received two bullets in the back. His son covered him with a wine-coloured corduroy bedspread that had been in the room since Jean-Claude's childhood. Then he went to get his mother. She hadn't heard the gunshots, fired with a silencer. He made her go into the sitting room, which they never used. She was the only one who was shot from the front. He carefully closed up the house and drove off at around two o'clock. He was heading for Paris where he was to meet Corinne.  Read the second part of the story here.  Taken from the book The Adversary by Emmanuel Carrére and translated by Linda Coverdale to be published by Bloomsbury on 22 January 2001 at 14.99

fields.headline: Et cetera
fields.standfirst: Steven Poole  on new non-fiction
fields.trailText: Steven Poole on new non-fiction: Words Alone: The Poet T S Eliot, Java Man and Lost Highways
fields.body:
Words Alone: The Poet T S Eliot
Denis Donoghue
(Yale, £17.95)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Festooned, this is, with plaudits from Frank Kermode and the estimable Michael Wood, so it is at first promising. Is Donoghue in the same league as Wood? Not to my taste: his is a gently moralising kind of criticism, always too ready to bring Eliot's life to the table. Donoghue has a wry humour, and he is reliable on the background - the French symbolists, F H Bradley and all that, although he travesties Wallace Stevens the better to praise Eliot - but in critical terms he never quite manages to do more than a broad-brush sketch of metrical and metaphorical technique. It is the spadework to a close reading, without the consequent analysis. His treatment of Eliot's "Burbank with a Baedeker: Bleistein with a Cigar", made notorious by accusations of anti-Semitism from Anthony Julius and others ("The rats are underneath the piles./ The Jew is underneath the lot"), is representative. First Donoghue soberly divides responses to the poem into six types, and then attempts to defend the guilty lines by appeal to style indirect libre. We are to read them, he contends, as Burbank's own perceptions: a defence persuasively denied the poem by Julius and Ricks. That done, Donoghue blandly continues "Few critics have remarked how fine the poetry is", seemingly unaware of the bathos.

Java Man
Garniss Curtis, Carl Swisher and Roger Lewin
(Little, Brown, £18.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Ah, I nodded sagely to myself, as I warmed my cafetière and ground my beans, a much-needed history of homo caffeinus, man perfected by coffee. Or - just perhaps - a bijou history of multi-platform internet programming. Imagine my surprise when I found out it was actually about human evolution. Java Man is the nickname for homo erectus, once supposed to be a simple evolutionary precursor to homo sapiens. But this well-told pop-science yarn shows how our geochronologist heroes changed all that by proving that Java Man was still roaming the earth a mere 50,000 years ago. So far from our evolution being a business of smooth transitions, it appears that at one point, homo sapiens was battling it out with homo erectus and even Neanderthal Man for planetary supremacy. Think of it as Robot Wars, only with hairy people.

Lost Highways
eds Jack Sargeant and Stephanie Watson
(Creation Books, £14.95)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Road movies are oddly miscalled, for they are not really about roads. Or are they? Perhaps in David Lynch. This book doesn't seem to know either, being a highly variable collection of essays by different writers on such themes as "Biker Movies", "Killer Couples" and "Pulp Noir on the Road". Much anaemic plot summary, and little insight; though the retrospective classification of The Wizard of Oz as a road movie is cute, and there is some bloody satisfaction to be had in Omaya Cruz and Ray Guins's essay on "Vampire Road Movies". Nice pictures, too.

webTitle: Small press corner: The Devil's Dictionary, by Ambrose Bierce

fields.headline: The Devil's Dictionary, by Ambrose Bierce
fields.standfirst: Parsimony Press, £1.50
fields.trailText: "Patience, n. A minor form of despair disguised as a virtue."
fields.body: Take a 19th-century American satirist, set him between hard covers in a format small enough to slip into a pocket and tough enough to survive therein, and undercut all other purveyors thereof. Such is the philosophy of Somerset-based Parsimony Press, whose first batch of books includes this gem from the "laughing devil" of San Fransisco. Bierce's bons mots would make good travel companions in the era of the train delay, to wit: "Patience, n. A minor form of despair disguised as a virtue." Other titles include Graves' Garden Birds - early 19th-century ornithological engravings - a guide to climbing roses, ideal for the glove compartment of a garden-centre nut's car and, less convincingly, The Basics of Cooking.

fields.trailText: Le Carré winds the listener nice and slowly into this tale of the unacceptable face of global pharmaceutics
fields.body:
The Constant Gardener, written and read by John le Carré (Hodder, £14.99, 360mn)

Backed by spooky, ambiguous African drumming, le Carré winds the listener nice and slowly into this tale of the unacceptable face of global pharmaceutics. The British high commission is more familiar territory than his last novel about a dodgy merchant bank, although his dialogue is dated. Does anyone under 80, in or out of a pith hat, use the word "pray" as in "what, pray, do you mean"? The themes are bang au courant, though: tuberculosis revival, use of developing world to test drugs, etc. Even his passion for reading his own stuff is more successfully sated. Justin, the buttoned-up old-Etonian diplomat protagonist who's getting on a bit, doesn't demand too much of an accent shift.

fields.headline: Adult grief, childish hope
fields.trailText: Isobel Montgomery gets lost in Hans-Ulrich Treichel's Lost, plus The Constant Eye, Kingdom of Shadows, The Verificationist and A Heart Of Stone
fields.body:
Lost

Hans-Ulrich Treichel

(Picador, £5)

Buy it at a discount at BOL

This is the story of a German family living on the fat of the Wirtschaftswunder but unable to enjoy prosperity until they discover what happened to the child they lost on the trek west to escape the Red Army - smells like a history lesson dressed up as literature. But through the unnamed narrator, the child who will never compensate for the loss of his big brother, Treichel sustains a dark comedy of adult grief and childish hope. The parents' efforts to discover whether an orphan child, known only by its number, might be Arnold, is a high point of sad comedy. The boy's selfish desire that Arnold be lost forever, and his cynicism towards his parents' grief, are utterly convincing.

The Constant Eye

Candida Clark

(Vintage, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Clark's debut, involving a love affair between a young woman and a dying writer, was followed by this second novel, which centres on a flirtation between a writer and a beautiful woman on the Eurostar to Paris. Clark has already found niches both in plot and style to explore. She is clearly fascinated and repelled by the notion of the writer as vampire, preying on people and experiences to remake as novels, and stylistically intrigued by the minutiae of two characters' sexual obsessions. The Constant Eye succeeds, aided by a conventional narrative trick, in sustaining the reader's interest through the unfolding of a gossamer-thin plot about the exercise of power.

Kingdom of Shadows

Alan Furst

(Phoenix, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

A Hungarian émigré in post-Anschluss, pre-Munich Paris who is prepared to deal with Nazis, communists and British spies in the hope that his country will be able to sit out the coming world war as a neutral is not the most comfortable of heroes. The politics of a former cavalry officer in the Austro-Hungarian army are surely suspect, and his cause - a Hungary allied neither to Moscow nor Berlin - seems an already outdated bourgeois fantasy. While Furst is expert at evoking an anxious Europe peopled by the already or soon-to-be dispossessed, Morath is inescapably a character whom hindsight says should be consigned to the dustbin of history with little regret.

The Verificationist

Donald Antrim

(Bloomsbury, £6.99)

Buy it at a discount at BOL

A dinner gathering of 20 east-coast psychotherapists in a pancake house is a delicious device: no gesture, word or intonation can be taken at face value. The venue? For Tom, "Breakfast foods have, in my experience, a comforting, anti-depressant quality." Choice is an "inevitable invitation to loss". The danger with such a rich premise is the descent into routine farce, from which Antrim is not immune. But he prefers wit to pantomime pratfalls, and the descent of hero Tom from mild social discomfort to a complete loss of self is tinged with anxiety. Antrim's comic portrayal of the American intelligentsia has real substance.

A Heart Of Stone

Renate Dorrenstein

(Black Swan, £6.99)

Buy it at a discount at BOL

It is 25 years since Ellen and her siblings waited for their mother to come back from hospital with new baby sister, Ida. Now pregnant herself, Ellen can finally rake over her memories of a chaotic but comfortable childhood and its destruction. Reading Dorrenstein's novel is like watching old family home movies dropped into a documentary. A shot of a red bicycle, dated fashions, a hairstyle or a pattern of wallpaper set off explosions of personal histories. They serve the novel's narrative but signpost the reader's past too, making for durable emotional connections. Ellen, the narrator of the family tragedy, has a welcome sense of humour, but the exposition is mechanical and superficial.

fields.headline: Life is sweet
fields.standfirst: Vera Rule digests The Chocolate Wars and   For God, Country and Coca-Cola while Harriet Porter looks at Heroes
fields.trailText: Vera Rule digests The Chocolate Wars and For God, Country and Coca-Cola while Harriet Porter looks at Heroes
fields.body:
The Chocolate Wars

Joel Brenner

(HarperCollins £7.99)

Buy it at a discount at BOL

This is a coarse, dense book - like the Hershey GI Field Ration D bar and its heat-resistant successor, the Desert Bar, which was supposed to have been supplied to the troops of the Gulf war but got supplanted on the ground by Mars-manufactured frozen Snickers. Brenner complains that the CIA is more open than US confectionary firms (a $14bn-a-year industry) but he still managed to research the mouthfillers, including M&Ms, developed by Forrest Mars Snr from sugar-coated chocolate "lentils" that he saw soldiers eat in the Spanish civil war; and Kisses, Milton Snavely Hershey's 1907 milk chox for the melting-pot millions.

For God, Country and Coca-Cola

Mark Pendergrast

(Orion, £14.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

And here is another lifetime's research into American sweet-ness. It all started with the original 1886 temperance tonic formula devised by cocaine addict Dr John Stith Pemberton of Columbus, Georgia, with its fluid extract of coca and oils of coriander and neroli. Pendergast moves from the 77 fake colas that were on offer by 1903 (among them the candid Dope, Mellow Nip and Pepsi-Nola - yep, Nola) to the 1950s, when Coke was targeted by anti-US protestors, who were delighted when those tasting it for the first time said it had the bouquet of a burnt comb.

Heroes

John Pilger

(Vintage, £7.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

This 1986 book, so its author tells us, was circulated among prisoners on South Africa's Robben Island and found in the luggage of the journalist Farzad Bazoft, after he was executed on false spying charges by Saddam Hussein. Pilger is not a man to miss his own trumpet when it comes to hand, but then he has some trumpet to blow. Heroes takes him through Africa, Asia and the Americas. He doesn't just stand on the sidelines shouting (though he does that too). He bears witness - in a way that few journalists today are permitted to do - to history, particularly to the holocausts that were the curse of the 20th century, and whose legacy shows no sign of diminishing in the 21st.

Harriet Porter

fields.headline: Notes from an accidental career
fields.standfirst: Adele Geras tells Julia Eccleshare why she wanted to be Judy Garland
fields.trailText: Adele Geras tells Julia Eccleshare why she wanted to be Judy Garland
fields.body:
Adele Geras has published 75 books - the most recent, Troy , is on the shortlist for the Whitbread Children's book prize - yet she freely admits that she came to writing entirely by accident. "I went in for a competition in the Times offering £250 for a children's story. I looked at the books I was reading to my daughter and they did look very short. I'm extremely lazy and thought that a picture book, with very few words, would be the easiest thing to write."

In fact, she found out, it's the hardest. "I know that now. I didn't win, but I loved writing my story so much that I just kept right on trying to do it." That first story, Apricots at Midnight, was published, and her accidental career was under way.

Geras has written both novels and poetry, including a single poem for adults, "The Sampler Alphabet", for which she won the Housman Society prize and an Arts Council award last year. Her stories range from those picture-books to Troy, which, though published on a children's list, is for readers of all ages. It's not a retelling of Homer; Geras describes it as "a story about five young people who happen to be living in the besieged city of Troy just before it's sacked. It's a domestic and youthful view of the events of the Trojan War, rather than the heroic and traditional one."

This is a love story in which runaway romance is tethered by the domestic needs that continue behind the scenes of the war. The world of the people of Troy is made real, and even the presence of the gods seems a convincing detail of everyday life.

The span of Geras's writing reflects her own experience and enthusiasms. Troy was triggered by her passionate support for the Trojans as a child, but her early childhood in Jerusalem, schooling at Roedean and spell of acting at Oxford have all fuelled different stories. "Everything I write is different from what I have written before. I write entirely for pleasure: first my own and then other people's. I'm the first person who has not to be bored, has to cry when it's sad, fall in love with the hero and so forth."

The legacy of Geras's Jewish background and her early years growing up in Jerusalem is reflected in her novels Voyage and Girls in a Velvet Frame. In different ways, both tell the familiar story of early 19th-century Jewish emigration to the US from the warmth of a close-knit family. Describing herself as a Jewish atheist, Geras loves the culture but not the religion, and has retold traditional Jewish stories in two collections now published in one volume as Stories from Jerusalem .

It was Roedean that provided the inspiration for her Egerton Hall novels, a trilogy of tales each revolving around the theme of a traditional fairy story. "I wanted to combine my three favourite kinds of stories - school stories, love stories and fairy stories - and my own school seemed the perfect setting. I was very happy at Roedean, even though I was away from my parents and only had my school trunk to keep everything in."

It was at Roedean, too, that Geras learnt the discipline of writing. "On the downside, I stopped writing the kind of poems and plays for my friends to perform that I'd done before I went, because there was 'proper work' to be done. But my English teachers were brilliant, and I often feel that I write for them. They had very active red pens that were forever pointing out things like irrelevant adjectives, of which I was very fond."

At the time, Geras did not know how important that would be, as her ambitions lay in quite a different direction. "I spent a lot of time at school preparing to be a singing star. I went to the movies as often as possible, listened to songs and performed in everything I could perform in. I was going to be the new Judy Garland." At Oxford, Geras hardly had time to put pen to paper as she got in training for an acting career. "I was in every single thing I could manage. Best of all was Hang Down Your Head and Die, an anti-capital punishment show which we took to the West End. It got rave reviews, though I haven't forgiven the critic for calling me a 'stocky brunette'. The fact that it was true made it all the more awful."

A brief spell of acting in London followed, but Geras found being an out-of-work actress was no fun. Now married, she became a teacher instead and, though useless at keeping order, was able to keep going by treating every lesson as a kind of performance.

Her novels set in a school of performing arts, a series of ballet stories and re-tellings of opera stories all reflect Geras's love of the theatre, but she has also written ghost stories, family stories and animal stories, even writing as a cat. Whatever she writes, Geras loves detail, describing rooms, clothes, food with precision, lifting a mirror from someone's house or a necklace seen at a party.

When her children were small, she didn't write stories for them but pinched the details of their lives for authenticity. Though they are now adults, Geras still uses them to get things right. For Troy , she drew on her younger daughter's Classical Studies A-level essays; her older daughter, poet and novelist Sophie Hannah, read the first draft and put her straight about how sisters behave towards one another.

Geras is now writing a follow-up to Troy , "which is definitely not a sequel". Beyond that, she says, who knows? "Not fantasy or science fiction, though. I think you write the kind of books you know you can write, and which you enjoy reading."

fields.headline: Mary, Mary, quite contrary
fields.standfirst: A fiercely combative philosopher, she wrote her first book in her 50s after she raised her family. Now 81,  she is our foremost scourge of 'scientific pretension' and a staunch defender of  religion - although she doesn't believe in God
fields.trailText: A fiercely combative philosopher, she wrote her first book in her 50s after she raised her family. Now 81, Mary Midgley is our foremost scourge of 'scientific pretension' and a staunch defender of religion - although she doesn't believe in God
fields.body:
Mary Midgley, aged 81, may be the most frightening philosopher in the country: the one before whom it is least pleasant to appear a fool. One moment she sits by her fire in Newcastle like a round-cheeked tabby cat; the next she is deploying a savage Oxonian precision of language to dissect some error as a cat dissects a living mouse.

She believes that philosophy matters, perhaps especially to the people who think it is merely a garnish on the brute facts of life - "like the bed of tulips in front of a nuclear power station", as she puts it with typical vividness. That is why she is so much fun to read and why she has become the foremost scourge of scientific pretension in this country: someone whose wit is admired even by those who feel she sometimes oversteps the mark.

Perhaps the oddest thing about her career is that she did not publish her first book until 1978, when she was 56, and had for years been working in provincial obscurity. Beast And Man was highly praised by her old Oxford friend Iris Murdoch, and pitched her almost by accident into a career as the voice of acerbic sanity about science. With two others, Science And Salvation, and Evolution As A Religion, she staked out a territory all of her own, examining how science comes to function as a substitute for religion, and how very badly it does the job.

It is entirely characteristic that her latest book, Science And Poetry takes its epigraph from Richard Dawkins, "Science is the only way we have of understanding the real world", and proceeds to dance all over this apparently reasonable statement. It's not that she considers science a bad way of knowing the real world. But it is only one among many, and one which must be kept in firmly its place.

In a characteristic image, she compares human knowledge to the dolphin tank in a zoo: "human life [is] like an enormous, ill-lit aquarium which we never see fully from above, but only through various small windows unevenly distributed around it. Scientific windows - like historical ones - are just one important set among these. Fish and other strange creatures constantly swim away from particular windows... reappearing where different lighting can make them hard to recognise. Long experience, along with constant dashing around between windows, does give us a good deal of skill in tracking them. But if we refuse to put together the data from different widows, then we can be in real trouble."

She started looking in from a window that has now almost vanished. She was born in 1919, the daughter of Canon Tom Scrutton, then the chaplain of King's College, Cambridge, and had a conventional middle class upbringing in a large vicarage in Greenford, which was at the time a village distinct from west London and is now a rather gloomy suburb. Her father, she says, was "a rather notorious pacifist: the chair of the Anglican Pacifist Fellowship. He had been a chaplain in the first world war, and had had to explain to people why they were dying. That had put him off war." Her mother, Lesley, née Hay, was the daughter of the Scots engineer who built the Mersey Tunnel. Her elder brother. Hugh Scrutton, became a distinguished art gallery director.

At 12, she was sent to Downe House, a boarding school which had been started in Darwin's old home, though it later moved. She found it a rather an enlightened place. "I loved it. There was quite a lot of spare time, quite a good library, and a headmistress interested in all sorts of things. I got philosophy when I was there: when I was about 16 I picked Plato off the shelf and thought it was tremendous stuff."

By this time, she had realised that she was not a Christian. "Christianity never really took. I tried to operate it, but there never seemed to be anybody there." When she eventually explained to her father, he accepted without fuss that she just didnÍt have the right temperament.

In 1938 she went up to Somerville College as senior scholar. Iris Murdoch was in the same year, and they became close friends at once; Elizabeth Anscombe, later to become Wittgenstein's foremost disciple, who died last week, was a year ahead of her, and the moral philosopher Philippa Foot a year behind her. Foot says today, "[Mary] was a very grand figure indeed." For Midgley, the war years were a uniquely wonderful time to be a woman studying philosophy at Oxford. "I think the fact that there was not an endless gaggle of young men who were distracting helped us - and there was nobody doing philosophy then who didn't really want to do it. Also, there didn't seem to be a future, so nobody was thinking of careers."

Many of the women left, too, for war work. But she stayed, with her friends, rather than rush off to volunteer for some job where they could be pretty sure their talents would be misused. "It wasn't that we underestimated the evil that was out there, or that we didnÍt want to do our bit, but it didn't seem to us a trifling matter to try and make sense of Kant meanwhile."

There were also politics to contend with. Murdoch had joined the Communist party soon after coming up, an act which seemed to her circle like a kind of ordination. "The party was very important, it was there like the church: only really serious people actually joined it. ThereÍs nothing like that out there now: there's nothing righteous by way of a cause that one is refusing to join. I and my other friends had this guilty feeling that it was our insufficiency that prevented us from following her, but there were also the [Stalinist] treason trials..."

One way or another, these kept Midgley out of the party, and when the Oxford Labour club split after the Hitler-Stalin pact, she ended up on the committee of the new social democratic club, along with Roy Jenkins and Tony Crosland. "I remember Roy Jenkins, as a slender youth, singing Frankie and Johnny at committee meetings." Perhaps a woman who has seen the subsequent vice-chancellor, Lord Jenkins of Hillhead, in this light would never be unduly impressed with the pomp and gravity of Oxford. In any case, she has few regrets about leaving the place.

"I put in for the job that Mary Warnock got at St Hugh's. It was providential, really. I would have been destroyed by the terribly destructive and critical atmosphere. It isnÍt destructive of everyone, but look what happened to Isaiah Berlin, who also started as an Oxford philosopher. They kind of frightened him to the point where he said I shall go away and do the history of thought. I think pretty much the same thing happened to Iris Murdoch. The minute you got out of Oxford a great weight lifted, at least for a person like me."

This disdain is mutual, even when strongly coloured with affection. Her friend Philippa Foot, who thrived in Oxford after the war, says, "Her mind doesn't quite work like most straight Oxford analytic philosophers, I'd say. I don't mean that we're not keen on the poor old planet, but we don't talk about it an awful lot. It doesn't come into our work. I think she found her forte being witty and sane on television."

In 1945 she met Geoffrey Midgley, who was doing a doctorate at New College. "The dominant philosophical line at Oxford at that time was a refined kind of logical positivism. But there were also present highly metaphysical people like Elizabeth Anscombe and Peter Geach. So there was a very great deal of argument. Someone brought him round to my rooms in Park Town at about 11 o'clock one morning, and we were still arguing at six that evening. But what impressed him was that I had produced a pork pie and a tin of spaghetti to enable the argument to continue."

He found a job in Newcastle but after a year they met again, and got engaged. They were married in 1950. She had three sons in five years and stopped working, except for reviewing children's books and novels for the New Statesman. This interruption supplies one of the most distinctive qualities of her thought: to the natural Oxonian self-confidence which assumes that learning is important and foolishness a crime, she adds a belief that the learned are often importantly foolish.

Sometimes this leads her to aim at soft targets but also to some exhilarating removals of the Emperor's New Trousers. "Inside every real philosopher", she has written, "is not only a lawyer, but also that lawyer's client: someone with a substantial idea to express."

The ideas she considers really substantial are those which deal with Aristotelean questions: how should men and women live (not that Aristotle had any interest in women's lives), and she has little time, or inclination for more Platonic interests in pure logic or ultimate reality. In Science And Poetry she writes, "Any major kind of philosophising always presents some distinctive ideal for life as well as for thought because life and thought are not really separate at all, and if the contemporary academic philosophers suppose they are not doing this they are mistaken. Academic narrowness is a style of thought as much as any other. It is quite as easily conveyed by a style of writing, and even more easily by a style of teaching."

This distance from academic proprieties comes out in her friendship and admiration for James Lovelock, the originator of the Gaia hypothesis. "I think we all have a pretty high opinion of her", he says. "She's so right about science. It is becoming fragmented to such an extent that the average scientist is now a specialist who knows no more outside his speciality than the average layman; and somebody needed to say that." The fierceness of her character seems to him a purely professional affectation. "She's enormously good at friendship. In the academic world they are prepared to say in print things that none of us would dare say in person, but I donÍt think they feel it the same way."

He met her when she gave a talk on one of her favourite metaphors: philosophy as plumbing. The idea that it is something on which civilisation depends, but which no one notices until it goes badly wrong, when you have to bring a specialist. It's about as far removed from the ivory tower as any idea might be, and you could not get further from academic narrowness than the place where she emerged after her interlude of motherhood as a publishing philosopher, in the 70s.

She started with the problems of animal behaviour, reading Konrad Lorenz and Nico Tinbergen, who shared a Nobel prize for their researches into the ways that animal behaviour is as much a genetic product as are animal bodies. Animals inherit their ways of thought and feeling quite as much as the leopard inherits its spots. This is now the stock of hundreds of pop science books, but back then it was worth a Nobel prize. But, of course, since we are a species of animal, we too must have inherited predispositions and these will shape the ways we understand the world, and things we can hope to get out of it.

These are not ideas which would have appeared strange to any philosopher until about 1900. But recognising that human beings are a sort of animal lets these questions of purpose back in. At the same time, Darwinism was enabling scientists to ask the question "what are things for" and get answers that looked scientific as well as philosophical.

The convergence of so many different lines of enquiry on these questions was unfortunate. When the humanists met the scientists, the middle ground was churned into a muddy no-man's-land of controversy, where only the bravest dared change their position by scuttling between shell holes and opponents' positions were illuminated only to make it easier to fire on them.

John Cornwell, the writer and director of the science and religion project at Jesus College Cambridge, says, "Mary is an excellent thing, of course. Whenever you look for a debate, she is the natural against the ultra-Darwinists, like Richard Dawkins or Dan Dennett. But although she often professes to be talking about science, she does draw an equivalence between scientism [applying scientific method inappropriately] and science. I think a lot of the stuff she does is very good knockabout, which pleases people who don't like science, and she tends to lump together an enormous amount in her criticisms.

"I tackled her once exactly on this point about confusing scientism with science, at a conference I organised. It was in the evening down in the college bar: she had collected a gang of groupies, and when I had finished, she declared to the audience, 'is Cornwell drunk?'. She's very feisty. I was entirely sober: but just for making this point against her, I got the treatment. She's a daunting opponent, and she does go as close to playing dirty as you can get." With all that said, Midgley remains surrounded by affection, described by many as "an excellent ting". As Philippa Foot says, "She's raised three splendid foals, and so on. She's very much someone who is very successful in family life." She was simply surrounded with affection and respect. Yet she is formidable. She's incapable of being stopped once she's started.

So she put her hand over her eyes, closed her eyes, and turned away; then she launched into a tremendous denunciation. Melvyn Bragg, who was presenting the show was enchanted and frustrated by it because of course he couldnÍt catch her eye or signal to her."

The vehement clashes on such occasions are not scientific or factual at all.
