The bitter question has become an insoluble one of academic competence, part of the war between science and the humanities.

Midgley feels that modern scientists, though they have realised what the urgent problems of the human race are, still talk as if science, or simply increasing knowledge, could solve them. But "If there is one thing that we know from the long and hard experience of the human race, it is that what is wrong is not simple."

She started off much more horrified, she says, by the stupidity of her own tribe, the humanists and sociologists, who believed that human nature was either uninteresting or non-existent; and that if it did exist, it could be moulded into any shape we wanted. One place where this was a real problem was feminism: the question do women differ from men only in the position of their dangly bits, or in their hearts and minds too, is not purely academic. Science, philosophy and ethics all can help to solve it, but that is not what makes it urgent. It's interesting because it is a question that everyone must solve in their own lives, and which various academic disciplines can help them to solve. Those have always been the kind of questions that interest Midgley.

But now that everyone is more or less a sociobiologist, or Darwinian in polite society, what really distinguishes her controversial position is the idea that pre-Darwinian ideas of human nature are likely to be just as accurate and a great deal more revealing than whatever the latest pop-science best-seller tells us. I am saying that, if the theory had had different roots, it would not have brought with it this particular word-picture, this myth, this drama, this way of accommodating science in the range of human activities, this notion of what it is to have a scientific attitude (it would no doubt have brought a different one)."

Such assertions are anathema to the kind of scientist who believes that his theories arise strictly from the facts. Certainly, it doesn't account for the developments of science which postulate things we literally cannot picture, such as modern particle physics. But it certainly explains the way in which phrases that can have a strict scientific meaning, such as "genes for something" can spread in the wider culture with meanings that would horrify the scientists involved if they thought them important. But of course few do. For most, the metaphors in which their theories are described really are no more significant than the tulips in front of a nuclear power station, whereas she sees metaphorical thought as the ground on which even nuclear power stations are built.

This is in part a consequence of her attitude to religion. Though she is not any sort of Christian, believing that too many of the essential doctrines of Christianity are impossible for a decent and educated person to subscribe to, she remains convinced that the religions of the world can't simply be superseded because we don't like them. "It is absurd to talk as if religion consisted entirely of mindless anxiety, bad cosmology, and human sacrifice."

There is a sense of rather Victorian moral astringency about her that preserves the high-minded and disciplined attitudes that led privileged Oxford youth to see the Communist party as a kind of church. "It is an extraordinary thing to say of someone that they cannot control a character flaw", she once said about the certainties of one her opponents; and she meant it, whereas nowadays it is more common to find it remarkable when anyone does manage to overcome a failing.

The great thing to be said for organised religion, she believes is precisely that it is not disorganised. "People are naturally ceremonial, ritualistic, and naturally inclined to find purposes in things. If these impulses are not brought together and disciplined, you get something even worse than organised religion. I feel this about the Guardian's anti-royal campaign. If you don't have your ceremonial life centred on royalty, you've got it centred on pop stars, and that's worse. It's all a matter of the lesser evil."

This fierce sense that organised religion has learned from its own mistakes fired her two shortest and perhaps most enjoyable books, Science As Salvation and Evolution As A Religion. These systematically dissect the ways in which much modern science simply assumes that scientists have the same kind of function in a scientific universe as priests had in a religiously motivated one, and the idiocies that follow from this assumption.

For instance, there are plenty of theologians who believe that God made creatures so they could know him and love him. That is a ridiculous claim on its own, but what are we to make of the remark by two prominent physicists that "a physicist is an atomÍs way of knowing about an atom?" She uses that as a classic example of folie de grandeur and adds: "It should surely be obvious that, if the universe is the kind of thing capable of knowing or wanting to know anything, it can do this on its own, and does not need help from physicists."

For all the obvious difficulties about believing in God, or in anything else that might answer our prayers, Midgley points out that prayer has been immensely important in history: "People have achieved the most amazing things by putting their trust in providence, or indeed by praying. They were not thinking about the virgin birth or the atonement when they did that. But they were thinking in a way that does seem central to human effort. I think it is reasonable to say that one can think that way with respect to the creation as a whole. All the formulations that one makes about this have something wrong with them, and it is very easy to say that there is something wrong with them; but thatÍs not to say that we can live without the religious attitude."

At first sight it is strange to see such a very hard-headed and deflationary thinker growing so apparently high-flown. She is, for example, a considerable fan of James Lovelock's Gaia hypothesis, as much because of its religious potential as because of its scientific truth. But of course the idea that the universe could be deflated down to the facts is one she has constantly fought against. We could not begin to understand a world that was made of facts and nothing else; such a world is itself an imaginative vision and not a scientific one.

It seems odd, though, that she can nowhere articulate her positive ideas with nearly as much stirring precision as she can do the demolition job. In person it is obvious that she loves company, family, and the fun of talking with live ammunition. Her house in a leafy suburb of Newcastle, where she has lived for nearly 50 years, has a comfortable litter of books around a shiny white computer - nothing else is brighter than the gas fire. Sitting in an upright chair in front of the fire, with one leg stretched out on the footstool, she seems to radiate contentment and a capacity for affection in an almost cat-like fashion, yet, like a cat, when she stretches comfortable, the claws appear as well.

"I keep thinking that I shall have no more to say - and then finding some wonderfully idiotic doctrine which I can contradict - a negative approach, as they say, but one that doesnÍt seem to run out."

Life at a glance

Born: September 13 1919, London.
Education: Downe House School, Berkshire; Somerville College Oxford.
Married: 1950 Geoffrey Midgley, (three sons - Tom, David, Martin; three grandchildren - two boys, one girl).
Employment: Senior lecturer in philosophy, Newcastle University, 1962-1980.
Publications: Beast And Man 1978, Science And Salvation 1992, Wickedness 1984, Evolution As A Religion 1985, Animals And Why They Matter 1983, Heart And Mind 1981, The Ethical Primate 1994, Science And Poetry 2001.

 Science And Poetry by Mary Midgley is published by Routledge in March, price £19.99.
fields.bodyText: Mary Midgley, aged 81, may be the most frightening philosopher in the country: the one before whom it is least pleasant to appear a fool. One moment she sits by her fire in Newcastle like a round-cheeked tabby cat; the next she is deploying a savage Oxonian precision of language to dissect some error as a cat dissects a living mouse. She believes that philosophy matters, perhaps especially to the people who think it is merely a garnish on the brute facts of life - "like the bed of tulips in front of a nuclear power station", as she puts it with typical vividness. That is why she is so much fun to read and why she has become the foremost scourge of scientific pretension in this country: someone whose wit is admired even by those who feel she sometimes oversteps the mark. Perhaps the oddest thing about her career is that she did not publish her first book until 1978, when she was 56, and had for years been working in provincial obscurity. Beast And Man was highly praised by her old Oxford friend Iris Murdoch, and pitched her almost by accident into a career as the voice of acerbic sanity about science. With two others, Science And Salvation, and Evolution As A Religion, she staked out a territory all of her own, examining how science comes to function as a substitute for religion, and how very badly it does the job. It is entirely characteristic that her latest book, Science And Poetry takes its epigraph from Richard Dawkins, "Science is the only way we have of understanding the real world", and proceeds to dance all over this apparently reasonable statement. It's not that she considers science a bad way of knowing the real world. But it is only one among many, and one which must be kept in firmly its place. In a characteristic image, she compares human knowledge to the dolphin tank in a zoo: "human life [is] like an enormous, ill-lit aquarium which we never see fully from above, but only through various small windows unevenly distributed around it. Scientific windows - like historical ones - are just one important set among these. Fish and other strange creatures constantly swim away from particular windows... reappearing where different lighting can make them hard to recognise. Long experience, along with constant dashing around between windows, does give us a good deal of skill in tracking them. But if we refuse to put together the data from different widows, then we can be in real trouble." She started looking in from a window that has now almost vanished. She was born in 1919, the daughter of Canon Tom Scrutton, then the chaplain of King's College, Cambridge, and had a conventional middle class upbringing in a large vicarage in Greenford, which was at the time a village distinct from west London and is now a rather gloomy suburb. Her father, she says, was "a rather notorious pacifist: the chair of the Anglican Pacifist Fellowship. He had been a chaplain in the first world war, and had had to explain to people why they were dying. That had put him off war." Her mother, Lesley, née Hay, was the daughter of the Scots engineer who built the Mersey Tunnel. Her elder brother. Hugh Scrutton, became a distinguished art gallery director. At 12, she was sent to Downe House, a boarding school which had been started in Darwin's old home, though it later moved. She found it a rather an enlightened place. "I loved it. There was quite a lot of spare time, quite a good library, and a headmistress interested in all sorts of things. I got philosophy when I was there: when I was about 16 I picked Plato off the shelf and thought it was tremendous stuff." By this time, she had realised that she was not a Christian. "Christianity never really took. I tried to operate it, but there never seemed to be anybody there." When she eventually explained to her father, he accepted without fuss that she just didnÍt have the right temperament. In 1938 she went up to Somerville College as senior scholar. Iris Murdoch was in the same year, and they became close friends at once; Elizabeth Anscombe, later to become Wittgenstein's foremost disciple, who died last week, was a year ahead of her, and the moral philosopher Philippa Foot a year behind her. Foot says today, "[Mary] was a very grand figure indeed." For Midgley, the war years were a uniquely wonderful time to be a woman studying philosophy at Oxford. "I think the fact that there was not an endless gaggle of young men who were distracting helped us - and there was nobody doing philosophy then who didn't really want to do it. Also, there didn't seem to be a future, so nobody was thinking of careers." Many of the women left, too, for war work. But she stayed, with her friends, rather than rush off to volunteer for some job where they could be pretty sure their talents would be misused. "It wasn't that we underestimated the evil that was out there, or that we didnÍt want to do our bit, but it didn't seem to us a trifling matter to try and make sense of Kant meanwhile." "The party was very important, it was there like the church: only really serious people actually joined it. ThereÍs nothing like that out there now: there's nothing righteous by way of a cause that one is refusing to join. I and my other friends had this guilty feeling that it was our insufficiency that prevented us from following her, but there were also the [Stalinist] treason trials..." One way or another, these kept Midgley out of the party, and when the Oxford Labour club split after the Hitler-Stalin pact, she ended up on the committee of the new social democratic club, along with Roy Jenkins and Tony Crosland. webTitle: Flora and Fauna by   John Burnside

fields.headline: Fauna and Flora
fields.trailText:
Once we are close enough to give them names

we cannot help but treat them as our own...
fields.body:
Fauna

 for Linda Gregerson

Once we are close enough to give them names

we cannot help but treat them as our own,

these animals;

though they are far from us, and rapt

in other frequencies,

like waves, or stars,

we speak as if they understood the words,

as if this fondness

were the only language.

They say, in the earliest myth,

before the descent,

our father Orpheus would sometimes charm

new creatures from the air: musk-ox and deer

pressed into life

and ringed about with song.

I always think of them as privileged,

enchanted by the intimate surprise

of other bodies; yet they might have been

uncertain of the presence they possessed,

the fresh light singling them out, like revenants,

as they took form

and shaped a chiming world.

It's difficult not to think in déja-vu

when everything seems so familiar

- wisteria; lilac; the century plant in bloom

like a pillar of salt -

difficult not to believe we might go down

amongst the shadows, stealing love from time

and coming home

to where the song begins

as if this world were nothing but a gap,

the afterlife of dust and locust trees

we used to imagine in school, or that cursive space

where one form is abandoned for the next:

the old flesh invested with snow

and the taste of currants;

the old regrets and loves becoming

tendons; milk-teeth;

misted fingerprints.

Flora

Because it can only be shared,

like a waltz,

or trust,

this commonplace affection singles out

a hairstreak,

or the pattern on a leaf,

leaving the rest untold;

the world

unspoken;

and though we mostly look

for what we know,

there is something we love in ourselves

that a meadow answers:

the blue of an upland flower

or a tideline of grass;

the heart-shaped

or spatulate leaf

of toadflax, or fern.

The colour

is nothing like baize

or polished jade;

the gap between coltsfoot and mint

no more or less

specific than a kale field after rain,

but looking always worked towards a word:

trading the limits of speech

for the unsaid presence,

the way the bird

that vanished through the leaves

is true forever now, being unseen,

and the magic

that speech performs

is all

continuum: the given and the named

discovered and invented,

one more time,

with each new bud or tendril that unfolds

upon the revelation

of the known.

 John Burnside won the Whitbread Poetry award last week for his collection The Asylum Dance, published by Jonathan Cape, price £8.

fields.headline: Land of no tomorrow?
fields.standfirst: John Adedoyin explores Nigeria's crisis of corruption in Karl Maier's This House has Fallen and Chinua Achebe's Home and Exile
fields.trailText: John Adedoyin explores Nigeria's crisis of corruption in Karl Maier's This House has Fallen and Chinua Achebe's Home and Exile
fields.body:
This House has Fallen: Nigeria in Crisis

Karl Maier

368pp, Penguin, £18.99

Buy it at a discount at BOL

Home and Exile

Chinua Achebe

115pp, Oxford, £9.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Endemic corruption is far from unique to Nigeria. Zimbabwe, Zaire (as was) and Russia also score highly in the nose-in-the-trough stakes. But it has rarely been seen on the scale practised by the late General Abacha, who along with other members of his kleptocracy stole $2.2bn from the Central Bank during their time in power. Abacha died in the arms of a couple of Indian prostitutes, an event which Karl Maier describes as "a coup from heaven".

In This House has Fallen: Nigeria in Crisis Maier relates a shocking litany of statistics: "Literacy is below that of the Democratic Republic of Congo... Gross domestic product per person is lower than the 1970s... The navy's 52 admirals and commodores outnumber serviceable ships by a ratio of six to one. The airforce has 10,000 men but fewer than 20 functioning aircraft." And so on. Maier pauses for breath, then says: "The facts speak for themselves." Well, not quite. It is not the facts that make this a fascinating book, but the sheer weight of voices competing to win the post-rationalisation contest, the analysis of what has happened to Nigeria since independence. Ex-heads of state (Babangida), tribal leaders (Ojukwu) and popular rabble-rousers (Adams) are all given a platform to justify their actions and put forward their heavily partisan analysis.

The only common thread among these jockeying voices is an unwillingness to admit mistakes or to give any ideological quarter to the perceived enemy. Maier's own summation is blunt: "a non-productive economy addicted to petrodollars, ruled by a coterie of army officers and bureaucrats growing fat on contract kickbacks and siphoning off the oil revenues".

It is all true. In the 1980s the 469 members of the National Assembly voted themselves $25-35,000 each in furniture allowance at a time when the minimum monthly wage stood at $30, which makes Lord Irvine's redecoration seem as prosaic as a trip to IKEA. Maier's thesis, that Nigeria has been sucked dry of resources and denied economic growth through successive rapacious administrations, is a hard one to refute.

He beats his depressing tattoo over 300 anecdote-rich pages. Nigeria has become a bureaucracy in its purest form, where bloated state administrations are there to serve themselves exclusively. The most prized jobs for university graduates are in customs and excise, primarily for the scope for self-enrichment they afford. The reason we do not accurately know the population of Nigeria is not an inability to count but because national revenues (mainly from oil) are distributed to individual states according to size of population. Therefore it is in the states' interest to inflate census figures.

Understandably, this kind of thing angers the inhabitants of less densely populated regions such as Ogoniland. It is worth pointing out that the well-reported localised struggles there are to a large extent a variation on a wider pattern of exploitation and greed. The drive to impose Sharia (Islamic) law in the Hausa-dominated states has far greater implications for the survival of Nigeria. The overlay of tribal law, British common law and Sharia law creates its own tensions, as Maier explains: "The wife of... Gideon Akaluka (an Igbo trader) was accused of desecrating the Koran by allegedly using its pages as toilet paper for her baby. The police detained Akaluka for his own protection. But militants broke into the jail, killed Akaluka, and led a procession around Kano with his severed head on a pole." The spark to this chain of events was the fact that the woman was illiterate.

The Sharia question is not an arcane legal issue but a tribal and political one. What makes the incident in Kano additionally unforgivable is that in the Hausa-dominated north, unless you are one of the elite, there is the perception that schooling is forbidden. The suppression of universal education is now seen as a legitimate tool for retaining power. A local commentator remarks that: "People have been imbued with the notion that Sharia is the answer to their frustration with life. These politicians want to use Sharia as a cover because the upper class in the north has come to the end of the line."

Beyond Maier's gloomy analysis, the book is a rather entertaining hybrid of political travel writing covering several different visits during which he seeks audiences with the political protagonists of the day at both local and national levels. Maier's volume itself becomes an accumulation of "stories", a catalogue of indignities imposed by the powerful on the weak, Igbo over Ibo, Hausa over Yoruba, military over civilian. We follow him as he travels through what are in effect war zones in order to get a more balanced view of the political situation.

So whose fault is it? In Home and Exile, a slim series of lectures mainly concerned with cultural appropriation, Chinua Achebe fastidiously unpacks the construct that is "history". Paraphrasing an Ibo proverb, he wryly states that "until the lions produce their own historian, the story of the hunt will only glorify the hunter".

Once more it is a question of competing voices. Elspeth Huxley's White Man's Country is described as "the best apologia for white settlement that has been written". Despite the gracious tone, Achebe cannot help but accuse her of "spinning stories to validate the transfer of African lands to white settlers". In contrast, Maier seems mostly to absolve the west of any culpability in Nigeria's present situation, as though her problems only started several years after independence in 1960. He is perhaps too generous to the colonials.

It is not insignificant that Achebe describes himself as an Ibo and not Nigerian. Even a Nobel laureate cannot help falling into the language of the tribe: "Conventional practice would call them a tribe, but I no longer follow that convention. I call them a nation."

Is there the political and social will to keep the country in its current form? Is grab-it-while-you-can Nigeria really, as a newspaper editor in Port Harcourt has it, "the land of no tomorrow"? Maier concludes that for all its faults -including the failure to produce a single piece of significant legislation in seven months in office - Obasanjo's government represents the last chance to establish enough political and economic stability to avoid the breakup of the country and in some way to reverse the excessive factionalism and corruption that has taken place over the past 40 years. If Obasanjo does not survive the next few years, neither will Nigeria as it is now.

Maier vividly encapsulates the challenge ahead and the apparent incompatibility of behaviour with aspirational rhetoric. The contrast becomes clear in one eyewitness vignette of the inauguration of Obasanjo, where he juxtaposes the high-sounding rhetoric of the inaugural speech with the looting of celebratory knick-knacks and trinkets on sale a few yards away.

webTitle: Review: Amaryllis Night and Day by Russell Hoban

fields.headline: Night shades
fields.standfirst: Alex Clark  enters the dark dreamscape of Amaryllis Night and Day by Russell Hoban
fields.trailText: Alex Clark enters the dark dreamscape of Amaryllis Night and Day by Russell Hoban
fields.body:
Amaryllis Night and Day

Russell Hoban

176pp, Bloomsbury, £9.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

A Klein bottle is a paradoxical construction in which the glass passes through itself, leaving it with no edge, no inside and no outside. The 18th-century artist Piranesi sketched a series of imaginary prisons that feature a nightmarish array of staircases twisting out of sight and endlessly receding arcades. In sleep, dreamers may have the experience of being able to direct events, of having already woken up, or of returning again and again to a particular place. Out of these disparate and disorienting facts, Russell Hoban has constructed a compelling meditation on the nature of loss and longing that, even after the final piece of the jigsaw slots into place, leaves us with enough unresolved mysteries to fill another book.

Hoban's last novel, Angelica's Grotto, ended with its hero crushed under the wheels of a number 14 bus. His demise pops up briefly here, but it is the appearance of another bus that provides the real connection between the two. Peter Diggs's conveyance is a rather different affair, "a tall and delicate thing of bamboo and rice paper, sheets of yellow, orange, and pink pasted together and candlelit from within like a Japanese lantern". It hoves into view at a bus stop marked Balsamic and declares itself to be headed for Finsey-Obay.

Diggs is bewildered, but then he would expect to be: he's having a dream. The setting is otherworldly and unrealistic, but his sensations are recognisable, particularly the mixture of thrill and terror he experiences as a beautiful young woman beckons to him to join her on the bus. He recoils for an instant, and wakes up. Not so easily accommodated in the comforting gloss of reality is the arrival of the same young woman as he peruses Klein bottles in the Science Museum the following day. Did she, as she claims, pull him into her dream in order to solicit companionship on the terrifying ride to Finsey-Obay? Is it possible to share dreams? If so, what bearing does a dream relationship have on a waking one?

The narrative that follows, in which Peter and Amaryllis - her name pregnant with warning, indicating the plant family that includes belladonna, the deadly nightshade - perform their experiments in lucid dreaming, has all the hallmarks of Hoban's ungovernable invention. Freighted with allusions to high art and low culture, alternately jokey and portentous, it proceeds in associative fashion, each pas sage spewing another half-finished staircase that might lead into thin air. At times one has the impression Hoban writes merely for himself, but watching his ludic mind is pleasure enough for the most exacting reader.

The novel is a dreamscape in which gnomic utterances, mis-said and misheard words and frightful journeys become commonplace. Even the streets, buildings, bus routes and pubs of London acquire the air of the capriccio , the half-real and half-imaginary conjoined in a seductive tangle. Diggs's feverish wanderings call to mind another dreamy writer, de Quincey, who searched "the mighty labyrinths of London" all his life for a prostitute who had fetched him food and drink. Diggs, a painter entrapped by aesthetic sensibility, is also searching for a woman, "the image of a beauty who beckoned but was unattainable". In Hoban's oneiric fable, Diggs's task is to discover whether he wants a woman rather than an image. If so, who will it be? And will she want him back? The exigencies of the quest, fraught with self-delusion, the unpredictability of others and the ghosts of memory, provide the novel with enough narrative charge to direct the mazy meanderings of dream life.

A reductive theory of dreams might have it that they all concern sex or death. Hoban expands this to encompass the intricacies of mental imagery and the complexity of desire, with its twin poles of attraction and repulsion. Amaryllis Night and Day is definitively about sex and death, but it also affords the hope that we might be able to escape those imaginary prisons, to leap from the "hairy shadow" of one staircase onto the light-filled bottom step of another.

webTitle: Review:  One Market Under God by Thomas Frank

fields.headline: Chips, guns and muscle
fields.standfirst: Is capitalism really cool? Andy Beckett finds Thomas Frank's One Market Under God to be  a rebellion against the new economy
fields.trailText: Is capitalism really cool? Andy Beckett finds Thomas Frank's One Market Under God to be a rebellion against the new economy
fields.body:
One Market Under God: Extreme Capitalism, Market Populism and the End of Economic Democracy
Thomas Frank
414pp, Secker & Warburg, £18.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Good timing, as any stock-market trader will tell you, is generally more profitable than pure foresight. The following prediction about the American economy is perhaps the longest, most confident sentence in this fat, bold book: "As the free money dries up and the euphoria cools off, as the commercials get pulled and the websites are disconnected and the high-flying shares settle down for a 30-year flat-line... we will look back on this long summer of corporate love and wonder how it was that we ever came to believe this stuff."

Thomas Frank wrote this, to judge by the examples he uses, some time early last year. To give a sense of American business sentiment around then, before the air began to leak from the New Economy bubble, he deliciously quotes the publisher of the money magazine Forbes: "The pace can go on. The physics of the Information Age is a sure bet. [Silicon] chips are headed towards infinite speed at zero cost... The radical new software and e-commerce business models that will follow in their wake can only be guessed at. But their arrival is... locked in."

If you always hated boo.com, this could be the book for you. In Chicago, a defiant distance clear of Silicon Valley and Wall Street, Frank has been sharpening his theories about the emptiness of the 1990s boom in America and beyond for years. He has edited countless issues of his polemical quarterly The Baffler, page after old-fashioned page of witty pinpricks against the corporate order, as the newsstands have filled regardless with new Technicolor titles about the sexiness of modern capitalism. And he and his young-fogeyish allies have waited for their complaints to register in the world outside.

Naomi Klein, a Baffler contributor, managed it first. Last year her book No Logo put sweatshops, bullying sponsorship deals and the other dirty secrets of the global conglomerates on the front table at Waterstone's. This book is different - funnier but more dogmatic, focused on corporate words rather than deeds - yet its ambition is on a similar scale. By explaining how Americans have been seduced and coerced during the 1990s into accepting the free market as the perfect way of arranging human affairs, and by showing just how absurd and vulnerable this view of the world has become, Frank means to give us a warning. As with No Logo, there is a presumption here: that North America is the most important place on earth, and that criticisms of its particularly harsh brand of capitalism can be beneficially exported and absorbed elsewhere, like Coca-Cola. This may be slightly galling to people in countries with more pronounced traditions of scepticism about business; but the fact that Frank and Klein have had their spiky thoughts put between smart covers and distributed globally is reason to read them. You could call this the second report from the anti-management consultants.

Its central argument is that American businessmen have changed their spots. Before about 1990, their position in society was powerful but contested - by campaigning journalists during the 19th century, by New Deal regulators during the 1930s, by unions and the young and rebellious right up until the Reagan 1980s. But then, with the end of the cold war, the first public enthusiasm for the internet and the discovery that great profits could be made from youth culture, the corporations saw an opportunity to make themselves seem more heroic, more popular, younger. They enlisted any ideas they could: the rosy predictions of eccentric futurists, the pseudo-religious promises of management literature, the useful enthusiasm of cultural-studies professors for everyday products.

The next step was to turn reality on its head. With the willing help of the American media, itself increasingly owned and steered by big business, prosperous company heads repositioned themselves as "rebels". Working for them became "being yourself"; making money became "revolutionary"; and opposing any of this became "elitist" and "old-fashioned". The language and postures of radicalism and hipness were shamelessly adopted by a private sector that was actually growing more conformist, with longer working hours, a cautious emphasis on market research and share options for managers so they had an interest in minimising costs. Beneath the brightening tints of photos of entrepreneurs in magazines like Wired, the pale faces of workaholics were masked.

Frank lists examples of this craze for economic euphemisms with a mixture of horrified amazement and scorn. There are the happy-clappy shareholders of Iomega, a maker of computer hardware, who during the mid-1990s called themselves "Iomegans" and shouted down any doubters at annual general meetings. There are the bizarre exhortations of the international business guru Tom Peters: "Say (SHOUT) YES to BRAND!" And there are folksy old ladies from the remote Midwest whose successful part-time share-trading briefly made them celebrities, launched websites and other spin-offs carrying their advice, and helped give the impression that all America was participating. (In fact, the majority of the population still does not own any shares.)

Meanwhile, behind this screen of - in the author's slightly dusty phrase - "market populism", the usual people were getting richer. Between 1979 and 2000, Frank tellingly reveals, the wealthiest one per cent of Americans saw their share of the country's assets double, from a fifth to approaching half. The ascension of George W Bush, with his man-of-the-people airs and Texas twang thinly disguising his prosperous old family and tax-cutting plan for millionaires, could be seen as the boom's perfect symbol.

Frank is not an economist, so he does not explore the material reasons for the unravelling of the boom - the vainglorious corporate mergers, the mass accumulation of debt - but such activities are implied by all the foolish talk he catalogues. The problem with this approach is that much of this volume is just that: talk. There is little eyewitness reporting, almost no actual scenes of the speculators and hucksters at work; Frank prefers to sift for damning quotations and summarise other books. The pages can feel airless, especially during the opening chapters, when his argument has yet to properly emerge. If all this business propaganda is such nonsense, why cite so many examples?

Then again, Frank argues persuasively that the reckless business optimist tells us something about America, and perhaps about money-making more generally. During the 1860s and the 1920s, similar triumphalist feelings gripped the country's wealthy and those who wanted to join them. He wonders whether this tendency to over-confidence is "a permanent feature of the American imagination, present always just beneath the surface and ready to flow forth at the slightest hint of prolonged good times".

It has its costs. Not just among investors when the good times stop, not just among the panicking share dealers we are traditionally supposed to feel sorry for, but among people for whom even a "boom" is actually a bust: the exhausted Californian cheap labour in hidden sub-contractors' sheds in Silicon Valley or the assassinated union leaders in poor countries (Frank counts 3,000 in Columbia alone since 1987) where western companies are so keen to set up. While modern politicians and economists talk about our money "frolicking open-mindedly through the economies of the world, chasing the best return without regard for color or creed," writes Frank witheringly, "what ensured those [1990s] returns was not the 'inevitability' of the microchip but the guns and the muscle and the hard unanswering face of economic power."

He makes a good moralist; you can imagine him rabble-rousing from some rough stage in a small town around 1900. There is a nostalgia here, and in The Baffler too, for such times when magnates were "robber barons" and the economic order was up for public discussion. But Frank's analysis of and attack on the much more complacent 1990s is thoroughly modern. Hopefully the odd anxious business guru or banker will come across it and repent, or at least go quiet for a while.

webTitle: Review: Instructions for Visitors by Helen Stevenson

fields.headline: End of the entente cordiale
fields.standfirst: Writer's block? Helen Stevenson's  answer is to live in France and write   Instructions for Visitors, finds  Stephen Romer
fields.trailText: Writer's block? Helen Stevenson's answer is to live in France and write Instructions for Visitors, finds Stephen Romer
fields.body:
Instructions for Visitors

Helen Stevenson

232pp, Doubleday, £12.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

By the second half of the first sentence in Helen Stevenson's Instructions for Visitors we are entangled in a mixed metaphor: "Leave the motorway at the last exit in France, where the eastern blade of the Pyrenees shelves down to the sea." She has a line in similes for mountains: the summit of Canigou is variously likened to "a sail", "the skirt of a ballgown caught in a moment of grace" and, more bizarrely, to the shape of a "clean cutting kitchen instrument against the Mediterranean sky".

Stevenson implies in this memoir of "life and love in a French town", as the subtitle dismayingly describes it, that the book developed from some straightforward directions and descriptions written for an elderly American who came to rent her house in the region, the Pyrénées Orientales. To her credit, the town is never named, though the art-historical filler she supplies readily identifies it.

Apparently, these instructions "unblocked" Stevenson the writer - she has published three novels - but unfortunately the stylist goes missing along the way. The grind is palpable in her descriptive set pieces, a routine part of this genre, as her style wavers between the labouringly lyrical ("each house looks like a children's dressing-up trunk that has been plundered, contents spilling out into the sun") and the fey: "Cadaques, blue and white like friendly china", the famous Catalan seaside town thus diminished to the flowery crockery of the heritage shop. Sometimes a "muscular" subject like her lover's horses comes up, and the cliches lie to hand - "they were huge as bronze monuments... their flanks like continents on a map". Sexy stuff, like riding itself - "I needed to be hurtling across country, with the horse reaching out with great strides and my body moving with his, like a piston..." Even the French words she scatters like an exotic seasoning can be inaccurate - there is no such thing as a brocanterie, and the name Catherine usually has no accent. These are signs of careless haste.

If her language too often provides an effective barrier to enjoyment, so do the locals she gets mixed up with; particularly her painter-cum-dentist lover, the egregious Luc. It is her involvement with the oddball "marginals", the soixante-huitards who still infest the south of France, with their goats' cheese and self-righteousness, that is supposed to differentiate this book from the Peter Mayles or the Frances Mayeses and raise it above that chatty brand of "lifestyle" journalism that can bring one out in a rash. To her credit, Stevenson's portraits of these individuals are lively and witty - they draw out the ironist in a way love and landscape cannot. There is Stéfan the Maoist, a "retired activist" who sleeps with other women while sponging on his partner and condemns the boulevard as "a bourgeois way of laying claim to property and space"; Gigi, the elegant, bitchy, dress-seller from Paris, who undertakes to reclothe the tall blonde Englishwoman and relieve her of her flowery numbers from Monsoon.

Gigi, it turns out, is an ex-lover of Luc's - as are most of the more "alternative" women of the town. Luc "could use his brown gold eyes to get whatever he wanted; he was stubborn and proud, but never deceitful". Alas, the more we hear about the reclusive, opinionated Luc, the creepier he seems. The breezy tobacconist's wife should really have warned Helen off someone who refuses to use ready-gummed cigarette papers because spit, properly applied, is adequate. Although he takes the English beauty - ma belle, ma coquine, as he calls her - to his bed, Luc is basically xenophobic, utterly indifferent to anything or anyone outside his own valley. In the end he dumps her because she's an alien - a straight-backed English girl who plays the piano.

Stevenson's growing awareness of Luc's "failings", to put it mildly, leads to some impressively written soul-searching on the state of the expat, and the feeling that never quite goes away and in fact increases with time: "the terror of growing old and dying in a foreign place", and her realisation that to these people "nothing I have done before I came here has any weight". It comes as no surprise when she packs up and returns to England - where, it may be hoped, she has reverted to writing novels.

webTitle: Reviews: Infinite Variety and La Divina Comtesse

fields.headline: Painted ladies
fields.standfirst: Vera Rule  on the artful society dames in Infinite Variety by  Ryersson and  Yaccarino and La Divina Comtesse  by Pierre Apraxine
fields.trailText: Vera Rule on the artful society dames in Infinite Variety by Ryersson and Yaccarino and La Divina Comtesse by Pierre Apraxine
fields.body:
Infinite Variety

Scot D Ryersson and Michael Orlando Yaccarino

249pp, Pimlico, £12.50
Buy it at a discount at BOL

La Divina Comtesse

Pierre Apraxine

192pp, Yale, £16.95
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Marchesa Luisa Casati, heiress and young wife to minor nobility, was spotted while out foxhunting in 1903 by the stocky, cocky Gabriele D'Annunzio, poet and dealer in decadent Art Nouveau imagery. He went after the slender Amazon first as a trophy, then as a muse: he switched her on from dim shyness to blazing, narcissistic exhibitionism.

Much of the 20th century's repertoire of female weirdness, from the kohl-blackened eyes of silent movie vamps to rock queens' taste for snakeskin, is traceable to the illuminated Casati. She wore Fortuny velvet, diamond cycle-clipped harem pants, hawsers of pearls or nothing at all under her furs while loping about Venetian piazzas bracketed by cheetahs on leashes and servitors bearing her leopardskin trunks and hatboxes.

Over 30 extremely odd years, she divorced the husband and dissipated the fortune in staging herself as a spectacle: she made drop-dead entrances at costume balls or brooded in the palazzos she had redecorated to showcase her outrageousness - filling them with albino blackbirds and snakes to wear in lieu of jewellery. She posed for painters from the supersleek Boldini to the shaggily lecherous Augustus John, and for the new celebrity snapper Man Ray. She wore an electrified ensemble that accidentally stunned her rather than spectators; lugged a wax twin to Paris to be fitted for matching couture ensembles; threw tantrums and gems from the windows of her suite at the Ritz and lit a torch on the balcony of her Capri holiday home to signal her sexual satisfaction with D'Annunzio...

Stop there. Yes, this is all true. But it is also exactly how the authors of Infinite Variety want readers to react - to consider Casati as they do, in an ooh, fancy-that manner. They are besotted with the visual effects she contrived, and with her legacy in art and movies, from the silent Cabiria to Vivien Leigh. They are especially entranced by her influence on fashion, reporting in campy catwalk prose the 1998 collection that John Galliano dedicated to her.

But the nearest they get to attributing to her the possibility of an inner life is to quote the notes she exchanged with D'Annunzio, which read like code broadcasts to occupied territory ("You will receive a tortoise from Hagenbeck"). Otherwise, the book is biography as extended caption, or maybe catalogue: how Casati launched her first flagrances; repackaged herself at 35 as the angular, amused muse of the futurists; ruined herself by extravagance before 50; and was a bag lady for three decades, bottles clinking in the cupboards of her London digs. They attribute her downfall to one crucial ball at her Pink Palace in 1927: the event, based as it was on Lu's tomb-and-zoo definition of exoticism, was out of date for the jazz age. The authors plead for us to honour Casati's nerveless style, but her dandyism depresses: it is vanity as nihilism - and nihilism less in the sense of the rejection of norms than of the worthlessness of living at all.

Loopy Lu seems almost cheerily sane beside Virginia, the Countess de Castiglione celebrated in La Divina Comtesse, so legendary a looker that Lu herself owned some of the charismatic old bat's trinkets. Castiglione's fame derived from a brief season in the 1850s as the crinolined mistress of Napoleon III. She fell from imperial favour at 20 and after Paris reviled her took to acting out the triumphs of her beauty before the camera of Pierre-Louis Pierson in a Passy portrait studio. The compilers of this catalogue of a New York exhibition of the resultant pictures regard them as narratives of high and low life told in a single frame, as the beginning of the choreography of fashion photography, and as a prefiguring of the type of face that cinematography later worshipped in close-up - some shots suggest Garbo.

Again, all true; it's chic in NY to knowingly compare the show with Cindy Sherman's self-portraits. But the Countess's unhappy snaps are far more disturbing than Sherman's savvy parodies: Virginia demanded that the paid eye of Pierson's camera accord her the adoration society denied her once she was no longer modish. After 35, supermodelling did not console her, and she became a mad recluse, secluded in draped, darkened rooms with silenced clocks. She emerged in the 1890s, toothless, bewigged and in the bedraggled finery of her prime, for a few final plates of dignified pathos. She died in 1899, and devotees such as Robert de Montesquiou (who built a shrine to the Countess in the very Palais Rose in which Casati later gave that damned ball) bought her tatty accessories in veneration of what they claimed was her heroic retreat when age defeated beauty.

And we're expected, reading both these books, to join the cult; to vow that - only for a woman, of course - posing in the perfect frock (or, better, sublime nudity) for a single canvas or photograph that excites admiration is worth a lifetime never lived. Nah. Not even a minute.

webTitle: Review: Frantz Fanon: A Life  by David Macey

fields.headline: Call to arms
fields.standfirst: Peter Lennon  on David Macey's biography of Frantz Fanon, Algeria's hero
fields.trailText: Peter Lennon on David Macey's biography of Frantz Fanon, Algeria's hero
fields.body:
Frantz Fanon: A Life

David Macey

651pp, Granta, £25

Buy it at a discount at BOL

Occasionally a book appears at an optimum moment through a simple caprice. This is the case with David Macey's biography of Frantz Fanon, the man who passionately articulated the cause of Algerian independence and excoriated French racism in his The Year V of the Algerian Revolution (1959) and The Wretched of the Earth (1961). A few weeks ago, after a 40-year silence, General Paul Aussaresses, the counter- espionage chief charged in 1957 with "dismantling" the FLN (Algerian National Liberation Front), decided at the age of 82 to unburden himself and confess to Le Monde that torture and summary execution were routine in the operation against the Algerian population.

He made it clear that the commander of the French forces in Algeria at the time, General Jacques Massu (later de Gaulle's right-hand man during the May events of 1968), was well aware of what was happening. In June, Massu himself expressed vague regret: "When I think of Algeria I am very sorry," he said. "We could have done things differently." Until 1999 the French did not even admit that there had been a war in Algeria; officially it was a peace-keeping operation in a French province. But over the past few months debate has raged in France over the "officers who left their soul" in Algeria.

Fanon was in the best position to know their souls. Remembered, if at all, as a kind of Che Guevara of the Algerian independence war, this powerful voice of the anti-colonial movement that swept Africa and Asia in the late 1950s and 1960s was also a respected psychiatrist whose patients in his Algerian clinic included French soldiers. In The Wretched of the Earth, Fanon recorded anonymously the confessions of patients who had been army torturers, distressed by their own activities. Although already in the FLN, Fanon, whose advocacy of violence against the colonisers had almost mystical overtones, never betrayed these men.

Macey's Fanon is a hugely complex figure. One could fear that the author of a life of Jacques Lacan might, in emphasising the psychiatrist side of an over-mythologised revolutionary, be using a gimmick to freshen up his subject. But Fanon's background in psychiatry was central to his life. It was also the path that, having first treated Algerian victims of oppression in Lyon, led him directly to active revolt. Eventually he had to leave his hospital and take refuge in Tunis.

There are superficial contradictions in Fanon's character. He was not Algerian, but a black native of Martinique, also a département of France. It was only in the last years of his life that he adopted the Algerian identity, but his vision always embraced vengeful triumph of oppressed peoples. He was also a decorated hero of the French army during the second world war, a matter he preferred not to discuss. By the end of that war it was clear to him that he could expect nothing from France: racism in the army gave no quarter to decorated black soldiers.

In Algeria he discovered "racism with scientific pretensions" and found that French psychiatrists there were willing to provide scientific justification for torture as a peace-keeping tool. Of course, he himself was a prophet of the cleansing and liberating effect of violence (and the FLN were guilty of major atrocities), but not just as a guerrilla fighter. "Nationalisation," he wrote, "simply means the transfer into native hands of those unfair advantages which are a legacy of the colonial period." His call to violence found an echo among black Americans and briefly terrified the State Department. When he died, aged 37, of leukaemia, his body had to be smuggled 15km across the Tunisian border in order to honour his wish to be buried in Algerian ground. Seven months later, Algeria's independence was formally declared.

But Fanon died a second death. Macey points out that a black agnostic was not a convenient hero for a Muslim state; he is not on the official list of Algerian war heroes. As the French now agonise over their past, a question arises for us. During those crucial years from 1957 to 1961, while the world marvelled at France's cultural prowess - the nouvelle vague , the "new novel", vibrant theatre - France was conducting a continuous campaign of torture and atrocities that knew no restraints (entire villages were wiped out) and was officially sanctioned. And not only in Algeria. While the Right Bank offered tourists the Folies Bergère , the police torture chambers of the Goutte d'Or at the back of the Gare du Nord were only 15 minutes away. A theatregoer who absentmindedly forgot to get off at the right stop for the Left Bank Odéon theatre might travel a few stations to the Porte d'Orléans, where more powerful dramas were being conducted in a police torture centre.

The torture chambers were well known in Paris: the editor of La Nouvelle Observateur and a councillor at the Porte d'Orléans protested; Beckett's publisher, Jerome Lindon, published testimonies of torture and was continually raided by the police. Distinguished journalists on Le Monde issued wise, measured and ineffectual rebukes.

But it is in the behaviour of the outside world that the ultimate justification of Fanon's rage against the white world in general will be found. Any non-white country that regularly committed the atrocities the French committed month after month, year after year, would, as a matter of simple reflex, have become a pariah. Why did France escape censure? The answer must be that whether by indifference or diplomatic discretion, the media and institutions of all western countries practise racism as a matter of course when it concerns the wretched of the earth.

webTitle: Review: Robert Graves:  The Complete Poems in One Volume

fields.headline: A muse of fire
fields.standfirst: Sean O'Brien  salutes the poetry of Robert Graves, collected in The Complete Poems in One Volume
fields.trailText: Sean O'Brien salutes the poetry of Robert Graves, collected in The Complete Poems in One Volume
fields.body:
Robert Graves: The Complete Poems in One Volume

eds Beryl Graves and Dunstan Ward

896pp, Carcanet, £50
Buy it at a discount at BOL

What is it about Robert Graves? He seems hard to place. His poems are, for the moment, in a kind of administrative limbo from which not every writer emerges. Yet Graves (1895-1985) was a very prominent figure, with a readership extending far beyond the poetry audience. He was also a bestselling historical novelist (I, Claudius), the author of an autobiographical classic of the first world war (Goodbye to All That) and an idiosyncratic interpreter of mythology (The White Goddess, found on every good psychedelic bookshelf, was the unwitting progenetrix of a good deal of New Age mystification).

Certainly Graves would have viewed all these works as subordinate to his poetry, although they did much to subsidise it, but it is a fair bet that the prose is now much more widely read. However, Carcanet has now delivered The Complete Poems in One Volume, which at around 900 pages provides a monumental basis for looking at the poems afresh.

Conventional wisdom finds Graves coming relatively late to poetic distinction, despite obvious talent. Conventional wisdom is right. Much of the earlier work is whimsical or evasive, based in an idealised rural world, suggesting a poet actively resisting the deeper drag of his gifts yet producing a handful of memorable poems of love, war and the imagination.

While Graves was at pains to separate himself from the ruck of indifferent pastoral poets in Edward Marsh's popular Georgian anthologies (1912-1922), the grounds for doing so are not clear. For all its folktale violence of gesture, the verse often has a domesticated, anaesthetic quality, as if providing the imagination with a period of convalescence following the horrors recounted in Goodbye to All That. Mistakenly reported dead in action, for years afterwards Graves found himself greeted by dead comrades:

You grin at me from daylight places,

Dead, long dead, I'm ashamed to greet

Dead men down the morning street.

But on the whole, the war is more effectively handled in the novel.

Graves underwent breakdown and psychoanalysis in the effort to come to terms with his experience. Dismissive of what appeared to be merely scientific knowledge, he was nonetheless a seeker after systems that could negotiate between the self and its inner and outer terrors. "The Cool Web", among the best of the early poems, considers the relationship between language and experience in the light of his own poetic practice. If the domesticating fireguard of language is removed, then

Facing the wide glare of the children's day,

Facing the rose, the dark sky and the drums

We shall go mad no doubt and die that way.

Graves paid careful attention to some features of modernism, and collaborated with his formidable mistress and teacher Laura Riding on A Survey of Modernist Poetry (1926). However, while he had, like Eliot, Pound and Yeats, the arrogance and the mythological impedimenta needed to focus the poems, his verse seems to find little value in the overt friction between the poetic imagination and the historical moment that proved so productive for those other poets. Lyric is his beginning and ending.

Instead of history, Graves has the still marble pool of mythology, by which he awaits the next encounter with the inspiring but destructive powers of the White Goddess, "Whom we desired above all things to know,/ Sister of the mirage and the echo." A true poem, he wrote, "is necessarily an invocation of the White Goddess, or Muse, the Mother of All Living, the ancient power of fright and lust - the female spider or queen-bee whose embrace is death".

The Muse would take up temporary residence in successive actually existing women, who might individually contain several other mythic identities (in one case Andromeda, Niobe and Helen), but Her truth remained the same. She would demand all from her acolyte/lover and at the last yield nothing, except poems: "So each new victim treads unerringly/ the never-altered circle of his fate." Whatever you make of the contraption, Graves derived some very powerful work from a struggle that has as much to do with the problem of consciousness as with sexuality. The famous Chinese box poem, "Warning to Children", seductively and chillingly foretells what knowledge of the world will be like:

For who dares undo the parcel

Finds himself at once inside it,

On the island, in the fruit,

Blocks of slate about his head ...

The attraction to pattern and repetition, unusually powerful even for a poet, is handled in more adult terms in "Ulysses", a poem that seems like a template for the work of many succeeding poets, including figures as various as Thom Gunn, Fleur Adcock and Michael Longley. Gunn's acerbic confidence surely owes something to these lines:

To the much-tossed Ulysses, never done

With woman whether gowned as wife or whore,

Penelope and Circe seemed as one:

She like a whore made his lewd fancies run,

And wifely she a hero to him bore.

Readers are likely to divide at this point, not only about sexual politics but also about matters of authority and cultural baggage. As Graves's poetry achieved acclaim in the post-war years, those who might seem like his poetic enemies also began their ascent. Among them was Larkin, an avowed opponent of the "myth-kitty", who wrote "I really think I dislike [Graves] more than ever I disliked Dylan [Thomas]". Everything in Graves's description of the genesis of a poem seems designed to draw sceptical fire: "The nucleus of every poem worth the name is rhythmically formed in the poet's mind, during a trance-like suspension of his normal habits of thought, by the supra-logical reconciliation of conflicting emotional ideas." "In a pig's arse, friend," Larkin might have replied - except that the dialectical form of much of his own work bears out Graves's admittedly elevated description.

Neither poet was in the habit of ingratiating himself with the public, and both were idiosyncratic and powerful formalists. Given these points of contact, why is Larkin the more widely read poet now? Is it because he suits an audience without a classical education? Partly. But it also goes back to attitudes to history: Larkin's instinct to preserve the odds and ends of life as well as its defining moments holds a stronger appeal in a period of flux and alarm than Graves's devotion to the cycles of mythology. In The Oxford Book of English Verse, Larkin, like Edward Thomas, gets 10 poems to Graves's seven. This seems about right, but all of them are over-represented in comparison with Yeats and Auden, who were major poets as distinct from poets who sometimes wrote great poems. "There is one story and one story only," Graves said, which is not true; but the resulting love poems, with their continual sense of threat and change, ought to be read alongside playful anthology pieces such as "The Persian Version" and "Welsh Incident". No one else offers his precise combination of eroticism, nightmare and epigram.

webTitle: Review: Dark Inheritance  by Elaine Feinstein

fields.headline: Family affairs
fields.standfirst: Helen Falconer  on the  literary thrills of Elaine Feinstein's Dark Inheritance
fields.trailText: Helen Falconer on the literary thrills of Elaine Feinstein's Dark Inheritance
fields.body:
Dark Inheritance

Elaine Feinstein

198pp, The Women's Press, £9.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Emanuel Cellini, the emotionally messed-up son of a leading Italian politician, has written a sensational novel about a bored second wife sexually exploiting her barely pubescent stepson. Freelance book reviewer Rachel O'Malley is dispatched to sun-soaked Rome by a glossy magazine to hunt the author down and drag out of him what the readers are dying to know - where does fiction end and truth begin?

Dark Inheritance is Elaine Feinstein's first venture into a new genre: the literary thriller, to pop it in the right pigeonhole. A veteran novelist and award-winning poet, she carries the whole thing off with huge panache, driving the story along at 100mph with no time to catch a breath, so we stumble over the finishing line gasping for air (and in my case with tears in my eyes).

A S Byatt referred to a previous Feinstein novel, Loving Brecht , as "quiet, elegant and deep", while Fay Weldon described The Border as "ruthlessly brilliant". It's not surprising that these two writers are fans, because Feinstein falls somewhere between the two - imagine a faster-moving Byatt, or a Weldon with extra layers of meaning.

Dark Inheritance is also elegant and deep, but it is far from quiet. Under its surface run swift-moving currents of subtle violence, rough sex and the fierce creeping tentacles of mother love. O'Malley welcomes her voyeuristic assignment to track down Emanuel. She needs to solve her latest brown-envelope crisis, but she also hopes that the quest will distract her from her own filial sadness and guilty maternal terror. Her father, a well-known writer, has recently died, and she has just allowed her beloved son to go dashing off to travel around dangerous Indonesia in his gap year.

Once in Rome, O'Malley of course discovers that forcing one's way into someone else's family affairs is no way to escape one's own emotional problems. Rather, she is brought face to face with them. The truest answer to the literary riddle posed by Emanuel and his book turns out to be a mother love that can't let go, though its tender arms have to stretch from behind death's curtain; while Emanuel's father, Giorgio, overpowers O'Malley in his own physical way as much as the shadow of her famous father does. Giorgio's Mafia past is not precisely in the past, and the promise of personal danger turns up O'Malley's erotic heat. In the sickly Italian nights, crude ugly passions flare up and die. An old crush reappears in a new mysterious light and, time and again, trust equals risk.

Elaine Feinstein is a writer of enormous experience - a fellow of the Royal Society of Literature, she has 15 novels under her belt, holds a Cholmondeley Award for Poetry, has won three awards for her translations of Marina Tsvetayeva's poems, has written for theatre and television and, to cap it all, is also a renowned biographer (her life of Ted Hughes is out later this year). I'm just off to the bookshop to stock up my shelves.

webTitle: Review: In This Block There Lives a Slag by Bill Broady

fields.headline: Sheepish lives
fields.standfirst: James Hopkin  on a writer trapped: Bill Broady's In This Block There Lives a Slag
fields.trailText: James Hopkin on a writer trapped: Bill Broady's In This Block There Lives a Slag
fields.body:
In This Block There Lives a Slag

Bill Broady

242pp, Flamingo, £9.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Last year Bill Broady's skinny-dipping debut, Swimmer, caused a ripple or two with its elegant strokes and eager sense of fun. Stylish though it was, the latter part bore all the stretch marks of a swimming cap on an outsized head: there simply wasn't enough to go round. Perhaps, then, Broady's sardonic set pieces would prove better suited to short stories.

Collected together as "Yorkshire Fables" and given the graffiti lyricism of a no-messing title, this collection of 12 stories opens with the best of the bunch, "Wrestling Jacob". Jacob is a stocky Swaredale Ram who enjoys mock-fights in the field with a local lad, and Broady grants their bizarre friendship a teasing, poetic-erotic undertow in a witty tussle between the hardy and the heartfelt. Can a sheep be a love object? The author's answer: in Yorkshire, yes. The irony is well measured, the descriptions simple and evocative, and the story exhibits the same combination of cheek and charm that made the better moments of Swimmer so endearing.

Which is more than can be said of the title story. Set in the run-down tenement blocks of Bradford 13, Broady shows us an estate in fetid decline. Dogs lick used nappies and then their owners' faces, and in a clever union of the municipal and the metaphysical the lifts seem to go not up or down, but inwards. Yet having set the scene, Broady's first-person narrator offers a desultory recollection of odd jobs and incidents, not one of which is sufficiently animated to galvanise the pensive prose.

Throughout the book, the dialogue switches from costive to rambling in the time it takes you to yawn, while the narrative sporadically launches into polemical outbursts that read like a social worker's end-of-year report. The main problem lies with the odious character who narrates most of the tales. A writer manqué approaching middle age, his unfulfilled ambitions have fostered an embattled view of the world, and his self-consciousness fixes the stories in bitter memoir mode. Sensing his own writerly entrapment, Broady tries a few tricks with etymological curios and one or two words you may not find in the dictionary: impartibility, doylems. There's also an abundance of exclamation marks and ellipses, a desperate bid to create tension with punctuation because the prose is just not up to it.

We're left with a repetitious notebook of under-developed character sketches and descriptions, few of which come together to make the satisfying leap into fiction. We see little of Yorkshire, little of life. In this book there lives a writer? Well, it would appear that after the first story he moved on.

Which is more than can be said of the title story. Set in the run-down tenement blocks of Bradford 13, Broady shows us an estate in fetid decline. Dogs lick used nappies and then their owners' faces, and in a clever union of the municipal and the metaphysical the lifts seem to go not up or down, but inwards. Yet having set the scene, Broady's first-person narrator offers a desultory recollection of odd jobs and incidents, not one of which is sufficiently animated to galvanise the pensive prose. Throughout the book, the dialogue switches from costive to rambling in the time it takes you to yawn, while the narrative sporadically launches into polemical outbursts that read like a social worker's end-of-year report. The main problem lies with the odious character who narrates most of the tales. A writer manqué approaching middle age, his unfulfilled ambitions have fostered an embattled view of the world, and his self-consciousness fixes the stories in bitter memoir mode. Sensing his own writerly entrapment, Broady tries a few tricks with etymological curios and one or two words you may not find in the dictionary: impartibility, doylems. There's also an abundance of exclamation marks and ellipses, a desperate bid to create tension with punctuation because the prose is just not up to it. We're left with a repetitious notebook of under-developed character sketches and descriptions, few of which come together to make the satisfying leap into fiction. We see little of Yorkshire, little of life. In this book there lives a writer? Well, it would appear that after the first story he moved on.

fields.headline: Memories of Venus in flight
fields.trailText: Soon after meeting Lorna Sage 12 years ago, I became her agent. Her method of writing Bad Blood was extraordinary.
fields.body:
Faith Evans writes: Soon after meeting Lorna Sage 12 years ago, I became her agent. Her method of writing Bad Blood was extraordinary. Each chapter would take several months to conceive, and when she finally put pen to paper, what she produced was exactly what she intended. It was as though she cooked it inside her head so as to present a perfect meal. There was no question of rewriting or editing.

She was an intensely social person. Talk - about people, books, the ways of academe - meant almost everything to her. When she seemed to have no physical strength left to draw upon, she could be transformed by a long gossip or an impromptu seminar. She was completely professional; she had firm views of her own on most things, but if she took you on, her trust was total.

This is not to say she was always easy. On form, she was the best and kindest companion you could hope for; when feeling low, she could push you to the very brink of your patience, then pull you back with an outrageous display of charm. It was as though she knew she must not waste the precious time she had left.

She saw through puffery in a flash, though it amused rather than infuriated her, and she would often have to force herself to behave well when confronted by academic bureaucracy and wrangling.

Her brain remained supremely active, even when she was sometimes barely able to breathe. Temperamentally opposed to the role of victim, she met her ailments head on, developing a clinical, even comic, interest in her symptoms that must have been intimidating to her doctors. She had the most intense will to live of anyone I have ever known.

Gore Vidal writes: Arguably (one must never not argue), Lorna Sage was the best literary critic in England of her generation. She knew a very great deal about sentence-making, and she had a supersonic bat's ear for the false note in a piece of prose. "I could memorise anything," she told me years ago, when I praised her criticism. "That trick got me out of where I was, and on to university, and so forth."

Last fall, I read Bad Blood in a New York hotel room; realised what a very long way she had come from where she started. One gift to be noted: "How on earth," I asked, "can you deal with all those school teacherly books on literary theory?"

She had a low conspiratorial chuckle when giving away trade secrets. "Well, remember that they are all written in a special near-English jargon that I understand. So all I do is translate them back into English, and the reader can see what rubbish it is without my ever making an unkind remark."

For several decades, she was uncommonly beautiful, with long blonde hair, blue eyes, an ominous smoker's cough and a surreal imagination. Once, she bounded out of the sea at Amalfi, like Venus in flight from her half-shell. "I have been attacked," she shouted, "by killer clams." Life's duller now.

Doris Lessing writes: It was only when I read Bad Blood that I realised what obstacles she had had to overcome, and what gusto and energy went in to it all. She relished life; she was a great enjoyer. Sometimes, you meet people who say, I was so lucky to have had a teacher who taught me to love books and literature; she was such a teacher. And she was a good critic and reviewer too. She was much too young to die.

Snoo Wilson writes: Thirty and more years ago, when I was one of the two Sages' students, I took Lorna and Vic's photographs. Keen to add additional light sources as well as photogenic smoke, I persuaded Lorna to light a fresh cigarette with a match - swoosh! - for each take. This she did, with evident pleasure, saying she never had known photography to be such fun before.

Lorna's extraordinary scholarship never quite won me over to the Faerie Queene, which I pretended to study under her. However, her own keen appreciation was always laced with a humorous and deadly irreverence. She had an anarchic eye for most of life's absurdities, and used her declining health frequently as the starting point for some cruelly comic anecdote.

fields.headline: First novels
fields.trailText: Lisa Darnell picks out the best of the new: Something Like a House, Cape Breton Road, The Mineral Palace and The Tin Man
fields.body:
Perhaps the best way for a first-time novelist to move beyond thinly disguised autobiography is to set about evoking a particular place, the more distant the better. Set in the famine-ridden China of the Cultural Revolution, Sid Smith's painstakingly researched Something Like A House (Picador, £12.99) tells the story of 18-year-old Fraser, a deserter from the British army living in the Hong Kong hills. Orphaned, without purpose or personality, Fraser learns to survive in a culture and climate so harsh that nothing can be wasted. He sets up home in an empty storehouse, securing it from the elements with stolen straw, and unwittingly becomes the champion of his beleaguered community when he bears witness to a covert form of ethnic cleansing. Smith's sparse narrative well evokes the bleak environment, but eventually the deliberate flatness of tone makes this otherwise admirable novel difficult to fall for.

Buy it at a discount at BOL

In the frozen wilderness of D R MacDonald's lyrical and evocative Cape Breton Road (Chatto, £10), 19-year-old Innis Corbett is marooned in his native Canada, "unmoored and anonymous, a nobody". Expelled from the States for petty crime, he's now living in uneasy conflict with his dour uncle. Except for walking, wood-chopping and the local church, distractions are few. Instead, Innis secretly nurtures his precious crop of marijuana seeds and openly covets his uncle's girlfriend. As the slow, cold winter becomes languorous, steamy summer and his plants grow to a full-budded crop, Innis is broiled over the hot coals of frustrated desire. MacDonald's lengthy affirmations of the merits of marijuana are about as stimulating as the drug itself, but robust descriptions of the Canadian landscape are unexpectedly refreshing.

Buy it at a discount at BOL

In Heidi Julavits's remarkably assured The Mineral Palace (Virago, £9.99), Bena and her husband drive to a new life in Colorado, their month-old baby in a drawer on the back seat. Once there, Bena is frustrated and weepy, until she starts writing for the local newspaper. It doesn't take long for her to unearth some everyday horrors that will never make the pages of the Chieftain - "the screams of trespassed girls, the quiet agony of poverty, of slipping low, low, lower than a person ever thought possible". Although Bena wants to challenge the abhorrent behaviour that passes for small-town life, we realise she is turning a blind eye to her husband's fumbled infidelities, the increasingly worrying state of her baby's health and the unsavoury rattling in her own family closet. Oblique, unsettling and teeming with subtle observations.

Buy it at a discount at BOL

"Aberdeen is freezing and it's only September," complains Joe in Martin Shannon's charming The Tin Man (11:9, £9.99). As a sensitive boy growing up in the 1970s, Joe lives in terror of the Bomb. Determined to endure the blast, he packs his "survival kit" in an old tobacco tin, hoping to use the reflective lid to signal passing aircraft. As an adult, however, he discovers that real life is harder to defend himself against; his marriage has foundered, and with it his relationship with his four-year-old daughter. Funny and heartfelt, Shannon's is an uncommonly authentic voice that suggests an engaging new talent.

fields.headline: Window shopping
fields.trailText: Roll up, you lucky, lucky people! Waterstone's is offering publishers the unique chance to part with vast sums of money in a lottery-style auction of window space
fields.body:
 Roll up, you lucky, lucky people! Waterstone's is offering publishers the unique chance to part with vast sums of money in a lottery-style auction of window space. Pointing out the potential uplift in sales for a "solus window promotion" for 10 days (with a weekend at each end) and promising regular checks of "branch compliance", the round-robin email from Waterstone's HQ goes on to solicit what they euphemistically call "contributions". If you're an ambitious writer, all you need to do to see your name in lights is persuade your publishers to "name their best offer", bearing in mind that Waterstone's "will not consider any offer of less than £6k".

 Meanwhile, if you want to earn money rather than spend it and you can dash off a poem of 70 lines or fewer, you might want to enter this year's Strokestown Poetry Prize. The Prize's administrators, undaunted by its lack of celebrity, boldly proclaim it as "the Louis XIV of prizes", albeit from "the E J Thribb of towns". In fact, obscurity has one bonus: "The number of entries is still low enough to make winning big money a high probability for an emergent genius." To find out more, visit www.strokestownpoetryprize.com, but quickly - the closing date is 23 February.

 A touching tale of aspiration thwarted reaches the Loafer from a dogged reader whose New Year's resolution was to read all six volumes of Proust's In Search of Lost Time. Amazon duly obliged with five - but the first instalment of the mammoth tale has yet to arrive. Better luck next year.

 A lesson in modern marketing for those who need it. A new Penguin Classics edition of Homer's Odyssey is graced by the lovely George Clooney and his co-stars in the film O Brother, Where Art Thou?. The Coen brothers did, it must be said, derive some inspiration from the ancient Greek, but fans expecting more than a passing resemblance to an American all-singing, all-dancing extravaganza might find themselves disappointed. One can only hope it's not a trend, but as the film's slogan has it, "They have a plan but not a clue ..."

 From the States comes news that Harvard University Business School Press has paid $250,000 for a mysterious invention code-named "Ginger", apparently so ground-breaking that Amazon founder Jeff Bezos claims it will sell itself, Apple chief Steve Jobs thinks it will revolutionise cities, and eager investors are on tenterhooks. Whatever it is, both author and inventor are keeping mum, having mastered, at least, the art of hype.
