fields.headline: Lorna Sage
fields.standfirst: Brilliant teacher and critic who expanded the horizons of English literature and women's writing
fields.trailText: Brilliant teacher and critic who expanded the horizons of English literature and women's writing.
fields.body:
Lorna Sage, who has died in Norwich two days before her 58th birthday, was one of the most brilliant literary critics of her generation. The success of her memoir, Bad Blood, brought her a new readership at the end of her life. But before the book's publication she had established an international reputation as a critic, scholar and writer who made reviewing into her own distinctive art form.

She was a charismatic teacher at the University of East Anglia, where she worked from 1965 until her death. Her passion for literature and her learning inspired generations of students who worked with her. She was not a person who needed to be reminded that good teaching is central to the profession of an academic.

Sage was born in Hanmer, a village on the English-Welsh border. Her memoir gives a vivid account of her childhood. She learnt early on about the strangeness of families and the value of reading. Initially, she was brought up in the village rectory with her grandparents and her mother. Her grandfather, who lived a life of sexual scandal and frustrated ambition, introduced her to books. Her grandmother introduced her to the secret lives of women.

Reading provided an alternative world, a way of living apart in the midst of family turbulence. When her father returned from the second world war, the family moved from the old rectory to a newly-built council house. But the new possibilities presented by postwar reconstruction were shrouded by older patterns of English provincial custom and prejudice. In her own description, Sage was an "apprentice misfit". This sense of self fuelled her determination to make her own way on her own terms.

In 1953, she moved across the border into England as a pupil at Whitchurch high school for girls. Here, she discovered a love of Latin to add to her love of reading. She learnt, too, the importance of being top of the class; intellectual success was a means of keeping moral disapproval at bay. Outside the proprieties of an English girls' grammar school, there were other fascinations: boys and the discovery of the power of her own beauty. Sage grew up with the sounds of rock 'n' roll and a sense that the old ways were no longer any good.

At 15, she met Vic Sage, the man shortly to become her first husband. At 16, she was married and pregnant. At 17, she gave birth to her first and only child, Sharon. Undaunted, Sage continued to pursue her intellectual ambitions. She applied to Durham University to read English, and was awarded a scholarship. Her brilliance found a way through circumstances that might well have overwhelmed other women of her age and class.

St Aidan's College altered its rules to allow access to women students who were also wives and mothers. Vic had also been awarded a place to read English at Durham. In 1961, a unique student family took up residence in a traditional English university.

Even though their marriage was to end in divorce, the intellectual and emotional partnership Sage established with Vic was to last throughout her life. Their careers ran in parallel; both graduated with first-class degrees in 1964, both moved on to Birmingham University, where Sage studied at the Shakespeare Institute. In 1965, she became an assistant lecturer in English at the recently established University of East Anglia. In 1967, Vic took up a similar post at the same university.

The institution that she joined was small, intense and experimental. Malcolm Bradbury and Angus Wilson were colleagues. The Shakespearian critic and scholar, Nicholas Brooke, who had taught Sage at Durham, was also there, as was the writer, Jonathan Raban. Both became close and lasting friends and discerning readers of her work.

In the late 1960s, another significant friendship began with the historian and politician Patricia Hollis (now a government minister). Young women academics in a predominantly masculine environment, Sage and Hollis developed their friendship through their teaching.

Well before the invention of "new historicism" they taught what was, at the time, a unique course on the urban landscapes of the 1830s and 40s. Questioning a simple-minded distinction between fact and fiction, they analysed the rhetoric of 19th-century fiction, philosophy and government reports, finding in the forms of language a guide to the mentality of a culture.

This kind of teaching appealed to Sage, precisely because it made teaching a form of research. She believed university teaching should open up fields of inquiry rather than deliver settled doctrines. Her teaching grew out of the latest discoveries in her reading. Her seminars were intellectual events, where some new line of critical thought would unfold.

If Sage was a charismatic teacher, through out the late 1960s and the 1970s she developed her identity as a critic. Early publications on Milton grew out of her work as a graduate student. These reflected her growing interest in neo-Platonism, an interest that was to take her to Italy and the archives and galleries of Florence.

Neo-Platonism was a source of endless fascination. It played a crucial role in the English poetic tradition, something that could be traced in the work of Milton, Shelley and, in a transatlantic version, the poetry of Wallace Stevens. More than a set of philosophical doctrines, it offered a way of both imagining and managing the world; it was possible to be both this worldly and other worldly at the same time.

Sage's major study of neo-Platonism and English poetry was uncompleted at the time of her death. Instead, there was an abundance of other published work. During the 1970s, she established her reputation as an authoritative reviewer of contemporary fiction. She worked with a number of distinguished literary editors, including Terence Kilmartin at the Observer, and Ian Hamilton at New Review.

For Sage, reviewing was serious criticism. Her habit was to read all the available published work of any author she was reviewing. She was deeply engaged by the idea of writing about literature before it became canonical. Her reviewing was an opportunity to forge a style that could be both intelligent and accessible.

Literary London became part of her actual and imaginative topography. It provided an alternative to academic life, but also a complement to it. Moving back and forth between what Sage described as "Grub Street and academe", she could combine the intellectual authority of the university with the stylistic energy of the great literary journalist. It also enabled her to satisfy that temperamental need to be inside and outside whatever world she was in.

By the end of the 1970s, her first marriage had ended and her second marriage to Rupert Hodson had begun. This relationship was intimately connected to another doubling of her world; her research had taken her to Italy, where they met. She decided that she wanted to live in Italy and England, and developed a pattern of teaching at UEA during term time and writing in Italy during vacations.

New and important friendships developed with Gore Vidal and Angela Carter. The friendship with Carter was deeply important to Sage, and coincided with another development in her work. From the late 1970s onwards, she published widely on women writers and woman's writing. In 1983, her study of Doris Lessing appeared. In 1991, she published Women In The House Of Fiction, a brilliant study of women's fiction in the 20th century. In 1994, a short book on Angela Carter came out, and in the same year she edited a collection of essays on Carter, The Flesh And The Mirror.

But her concern was not simply to write about women, rather to make their work more widely and intelligently known. She wrote introductions to fiction by Katherine Mansfield, Christina Stead and Virginia Woolf. In 1994, she was appointed editor-in-chief of The Cambridge Guide To Women's Writing In English.

As with so much of her work, Sage's engagement with women's writing combined passion with intelligence. She was attracted to women who wrote in order to survive and to overcome the cultural circumstances they had to endure. She was a feminist, but not one who wanted to live out her life as a public martyrdom. She was contemptuous of the way that men intrigued against women, but wanted to make her way in the world as she found it. She played a central role in the academic life of UEA. She was twice dean of the school of English and American studies and, in 1994, was appointed to a chair in English literature.

The last five years of her life were increasingly dominated by the illness that eventually caused her death. Sage did not suffer fools gladly, and often the world seemed increasingly full of them. Although physically diminished by illness, she continued to write and teach with undiminished energy. Her Cambridge Guide was published in 1990, but what preoccupied her most was the completion of the memoir which provides such a compelling portrait of her as a young women.

Life grew very hard for her. Her second marriage was under strain, but she was heroically supported by Sharon and a small circle of friends. At the time of her death, she had many projects in train and more to give to a literary culture she had done so much to shape. She is survived by Rupert Hodson, Vic Sage, Sharon and her granddaughter, Olivia.

 Lorna Sage, journalist and critic, born January 13 1943; died January 11 2000

Their careers ran in parallel; both graduated with first-class degrees in 1964, both moved on to Birmingham University, where Sage studied at the Shakespeare Institute. In 1965, she became an assistant lecturer in English at the recently established University of East Anglia. In 1967, Vic took up a similar post at the same university. The institution that she joined was small, intense and experimental. Malcolm Bradbury and Angus Wilson were colleagues. The Shakespearian critic and scholar, Nicholas Brooke, who had taught Sage at Durham, was also there, as was the writer, Jonathan Raban. Both became close and lasting friends and discerning readers of her work. In the late 1960s, another significant friendship began with the historian and politician Patricia Hollis (now a government minister). Young women academics in a predominantly masculine environment, Sage and Hollis developed their friendship through their teaching. Well before the invention of "new historicism" they taught what was, at the time, a unique course on the urban landscapes of the 1830s and 40s. Questioning a simple-minded distinction between fact and fiction, they analysed the rhetoric of 19th-century fiction, philosophy and government reports, finding in the forms of language a guide to the mentality of a culture. This kind of teaching appealed to Sage, precisely because it made teaching a form of research. She believed university teaching should open up fields of inquiry rather than deliver settled doctrines. Her teaching grew out of the latest discoveries in her reading. Her seminars were intellectual events, where some new line of critical thought would unfold. If Sage was a charismatic teacher, through out the late 1960s and the 1970s she developed her identity as a critic. Early publications on Milton grew out of her work as a graduate student. These reflected her growing interest in neo-Platonism, an interest that was to take her to Italy and the archives and galleries of Florence. Neo-Platonism was a source of endless fascination. It played a crucial role in the English poetic tradition, something that could be traced in the work of Milton, Shelley and, in a transatlantic version, the poetry of Wallace Stevens. More than a set of philosophical doctrines, it offered a way of both imagining and managing the world; it was possible to be both this worldly and other worldly at the same time. Sage's major study of neo-Platonism and English poetry was uncompleted at the time of her death. Instead, there was an abundance of other published work. During the 1970s, she established her reputation as an authoritative reviewer of contemporary fiction. She worked with a number of distinguished literary editors, including Terence Kilmartin at the Observer, and Ian Hamilton at New Review. For Sage, reviewing was serious criticism. Her habit was to read all the available published work of any author she was reviewing. She was deeply engaged by the idea of writing about literature before it became canonical. Her reviewing was an opportunity to forge a style that could be both intelligent and accessible. Literary London became part of her actual and imaginative topography. It provided an alternative to academic life, but also a complement to it. Moving back and forth between what Sage described as "Grub Street and academe", she could combine the intellectual authority of the university with the stylistic energy of the great literary journalist. It also enabled her to satisfy that temperamental need to be inside and outside whatever world she was in. By the end of the 1970s, her first marriage had ended and her second marriage to Rupert Hodson had begun. This relationship was intimately connected to another doubling of her world; her research had taken her to Italy, where they met. She decided that she wanted to live in Italy and England, and developed a pattern of teaching at UEA during term time and writing in Italy during vacations. New and important friendships developed with Gore Vidal and Angela Carter. The friendship with Carter was deeply important to Sage, and coincided with another development in her work. From the late 1970s onwards, she published widely on women writers and woman's writing. In 1983, her study of Doris Lessing appeared. In 1991, she published Women In The House Of Fiction, a brilliant study of women's fiction in the 20th century. In 1994, a short book on Angela Carter came out, and in the same year she edited a collection of essays on Carter, The Flesh And The Mirror. But her concern was not simply to write about women, rather to make their work more widely and intelligently known. She wrote introductions to fiction by Katherine Mansfield, Christina Stead and Virginia Woolf. In 1994, she was appointed editor-in-chief of The Cambridge Guide To Women's Writing In English. As with so much of her work, Sage's engagement with women's writing combined passion with intelligence. She was attracted to women who wrote in order to survive and to overcome the cultural circumstances they had to endure. She was a feminist, but not one who wanted to live out her life as a public martyrdom. She was contemptuous of the way that men intrigued against women, but wanted to make her way in the world as she found it. She played a central role in the academic life of UEA. She was twice dean of the school of English and American studies and, in 1994, was appointed to a chair in English literature. The last five years of her life were increasingly dominated by the illness that eventually caused her death. Sage did not suffer fools gladly, and often the world seemed increasingly full of them. Although physically diminished by illness, she continued to write and teach with undiminished energy. Her Cambridge Guide was published in 1990, but what preoccupied her most was the completion of the memoir which provides such a compelling portrait of her as a young women. Life grew very hard for her. Her second marriage was under strain, but she was heroically supported by Sharon and a small circle of friends. At the time of her death, she had many projects in train and more to give to a literary culture she had done so much to shape. She is survived by Rupert Hodson, Vic Sage, Sharon and her granddaughter, Olivia.  Lorna Sage, journalist and critic, born January 13 1943; died January 11 2000 The first chapter of Lorna Sage's Bad Blood can be read at: www.booksunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Review: Humanity: a Moral History of the Twentieth Century, by Jonathan Glover

fields.headline: Prime evils
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard on Jonathan Glover's  necessary guide to our inhumanity - Humanity: a Moral History of the Twentieth Century
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard on Jonathan Glover's necessary guide to our inhumanity - Humanity: a Moral History of the Twentieth Century
fields.body:
Humanity: a Moral History of the Twentieth Century
Jonathan Glover
(Pimlico, £12.50)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

If, like me, you have been following the second reading of the Armed Forces Bill like a hawk, you'll have been amused at the Conservative party's incoherent objections. As Robert Key, William Hague's defence spokesperson, puts it: "We believe that members of the armed forces are different, and should be different from most civilians ... we must be prepared to front up to the entire issue of political correctness in relation to the armed forces." Standard, barely literate Tory grumbling, but some people really do think like that. This is what much of the book is about: should soldiers be different from us, or should they entertain moral scruples?

It is as well that no-one quite like Key prevailed during the Cuban Missile Crisis of 1962. Christopher Hitchens coined a neat inversion: he remembers exactly where he was when President Kennedy tried to kill him. According to this book, Kennedy might have pushed us to the brink, but he pulled us back again - although the real hero of the hour was Krushchev, who was prepared to lose face in order to avoid our annihilation. But the Americans really came close to roasting half the planet, and the following names should live in infamy: Douglas Dillon, somewhat extending his brief as US Treasury Secretary, who complained of elements in the cabinet who were "so irrationally fearful of nuclear war", and Paul Nitze, Assistant Secretary of Defense, who moaned about the ethical discussions of the time - eg about whether it was right to precipitate a third world war - as being "sophomoric".

One wonders how many wackos like that are in Bush's new cabinet (although Colin Powell, an apologist for the My Lai massacre, has the admirable quality, in a soldier at least, of cowardice); it might do well for them to read this book, which although misleadingly titled and with the occasional air of the exalted cuttings job, is a useful primer on our inhumanity. In chapters on, among others, the first world war, My Lai, Hiroshima, Rwanda, Stalin, the Nazis, Mao's Cultural Revolution and Pol Pot, Glover rubs our noses in our own ordure while at the same time proposing a model of how we should be governed. The leader we want, in short, should be intelligent, imaginative, capable of empathy and, while a swift decision-maker, not given to acting on impulse. A tall order, but a necessary one.

There are glitches - is the Sir Edward Grey on page 194, who "carried nearly all the cabinet with him in support of going to war", the same Sir Edward Grey who, on page 199, "saw that war would be a disaster and tried harder than most to avoid it"? Does Glover's wrestling with matters of primary ethical concern (such as whether murder is wrong), and his potential audience of politicians, mean that he has to use what at times comes close to baby talk? (Unfortunately, yes.) And is there something verging on the pornographic in the way we read the minutiae, the everyday details of despotism, while comforting ourselves on our own distance from them? (Yes, but that's hardly Glover's fault.) This is an uncomfortable and unsettling book - when Stephen Pinker says he "could not put it down", you have to wonder whether he's weird or not. But as an account of our greatest degradation - and a how-not-to manual for our survival, it is, I'm afraid, essential.

webTitle: Now, where did I leave those rose-tinted spectacles?

fields.headline: Now, where did I leave those rose-tinted spectacles?
fields.trailText: Director's diary
fields.body:
December 30 2000

Our last day in Beauvais and, leaving the best till last, we visit the cathedral. It's a fantastic monument to the fallibility of architects and the vanity of bishops, who wanted to build a gigantic cathedral in this small town but only achieved a third of it - a chancel broken off at the transept. The building soars over the town, a crown of stone supported by slim fingers which reach towards heaven, defying the laws of gravity. But gravity triumphed over the rest of the cathedral: a spire was built above the transept, taller by about 50ft than the spire of Salisbury cathedral and, too high and too wide, and it collapsed on Ascension Day 1573 just as the congregation emerged from the church.

Beauvais cathedral might have ended up like other gross fantasies, as clumsy as Bokassa's half-completed cathedral in the Central African Republic or as ugly as Ceausescu's palace in Bucharest, but it has the splendour of a great (if unfinished) symphony: unresolved chords continue to resonate, a monument not to earthly ambition but to spiritual inspiration - what we would now call "a work of art". Edith Wharton described it, in a book about motoring through France that a friend sent me for Christmas, as the "Kubla Khan" of architecture.

She drove - well, of course she didn't drive - her chauffeur drove her and her occasional travelling companion, Henry James, from fine restaurant to fine restaurant, from hotel to hotel (their luggage sent ahead), fastidiously weeding out the inferior ones: "a brief peep into the hotel promptly quenched the impulse to spend a night there". When they were travelling through the north of France it was unblemished by war: "so green, so full and close in texture". The same area was described by Scott Fitzgerald 16 years later in Tender Is the Night: "Great funeral pyres of sorted duds, shells, bombs, grenades, and equipment, helmets, bayonets, gun stocks, and rotten leather... And suddenly round the bend the white caps of a great sea of graves."

December 31

"The motor-car has restored the romance of travel," said Wharton. Sitting in a traffic jam on the M25 I feel that something might have been lost in the near-century since her love affair with the car.

Back in England, it's a relief to find that the media appears to have found nothing more to celebrate this New Year's Eve than Arthur C Clarke's novel and Stanley Kubrick's film 2001: A Space Odyssey. Last year the press, desperate as ever for topics to fill their glut of supplements, clutched at the celebration of the millennium like alkies topping up their Special Brew with a dose of meths. Articles spewed forth about the best person, politician, religious leader, building, book, film, play or song of the last 1,000 years. I remember only two statistics: the man of the millennium was Shakespeare, and the best song of the last 1,000 years was Bohemian Rhapsody by Queen. As Max Miller would have said: "Go on, lady, make something of that!"

The incessant invocation of the millennium's "significance" was like totalitarian propaganda, and as the clock moved towards midnight I felt like a dissident standing in Red Square while convoys of weapons and marching troops paraded to demonstrate the enduring glories of communism. The Dome was the Lenin's Tomb of millennium ideology. Now, only a year later, I wish that the politicians responsible for initiating and perpetuating it, as in the aftermath of the velvet revolution, showed some shame, but shame and politics are strangers to each other. At least it may have given some politicians pause before criticising managers of arts organisations for not knowing how to manage "public attractions".

January 1 2001

New Year's Day. For me, making new year resolutions is like going to confession - a meaningless ritual intended to show piety and to assuage guilt at doing nothing positive to improve your life. This year I promise myself less drink and more exercise, both on St Augustine's terms - not yet. Yesterday's snow has disappeared and my wife and I walk in the footsteps of our local poet, the "Super Tramp" WH Davies, whose "What is this life if, full of care,/We have no time to stand and stare?" is currently featured in a TV commercial for Center Parcs leisure centres.

I've spent much of the past year working as a writer, and for someone used to working with a group of people and, until three years ago, being responsible for a theatre the size of a small town, the solitude is hard to bear. "A writer is a maker, not a man of action," said Auden, scorning biographies of writers as "always superfluous and usually in bad taste". These days, a truthful account of my life is as follows: "Went to the country. Went for a walk. Saw a yellow wagtail. Wrote diary for the Guardian. Wrote rewrites for screenplay. Er, that's it."

January 2

The screenplay I've been writing (with Charles Wood) is about love and old age. It's based on John Bayley's books about his life with his wife, Iris Murdoch, and her Alzheimer's disease.

My mother got Alzheimer's in her 50s, so I have enough experience of observing it and warily examining my own memory from time to time. At a certain age, bits start to drop off and you begin to think: "Have I got this or that?" I once had a brain scan after a car accident; the good news was that I didn't have any sign of incipient Alzheimer's, but the bad was that I had a spot that might have been the beginnings of Parkinson's.

"The disease will probably start with a spasm in your arm which will become a tremor," said the doctor. So there's rarely a spasm in my arm that goes unaccompanied by a spasm of anxiety, and rarely a forgotten word or name that doesn't invoke a flicker of unease.

I lean towards thinking of happiness as an absence of unhappiness, or agreeing with Tennessee Williams when asked for a definition of it: "Er_ insensitivity, I guess." So I was chastened when I read a piece in the Observer by John Diamond, who has cancer and yet was celebrating his reasons to be cheerful. His ability to be thankful for what he regards as his good fortune is as admirable as his courage in dealing with his bad fortune. He makes me feel that not to try to be happy is an unforgivable self-indulgence. Now there's a new year resolution.

January 3

I am giving up writing about myself: I'm giving up this diary, or it's giving me up, at least on a weekly basis. After 11 weeks of it I'm beginning to understand the weariness of the columnists who drop their opinions like cowpats week after week, those ones who live down to the German philosopher Karl Kraus's description of journalists: "They write because they have nothing to say, and they have something to say because they write." At the same time my admiration has increased for those few regular columnists who manage to keep it up week after week: Miles Kington and Craig Brown, for instance. Perhaps they have a lively correspondence with their readers, who constantly suggest topics for them to write about. I've had two responses to my column. One letter demanded that I invite Jesus into my life before it was too late; the other referred to my "special, beautiful soul" and was keen to induct me into the Hindu faith. I begin to see the God Shiva beckoning.

webTitle: Police check link to two other children

fields.headline: Police check link to two other children
fields.trailText: Police are investigating the cases of two other children from Ivory Coast after they found paperwork in Carl Manning's flat to suggest that they had been adopted by Marie Thérèse Kouao.
fields.body:
Police are investigating the cases of two other children from Ivory Coast after they found paperwork in Carl Manning's flat to suggest that they had been adopted by Marie Thérèse Kouao.

The officer who led the investigation into Anna's death, Det Insp Keith Niven, said he was carrying out inquiries with the French authorities with regard to two children who he believed may have suffered at the hands of Kouao. He said: "I just want to talk to them to check upon their welfare in the light of what Marie Therese has done in relation to Anna.

"Knowing this woman's capabilities, we are very concerned for the other children. We need to know they are safe and are making inquiries."

While trying to find paperwork that would lead them to Anna's real identity - Kouao was adamant after her arrest that she was her daughter - police discovered documents from the minor supervision department of Vanves magistrates court in France, dated April 28 1993, which show that Kouao applied for guardianship of a girl named Christelle Koula, age not stated, at a time when she was living at 27 Rue Phileas Lebesque in Amiens.

During her trial at the Old Bailey, Kouao claimed that Christelle was her sister's daughter and that she was still living in France.

Paperwork from Abidjan magistrates court shows that Kouao also applied for custody of a boy named Aime Constant Allo, 15, on September 5 1996. When asked in court about him, Kouao claimed she never took the boy to France and he remained with his parents.

Kouao has an adopted daughter, Claudine, who is living in France.

Police said they were interested in speaking to another person with regard to Kouao's actions.

fields.headline: Incognico
fields.standfirst: It may be called Incognico, but there is no mistaking Nico Ladenis's magisterial imprint in the simpler fare of his latest gastronomic venture, says Matthew Fort
fields.trailText: It may be called Incognico, but there is no mistaking Nico Ladenis's magisterial imprint in the simpler fare of his latest gastronomic venture, says Matthew Fort.
fields.body:
Have you ever wondered what great chefs do when they get tired of manning the pass, cuffing incompetent underlings around the ears and berating less than subservient critics? They get around to making real money by starting up cheap(er) brasseries and bistros. It's been all the rage in Paris for some time. Over here, Marco Pierre White has done it. Raymond Blanc has done it. And Nico Ladenis, formerly of triple Michelin starred Chez Nico at 90, has done it twice. A few years back, he built up a mini-chain of Simply Nicos which he eventually sold on (and the standards promptly fell through the floor). Now he's at it again with Incognico, a medium-sized, rather manly establishment, which promises to be the first in a new series of eateries designed to bring decent grub to the New Labour working classes.

The name, of course, is a joke. It's not simply a pun, but a pun which contains an interior fallacy. Nico has never been incog-anything. I suspect that personally he is a shy and retiring sort of chap, publicly he had a deft way with the headlines and the gossip columns, and while he may not be setting the tempo in the kitchen any more, there is a good deal about the food at Incognico that bears his unmistakable and magisterial imprint.

This is not the cèpes risotto or boudin of foie gras of yesteryear, the Michelin marvels that many admired and few could afford, but altogether simpler and more accessible fare. The cèpes in the risotto have been replaced by ordinary mushrooms. There's the time-honoured combination of endive, Roquefort and pears; an equally traditional fillet steak au poivre vert; a dauntingly simple dish of grilled fillets of John Dory with thyme olive oil; veal kidneys with mustard sauce. Nothing particularly fancy about them, you may think, and nor is there, but there is a brilliant technical assurance which produces dazzling consistency.

These days, this is really rather refreshing. It's not so much a matter of an old dog learning new tricks, but of an old dog paring his tricks down to the basic elements and polishing them to a lapidary gloss. So what if the menu is fabulously, unreconstructedly old-fashioned? But for the passing nod to contemporary fad (crispy salmon with ginger and plum sauce) it could have been lifted lock, stock and petits pois a la française from some L'Epicure or La Popote of yesteryear, even down to the cursory, if characteristically polished, gesture in the direction of Italy (a grand, semi- deliquescent osso bucco with Parmesan risotto). This is French food that made our parents, nay even our grandparents, misty-eyed with gastro-nostalgia. It is the food that made them fall in love with food in the first place. And, in truth, it does so all over again.

I took Dorabella, as dedicated a vegetarian as I know, and the artichoke stuffed with a mushroom duxelle and enrobed (no other word will do) in a fulsome hollandaise caused her so much pleasure that nearby tables were under the impression that she was re-enacting the celebrated scene from the movie When Harry Met Sally. She was almost as deeply impressed by the open ravioli of goats' cheese with roast peppers, tomatoes and basil oil. Heaven knows, I have said my bit about this clichéd sop to vegetarian eating of the contemporary restaurant menu, but when the goats' cheese itself is a Class A item, as it was this time, and the bits and bobs making up the dish given due attention, why then goats' cheese dishes have their place.

While Dorabella was waxing lyrical, I was getting quieter, if no less profound, satisfaction from the endive, Roquefort and pear salad, which was rather fancier in the presentation terms than I am used to, but which is a classic because, with ripe pears, ripe cheese and crunchy endive, it is very, very harmonious. The grilled John Dory fillets were even more splendid, fat fingers of taut fish, the just caramelised outside of which helped emphasise the shining freshness of the fish.

As was always the way with French restaurants in the olden days, puddings get less significant treatment. On this occasion, the chocolate marquise bore scant resemblance to the definitive (and, it has to be said, system-crashingly rich) version of the recipe in Nico Ladenis's My Gastronomy, and the warm chocolate mousse, while suitably mousse-like, was rather too sugary for my liking. Still, considering what goes before, these are easy things to forgive.

And considering you can eat a three-course lunch of this standard for £12.50, why, you should come out smiling. We did, although the bill came to £74.50 (food, £54; drink, £21.20); we had wandered far from the set-price menu, but that's my prerogative.

fields.headline: Feeding frenzy
fields.standfirst: Time to think about planting vegetable seed. Be led by your tastebuds, says Christopher Lloyd
fields.trailText: Time to think about planting vegetable seed. Be led by your tastebuds, says Christopher Lloyd.
fields.body:
We have been considering which vegetable seeds to grow this year. Even though they are fun and achieve a huge amount of growth in a short time, I steer clear of marrows, courgettes, squashes and pumpkins - whatever my friends may claim to the contrary, I find them watery and short on flavour. If you are supposed to eat them small and young, which is the case with courgettes, they need to be picked every day; otherwise they will quickly get ahead of you when your back is turned.

But I do, on our compost heap, grow outdoor cucumbers, and found F1 Burpless Tasty Green prolific and prolonged-fruiting last year. Of moderate length, the fruits are thin-skinned, so I rarely peel them, and then only partially, when making soup, say. You do need to pick them regularly, however, so that the plants continue to make new cucumbers. Just twitch off the ready ones and lay them down where picked if you don't need any for cooking. There are only 10 seeds to a packet, but that is ample. We sow in pots under cold glass in early May, and cropping starts in late July.

Last month, I was still enjoying a wonderful crop of Florence fennel, the bulbous-rooted kind, that we sowed in situ in mid-August. The seedlings were for a long time desperately slow, but the mild and wet autumn certainly suited them. They gave me really large bulbs, which I cut into four before boiling for 15 minutes. Then I drained and finished them off at a low heat in olive oil for five to 10 minutes. Lovely with fish, and so tender.

It is important to space the fennel plants widely, so that they do not compete with one another and, in the cool weather, they hold for weeks without bolting. When frost has threatened, we throw over a length of hessian for the night. If need be, the uncooked bulbs keep well in a plastic bag in the fridge.

I was very pleased with a dwarf French bean that we grew for the first time last year, called Masai. Its pods are small, slim and prolific, and they remain small for a long while. Naturally, they are stringless, which we have come to expect these days. On our cold clay soil, we seldom sow before mid-May.

I don't grow a range of potatoes, as the ordinary kinds for baking or mashing are so easily bought, but waxy potatoes - especially useful in salads, but also for general purposes - are not so easily found in the shops. The old English variety, pink fir apple, is a must, for me, although its appearance is rather extraordinary - long, thin and often branching. I normally peel it after cooking, rather than before. Charlotte, which is a popular second early variety, is quite a large potato and keeps into the new year. Pink firs keep in a cold shed until April. We sprayed regularly against blight last summer, but there was no sign of any, right up to the end.

Another spray that we had to repeat was on our broad beans, Express. That was against black aphids, which attack the young shoot tips in early summer and can make a complete mess of your plants if immediate action is not taken with a quick-acting chemical. Ladybirds and hoverfly larvae are too slow off the mark to do the job.

Early purple-sprouting broccoli is just coming in now, and that is so welcome if the winter is mild enough to allow it to develop. A row of late purple will follow in April. I have been able to pick romanesco broccoli spasmodically ever since early autumn, but the strain needs re-selecting and gives very uneven results from plant to plant, but even so I am glad to have it. The flavour of cauliflower cannot touch that of the broccolis.

On the whole, I am happy to forgo brassicas in summer, but make an exception of the Green Comet calabrese, which we bring on in pots (being an F1 hybrid, there's not a lot of seed) fairly early and which crops late June and July, if we get the timing right (and keep the pigeons at bay), before the green caterpillars get going in the heart of the curds.

I see that Thompson & Morgan is offering a Brussels sprout, F1 Trafalgar, of which it says that "even children love them". When I think of the way that greens were presented on the table when I was a child, it does not in the least surprise me that children should be put off, and Brussels are more often than not mishandled to this day. To keep their colour and flavour, all green brassicas should, in my experience, be boiled (not steamed) hard with the lid off the saucepan, for at least 10 minutes and served immediately. If not, they lose their colour and develop an objectionable tired flavour. Last-minute cooking can be a bore, I know, but in their case it really is important. If you are growing good vegetables, you might as well not spoil them when they reach the kitchen.

That is why I always prefer to leave carrots in the ground through the winter, lifting them only when required. Their flavour, compared with what you can buy or store, is unrecognisably tasty. We are fencing them in (not covering them) with fleece these days, as it really does deter the carrot fly, which is not a high-flier and never reaches them. But we have to keep the carrots in a cage, away from badgers, which are lethal.

fields.headline: Catalogue of cruelty
fields.trailText: 1984 Jasmine Beckford is battered to death. The four-year-old had been slowly starved and beaten by her stepfather Maurice Beckford while her mother looked on.
fields.body:
1984 Jasmine Beckford is battered to death. The four-year-old had been slowly starved and beaten by her stepfather Maurice Beckford while her mother looked on.

1984 Tyra Henry dies in local authority care. A report found that central to the case was the families being black and the social workers white. This encouraged social workers to be too trusting towards the parents.

1984 Heidi Koseda dies of starvation in Hayes, west London. Her stepfather Nicholas Price was jailed for life while her mother Rosemary Koseda was sent to a psychiatric hospital.

1986 Kimberley Carlile, four, is killed by her stepfather, Nigel Hall, who frustrated attempts by social workers and health visitors to investigate.

1987 Doreen Mason, 16 months, dies of neglect. She slept on the floor where her parents puts crisps, chips and hamburgers for her to eat. She had been tortured.

1992 Leanne White, three, is beaten to death by her stepfather who made her sleep on floorboards. Doctors found 107 marks on her body.

1993 Rikki Neave, six, is throttled with his coat zipper. A report three years later concluded that social workers failed to protect him and were "scared" of his drug-addict mother Ruth.

1994 Paul, 15 months, dies of neglect in a pool of urine. His grandmother had alerted social services, but no one acted. Paul's father, never named for legal reasons, was jailed for manslaughter.

webTitle: Inquiries, suspensions and disciplinary action as authorities pick up the pieces

fields.headline: Inquiries, suspensions and disciplinary action as authorities pick up the pieces
fields.trailText: Anna Climbié was failed at every turn by authorities who could have taken simple measures to prevent her murder. Now, detailed investigations are to look at what went wrong in the slow, tormented months that led to the child's death in February 1999.
fields.body:
Anna Climbié was failed at every turn by authorities who could have taken simple measures to prevent her murder. Now, detailed investigations are to look at what went wrong in the slow, tormented months that led to the child's death in February 1999.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, said yesterday that a statutory inquiry would look at every aspect of the case, including health, housing, social services, local authority and police involvement across four London boroughs.

In the meantime, a social worker has been suspended and four other social workers and eight police officers have been served with disciplinary papers. All are being investigated over their involvement in the case. Their failings were underlined at the Old Bailey by Nigel Rumfitt, the defence QC. "Those people exhibited a blinding degree of incompetence. If you came across a child in need, you would do more good calling the RAC than those people," he said.

Yesterday, the trial judge, Richard Hawkins, said that "lessons must be learned about failures of social services and the police inquiry following Anna's release from the North Middlesex hospital". He added: "I would like to be kept informed of the result of any inquiry."

Mr Milburn has asked for an early report "to determine what action should be taken to enhance the protection of vulnerable children". All agencies will be required to cooperate and the report will be published in full. The inquiry will be by Lord Laming, a former chief inspector of social services who had been due to chair a private inquiry into Harold Shipman, the killer GP, before relatives of the victims forced a public inquiry.

Anna's death was an appalling tragedy, Mr Milburn said. "She was murdered by her 'carers', but was undoubtedly failed repeatedly by the child protection system. We will take all necessary steps to ensure wherever possible such failures cannothappen again."

The government placed the Haringey social services department, the main child protection agency in the case, under special measures requiring close supervision by the inspectorate.

A review undertaken when a child has died and abuse is suspected was suspended pending the trial. However, it had already concluded that "a catalogue of errors and poor judgment led to the failure to protect this girl. Anna came to the agencies... on three separate occasions with signs and symptoms of abuse. Intervention on any one of these could have saved her life."

It recommended a thorough review of the way police and social services work together, and clear and comprehensive child protection guidelines in every local authority.

Apart from the government inquiry, the agencies that failed Anna have all launched internal investigations. Two other councils - Brent and Ealing - whose social services departments had had concerns about Anna lodged with them, will cooperate with the government inquiry.

Yesterday, the Metropolitan police's child protection team admitted that its procedures were "inadequate". Its child protection teams have been restructured and eight officers are being investigated by the police complaints authority.

Commander Carole Howlett, who has special responsibility for the teams, said she would ensure "as far as possible that such an appalling tragedy cannot happen again".

Haringey's director of housing and social services, Anne Bristow, admitted that the council should have prevented the tragedy. She said officers should have checked on the fact that Anna had never been to school in this country.

"Clearly visits should have been made and action taken when the allegations were made," she said. "The system failed Anna - and we are part of the system."

She said Lisa Arthurworrey, the social worker who refused to visit Manning's flat in Tottenham for fear of catching scabies, had been suspended pending the inquiry outcome.

John Riordan, medical director for the North-West London hospital NHS trust, responsible for North Middlesex hospital from where Anna was discharged back to Kouao, said they would not be carrying out disciplinary procedures against their staff, but would help with Mr Milburn's inquiry as much as possible.

Moira Gibb, president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, said it was premature to call for a fundamental overhaul of a child protection service that was "probably the most sophisticated in Europe, and which many professionals from other countries envy and admire".

She acknowledged "serious, inexcusable professional failures in this case", but said they did not seem to stem from a lack of collaboration between agencies. "The system we have is pretty good, but it obviously depends on the individuals working in it," she said.

The association said the inquiry should look particularly hard at protection arrangements for vulnerable children coming from abroad.

Missed chances

July 15 Anna is returned from Central Middlesex hospital to Kouao because the consultant paediatrician is persuaded that her injuries - cuts, bruises and red eyes - were self-inflicted as a result of scratching because of itchiness from scabies.

August 6 After two weeks in North Middlesex hospital having allegedly poured boiling water over her head Anna is returned again. She had told social worker Lisa Arthurworrey and PC Karen Jones that she caused her own injuries.

November 1 Anna makes an unfounded sexual allegation against Manning, withdrawn the next day. Arthurworrey believes Kouao put the child up to it in order to get housing. The social worker's police partner on the child protection team is assigned to find out why the false allegation was made. Her letter to Kouao is ignored. No further action is taken.

webTitle: NSPCC calls for complete overhaul of child protection procedures

fields.headline: NSPCC calls for complete overhaul of child protection procedures
fields.trailText: The NSPCC said the inquiry into Anna Climbié's murder should lead to a complete overhaul of child protection procedures.
fields.body:
The NSPCC said the inquiry into Anna Climbié's murder should lead to a complete overhaul of child protection procedures.

Mary Marsh, the society's director, said the rate of child murders in England and Wales had not dropped in the past 25 years. "In each generation of children more than 1,000 will be killed before reaching adulthood. Most will die at the hands of violent or neglectful parents and carers.

"This country has made great strides in reducing the number of children who die from accidents or illness. Child protection agencies protect tens of thousands of children from harm every year, often under extremely difficult circumstances. Yet nationally we have failed to cut the overall number of children who die from abuse or neglect."

She said a new national strategy should include child wellbeing indicators, to monitor cases of maltreatment, and national targets to reduce deaths from child abuse and neglect. Child death review teams should look at the circumstances of all unexpected or suspicious deaths.

Alison Murphy, director of children's services at the charity Childline, said lessons should be learned from the case.

"Child death inquiries point to a number of factors in protecting children, including the importance of communication. Child protection is everyone's responsibility and we must all look for early warning signs and listen carefully to children. Childline receives many calls from children who are suffering in dangerous situations and feel they have nowhere else to turn. It is important that children can access help when they are in trouble or danger."

David Lammy, Labour MP for Tottenham where Anna endured the torture, said: "One cannot account for the wickedness of individuals. However, it is our collective responsibility to intervene in such wickedness and ensure that no harm comes to innocent people, particularly our children. There were distinct opportunities for intervention that were missed. Anna had been in the country for two years, yet she wasn't registered with a GP or a school.

"People in deprived communities deserve and require the best from public services. Too often they receive the worst."

Taki Suleiman, lead member for housing and social security at Haringey council, said the authority accepted full responsibility for the part it played as the leading child protection agency in the case.

fields.headline: They all failed Anna
fields.standfirst: She had 128 injuries. She was eight
fields.trailText: No system is stronger than its weakest link. In the wake of earlier child abuse tragedies stretching back three decades, enormous investment has been made in our child protection system. The emphasis has been on earlier intervention, better agency coordination and much faster response to signs of abuse. As even the NSPCC conceded yesterday, real progress has been made in reducing abuse and the numbers of children who die. Even so, another sad name was added yesterday to the grim list of child victims who have been tortured and murdered by their carers. In the words of John Hutton, the health minister who announced a statutory inquiry into Anna Climbié's murder: "On three separate occasions she knocked on the door, but the door was slammed in her face."

No system is stronger than its weakest link. In the wake of earlier child abuse tragedies stretching back three decades, enormous investment has been made in our child protection system. The emphasis has been on earlier intervention, better agency coordination and much faster response to signs of abuse. As even the NSPCC conceded yesterday, real progress has been made in reducing abuse and the numbers of children who die. Even so, another sad name was added yesterday to the grim list of child victims who have been tortured and murdered by their carers. In the words of John Hutton, the health minister who announced a statutory inquiry into Anna Climbié's murder: "On three separate occasions she knocked on the door, but the door was slammed in her face."

The injuries which eight year old Anna suffered were described by a home office pathologist as the worst he had seen. There were 128 separate injuries to her body, including cigarette burns, weals from being beaten with bicycle chains, belt and buckle and coathangers, and hammer blows to the toes. As on earlier occasions when the system has failed, the mistakes were multiple and spread among several agencies: a consultant paediatrician who misdiagnosed cigarette burns as scabies; social services ignoring separate warnings by a relative and a childminder about serious signs of abuse; and an almost unbelievable decision by a police officer and social worker to return Anna from a hospital where doctors had identified abuse to her carer. It is not just individual mistakes but the lack of effective supervision that must be rigorously examined.

Lord Laming, former chief social service inspector, who will head the inquiry has a daunting task. He will need to review the record of nine public agencies and that of the evangelical churches to which the murderers took the child seeking an exorcism. There is an even more delicate racial dimension. The key social worker and police officer were female and black. The highly disciplined relationship between child and carer that worried hospital staff was described by the social worker as "normal within the context of their Afro-Caribbean background". We need to know why both female officers backed off. Was it fear of assault that delayed them from visiting the home? The danger faced by female officers, in many other contexts beside this one, has not been been fully addressed.

fields.headline: Senior nurses defend HIV trainees
fields.trailText: The Royal College of Nursing has criticised the government for planning to revise admission procedures for foreign trainee nurses after a health authority said some African trainees were HIV positive.
fields.body:
The Royal College of Nursing has criticised the government for planning to revise admission procedures for foreign trainee nurses after a health authority said some African trainees were HIV positive.

The Department of Health stressed there was no risk to the public from Wolverhampton's decision to employ five to 10 men and women nurses infected with HIV. But a spokesman suggested tests for HIV should come at the earliest possible stage of the admission process.

The Royal College of Nursing said the government was treading difficult ground as it was illegal in Britain to test for HIV unless an individual consented.

The trainees, from sub-Saharan Africa, including Zimbabwe, are working at the city's New Cross hospital or completing a three-year nursing course at Wolverhampton University. After training they will work in British hospitals and are not obliged to tell patients or colleagues they have the virus.

Jane Eminson, chief executive of Wolverhampton health authority, said the nurses conformed to NHS guidelines on the employment of HIV staff, and were part of a number of NHS staff with the virus across Britain. They did not take part in procedures where there was a risk of patient tissue being exposed to their blood.

Ms Eminson said Wolverhampton's intake of HIV positive nurses from Africa had increased in the past three months.

A Department of Health spokeswoman said: "We must be clear that this is not part of the NHS's international recruitment campaign. The NHS is not actively recruiting from developing countries such as Zimbabwe."

She added: "It is unusual to have such a group of HIV positive students from one country at one school of nursing, and the government will be reviewing the way in which nursing schools admit overseas student nurses."

The spokeswoman said trainee nurses from countries with a high prevalence of tuberculosis were screened for TB in a test which indicated whether they should also be screened for HIV. The department suggested HIV tests should come at the earliest stage.

A RCN spokeswoman said: "Foreign trainee nurses receive the same occupational health testing as UK trainees and we would like to see that continued. If admission procedures for foreign trainees are reviewed, we would want to know why one set of standards is being set for foreign trainees and another for British."

Derek Bodell, chief executive of the National Aids Trust, said: "Given everything we know about how difficult it is for HIV to be transmitted, the public does not have a right to know if someone is HIV positive except under the most unusual circumstances."

fields.headline: Alternative to MMR jab 'not safe'
fields.trailText: Separate doses of measles, mumps and rubella vaccines are not a safe alternative to the combined MMR jab, which some parents have shunned because of scares over alleged links to autism and bowel disease, government and independent scientists said yesterday.
fields.body:
Separate doses of measles, mumps and rubella vaccines are not a safe alternative to the combined MMR jab, which some parents have shunned because of scares over alleged links to autism and bowel disease, government and independent scientists said yesterday.

The heads of the independent Joint Committee on Immunisation and Vaccination (JCVI) and the Committee on the Safety of Medicines, as well as the government's head of immunisation, came together to warn that obtaining individual vaccinations for the three diseases involves delay, which exposes children to the real and increasing risk of infection. Last week the government said that low rates of immunisation could shortly lead to a fatal measles outbreak, as it did last year in Ireland, where there were two deaths, and the Netherlands, where there were three.

Michael Langman, head of the JCVI, said there were also worries about some of the individual vaccines available in other European countries. Some parents in Britain have gone abroad for supplies of separate vaccines because of the MMR scare.

"The mumps vaccine in France is the Urabe vaccine, which is one we have abandoned in the UK because of a distinct, though small, risk of meningitis," he said. He added that there were doubts about the efficacy of the measles vaccine used in Switzerland and that high potency measles vaccines used in the past had been withdrawn by the World Health Organisation. The main measles vaccine used in Europe is, however, the same one used in the MMR jab.

The government has banned individual vaccines from the NHS, but some private clinics have imported supplies.

The scientists cited Japan as proof that single vaccinations do not protect the population as well as the combined MMR. In Japan, which has single measles and rubella injections, there were 79 deaths from measles between 1992 and 1997. There have been no deaths in Britain since 1990.

The two committees had again reviewed the safety data for the MMR vaccination, the scientists said, and concluded that the combined jab was the safest way to protect children.

They cited a 14-year follow-up study of children immunised with MMR in Finland, released last month, which found only 173 potentially serious reactions in 1.8m children vaccinated. Nearly half those reactions were probably caused by other things. The most serious were cases of encephalitis, of which there were three.

The authors of the study say they found "no cases of inflammatory bowel disease or autism" linked to MMR.

"This finding is important because were there an association with MMR vaccination after such a short interval as suggested, this prospective study design would undoubtedly have disclosed at least some cases," they write in the Paediatric Infectious Diseases Journal.

The scientists were mounting a pre-emptive strike ahead of a further study to be published by Andrew Wakefield of the Royal Free hospital in London. Dr Wakefield first suggested a link between MMR, bowel disease and autism in a paper which caused uproar when it was published in the Lancet in February 1998.

Dr Wakefield's next paper is expected to question the clinical trials that were carried out to ensure the safety and efficacy of the combined MMR before it was licensed in 1972. He is expected to claim that the trials were inadequate, the follow-up data was collected over too short a period and that the vaccines can interact.

Alasdair Breckenridge, chairman of the Committee on the Safety of Medicines, insisted there was sufficient evidence of MMR's safety available in 1972, and that there was far more evidence now that more than 500m doses have been given to children worldwide.

David Salisbury, head of immunisation at the Department of Health, said officials were concerned about further scare stories. "This would be a really unfortunate time to have coverage go down when we really need to be working our hardest to get coverage up," he said.

webTitle: TV crew faces ejection from festival

fields.headline: TV crew faces ejection from festival
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: It could have been the lump of meat that did it. Or maybe it was the five-star tents, with their comfortable beds, hot water and ostentatious basins.
fields.body:
It could have been the lump of meat that did it. Or maybe it was the five-star tents, with their comfortable beds, hot water and ostentatious basins. Either way, the future of Channel 4's coverage of the Kumbh Mela, India's largest religious festival, was hanging by a thread last night after the luxury camp where the Channel 4 team is staying was served with an eviction notice.

The camp, run by the tour operator Cox and King's, attracted the wrath of the festival's sadhus (holy men), who accused the camp's organisers of allowing foreigners to consume meat and alcohol. They also objected to the camp's "five-star culture". The authorities in the north Indian town of Allahabad agreed and told Channel 4 to leave.

The 52-strong Channel 4 team, which is broadcasting 10-minute daily highlights from the festival, yesterday won a temporary reprieve when lawyers argued that the authorities' decision was unfair. Meanwhile, executives, from Channel 4 had been spotted lugging sacks of rice, ghee and fruit to the sadhus' camp as a peace offering.

Eyebrows were first raised when it emerged that Cox and King's was charging foreigners $481 (£320) a person for a two-night stay at the Kumbh Mela, held once every 12 years. The row snowballed when three foreigners were allegedly spotted tucking into a lump of meat in the camp's dining tent. Organisers deny the claim and say food served to the Channel 4 crew is strictly vegetarian.

Two days ago a group of sadhus protested outside the camp, which they said should be handed over to genuine Hindu pilgrims, 70m of whom are expected to bathe at the confluence of two holy rivers, the Ganges and the Yamuna, in Allahabad in the next month. A police investigator arrived yesterday to see whether the rules on vegetarianism had been broken.

Sources at Cox and King's last night said that the Indian foreign ministry had granted permission for the Channel 4 team to stay at the vast tented city erected for the festival on the banks of the Ganges. But he added: "If we have to close the camp they will have to pack up and go."

The Allahabad high court is expected to make a final ruling on Tuesday.

Closure would also deal a blow to several celebrities, including Goldie Hawn and Kurt Russell, who are due to stay at the camp. Paul McCartney has arrived in Delhi en route to the Kumbh Mela but is believed to be staying elsewhere.

fields.headline: Sixty seconds in: Sign language
fields.standfirst: Audrey Simmons, an interpreter with the Royal National Institute for the Deaf, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.trailText: Audrey Simmons, an interpreter with the Royal National Institute for the Deaf, talks to Miles Brignall.
fields.body:
I discovered sign language after being offered training by a former employer to learn a second language - I was awful at French at school and chose this because I thought it suited me better. But what many people don't realise is that signing is a completely different language to English with its own grammar, structure and syntax.

For example, to sign "I am going to meet you at the station", you have to turn the sentence around and start by establishing where it will happen, who the person is and, only then, what is going to occur. And while the arms and hands convey the words, the face conveys the tone. If you are trying to express anger or happiness, it's all done with the eyes and mouth.

I am what we call a community-based interpreter which involves interpreting for deaf people as they go about their ordinary lives. One morning this week I was interpreting for a computer programmer who was having a job interview. Other typical assignments include accompanying someone going to see their GP or attending a company meeting.

Before a session I try to read up on the subject we will be discussing or take a few minutes with the person to find out background to what I will be translating. Assuming I understand what's going on - some technical conversations can go over my head and meetings where lots of people talk at once can be difficult - the translation should be virtually simultaneous.

Keeping up with a lively conversation is physically demanding, so the longest session we do is around two hours. I'm always conscious of trying to remain completely impartial - our job is be a person's voice rather than to fight their battles for them.

That said, it's a job that, at times, requires great sensitivity. Much of the work is very personal and you can find yourself at a hospital explaining to a person that the doctors have found a lump or something similarly awful.

One of the exciting things is that the language is always changing. Overnight a word can become the in-word, particularly with kids, and a way of signing it soon appears. I work with a youth club where I learn all the latest phrases.

One downside is that people often have to wait ten days before one of us can accompany them. There is a shortage of fully trained interpreters - the training takes between five and seven years - which means many people are left waiting for what can be a vital service.

webTitle: Start with a blank canvas when sketching plans

fields.headline: Start with a blank canvas when sketching plans
fields.standfirst: Options that will add colour to your career
fields.trailText: Options that will add colour to your career.
fields.body:
Only a very few gifted or lucky artists are able to earn a living solely by the sale of their original work. But graduates of fine art who feel they are not cut out for the self-employed life should not despair. A fine art degree equips graduates for a wide range of art and art-related career options apart from the usual teaching and museums and gallery work.

Some fine art graduates go on to pursue postgraduate study and develop careers as artists or designers, while others take up the opportunity of entering a wide variety of related fields such as art therapy, conservation and restoration, or community support.

Take fine art conservation - the job of the conservator is to clean, repair and maintain works of art and objects of historic interest. An important part of the work involves spending time in museums, art galleries and, sometimes, private homes to survey collections and give advice on the correct conditions needed to keep art works in good order.

For more information about careers in this field, contact the Conservation Unit Museums and Galleries Commission, 16 Queen Anne's Gate, London SW1H 9AA (tel: 020 7233 4200) and the UK Institute for Conservation, 109 The Chandlery, 50 Westminster Bridge Road, London SE1 7QY (tel: 020 7721 8721).

Art therapy is used as treatment for psychological and emotional disorders - drawing, painting, modelling and sculpture are just some of the creative activities used. Most art therapists work in hospitals, though some ply their trade in specialist schools and child guidance clinics. Art therapists need to have an interest in teaching and an ability to apply art in a practical way. For details of courses and career opportunities contact The British Association of Art Therapists, Mary Ward House, 5 Tavistock Road, London, WC1H 9SN.

Community artists work with groups who are often disenfranchised in some way. An example of this might be working with people with disabilities to produce a work of art that reflects their concerns and opinions. The job requires good interpersonal skills, and an ability to work with often challenging clients.

This way of working is very different from pursuing your own artistic ideas, but it can enrich them.

Length of contracts can vary, depending on the amount of funding available, and community art does not offer steady employment. However, the advantages include an enriching experience, a lasting monument in some cases, and the publicity from project reports and media attention.

For more information contact the Royal Academy of Arts, Piccadilly, London W1V 0DS.

For details of courses and career opportunities contact The British Association of Art Therapists, Mary Ward House, 5 Tavistock Road, London, WC1H 9SN. Community artists work with groups who are often disenfranchised in some way. An example of this might be working with people with disabilities to produce a work of art that reflects their concerns and opinions. The job requires good interpersonal skills, and an ability to work with often challenging clients. This way of working is very different from pursuing your own artistic ideas, but it can enrich them. Length of contracts can vary, depending on the amount of funding available, and community art does not offer steady employment. However, the advantages include an enriching experience, a lasting monument in some cases, and the publicity from project reports and media attention. For more information contact the Royal Academy of Arts, Piccadilly, London W1V 0DS.

webTitle: Moving on up: An ABC guide to setting and keeping your focus

fields.headline: Moving on up: An ABC guide to setting and keeping your focus
fields.trailText:
A. Look here

Overwhelmed by all you still have left to do? One solution is to work at becoming more focused. This means having a clear vision, knowing exactly where you're going and the fastest way of getting there. If you can master the techniques for becoming streamlined and energy-efficient you'll also develop the strength to resist procrastination and distractions thus getting more done while working less hard. Daunting, isn't it? Like any image of perfection, it leaves you feeling inadequate rather than inspired.

A. Look here

This means having a clear vision, knowing exactly where you're going and the fastest way of getting there. If you can master the techniques for becoming streamlined and energy-efficient you'll also develop the strength to resist procrastination and distractions thus getting more done while working less hard. Daunting, isn't it? Like any image of perfection, it leaves you feeling inadequate rather than inspired.

B. Look there

The methods for achieving sharp focus always sound plausible in theory, but are usually disappointing once unwrapped and put into use. One significant problem is that the working world is neither static nor logical. Rules keep changing - concentrating on one point may cause you to overlook the sneaky manoeuvrings of goal post movers until it's too late. It's quite a blow when the reward for all your efforts is to be told you need to refocus.

C. Look out

The ability to compartmentalise, although an effective way to get some things done, can prevent you exploiting connections when taken to extremes. If you stop seeing things in a joined up way your world becomes one-dimensional and your approach blinkered. Don't allow the quest for efficiency to push you into obsessive behaviour and isolation. Be kind on yourself. A little blurring adds depth and interest.

fields.headline: How to do hypnotic presentations
fields.standfirst: Tap into the unconscious minds of your audience
fields.trailText: Tap into the unconscious minds of your audience.
fields.body:
Hypnotism has a terrible reputation. We think it's all about sinister men on stage making people hop like rabbits or do stripteases. But hypnotism has far wider and subtler applications, and you can even use it to improve your presentations at work.

"We teach people to communicate with their audience's unconscious minds," says David Shephard, chairman of The Performance Partnership, whose presenting course uses hypnotic techniques.

"We only use 5% of our brain power consciously, and the rest is unconscious. People respond, feel and make decisions with their unconscious mind, so any presentation will be much more effective if you communicate directly with that part of the brain," he explains.

Alex McKie, a presenter who is studying hypnotherapy, adds: "We get information at 2 million bits per second. The conscious mind can only remember about 32, whereas your unconscious takes in everything."

Interestingly, the first step is to hypnotise yourself. Anyone who has ever given a presentation will be familiar with the racing heart, dry mouth and squeaky voice that nerves provoke. By hypnotising yourself into a light state of trance, you can overcome both physical and mental distractions.

Practitioners insist self-hypnotism is perfectly safe and claim that many of us spend much of the time in a trance-like state anyway. As David Shephard says: "Watching TV is hypnotic, and so is driving a car."

The technique involves making yourself comfortable, slowing down your breathing, then staring at a spot on the wall, concentrating on feeling relaxed. Gradually, start noticing instead what is on the periphery of your vision. David Shephard explains: "When you focus on one thing, the nervous system has a stress response, whereas peripheral vision makes you feel more relaxed."

The technique has another benefit, too. If you use peripheral vision, you won't be distracted by the one person who is bored. Instead, you'll give attention to the whole audience and will be able to observe the overall response.

In the presentation itself, the principal hypnotic techniques involve your tone of voice, appealing to people's unconscious questions and preferences, and using stories and anecdotes.

"About 38% of your communication comes from the pitch, pace and tone of your voice," says Alex McKie. "So if you want to relax people, you drop your voice, talk much more slowly and leave lots of spaces."

The next point is appealing to people's unconscious questions and preferences. "People prefer to take in information in different ways," says David Shephard. "Some like to have information visually, some prefer to hear it, some want to experience it kinesthetically through touch, and others want logic. In any audience, people will have a preference for one of those four types of information."

The trick is to use all four channels. So as well as talking, show slides or pictures, have questions or voting for the hands-on approach, and use a logical flow of information.

Unconsciously, different people in your audience will also be looking for answers to different questions. They are:

Why is this information important?

What are the facts?

How does it work?

What are the consequences?

According to David Shephard, by answering people's instinctive questions, "your presentation will always be perfectly structured".

Another powerful hypnotic technique is using stories and anecdotes. "Storytelling is a fundamental way that we communicate," says Alex McKie.

David Shephard adds: "Metaphors, stories and anecdotes appeal to the unconscious mind and enable you to communicate a far deeper message. They make your presentation memorable and can have a huge impact on your audience.

"There's also the idea of 'nesting' stories, where you start a number of stories but don't finish them. This keeps the audience's attention because at an unconscious level they're waiting for the end of the stories. So you have their full attention and they're captivated."

The usual approach is to 'nest' stories at the start of your presentation, giving the main content, then finishing the stories to signal you're coming to a close.

Finally, you'll be reassured to know you can't get somebody to do something against their will using hypnosis.

"CIA research shows that hypnosis alone isn't enough to get people to do things against their wishes. It found it also required the use of psychoactive drugs, sleep deprivation or electric shock treatment," says David Shephard, "none of which is provided in our training."

If you don't remember anything else...

Remember that the audience wants you to do well. Hypnotic techniques help you and the audience relax so you can communicate your message more effectively.

webTitle: Help: I'm at a loose and lonely end!

fields.headline: Help: I'm at a loose and lonely end!
fields.trailText: Irene Krechowiecka offers her advice.
fields.body:
I've been in my new job for a week and no one has told me what I should be doing. I feel like a spare part.
KH, business development manager, Leeds

Perhaps they're waiting for you to take the initiative, but it is reasonable to expect guidance on the type of initiatives that would be welcome. Make a list of everything you need to know, then start asking questions. You must have some idea of what you were taken on for; if the reality is nothing like you were led to believe, don't allow things to drift. Use your job description as a starting point. If you don't have one, make getting something in writing about your responsibilities a priority.

Lack of clear communication is the greatest cause of misunderstanding and unhappiness at work. During the early days of a new job it's essential to explore and use all the channels that exist for getting answers. It's not always easy to do this on your own. Finding a mentor can provide an excellent short cut to becoming confident and effective quickly. Admitting to what you don't know is safer than trying to cover it up. Don't worry about showing lack of knowledge or experience.

Being new gives you the licence to ask questions and seek help, so use it. You could then make a significant contribution by offering to devise an induction programme for new starts while you still remember how being new and lost feels. Take care, however, to appear constructive rather than critical - approach the subject with a sense of humour rather than the air of being wronged.

 Contact Irene Krechowiecka at ijk@excite.com
