fields.headline: Ready for community service?
fields.standfirst: Choosing a cuddly company
fields.trailText: Choosing a cuddly company.
fields.body:
If you have strong ethics and an acute conscience the chances are that one of the things you will look for in your employer is a corporate version of yourself - you will want to work for a company that cares.

And, today, it's increasingly likely that as you hunt down your dream job you will find that there are more and more cuddly companies around to choose from.

Companies have to be aware of the triple bottom line - profit, society and the environment, says Warwick University's Professor Malcolm McIntosh. His business school has a Corporate Citizenship Unit which was set up in response to young managers' demands for social accountability to be included in MBA courses.

"Business does not operate in a vacuum," says Professor McIntosh. "The rules of the game are such now that we have to be aware of all stakeholders, customers, staff and the communities in which companies operate."

And the message seems to be getting through to companies: people want to work for organisations they can be proud of and relate to.

Take the CIS, which has a reputation for ethical investment and which recently started to invest time, money and people in a Manchester-wide community scheme called Greater Manchester Cares. The initiative was set up with the Business in the Community organisation and is based on a similar scheme in the US.

Graduates on the CIS training scheme took part in the first Greater Manchester Cares volunteer action days. Six trainee statisticians and actuaries took time off from crunching numbers to put their backs into a Ground Force-style action day at St Marks United Reformed Church in Wythenshawe. They built fences and did gardening which benefited the church but also helped them with team building, communication, delegation and motivation. A second group of 10 trainees (see case study) did work at the Sale Road Children's Centre.

These schemes are part of the CIS's wider Social Accountability Programme and won praise from social accountability minister Kim Howells during a recent visit.

Supermarket giant Asda is also very active in its local communities and individual stores can achieve "store of the community" status. Work is funded by the Asda Foundation charity and focuses on children and education, women's health, people with disabilities and victims of crime.

Nationally the stores have a series of charitable schemes such as The Big Read, to back the National Year of Literacy, The Big Sum, to bring maths to life for schoolchildren, and Asda Local Heroes.

Individual stores can set up their own initiatives in response to local need. "Asda believes in putting something back into the communities where our colleagues live and work," says company spokeswoman Zaria Pinchbeck. "We estimate that our community involvement programme for 2000 represented an investment in terms of money, time and gifts in kind of approximately £4m."

It isn't just the big companies that have become aware of the world outside the corporate walls. Oxford based occupational psychologist Pearn Kandola has recently introduced the idea of Enrichment Days and Community Days for its members of staff.

"We wanted to find a way of making the experience of coming to work more interesting," explains partner Binna Kandola. "So, we created legitimate time for people to do something different."

One psychologist took an Enrichment Day's leave from the Oxford office to visit museums in London. Binna Kandola himself aims to spend a day at a multiplex cinema in Birmingham - an idea he got from a Guardian feature. Staff then present a report on their Enrichment Day afterwards.

Community Days give staff a chance to do something locally. One member of staff who is a Tai Chi instructor taught people at a retirement home for half a day and has been invited back.

Pearn Kandola's Oxford office has established a link with a local school working for charities and Binna Kandola says staff response has been tremendous.

"They like to be part of a business that allows them to get involved in other things. It helps the employer too. People bring something back into work and this can spark some ideas. And we want our staff to feel they are working for a progressive organisation," he explains.

Because ethics and sustainability have crept much higher up the business agenda companies now seek assistance in developing programmes and the benefits can be spelled out to them in hard facts.

Jane Fiona Cummings, of Article 13, a company which advises other organisations on these issues, explains companies also benefit financially from socially and environmentally-friendly practices.

And feedback from research is very big in terms of staff motivation, she says. People and companies want to know how they can make a difference in the world.

"Research has shown that it is absolutely crucial to get staff involved in the planning process of any programme. This leads to a more innovative culture in a company," she explains.

"Employees want to be able to say what their company stands for. We work to enable them to become advocates for their companies so they can say 'I work for so and so and this is what they do, and this is what I do for them'.

"It has a business benefit and for the individual employee it also adds another career-enhanching element to their CV."

First-hand view

"We're not here just to sell"
Asda's Andrea Gill

Andrea Gill's job is to oversee local and national volunteer programmes for 40 Asda stores across the Midlands and North Wales. She joined the company on graduation from Nottingham and at 25 is a regional marketing support manager.

"We have listening groups with customers for them to air community problems. There are specific issues which are identified by individual stores."

Asda staff do volunteer work in response to local needs - painting a school playground, refurbishing sheltered housing. Or, it might be providing a minibus for special needs, or just providing drivers. "It is not always money," says Andrea. "It can be time and people."

Stores will also liaise with the local police force and run Bobby Lobbies in-store to give customers aid and advice. "We have very positive feedback. Customers come in with their requests," says Andrea.

And the benefit for her? "It's having respect for the company which has the same values as I do. We are not here just to sell, we have a human face as well."

"It's a challenge"
CIS's Katy Redmond

Katy Redmond, a 22-year-old natural sciences graduate from Cambridge, works as a research analyst for the Responsible Shareholding Unit and Ethical Investment Fund for the CIS.

On her graduate training programme with the CIS she worked as a volunteer at the Sale Road Children's Centre in a team of 10.

"We had to do over the garden, clean it up and lay a nature trail. We were given a list of the materials and told what needed to be done. We were left to organise ourselves. The project had to be completed in two days, and it was treated as a challenge," she says.

"It was really good working in a team and getting to know other people and be outside the work atmosphere. I learned how communication worked in a more practical context. It was a bit hectic towards the end, but it was brilliant.

We were very pleased with the result and felt we had achieved something.

"The community also gets something from us and it seems such a sensible thing to do."

fields.headline: News
fields.trailText: Top(less) idea | Book of the week | On the up.
fields.body:
Top(less) idea: How far would you go to get a job? North-east advertising agency AD78 has invited graduates to send in topless photos of themselves to see how far they would go to get a job as an account handler. The idea hasn't gone down well with the TUC, where a spokesman says: "It isn't funny - and it is a potential breach of sexual discrimination law."

Book of the week: Having sat on both sides of the interview table, outplacement specialist Alan Jones is well placed to bring us Winning at Interview , a guide to answering the toughest questions and landing the jobs you want. Published by Random House, the book can be ordered at the special price of £4.99 plus p&p from our Cultureshop on 0800 316 6102.

On the up: The number of first degree graduates increased by 1%last year to 265,300, according to figures from the Higher Education Statistics Agency. The numbers achieving a first remained steady, but the number gaining a 2.1 increased by 1% too.

Opportunity knocked: Women are being denied access to bonuses and performance-related claims research for the Equal Opportunities Commission which says the near 20% gap between the earnings of men and women remains so high because employers are "shockingly complacent" about dealing with the issue of equal pay.

Spell checker: Did you get stars for spelling at school? Sloppy spelling errors and commas in the wrong place can bring your climb up the career ladder to a full stop, warns a survey from temp agency Office Angels which claims one in three managers don't bother to read any further once they have spotted a couple of literacy errors in CVs, letter or reports.

Job-hunter of the week: Don't give up hope, says Kevin Denton who has just found work after 17 years of searching. After five weeks of working in his new job as a clerk for an accounting firm in Bideford in Devon, Kevon says he has finally regained the confidence so badly dented by literally hundreds of rejection letters.

Clock on: Are you envious of high-achievers at work? Do you wonder how they manage to coolly juggle so many balls? They have the same number of hours in their day - but something is different. They synchronise their work to their body clock, says career columnist Kathy Simmons: "If you are mentally sharper in the early morning hours, don't do your filing and routine follow-up calls at this time. Use times of highest brain-power and energy level for demanding tasks. Reserve less challenging activities for afternoons. Schedule your work to match your natural body clock."

Job-hunter of the week: Don't give up hope, says Kevin Denton who has just found work after 17 years of searching. After five weeks of working in his new job as a clerk for an accounting firm in Bideford in Devon, Kevon says he has finally regained the confidence so badly dented by literally hundreds of rejection letters. Clock on: Are you envious of high-achievers at work? Do you wonder how they manage to coolly juggle so many balls? They have the same number of hours in their day - but something is different. They synchronise their work to their body clock, says career columnist Kathy Simmons: "If you are mentally sharper in the early morning hours, don't do your filing and routine follow-up calls at this time. Use times of highest brain-power and energy level for demanding tasks. Reserve less challenging activities for afternoons. Schedule your work to match your natural body clock."

fields.headline: Top rung/Bottom rung
fields.trailText: Two employees of Tate Appointments share their experiences from either end of the career ladder.
fields.body:
Top rung

Gill Stewart
Aged 35
Managing director
Tate Appointments

Winner of the Recruitment and Employment Confederation's Business Manager of the Year Award 2000, Gill Stewart says her original career plan was to be a teacher.

Graduation in business studies with French and Italian in 1992 was followed by a spell abroad as an overseas rep with a holiday company. On her return she joined a small recruitment company in the Thames Valley area before moving on to Tate.

Gill was made a director in 1998 and became managing director last December.

The buzz? "I never know what the day is going to bring. We have a team of committed individuals and I get a buzz from working with them. One of our values is continuous improvement and I love thinking about what we can do better."

Must-have qualities: Gill looks for people with mental agility. "The ability to multi-task, be goal-orientated, have a competitive spirit and a true customer focus."

Recruits can join as administrators and become assistant consultants or recruitment officers. During this time they are sponsored to sit professional exams. They can progress into the role of consultant with a view to becoming a business manager.

Bottom rung

Sanne Nielsen

Aged 25

Receptionist

Tate Appointments

Like so many graduates, Sanne Nielsen started her career as a temp with the company she has now joined. During her studies for a degree in communication and cultural studies at the University of North London, she worked for Tate and continued temping with them after graduation last summer. "A career in recruitment was what I wanted, so I took it," she explains.

With no previous recruitment experience, she started by working in reception. "This provides me with invaluable customer service skills and allows me to learn at grass roots, how the recruitment process works."

Career approach: Tate believes in growing talent from within. "There is a great structure in place to ensure talented individuals get every opportunity to further their careers."

Sanne is already involved with business planning for next year. "It is fantastic from my position to be able to play a part in the way the organisation shapes itself."

Next move: Her ambition is to move into an assistant consultant's role and then onto the management team.

Tips for others? "Allow time to figure out your career path - even if it means spending time initially in a different job from the one you had imagined."

fields.headline: People person
fields.trailText: Toni Castle, HR director at international PR firm Lewis.
fields.body:
Name: Toni Castle

Status: HR director at international PR firm Lewis.

Past: Studied international business and German at Aston University. Joined Lewis as trainee PR consultant. Promoted to account manager and after a year transferred to Boston to work as account manager for a US client. On her return to London a year later, promoted to account director with responsibility for training and recruitment. Appointed HR director last year.

Present: "With help from two colleagues I handle the recruitment needs of our offices in London, Germany, France, the Netherlands, US and Scandinavia. We're always looking for trainee consultants, especially with language skills."

Future: "My goal is to build the international offices and make sure they get as much training support as the UK."

Strengths: "I'm flexible and a team player with a sense of humour."

Weaknesses: "I'm a bit of a worrier and prone to be too critical of myself."

Wisdom: "Look for the type of company that suits you. Do you want a company that invests in you? Then go for it."

References: www.lewispr.com

fields.headline: Over-protected
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: The problems began when she requested that, for safety's sake, I wear two condoms, one on top of the other
fields.body:
Monday, January 8, 2001, Ashby de la Zouch

I woke at 7.32am with a headache. Thankfully, the boys were still asleep, so I was able to dress and attend to my toilette in peace for once. I did not wash my hair in the shower. The friction caused by the massaging of the shampoo into the scalp is putting a strain on my follicles and causing hair loss. I was pleased to use one of those shower caps, which I have collected from hotel bathrooms over the years.

The reason for my tension headache must be linked to the fact that Pamela Pigg stayed last night. Or, at least, most of the night - she left my bed at 4.30 after sobbing for an hour and a half, incidentally smearing one of my finest pillow slips in blue eye-shadow.

Our date went well considering that Pamela had a heavy cold and kept asking the waiter for more paper serviettes in which to blow her nose. We talked about our on/off relationship, and Pamela blamed our sexual incompatibility for the fact that it was mostly off. She said she was willing to try again, and told me she had forced herself to read The Joy Of Sex, and then been astonished at the range of things on offer. She made it sound like the Argos catalogue.

After a protracted argument with the waiter about the bill (I refused to pay £3.50 for the extra services), we left the restaurant arm in arm. In the car on the way home, she placed her right hand over my left. It was difficult changing gear, but I didn't complain.

When we got home, Glenn was still up, doing his humanities homework. He was stuck on one question: "Name three members of the shadow cabinet, apart from William Hague."

Unfortunately, neither me nor Pamela could help him out. When Pamela went to the lavatory, Glenn glanced at her and whispered, "You must be desperate, Dad." In the lull before Pamela's return, I remembered Ann Widdecombe. When Pamela returned, smelling of Poison, and with newly applied pink lipstick, Glenn tactfully withdrew and went to bed.

I put on a Beethoven CD, the 1812, and tried to dim the lights, but the dimmer switch refused to work, so we sat under the glare of 500-watt spotlights. After a little conversation about my mother in prison, we went upstairs. Pamela apologised for her sports bra and utility-type knickers, saying that her best underwear was in the wash. I said it didn't matter, but, in truth, I was very hurt. She had known about our date for over a week. Surely that was enough time in which to hand-wash a few delicate scraps of lace and satin, and dry them on the radiator?

She commented on the fact that the spots on my back had almost cleared up, then turned the bedside light out and lovemaking commenced. The problems began when she requested that, for safety's sake, I wear two condoms, one on top of the other. God knows, I tried, Diary, but by the time I'd got the first fitted, the second had got lost in the bed.

The second problem was that Glenn shouted through the party wall, "For God's sake Dad, 'urry up an' get it over wiv." Which made Pamela roll over to her side of the bed, where she lay with rigid limbs and a set jaw. I tried to relax her by talking about my father's treatment for his hospital-borne infection, but she started to cry. And nothing I said would stop her.

An hour later

Glenn has just come into the kitchen angrily flourishing the used shower cap and shouting, "Tell that Pamela Pigg, to take 'er female condom 'ome wiv 'er in future." The lad obviously knows nothing about the female anatomy.

fields.headline: Perverting De Sade
fields.standfirst: The infamous Marquis comes to the screen next Friday in Quills. But, explains  Neil Schaeffer, his biographer, he was much more complex than the film shows, intent on testing the limits of his time
fields.trailText: The infamous Marquis comes to the screen next Friday in Quills. But, explains Neil Schaeffer, his biographer, he was much more complex than the film shows, intent on testing the limits of his time
fields.body:
The Marquis de Sade spent almost 30 years of his life in various prisons, and what got him there had almost nothing to do with his writing. His mother-in-law, Mme de Montreuil, having offered up her wealthy daughter to obtain De Sade's noble name, became outraged by his sexual scandals with prostitutes and with her other and most favoured daughter. Finally, Mme de Montreuil, "the Hyena", as De Sade called her, cut her losses and had him imprisoned under a lettre de cachet. - by which a prisoner's family paid his "rent" to keep him in prison.

De Sade's vows of vengeance were stoked up during all those years locked up in Vincennes and the Bastille and when he was freed after the revolution, becoming an official of the radical Section des Picques in Paris, he had the opportunity to wreak that vengeance. The Montreuils fell under suspicion but this is how he described what he did: "I caused the Montreuils to be moved on to a list of exculpated persons. If I had said a word, they would have been roughly handled. I held my tongue; there, you see how I avenge myself!"

De Sade is much more of a protean, amphibian creature, morphing from noble to revolutionary, and there is a great deal more to him, much of it decidedly more complex, interesting, and baffling, than the point that Quills, the film of his life, tirelessly belabours: that he is a martyr to the oppression and censorship of church and state.

The movie opens with De Sade at an upper window watching the guillotine at work during the French revolution's bloodletting terror of September 1793-July 1794. Much later, we are told that this kind of activity explains the sanguinary streak in his writing. In fact, his bloodiest and best work, 120 Days of Sodom, was written in the Bastille - obviously before the revolution. This is an important book, and to suggest that it was written late in De Sade's life in the asylum at Charenton, where he spent the last 11 years of his life until his death in 1814, does the book and the viewer a disservice.

De Sade was not at the height of his literary career nor of his literary powers at Charenton. Nor was he the imposing physical specimen implied by the tall, trim figure of the Australian actor Geoffrey Rush, who plays him in the film. At most, De Sade was of middling height. More to the point, his suffering and unhappiness had taken their toll. He had eaten himself into a considerable, even a grotesque, obesity. He was fortunate at Charenton to have come under the protection of the asylum's progressive and gentle director, the Abbé de Coulmier, who encouraged De Sade to direct the other inmates and some professional actors in plays that soon attracted substantial and even fashionable audiences. This new therapy certainly had a beneficial effect on De Sade's spirit and energy. But the plays he put on were conventional warhorses of the Paris stage. There was no violent and sexual orgy scene as the movie depicts.

Just as Rush in no way resembles De Sade, the handsome Joaquin Phoenix could never be mistaken for Coulmier, who, in fact, stood only four feet tall and was severely misshapen. This odd couple came to have a very good effect on each other. Coulmier was perhaps the first true male friend Sade made in his life, and this may indicate that some improvement had taken place in his mental health.

The movie sacrifices the truth of this relationship and of Coulmier's own fate to a surreal and didactic conclusion that has no connection with the truth, and is probably overwrought even as a twist of a fictional plot. Indeed, De Sade's hideous death in the movie is nothing like the truth, for he died in his sleep, in his 74th year, as peacefully as any good Christian. The villain of the piece is made out to be Dr Royer-Collard. True, there was such a person, and he did disapprove of Coulmier's drama therapy as well as De Sade's presence in a hospital environment when he should have been in a prison. But De Sade had never been convicted of anything, including publishing pornography. When Royer-Collard was finally able to install his protégé as Coulmier's replacement, the drama therapy had long ago been suspended, and while De Sade did lose some of his privileges, he was already in the last year of his life.

Of all the characters in the movie, Royer-Collard, played by Michael Caine, is the one that is the most inflated for melodramatic and didactic effect: he is given an underage orphan bride straight out of a nunnery; he is made into a sadistic husband and a fiendish tyrant in the asylum; and he is provided with the most implausible, seemingly ironic twist of fate to perform at the end.

The single didactic message of the movie is that the seemingly good people are all bad underneath, are all hypocrites, while the seemingly bad person, De Sade, probably has some redeeming qualities: he tells it like it is, and apparently did not take sexual advantage of the young chambermaid (Madeleine LeClerc, played by Kate Winslet) with whom he was so friendly. However, De Sade's last journal makes it clear that he had been having a regular sexual liaison with the 18-year-old chambermaid from her early teens until the week before he died.

In the film, the chambermaid /laundress smuggles De Sade's manuscripts out to his Paris publisher. In reality, this task was performed, quite unmelodramatically, by De Sade's companion of many years, Mme Quesnet, who was permitted to have a room at Charenton so she could be with him.

The movie totally ignores this stable relationship and instead intrudes impossible and misleading scenes with De Sade's wife, who had formally separated from him after the revolution.

Moreover the manuscripts Mme Quesnet smuggled out were not the dangerous novel Justine (whose much earlier publication had made his embarrassed family seek to hide him away in Charenton), but primarily a number of fairly conventional novels, as well as some stage plays he had written in his youth and which he hoped to have performed by the Comédie Française. He kept revising them in vain hopes of their acceptance.

In the last year of his life, he received yet another publisher's rejection letter. This time, he could not misinterpret its brutal clarity: "truly reprehensible... such a capital fault in a subject like this... inventions impossible not to find unfortunate... sheer 'melodrama'... written in verse that almost never rises to the level of good prose".

What is the harm in misrepresenting the true nature of De Sade's life and career? After all, some of the events in the movie did really happen to him at some time or other. Of course, playwrights and movie-makers are not under oath when they show us their work. And without condensation, there can be no art. The artist must make choices to put some things in and leave others out, a rule that applies to biographers as well. But if a biographer makes a mish-mash of his subject, there is hell to pay. If a movie does the same, there could be talk of Academy awards for all concerned, as there has been in this case.

The viewer of Quills should be aware that what he is seeing is not De Sade. To see if Quills is valid in its own terms, let the viewer imagine it is about someone else, let us say the Marquis de Newcastle, and that the scene is Bedlam and then see if the movie makes any sense.

The movie-makers and reviewers alike seem to think that the main point of De Sade's life and writing is to oppose censorship. In fact, his main obsession was to push the limits - sexual, spiritual, and political - as a means of feeling out the limits of his times and of his own mind. If there were no limits, there would be no meaning. When De Sade performed a sexual act with a prostitute and a communion wafer, he cried, "If you are God, avenge yourself!" The perversions were rhetorical acts at least as much as sexual ones. They were a way of opening a dialogue with the powers that be and with nature itself.

In the same way, censorship was important to De Sade's way of thinking; he felt compelled to chal lenge it. Quills simplifies De Sade into a modern "victim" and over-emphasises his potential as a focus for liberal-political meanings when, in fact, his life and perhaps his literary intentions - if you think of him as a satirist - can be seen as an object lesson, warning against the excesses of cultural relativism and nihilism; a very modern lesson, it would seem.

De Sade was an extremist on both sides. He plunged as deeply into the psyche as anyone had done before or since, yet he also sought some meaning, even if it were only punishment from above. "If you are God, avenge yourself!" God did not have to. The pity is that Quills did.

 Neil Schaeffer's life of the Marquis de Sade will be published in paperback by Picador in March (£8.99).

webTitle: Moving the goal posts risks an own goal

fields.headline: Moving the goal posts risks an own goal
fields.trailText: Occasionally it is tempting to wonder if the football media and the football public share the same perspectives. This week has been a case in point.
fields.body:
Occasionally it is tempting to wonder if the football media and the football public share the same perspectives. This week has been a case in point.

After Lazio had lost badly at the weekend the sports pages were dominated by renewed speculation concerning the early arrival of Sven-Goran Eriksson as England coach which intensified once the Swede had upheld the grand old Roman tradition of falling on his sword.

No sooner had it been confirmed that Eriksson would be taking up his new post six months ahead of schedule than the scribes were second-guessing his likely choice of squad. In a quiet week for football the story could hardly have been better timed.

For most fans, however, it is doubtful whether the dawn of a new era for the England football team has been of more than passing interest. After all England, on average, have had a new era roughly every two years since 1990.

To be sure there is a certain curiosity value in the idea of the national team's next flopperoo being explained away in a foreign accent. Otherwise supporters will be far more concerned with the affairs of their own teams; whether they are going up, staying up or, more crucially, staying put.

Consider, for example, the plights of the followers of Carlisle United and Wimbledon, who face black comedy on the one hand and a bleak hypothesis on the other. Each case involves the prospect of the club moving house, not within the same area but to a wholly new location, the benefits of which are highly speculative.

There is nothing new about the notion of Carlisle playing in the Scottish League. Geographically and economically it has always made some sense and in any case Berwick Rangers have long since established the precedent of an English team competing in Scottish football.

Carlisle supporters, however, may see it differently. Berwick is strictly a border town whereas Carlisle, while adjacent to Scotland, is as English as Cleckheaton or Cockfosters. Given the choice between travelling to East Fife or Exeter most United fans would probably opt for the latter.

Last weekend there was talk of a merger with Clydebank, given that one of Carlisle's new owners has in the past thought of moving the Scottish club to Dublin. Since then, however, speculation has been put on hold following the news that another supposed backer was a merchant banker only in the poetic sense.

None of which is likely to calm the nerves of Brunton Park fans who as recently as 1995 made up a generous proportion of the Wembley crowd of more than 76,000 that watched the Auto Windscreens Shield final between Carlisle and Birmingham City.

Being six points behind the rest of the league at the bottom of the Nationwide Third Division does not help but better the Conference than Clydebank, surely.

The Carlisle crisis carries uncanny echoes of the uncertainties which Wimbledon's supporters have suffered since the club left their natural home at Plough Lane 10 years ago.

Sharing Selhurst Park with Crystal Palace was supposed to be a temporary arrangement but Wimbledon's failure to win planning approval from Merton Council made them long-term exiles.

Like Clydebank, Wimbledon entertained the notion of playing in Dublin (notwithstanding the fact that Dubliners would much rather make regular visits to Manchester United and Liverpool). Now the Norwegian fishing magnates who own the club have decided that the honour of accommodating Wimbledon should go to Milton Keynes, home of the concrete cow.

Milton Keynes is delighted at the idea but Wimbledon supporters would rather watch their team on a ploughed field provided it was back somewhere near Plough Lane. Playing in a new stadium at Bletchley as MK Dons would destroy the identity of the club which the hard core of their support has preserved these 10 years past.

Wimbledon's owners need to realise that in this country football clubs and their supporters cannot be moved, merged and generally mucked about like shiploads of frozen haddock. The tribalism of British football may now be a cliche but is still real enough.

It is to be hoped that Wimbledon fans and their soulmates at Carlisle will be able to see off such misguided plans, much as the supporters of Reading took to the streets in 1983 when Robert Maxwell talked of merging their club with Oxford United under the name of Thames Valley Royals. Similarly, in 1967, a proposal that Queens Park Rangers should buy out Brentford and move into Griffin Park proved a nine-day wonder.

There is nothing wrong in a football club setting up shop elsewhere if the fans go along with the move. A while ago a club which had fallen on hard times - they were relegated with only £19 in the bank - moved 10 miles north despite objections from local residents and league clubs already operating in the area.

Since they had won only two games on their old ground in the space of a year the fans in south London were hardly up in arms and in any case support was soon found at the new home.

But that was 1913, Arsenal were moving from Woolwich to Highbury, and football clubs then were clubs, not commodities.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Cold water extinguishes Hammam's bonfire vanity
fields.trailText: •The FA must be hoping the Cardiff City owner Sam Hammam keeps a low profile when the Cup comes to town. On New Year's Day, a local journalist and author whom Hammam wrongly believed to have written an article critical of the club was doused in water inside Ninian Park by four of the club's apprentices. Comments on an unofficial City website, inspired by the same misapprehension, urged Hammam to "throw his books on the bonfire with the shirts". The shirts? Hammam had offered to sell Cardiff strips at cut price in exchange for any English club shirts, which would then be burnt. Yesterday, after widespread protests, the plan was dropped. Welcome to Cardiff indeed.
fields.body:
The FA must be hoping the Cardiff City owner Sam Hammam keeps a low profile when the Cup comes to town. On New Year's Day, a local journalist and author whom Hammam wrongly believed to have written an article critical of the club was doused in water inside Ninian Park by four of the club's apprentices. Comments on an unofficial City website, inspired by the same misapprehension, urged Hammam to "throw his books on the bonfire with the shirts". The shirts? Hammam had offered to sell Cardiff strips at cut price in exchange for any English club shirts, which would then be burnt. Yesterday, after widespread protests, the plan was dropped. Welcome to Cardiff indeed.

Things have not been going quite to plan at the 16-nation Millennium Cup in India. Two days before it began, both Iraq and Cameroon pulled out, too late to call up replacements (though Panama and Estonia were keen). Then the sponsors insisted the trophy be renamed after them. So the 14-nation Sahara Cup got under way on Wednesday with a match between Chile and Bahrain. At least it would have done, if only the Chileans' luggage hadn't been lost in transit.

Bury's dire financial plight eased slightly this week when Ipswich sold David Johnson, netting the Shakers a £380,000 sell-on fee. It may improve again on Tuesday, when a generous neighbouring club is staging a benefit match. A Premiership giant, perhaps? Not quite. Accrington Stanley, who resigned from the league in 1962, are doing the decent thing. "We can all remember what it was like when Stanley dropped out," said their chairman Eric Whalley. "We are only too pleased to help them in their hour of need."

Interesting times ahead for Parma, where Arrigo Sacchi has returned as coach. "Footballers are like fiancees," he explained on being asked to assess his squad. "You only find out what they are really like when you take them home and marry them." But Sacchi denied it was sex that tempted him out of retirement. No, it was addiction. "I am not saying football is a drug, but it is almost. We are not free to choose as we think ourselves to be." Time for your lie-down, Arrigo.

"We are treating these allegations very seriously," said a Hartlepool spokesman after their mascot H'angus the monkey was ejected from Scunthorpe's ground in November for simulating sex with a female steward. Not that seriously though, to judge from last week's game against Exeter, where H'angus (also starring on the kids' page of the club's website) spent much of his time making crude sexual gestures towards the crowd with bananas. The choice of fruit was especially unfortunate since Exeter's manager Noel Blake had to endure an afternoon of racist abuse. Victoria Park - a fun day out for all the family.

A handy betting tip. Next time Bradford are at home to Middlesbrough in the week of an eclipse, put your money on Boro to win 1-0. On Monday they repeated their feat of January 24 1925, when a solar eclipse threatened to disrupt the fixtures. "Neither the FA nor the League have issued any instructions to clubs," Aston Villa's News & Record complained at the time.

The race is on in Oceania to grab the cash on offer at Fifa's World Club Championship, with regional powerhouses such as Foodtown Warriors (Fiji) battling it out in Papua New Guinea. The thought of playing Real Madrid proved too much for Lotoha'pai FC of Tonga, who went down to Australia's Wollongong Wolves in their first match, described in one report as "a convincing 16-0 win". What does an unconvincing 16-0 win look like?


mike.ticher@theguardian.com

webTitle: Italian's word to the wise at Bridge of sighs

fields.headline: Italian's word to the wise at Bridge of sighs
fields.standfirst: Roy Collins  hears Sam Dalla Bona's youthful interpretation of Chelsea's woe
fields.trailText: According to the Chelsea midfielder Sam Dalla Bona, his manager Claudio Ranieri's command of English does not, as we are led to believe, fall somewhere between that of Inspector Clouseau and Stanley Unwin.
fields.body:
According to the Chelsea midfielder Sam Dalla Bona, his manager Claudio Ranieri's command of English does not, as we are led to believe, fall somewhere between that of Inspector Clouseau and Stanley Unwin.

"His English is quite good," says Dalla Bona, who could not speak a word himself when he arrived from Atalanta two years ago. "I think he could speak it more but he is perhaps a little shy to use it in a press conference."

It seems a common problem at Chelsea, where not a single senior player was willing to address the detested fourth estate before today's game against Arsenal at Highbury. Not even Dennis Wise, unless, of course, it was a paid-for interview with the newspaper to which his thoughts are contracted.

Chelsea players are a sensitive lot, convinced they are the objects of hatred and envy to all outside Stamford Bridge. Yet many of their recent wounds have been self-inflicted, not least Wise's transfer demand, followed days later by a kiss-and-make-up with everyone from the tea ladies to, perish the thought, chairman Ken Bates.

Wise omitted to mention his manager among those who persuaded him to stay. So Ranieri, though at the risk of gilding the lily, not only expressed his euphoria that Wise was staying but called upon him to help "construct a new Chelsea".

Wise will speak only via his Boswell, though Dalla Bona, 19, was happy to discuss the changes since Ranieri replaced Gianluca Vialli a few games into the season. He says: "We were all disappointed when Vialli went and it takes time to understand what a new manager wants.

"So in the beginning, we were a little confused and we were still adjusting to losing Vialli. But the mood is good now and every day we feel a little bit better. Naturally I am happy because I have become a regular first-team player and there is no problem communicating. I certainly do not have to interpret for the manager."

When necessary that job goes to the Uruguayan Gustavo Poyet, though at half-time, when there is little time for translations, Ranieri uses flip charts with noughts and crosses and arrows to get his message across. Stuff that a genetically modified monkey could understand.

The assistant manager Gwyn Williams says: "There is no lack of communication and there never has been. Some of the training is conducted in English but if the manager is speaking to Gianfranco Zola, it makes sense to do so in Italian. There is also a difference between instructing and joking with the lads and talking into a TV camera, though I am confident he will conduct a press conference in English soon."

Wise's sudden transfer demand was unsettling for the side. But it turned out to be a dissatisfied cri de coeur at being played out of position and left out altogether against Aston Villa on New Year's Day.

The ploy worked; chairman Bates and the chief executive Colin Hutchinson rushed to dry his eyes and assured him that he would remain a pivotal figure at the club. Bates and Hutchinson have since disappeared on holiday, apparently not together, leaving Williams holding the cry baby.

Williams says: "I don't know quite what happened with Dennis. A situation evolved and has now been sorted and though he might have wobbled for a while, he is totally committed to the cause."

Dalla Bona and his team-mates were also kept in the dark by Wise."He didn't say anything to us before or afterwards but we are all glad he is staying because he is a hero to everybody," he said. "If you mention Chelsea in Italy, people will know Ranieri and they will also see a picture of Dennis, because he is the symbol of the club."

Wise has always led by example on the pitch and though Ranieri seemed ready to push him towards the wings, both metaphorical and literal, he has brought in more young players in a hope of replicating that English bulldog spirit.

Remarkably, though, Chelsea will again seek a first away win of the season at Highbury today, where they have an appalling record. Given the swaggering performances at home, their away form is baffling; it cannot just be the absence of the inspirational messages inside and outside the dressing room door at Stamford Bridge that read "Strive To Win and Shun Defeat" and "Never Ever Give Up", the sort of homilies you see framed behind the desk of US middle-management executives.

Dalla Bona says: "It has become a psychological problem for us. We have played well in many away games but when the other team score we seem to lose confidence. Maybe we need to play with more personality away from home."

Williams is also at a loss to explain the side's failures away from the Bridge, though he offers an unusual solution. "I remember Gordon Strachan at Coventry going 18 months without an away win and then he sacked the bus driver and they won three on the trot away. Maybe that's the answer."

webTitle: Ellis seeks comfort in guardian Angel

fields.headline: Ellis seeks comfort in guardian Angel
fields.trailText: Aston Villa's chairman Doug Ellis appears to have headed off the strongest mass public critcism of his leadership to date by announcing last night that the signing of the Colombian striker Juan Pablo Angel is imminent.
fields.body:
Aston Villa's chairman Doug Ellis appears to have headed off the strongest mass public critcism of his leadership to date by announcing last night that the signing of the Colombian striker Juan Pablo Angel is imminent.

Continued failure to capture a much-needed striker, plus reports of increasing rancour between Ellis and his manager John Gregory, fuelled even greater discontent when Villa s attempt to pay a club record £9.5m for Angel turned into an embarrassing shambles a week ago. There were fears that protests would reach a new level of intensity during today s match against Liverpool, which is expected to attract Villa Park's biggest crowd for 6 years.

A Villa statement last night said: "We are delighted to confirm that Juan Pablo Angel is to travel to Villa Park to complete a club-record transfer from River Plate." Ellis himself echoed that sentiment "after a turbulent week of both rumour and conjecture".

He added: "For the last seven days we have all worked towards a positive conclusion following Fifa's initial intervention which stopped the original deal. We had to be 100% sure the deal would not collapse again before making this announcement."

The transfer originally fell foul of Fifa rules, which state payments for players must be club-to-club transactions. In Angel s case, a payment was also due to an agent who had a stake in the player, a situation that has now been resolved.

All that is left is for Angel, already granted a work permit, to pass a medical and sign his contract. Those formalities should be concluded early next week to end a quest for Gregory that began last summer.

It started with him pursuing Celta Vigo's Benni McCarthy and took another turn this week when Villa had a £12m offer for Liverpool s Robbie Fowler rejected.

But for some weeks now, Angel has been Gregory s No1 target. "We need a 20-goals-a- season man who can scramble goals home from three yards or off their kneecap," he said. "Someone who is capable of scoring what I call Gary Lineker-type goals - that's what Angel does."

Terry Venables hopes to lure Dean Windass to Middlesbrough after the Bradford City midfielder was told he could leave Valley Parade.

Bradford are willing to off-load Windass, their leading scorer last season, to cut their wage bill. Boro are willing to pay around £1.5m for the 31-year-old. "We are interested in him," confirmed Venables, who added: "The chairman Steve Gibson has said he will try to help if we want to do something."

Meanwhile Dan Petrescu completed his move from Bradford to Southampton, the 33-year-old Romanian taking a big wage cut to link up again with Glenn Hoddle, his former manager at Chelsea.

Petrescu signed a 2-year deal and Bradford will receive less than £100,000 of the £800,000 fee agreed because the bulk is being used to pay up the remainder of his contract at City.

Newcastle's £7m striker Carl Cort, attempting to come back from a hamstring injury, has broken down in training and is out for a further two weeks.

The disgraced Christoph Daum has admitted taking cocaine after returning from a three-month exile in Florida.

The former Bayer Leverkusen coach had been lined up to take charge of Germany in June before allegations of his involvement in cocaine-fuelled orgies with prostitutes.

Daum initially denied the allegations but now he says: "I admit I have taken cocaine in the past, in private. There's no question of me being an addict."

Arsène Wenger has revealed he wants to continue as Arsenal manager after his current contract expires in the summer of next year. "I've told Arsenal I'm very interested in staying but I've also told them that I won't make a decision until the new rules concerning players' contracts are decided," he said.

Newcastle's £7m striker Carl Cort, attempting to come back from a hamstring injury, has broken down in training and is out for a further two weeks. The disgraced Christoph Daum has admitted taking cocaine after returning from a three-month exile in Florida. The former Bayer Leverkusen coach had been lined up to take charge of Germany in June before allegations of his involvement in cocaine-fuelled orgies with prostitutes. Daum initially denied the allegations but now he says: "I admit I have taken cocaine in the past, in private. There's no question of me being an addict." Arsène Wenger has revealed he wants to continue as Arsenal manager after his current contract expires in the summer of next year. "I've told Arsenal I'm very interested in staying but I've also told them that I won't make a decision until the new rules concerning players' contracts are decided," he said.

fields.headline: Eriksson disarms bullish protest
fields.trailText: John Bull turned up outside the Football Association's new headquarters in Soho Square yesterday to protest about the appointment of a foreigner as England coach. A pity Mr Bull could not hear the man out. He might have learned something.
fields.body:
John Bull turned up outside the Football Association's new headquarters in Soho Square yesterday to protest about the appointment of a foreigner as England coach. A pity Mr Bull could not hear the man out. He might have learned something.

The niceties of national distinctions clearly do not mean much to Sven-Goran Eriksson, who today begins the task of taking England to the World Cup next year by watching West Ham United, the club which supplied the nucleus of the side that won the Jules Rimet trophy in 1966.

"Maybe today I feel more European than Swedish," said Eriksson when the xenophobes' point of view was put to him. "After all I've been away from Sweden since 1982. In any case football is the same all over the world. If the results are bad it doesn't matter if you are English, Swedish or Chinese - you will always be criticised. But if England's results are good I don't think anyone will be worrying about nationalities."

So confident is the Football Association that England have the right man to revive the national team that Eriksson is on a five-year contract worth £3.5m per annum with a two-year option. As England have had four coaches - Graham Taylor, Terry Venables, Glenn Hoddle and Kevin Keegan - since Bobby Robson's side reached the last four of the 1990 World Cup, the FA cannot afford to get it wrong now.

Yesterday the 52-year-old Eriksson gave his first press conference as England coach six months earlier than planned. Lazio's poor results, which led to his resigning as the Rome club's coach on Monday, saw to that.

A disarming personality, Eriksson is said to have few enemies in the game and after listening to him for the better part of an hour it is easy to see why. It is not that he avoids confrontation, he simply believes in preserving his energies for where they are most needed, and that is on the football field. "I don't like polemic," he explained. "If people make personal criticisms of me I try not to respond. I don't see any reason for it."

When asked what he thought of anyone who considered England had appointed a losing coach, he proved equally passive. "There is no use talking about what I have done or not done," he replied, "because now it is all about what I do in the future."

In terms of what he actually plans to do with the England squad Eriksson was less revealing. Which is hardly surprising since he has yet to watch English players live in any capacity other than an opposing coach or neutral observer.

Nevertheless he was prepared to reel off a list of those he considered to have either world class or world-class potential: Steven Gerrard, Emile Heskey and Michael Owen of Liverpool, David Beckham and Paul Scholes of Manchester United, Rio Ferdinand and Paul Robinson of Leeds and West Ham's Joe Cole.

Eriksson's requirements in an international footballer were equally unsurprising: "He must have speed, strength, good technique, a good understanding of the play and good vision. Very few players in the world have all these qualities, and experience is important too."

It seems safe to assume that Peter Taylor's caretaking decision to restrict his choice of team for the friendly in Italy to players of 30 or under will remain a one-off. "You need a good mix of young players and those who are more experienced," Eriksson declared. "So long as a player is good enough to play at the highest level then why not pick him? But experience is very important as well."

Tactically Eriksson is reputed to prefer 4-4-2 formations but like any other coach he will see what talent is available to England before deciding how the team will play against Spain in next month's friendly at Villa Park. "It is not true that I always play 4-4-2," he insisted. "Last season, when Lazio won the Italian championship, we also played 4-3-3 or 4-5-1. Against France early this season England played 4-5-1 and it worked very well."

Eriksson intends developing good relations with Sir Alex Ferguson and the other club managers who will regularly provide him with players. He also wants to have discussions with England's previous coaches on the job in hand.

"You have to be very open and if you can take ideas from someone then do so. You mustn't be too proud to ask questions and favours of other colleagues."

Eriksson looked slightly perplexed when asked how he expected his England players to behave. Why, behaving like people representing their country: eating the right food, perhaps with a glass of wine, and playing cards but only for small amounts. "If you play for big money it can become a problem."

Eriksson himself comes over as the sort of person who would enjoy a friendly game of contract bridge.

webTitle: Football fans unite to take over club

fields.headline: Football fans unite to take over club
fields.standfirst:
Lowly Lincoln City FC is set to become the first British team wholly owned by its supporters

Football Unlimited.co.uk
fields.trailText: Lowly Lincoln City FC is set to become the first British team wholly owned by its supporters.
fields.body:
For supporters of Lincoln City football club, following their beloved Red Imps has proved a true test of loyalty. Their team has been a permanent tenant of the football league basement since the club was formed in 1884, but they have stuck with the Imps through thin and thin.

The odd promotional season has usually been followed by relegation, with the club yo-yoing between the bottom two divisions. For the Red Imps tribe it has been more a case of the gory, gory years than any glory, glory years. But history is about to be made at Sincil Bank, Lincoln City's home ground. The club is set to become the first in British football to be wholly owned by its fans.

Last season the fans organised themselves into a supporters' trust with legal recognition, to give them a stronger voice. Around 800 fans have joined the trust, some already shareholders in the club.

Last year Rob Bradley, a trust member and Lincoln fan, became club chairman, with the outgoing chairman, John Reames, deciding to sell his controlling interest.

Mr Reames insisted that if anybody invested £400,000 in Lincoln City they could take it over, and, with support from local businesses, the Co-operative Society and individual fans, the Lincoln supporters' trust has raised the money, tabled a bid and is on the verge of buying its club.

Some fans have contributed £1,000 each, others as little as £25. All will be eligible to stand for the board once the trust assumes control. The fans' takeover is backed by the players and team manager.

Mr Bradley said: "We are calling this a community buyout because the community will own the club... It will belong to the fans, they will have a greater say in how it is run, and they will be able to influence changes."

The fans received help from Supporters Direct, set up last year to advise fans on how they can use shareholdings and form trusts to increase their influence in their clubs.

Government officials such as Andy Burnham - special adviser to the sport secretary, Chris Smith - and the fans are the main driving force behind Supporters Direct, which has annual funding of £250,000. It aims to use the principles of the Co-operative Society to help fans to organise and have a greater say in their clubs.

With many clubs listed on the stock market, fans are advised on how to pool their shares, allowing them to have a representative at boardroom level. Others, such as those at Lincoln, are advised on how forming a trust can increase influence in a club.

Brian Lomax, chairman of Supporters Direct, said: "Fans are no longer turnstile fodder. There is an unstoppable movement going on, with fans wanting a greater say in the running of their clubs. They have been taken for granted for too long."

Already 18 supporters' trusts have been formed at clubs around the country, and nine clubs have appointed fans as directors. Supporters Direct is also advising fans of 18 of the 20 Premier League clubs on how share ownership could give them greater influence.

Lincoln fans say they will be able to raise issues such as ticket prices and even team matters. They feel they are being listened to and action will be taken.

Kevin Stow, who has not missed a Lincoln match for 22 years, said: "I have always felt that the club didn't really care about the supporters. The fact that it will be owned by fellow fans means that they have to care about us. I will feel more comfortable raising issues, because I know that the new owners will have to listen to me. After all, I know them; they are fans who attend matches, just like me."

Lincoln fans insist that, if they become owners, team affairs will still be left to the manager, and that the club will try to make money.

Mr Bradley said: "Fans alone cannot run a club, because football is very emotional. We can't have fans voting on what next week's team should be. We are looking for a proper partnership between fans and business."

Mr Reames is in Spain considering the Lincoln supporters' offer and another from a private investor. Whoever takes over will have to deal with debts of £1m and a team languishing fifth from bottom of the Third Division. For the Red Imps faithful, the agony is likely to continue, whether or not they become owners.

webTitle: New coach eases into first day at the office

fields.headline: New coach eases into first day at the office
fields.trailText: His current reading matter is not, as has been widely touted, a volume of Tibetan poetry, but a history of Sweden. "I was sleeping during my lessons at school," Sven-Goran Eriksson said yesterday.
fields.body:
His current reading matter is not, as has been widely touted, a volume of Tibetan poetry, but a history of Sweden. "I was sleeping during my lessons at school," Sven-Goran Eriksson said yesterday.

Now he is catching up. And the improvement in his attitude to homework was given a practical demonstration when, interrogated about the young English players who have impressed him and his sidekick, Tord Grip, in the weeks since he accepted the Football Association's offer, he pulled a list from his jacket pocket.

A smooth move, performed with some alacrity. Outside, on the pavement in front of the plate-glass doorway in Soho Square, a lone protester hoisted a placard calling for the head of the FA's chief executive. Otherwise, Eriksson's first day at the office was proceeding without incident.

No doubt the new England coach will hope that the coming days offer more meetings with footballers and fewer with journalists. But yesterday he may have been pleasantly surprised by the comparatively civilised reception he received, even at the hands of those newspapers whose representatives have been characterising him, in the wake of his sudden departure from Lazio, as a loser.

There was no sign, mind you, of the "painted ladies" of Soho, to whose maquillage a senior sports columnist this week disparagingly compared the FA's "superficial and cosmetic" decision to appoint their "designer Scandinavian". But then such sights have not been a part of Soho at lunchtime since Terry Venables was a lad.

The atmosphere of cordiality looks likely to last until his first bad result. The tabloids may love to roast a failure, but even they would rather be celebrating success. Yet Eriksson is fully aware that, as he told a TV interviewer, with his first defeat he will be "hung". Football, he added, is like that over the world.

"I have read the discussions," he said, "and I know some people are against me and others are for me. Everyone is free to have an opinion. I'm sorry about the situation. Of course I'm happier when people are for me. But I think I have to defend myself in the future by playing good football with the team and by getting good results. That's the only way you can defend yourself as a manager."

Yesterday he told us a little more about himself. He will live in or near London, although he is unlikely to find quite as attractive a central location as the Piazza di Popolo, where he had his base in Rome. He likes to play tennis, which will no doubt lead to a new rash of "Anyone for Svennis?" headlines. A recent photograph of Eriksson astride a Harley-Davidson motorcycle turned out to have been a stunt on behalf of a charity appeal. "I have never been one metre on a Harley-Davidson," he said, "and I never will."

We have yet to see whether a reluctance to take risks on the road is reflected in his attitude to selecting an international football team. "I don't want to talk about individuals," he said yesterday, and naturally he was giving little away about the composition of his first squad. But he did say, when invited to send a message to the younger generation of English footballers, that "when I pick the first 22, it will not be that 22 for ever".

He was understandably equivocal about the balance between youth and experience in an international squad. "I think the future is for young players," he declared, "but when you come to pick a team you can't only choose young players. You must have players with a lot of experience also. You can't go and beat Germany away with no experience. That's impossible."

What would he do, he was asked, that would be different from, and better than, the work of his predecessors? "I don't know exactly how the preparation worked before me," he replied, "and I don't think I'm going to find out, either. It's history, and nothing to do with the future."

It was an advantage, he thought, that he was coming in from the outside, without allegiances or favourites among players and clubs. "But it's a big disadvantage that I've been seeing too little of English football lately." When pressed, he agreed that he would be talking to those of his predecessors still active with English clubs - Bobby Robson, Graham Taylor, Terry Venables, Glenn Hoddle and Kevin Keegan - although there was no suggestion that he would be looking for guidance.

The length of his contract, he agreed, was in itself a confirmation that the FA are thinking of the long term. "For a manager, that's perfect. It gives me tranquillità ."

His long stay in Italy came to a messy conclusion earlier this week, although Lazio's management and public gave him a warm send-off and on Thursday one of his former players, the Argentina midfielder Juan Sebastian Veron, absolved him of all blame on behalf of the squad. "I'm not happy with how it ended up at Lazio, that's for sure," Eriksson said yesterday. "But I'm happy to be here today. Every time we lost, the England story came up as one of the reasons. I never thought that because I believe footballers are more professional than that. It didn't help, maybe. But it's no use that I talk about what I've done or not done. What I've done doesn't matter. What matters is I must do for the future to show that England can have a good team."

Last week, France Football magazine produced a chart of European countries, based on international performances throughout the year 2000, which showed England in 20th place. "To me," Eriksson said when questioned about England's current lowly status, "the big European football countries are Spain, Germany, Italy, France - and England, for sure. Those are the countries with 50 or 60m people. England should be one of them. We hope to improve."

But does England possess players of the quality needed to lift them back into the elite? Have they, for instance, got the sort of full-backs needed to play with a flat back four? "I don't know. Give me that question again in one month and I will tell you. But I think you can find good players in every position in a big football country like England." This time, no one asked him if he knew the name of Sunderland's left-back. If he doesn't know now, then by Sunday night, after watching Sunderland's match at Portman Road, he certainly will.

And the chap on the pavement might like to know that Eriksson intends to sing the English national anthem before the matches. "I'll have to learn the words," he said. "I have no problem with that. I'm not a very good singer. That's the problem."

webTitle: ITV bags Champion to complete the jigsaw

fields.headline: ITV bags Champion to complete the jigsaw
fields.trailText: ITV has captured the BBC commentator Jon Champion to join Clive Tyldesley, Peter Drury, Guy Mowbray and Peter Brackley to complete the commentary team covering the Premiership and the Champions League for the commercial network next season. There are no plans for more commentators to be signed.
fields.body:
ITV has captured the BBC commentator Jon Champion to join Clive Tyldesley, Peter Drury, Guy Mowbray and Peter Brackley to complete the commentary team covering the Premiership and the Champions League for the commercial network next season. There are no plans for more commentators to be signed.

It is understood that ITV considered luring John Motson or Barry Davies from the other side but decided they might be "past the winning post" and also rejected big-money moves for Sky's Martin Tyler and Alan Parry. Champion is considered to be as sharp as they come as a commentator - quick with player identification and alive to the flow of the game - and also not lacking in journalistic skills, spotting a developing story at an early stage. He can tend to be a little Motsonian at times but the more edgy commercial atmosphere over at ITV may help his commentaries lose their occasional ponderousness.

Champion was keen to stress that the ITV head of sport Brian Barwick had bought him for what he is rather than what he can turn him into. Champion said: "Some might say I am a bit too much of a BBC man but who is more BBC than Des Lynam? Brian Barwick is a former BBC man himself and I think his plan is to take the best elements of their soccer coverage and combine it with ITV's virtues, as well as some of the values of Sky, whose football programmes are also much admired."

Clearly a key factor in Barwick's plan to imbue ITV's new highlights programme with some of the more successful elements of Match of the Day is his continuing raid on BBC Sport's backroom staff.

Tony Pastor, who at 30 is considered to be among the brightest young production talent at the BBC, is leaving his job as producer at MOTD for a similar role on ITV's new highlights programmes, while Paul McNamara, a Match of the Day executive who won a Bafta award for his redesign of the BBC's football show, will be working on the look of ITV's new highlights programmes.

As well as the new Saturday teatime show - 6pm is likely to be the only logical time for it, given the apparent immovability of the ratings winner Blind Date - there will be a Sunday or Monday highlights programme each week, including a round-up of all the weekend's Premiership action.

Additionally, towards the beginning and end of the season, there is likely to be a Wednesday night highlights show as well. Gabby Yorath seems to have the job of fronting these extra highlights packages in the bag but one area in which job opportunities still abound is punditry.

The Guardian columnist Ron Atkinson will still be the main man but Paul Tyrrell, the ITV Sport press officer, said there was likely to be an extended role for Andy Townsend. He added: "We were very impressed with Townsend and [Terry] Venables, who worked together for the FA Cup last week, and we could see some more of that."

Any other former footballers thinking of taking on a pub in their retirement might want to consider putting their plans on hold, as more talking heads will be needed not just for the Premiership but also for the Worthington Cup and Nationwide League, which will be covered on OnDigital next season."

John Barnes and Jim Beglin have already been signed up for some of this work, and possibly Barry Venison.

The BBC, meanwhile, will have to work hard to keep Alan Hansen. The hard man of punditry may feel himself under-employed next season when the BBC is restricted to the FA Cup and England internationals, with the possibility of buying some Uefa Cup action directly from British qualifiers.

Hansen has spread his wings on a successful documentary or two but, as they have been largely on his specialist subject - Premiership football - and as that will reside elsewhere next season, new avenues may have to be explored.

While ITV is cagey about the chances of Hansen jumping ship in its direction, Tyrrell insists there will be more production people joining in advance of its Premiership launch, some of them no doubt still wearing their Match of the Day lifebelts.

Peter Salmon, the BBC's new head of sport, says he relishes a challenge, which is just as well. With three different bosses in the past two years, BBC Sport clearly remains in some disarray, as epitomised by the PR disaster of David Coleman's departure, which was highly embarrassing when viewed alongside ITV's smooth handling of Murray Walker's retirement.

Salmon's urgent task is to persuade his talent that FA Cup football and the progress of Eriksson's England is a portfolio worth staying to work on. ITV, meanwhile, simply has to hope the Premiership does not lose its lustre by turning into an annual procession for Manchester United, for example.

It is going to be showing an awful lot of it and it will want it to be packed with action, excitement, and characters with at least some of the wide popular appeal of Stars In Their Eyes and Cilla.

fields.headline: Going for broke
fields.standfirst: How Hollywood lost its nerve, then found it again. By  Jonathan Romney
fields.trailText: How Hollywood lost its nerve, then found it again. By Jonathan Romney
fields.body:
We were sitting round talking about M Night Shyamalan's latest movie, Unbreakable, and someone asked: "Ah, but have you seen Fearless?" To which the buffiest film buff present declared: "That must be the most overrated underrated film of all time." That's a specialist category I could love; perhaps the National Film Theatre will do a season of overrated underrated films or, better still, underrated overrated ones.

Directed by Peter Weir, Fearless is underrated because it is very nearly superb, and was not much liked when released in 1993. And it's possibly overrated because it trips itself up in the final stretch, so frustratingly that you almost want to wash your hands of it. It makes instructive viewing alongside Unbreakable.

Shyamalan's film is about a man who is the sole survivor of a train crash, and discovers that he has powers that distinguish him from the rest of humanity. In Weir's film, Max Klein (Jeff Bridges) is one of several survivors of a plane crash. He too comes to believe there is something special about him - that he has not only escaped death but transcended it.

Early in the film, we get the strangest, subtlest inkling of what's happening to Max. Visiting an ex-girlfriend, he treats the two of them to a plate of strawberries - ripe and red, shot in succulent close-up. He pops one into his mouth and beams with the joy of life. Then his ex reminds him that he used to be allergic to strawberries - that one nearly killed him.

It's not just fruit he no longer fears. He casually walks across a busy freeway, then dances on the edge of a rooftop. He has witnessed the moment of his own death, and passed through it. He's unbreakable - or perhaps just in an extreme state of denial.

Weir's film - adapted by Rafael Yglesias from his own novel - plays with rather higher stakes than Shyamalan's avowedly comic-strip story. Fearless wants to go the whole philosophical and psychological nine yards, which makes it much less clear-cut than the average Hollywood essay in deep feeling. Max has become either an angel or a monster, either painfully honest or boorishly tactless. He turns his back on terra firma - on his kids and his wife, played with nervous intensity by Isabella Rossellini - and forms a bond with a young woman (a vividly pained Rosie Perez), who has lost her child on the flight. He both befriends her and takes drastic steps to cure her of her Catholic guilt.

Fearless dazzles you with the intensity of its images, shot with unnerving cleanness by Allen Daviau - notably the scene in which Bridges walks down a deserted flyover and through what appears to be a deserted city, as well as the opening slow-motion drift through a cornfield and Bridges impassively wandering through the carnage from the plane crash. Bridges is at his complex best, too - does any other Hollywood actor have the same knack of appearing at once a warm, vulnerable human being, yet also an abject, strutting creep? The film's boldness in overtly tackling big themes (guilt, mortality, theology) explains why it was a box-office dud. Fearless is a dazzling anomaly - the closest Hollywood has come to producing a Krzysztof Kieslowski film. Compare Kieslowski's Three Colours: Blue, in which Juliette Binoche survives the death of her family in a road accident.

Arguably, Fearless takes on too much, and there comes a point when all the talk gets a little leaden and theatrical. But the big flaw is at the end, when Weir feels obliged to lay on a major climax, in the form of an apocalyptic and extremely detailed flashback to the plane crash itself. And at the very last second, the film loses its nerve totally, and pulls back from the tragic abyss it's poised to leap into. Without revealing too much, it involves another strawberry, and what could have been devastating becomes one of Hollywood's ready-made redemptions.

Shyamalan, however, making a film that is supposedly pure entertainment, signally resists such compromises. Not only is Unbreakable's ending more than a little disturbing, but the film thrives on understatement, refusing, for example, to show the train crash that changes his hero's life.

I'd like to think that Unbreakable, like Shyamalan's The Sixth Sense and Christopher Nolan's rigorously mathematical Memento, shows signs of a new no-frills approach to storytelling in American cinema. Shyamalan is committed to telling a story and nothing in the film is superfluous to that. Fearless's last-minute failure of nerve is that it wants to send us out of the cinema feeling good, or at least relieved. Unbreakable doesn't - and perhaps its success will help other Hollywood films to resist pulling back at the brink. But what a brink - a centimetre more, and Fearless would have been pure west coast Kieslowski. In a parallel universe, I like to imagine it being the first part of a Peter Weir philosophical trilogy - Three Flavours: Strawberry.

 Fearless is available on video from Warner Bros.
