webTitle: For Anna, the promise of a new life ended in pain, fear and filth

fields.headline: For Anna, the promise of a new life ended in pain, fear and filth
fields.standfirst:
Agencies failed to act as girl, eight, suffered

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Agencies failed to act as girl, eight, suffered.
fields.body:
When Anna Climbie left the crumbling shacks of the sprawling shanty suburb of Abobo, Ivory Coast, in November 1997 she was "happy and excited".

The child was leaving the muddy streets and crammed housing of the west African country and going to a new life with her aunt.

The seven-year-old was being taken first to France and then to Britain for a better education and standard of living.

She was saying goodbye to a country where the average life expectancy is around 45, where each family has six children and where only 40% of women over 15 are literate.

To her mother and father, the move would bring a great honour on the family and eventually Anna might earn money and send some back to them. The Climbies had fallen on hard times and all nine of them had had to move in with a relative.

But instead of honour the family found only grief. Anna did not even get to go to school. Just over a year after leaving Ivory Coast, Anna Climbie was dead at the age of eight.

The victim of horrendous physical and emotional abuse, she was failed by all those who were bound up in her care.

Her death, in February last year, was the worst case of child abuse the Home Office pathologist who examined her battered body had ever seen.

Anna's last months were a savage existence. Instead of being at school and playing with other children she was bound hand and foot, naked, in a bathtub in a tiny flat in Tottenham in the middle of winter.

Instead of being fed she was starved: what little food she was given were scraps, fed to her in the bath on a piece of plastic bag.

Instead of being clothed, she was stuck in a black binbag which caught her excrement and trapped acids that burned her body.

Instead of praise, Anna was told she was possessed by the devil.

While her torturers were in the other room, Anna was left alone in the cold and dark in the unheated bathroom. They shut the door on her.

Anna simply got in the way of her demented aunt, Marie Therese Kouao, 44 - a woman the Old Bailey was told was "evil" - and her busdriver boyfriend, Carl Manning, 28, whom she picked up on a number 18 bus in Wembley.

Anna was not the meal ticket to social security benefits her aunt had first thought. She was just an inconvenience.

Over the months Anna was beaten with a variety of weapons including belt buckles, bicycle chains, coat hangers and shoes; razor blades were taken to her fingers and a hammer to her toes.

The child was burned with cigarettes and had boiling water poured over her head.

She "stooped like an old woman" after being confined to the bath.

After all this, she was dragged to a church to be exorcised because her aunt said she had evil spirits in her.

And all the while those who should have been concerned with her welfare - doctors, police and social services - let Anna down.

In spite of her being referred to social services on a number of occasions, no one ever checked on her properly.

In spite of the marks on her body, the child was returned to Kouao because a doctor believed her story that Anna had scabies.

And in spite of a senior doctor saying it was a case of child abuse, Anna went back to the Tottenham flat to become, as the same doctor said, "lost somewhere in Haringey". No one bothered to check.

Two police protection orders were taken out on the girl in July 1999, but nothing was done. A social services strategy meeting decided a home visit should be conducted but it never took place. The social worker and police officer were too scared of catching scabies.

Eventually, this small child - people remarked that she was half the size she should have been for her age - died from hypothermia due to exposure to cold and wet conditions.

The underlying cause was severe neglect and malnutrition.

The pathologist, Nathaniel Carey, found 128 marks on her body.

He said: "This little girl was covered in scars, she had been bound, she was underweight and she had been maltreated in terms of personal hygiene.

All cases of child abuse leading to death are pretty horrific but this one, in nature and extent of injury, is quite exceptional.

" When Marie Therese Kouao came to Abobo to take Anna away from her brothers and sisters, everything looked grand.

This woman - whom the family had only met on two previous occasions at funerals - seemed reasonably wealthy and said she had a good job in the aviation industry in Paris.

She had just been promoted, she said, and would soon be moving to London.

The widowed Kouao had three grown-up boys of her own and an adopted daughter.

She would treat Anna like a daughter, ensuring her education.

But the child, who was called Adjo Victoria in Ivory Coast, would have to change her name to Anna so she could carry the forged passport that had been made in the name of Anna Kouao.

(The real Anna Kouao was supposed to come to the UK but her parents changed their minds and refused to let Kouao take the child from Ivory Coast. Police say she is lucky to be alive.)

Anna was a bright girl who had been to kindergarten and had just started school where she was making good progress.

In the witness box of the Old Bailey, Anna's mother, Berthe Amoissi Ehoura, stood composed, a handsome, dignified woman determined to bear testament to the memory of her child.

She said of her daughter, the third youngest of seven: "She was very good with me and very easy with me. She had no illness as a child."

Soon after arriving in France Kouao decided to move to London.

She was being pursued over £2,000 in a suspected social security fraud.

She told people she wanted to learn English.

It was easy to get Anna, who Kouao said was her daughter, past British immigration authorities: Kouao was a French citizen and often children do not resemble passport photographs taken years or months before.

After a short time staying with a relative, Kouao asked Ealing council to accommodate her in April 1998.

The council told the woman and child that they should go back to her four-bedroomed house in France because they were intentionally homeless.

Eventually she was found a room in a hostel in Harlesden.

In May a social worker remarked that the child was poorly dressed in relation to her aunt.

One family member was shocked to see the little girl wearing a ridiculous wig.

On June 10, Kouao met Manning while he was driving his bus.

The man described by his own QC as "a bit of a nerd" who lived with his mother and led "a lonely, boring life", and who had never had a girlfriend, gave the older woman his telephone number and she called the next day.

He was impressed by this worldly woman who had boasted of being an air accident investigator and claimed to have studied at the "university of Oxford Street".

Ten days later the pair slept together.

Not long after, Esther Ackah, a distant relative of Kouao's, met Kouao, Manning and Anna in the street.

Afterwards Mrs Ackah, a nurse, twice phoned Ealing social services to raise concerns about Anna's living conditions and her deteriorating health.

She said she feared for the little girl's life.

But still nothing was done.

On July 6, Kouao and Anna moved into Manning's tiny flat in Tottenham.

Things did not go smoothly and Manning became angry when Anna urinated and defecated around the flat.

Panicking at the prospect of losing this new man or maybe his flat, Kouao tried to offload Anna on to a family who had done childminding for her in the past.

The Camerons took Anna for the night and put her straight to bed.

They were horrified the following morning when they saw that the child was covered in terrible injuries.

Anna had cuts on her fingers, across her cheek and eyelid and unusual marks on her body which Avril Cameron suspected were cigarette burns.

She took her to Central Middlesex hospital and was told Anna would only be released into safe hands.

But in spite of all the marks on her body, Anna was discharged after an overnight stay because the child protection doctor, Ruby Schwartz, said she was satisfied that she was suffering from scabies.

Dr Schwartz referred the case to social services because of concerns that the family appeared to be homeless and that Anna was not at school.

Social workers called a strategy meeting but failed to do anything because Kouao and Anna had moved out of the area.

Two weeks later Anna was in hospital again, this time with scalding to her head.

Her aunt said the child had poured hot water over herself to relieve terrible itching caused by scabies.

Instead of taking Anna to the health centre next to Manning's flat she walked the child 20 minutes to hospital, taking her there hours after the accident.

Staff on Rainbow ward noticed that Anna's clothes were dirty and that she was wearing no underwear.

One nurse remarked that she could not find a place on Anna's body that was not sore when she tried to lift her into a bath.

In the two weeks she was there nurses noted that there was a "master and servant" relationship between Kouao and Anna.

The child had shown signs of emotional abuse and anxious attachments and had poured a bottle of Hibiscrub over her head to ease her pain.

One morning she ate five bowls of cereal "like a child who does not know where her next meal is coming from".

But not once did she mention any abuse, leading staff to believe that this odd little girl had been coached not to say too much.

She would jump out of bed and stand to attention when Kouao - whom she called mother - came into the hospital ward, saying things like "my mummy's a good mummy".

Mary Anne Rossiter, a doctor who told the court that she had put in writing that she had no doubts this was child abuse, said: "I was aware that she came in an underclothed, dirty state in contrast to her very soignee, well-dressed mother."

She said the marks on Anna looked likely to have been inflicted with deliberate force, including the imprint of a belt buckle.

In spite of this, Anna was discharged on the authority of social services on August 6 while Dr Rossiter was on leave.

She said: "We asked after her and were horrified to learn that she had in fact been discharged."

In her letter to a social worker, Lisa Arthurworrey, she said: "I have enormous concerns about this child.

I think this child may have been abused."

Ms Arthurworrey was a member of Haringey's child protection team and, along with PC Karen Jones, saw Anna and believed Kouao when she repeated the scabies story, telling them that was what the other hospital had also said.

Without speaking to doctors or examining Anna without clothes, they let her go - back to what would become ever intensifying torture.

They did not visit the flat, fearing they might catch scabies.

They were happy enough, however, to let the little girl go back to what they believed was an infested place.

In court, these child protectors were criticised for their "blinding incompetence".

For Anna, things were to get worse.

By the end of October her tormentors began tying her up and throwing her in the bath.

In his diary, Manning begins to refer to Anna as "satan".

In one account, when he describes how after a row at New Year Kouao had run naked in the street after an argument, he wrote: "After a minute or so, she walked back to the flat in bare feet to release satan Anna from her rubbish bag."

The child was dragged around to various churches in London which reinforced the belief that evil spirits were within her.

Less than a week before her death, Anna was taken to the Universal Church of the Kingdom of God, stood in the middle of the congregation and shouted that prayers did not work for her and that she would eat everyone alive.

Earlier, she had asked a voluntary worker at the church whether she had any food.

Audrey Hartley-Martin gave Anna some biscuits which she repaid with a smile.

She added: "When mum came, the child put the biscuits in her pocket and jumped off my lap."

The following day Anna told the assistant pastor, Alvero Lima, that she used to have dreams where a vision of a snake would appear in front of her and tell her to do such things.

"She said it was satan," he said, adding: "Yes, I thought the child was possessed. She said she liked doing evil, she liked doing it."

The pastor told Kouao that he would pray and fast for the child who should be brought back the following Friday, February 25, to release the evil spirit.

But the day before the exorcism, Kouao phoned the church saying that Anna felt like a block of ice.

When the child was brought to the church, the pastor found that she was cold and wet and not speaking and he could not find a pulse.

He told Kouao and Manning that they must take Anna to hospital.

A taxi was called and told to take the family to Tottenham, but, seeing that the child was so ill, Kouao asked where the nearest hospital was and the driver dropped them off at a nearby ambulance station.

Anna was taken to North Middlesex hospital where her serious injuries and evidence of malnutrition were found.

Nurse Lesley Nelson, part of a three-person retrieval team which picked up Anna from North Middlesex hospital and took her to St Mary's in Paddington, said the condition of the child was "quite horrendous".

Her temperature was 27C, nine degrees below normal.

Despite extensive efforts by staff, Anna died early in the morning on February 25.

At last seeing clear evidence of abuse, police arrested Kouao at the hospital.

Manning was taken from the Tottenham flat where he immediately began confessing his role in the torture and eventual death of the child.

He admitted manslaughter and cruelty to a child - although he claimed he was responsible for just one third of her injuries - but his girlfriend defiantly denied any knowledge of how Anna came to be in her dreadful condition.

While in prison, the unremorseful Kouao told a pastor: "Anna caused trouble for me when she was alive, and now she is dead she is still causing trouble for me."

She also said: "Look what Anna has done to me.

After making me suffer, she has just died and I have suffered for nothing."

Stubborn to the end, Kouao did not tell police that Anna was not her daughter until confronted with DNA test results, and refused to give them details of her real identity.

Eventually officers traced Anna's family, who knew nothing of the trauma their little girl had had to live through.

They were told that a child was dead and that police were not sure if it was their daughter.

A family liaison officer who broke the news to the family and brought them to Britain said: "They were absolutely devastated but they wanted to do the identification. They wanted to be able to have knowledge of the injuries. They were shown post- mortem photographs of her injuries. This was a very difficult time for them. This was the first time they had been on an aeroplane or an escalator. They had no concept of the dangers of traffic."

But the horror was not at an end.

After they made a positive identification, the family could not take Anna's body home with them - Kouao refused to let them, saying she wanted to bury her herself.

It will be some time before Anna's body will be allowed to return home.

A coup in Ivory Coast has prevented her parents from coming to the UK to hear the jury's verdict and to take their daughter home.

Instead, Anna must wait a while more in a country that failed her terribly, a place which for this child proved less safe than her own trouble-torn country.
fields.bodyText: When Anna Climbie left the crumbling shacks of the sprawling shanty suburb of Abobo, Ivory Coast, in November 1997 she was "happy and excited". The child was leaving the muddy streets and crammed housing of the west African country and going to a new life with her aunt. The seven-year-old was being taken first to France and then to Britain for a better education and standard of living. She was saying goodbye to a country where the average life expectancy is around 45, where each family has six children and where only 40% of women over 15 are literate. To her mother and father, the move would bring a great honour on the family and eventually Anna might earn money and send some back to them. The Climbies had fallen on hard times and all nine of them had had to move in with a relative. But instead of honour the family found only grief. Anna did not even get to go to school. Just over a year after leaving Ivory Coast, Anna Climbie was dead at the age of eight. The victim of horrendous physical and emotional abuse, she was failed by all those who were bound up in her care. Her death, in February last year, was the worst case of child abuse the Home Office pathologist who examined her battered body had ever seen. Anna's last months were a savage existence. Instead of being at school and playing with other children she was bound hand and foot, naked, in a bathtub in a tiny flat in Tottenham in the middle of winter. Instead of being fed she was starved: what little food she was given were scraps, fed to her in the bath on a piece of plastic bag. Instead of being clothed, she was stuck in a black binbag which caught her excrement and trapped acids that burned her body. Instead of praise, Anna was told she was possessed by the devil. While her torturers were in the other room, Anna was left alone in the cold and dark in the unheated bathroom. They shut the door on her. Anna simply got in the way of her demented aunt, Marie Therese Kouao, 44 - a woman the Old Bailey was told was "evil" - and her busdriver boyfriend, Carl Manning, 28, whom she picked up on a number 18 bus in Wembley. Anna was not the meal ticket to social security benefits her aunt had first thought. She was just an inconvenience. Over the months Anna was beaten with a variety of weapons including belt buckles, bicycle chains, coat hangers and shoes; razor blades were taken to her fingers and a hammer to her toes. The child was burned with cigarettes and had boiling water poured over her head. She "stooped like an old woman" after being confined to the bath. After all this, she was dragged to a church to be exorcised because her aunt said she had evil spirits in her. And all the while those who should have been concerned with her welfare - doctors, police and social services - let Anna down. In spite of her being referred to social services on a number of occasions, no one ever checked on her properly. In spite of the marks on her body, the child was returned to Kouao because a doctor believed her story that Anna had scabies. And in spite of a senior doctor saying it was a case of child abuse, Anna went back to the Tottenham flat to become, as the same doctor said, "lost somewhere in Haringey". No one bothered to check. Two police protection orders were taken out on the girl in July 1999, but nothing was done. A social services strategy meeting decided a home visit should be conducted but it never took place. The social worker and police officer were too scared of catching scabies. Eventually, this small child - people remarked that she was half the size she should have been for her age - died from hypothermia due to exposure to cold and wet conditions. The underlying cause was severe neglect and malnutrition. The pathologist, Nathaniel Carey, found 128 marks on her body. He said: "This little girl was covered in scars, she had been bound, she was underweight and she had been maltreated in terms of personal hygiene. All cases of child abuse leading to death are pretty horrific but this one, in nature and extent of injury, is quite exceptional. " When Marie Therese Kouao came to Abobo to take Anna away from her brothers and sisters, everything looked grand. This woman - whom the family had only met on two previous occasions at funerals - seemed reasonably wealthy and said she had a good job in the aviation industry in Paris. She had just been promoted, she said, and would soon be moving to London. The widowed Kouao had three grown-up boys of her own and an adopted daughter. She would treat Anna like a daughter, ensuring her education. But the child, who was called Adjo Victoria in Ivory Coast, would have to change her name to Anna so she could carry the forged passport that had been made in the name of Anna Kouao. (The real Anna Kouao was supposed to come to the UK but her parents changed their minds and refused to let Kouao take the child from Ivory Coast. Police say she is lucky to be alive.) Anna was a bright girl who had been to kindergarten and had just started school where she was making good progress. In the witness box of the Old Bailey, Anna's mother, Berthe Amoissi Ehoura, stood composed, a handsome, dignified woman determined to bear testament to the memory of her child. She said of her daughter, the third youngest of seven: "She was very good with me and very easy with me. She had no illness as a child." Soon after arriving in France Kouao decided to move to London. She was being pursued over £2,000 in a suspected social security fraud. She told people she wanted to learn English. It was easy to get Anna, who Kouao said was her daughter, past British immigration authorities: Kouao was a French citizen and often children do not resemble passport photographs taken years or months before. After a short time staying with a relative, Kouao asked Ealing council to accommodate her in April 1998. The council told the woman and child that they should go back to her four-bedroomed house in France because they were intentionally homeless. Eventually she was found a room in a hostel in Harlesden. In May a social worker remarked that the child was poorly dressed in relation to her aunt. One family member was shocked to see the little girl wearing a ridiculous wig. On June 10, Kouao met Manning while he was driving his bus. The man described by his own QC as "a bit of a nerd" who lived with his mother and led "a lonely, boring life", and who had never had a girlfriend, gave the older woman his telephone number and she called the next day. He was impressed by this worldly woman who had boasted of being an air accident investigator and claimed to have studied at the "university of Oxford Street". Ten days later the pair slept together. Not long after, Esther Ackah, a distant relative of Kouao's, met Kouao, Manning and Anna in the street. Afterwards Mrs Ackah, a nurse, twice phoned Ealing social services to raise concerns about Anna's living conditions and her deteriorating health. She said she feared for the little girl's life. But still nothing was done. On July 6, Kouao and Anna moved into Manning's tiny flat in Tottenham. Things did not go smoothly and Manning became angry when Anna urinated and defecated around the flat. Panicking at the prospect of losing this new man or maybe his flat, Kouao tried to offload Anna on to a family who had done childminding for her in the past. The Camerons took Anna for the night and put her straight to bed. They were horrified the following morning when they saw that the child was covered in terrible injuries. Anna had cuts on her fingers, across her cheek and eyelid and unusual marks on her body which Avril Cameron suspected were cigarette burns. She took her to Central Middlesex hospital and was told Anna would only be released into safe hands. But in spite of all the marks on her body, Anna was discharged after an overnight stay because the child protection doctor, Ruby Schwartz, said she was satisfied that she was suffering from scabies. Dr Schwartz referred the case to social services because of concerns that the family appeared to be homeless and that Anna was not at school. Social workers called a strategy meeting but failed to do anything because Kouao and Anna had moved out of the area. Two weeks later Anna was in hospital again, this time with scalding to her head. Her aunt said the child had poured hot water over herself to relieve terrible itching caused by scabies. Instead of taking Anna to the health centre next to Manning's flat she walked the child 20 minutes to hospital, taking her there hours after the accident. Staff on Rainbow ward noticed that Anna's clothes were dirty and that she was wearing no underwear. One nurse remarked that she could not find a place on Anna's body that was not sore when she tried to lift her into a bath. In the two weeks she was there nurses noted that there was a "master and servant" relationship between Kouao and Anna. The child had shown signs of emotional abuse and anxious attachments and had poured a bottle of Hibiscrub over her head to ease her pain. One morning she ate five bowls of cereal "like a child who does not know where her next meal is coming from". But not once did she mention any abuse, leading staff to believe that this odd little girl had been coached not to say too much. She would jump out of bed and stand to attention when Kouao - whom she called mother - came into the hospital ward, saying things like "my mummy's a good mummy". Mary Anne Rossiter, a doctor who told the court that she had put in writing that she had no doubts this was child abuse, said: "I was aware that she came in an underclothed, dirty state in contrast to her very soignee, well-dressed mother." She said the marks on Anna looked likely to have been inflicted with deliberate force, including the imprint of a belt buckle. In spite of this, Anna was discharged on the authority of social services on August 6 while Dr Rossiter was on leave. She said: "We asked after her and were horrified to learn that she had in fact been discharged." In her letter to a social worker, Lisa Arthurworrey, she said: "I have enormous concerns about this child. I think this child may have been abused." Ms Arthurworrey was a member of Haringey's child protection team and, along with PC Karen Jones, saw Anna and believed Kouao when she repeated the scabies story, telling them that was what the other hospital had also said. Without speaking to doctors or examining Anna without clothes, they let her go - back to what would become ever intensifying torture. They did not visit the flat, fearing they might catch scabies. They were happy enough, however, to let the little girl go back to what they believed was an infested place. In court, these child protectors were criticised for their "blinding incompetence". For Anna, things were to get worse. By the end of October her tormentors began tying her up and throwing her in the bath. In his diary, Manning begins to refer to Anna as "satan". In one account, when he describes how after a row at New Year Kouao had run naked in the street after an argument, he wrote: "After a minute or so, she walked back to the flat in bare feet to release satan Anna from her rubbish bag." The child was dragged around to various churches in London which reinforced the belief that evil spirits were within her. Less than a week before her death, Anna was taken to the Universal Church of the Kingdom of God, stood in the middle of the congregation and shouted that prayers did not work for her and that she would eat everyone alive. Earlier, she had asked a voluntary worker at the church whether she had any food. Audrey Hartley-Martin gave Anna some biscuits which she repaid with a smile. She added: "When mum came, the child put the biscuits in her pocket and jumped off my lap." The following day Anna told the assistant pastor, Alvero Lima, that she used to have dreams where a vision of a snake would appear in front of her and tell her to do such things. "She said it was satan," he said, adding: "Yes, I thought the child was possessed. She said she liked doing evil, she liked doing it." The pastor told Kouao that he would pray and fast for the child who should be brought back the following Friday, February 25, to release the evil spirit. But the day before the exorcism, Kouao phoned the church saying that Anna felt like a block of ice. When the child was brought to the church, the pastor found that she was cold and wet and not speaking and he could not find a pulse. He told Kouao and Manning that they must take Anna to hospital. A taxi was called and told to take the family to Tottenham, but, seeing that the child was so ill, Kouao asked where the nearest hospital was and the driver dropped them off at a nearby ambulance station. Anna was taken to North Middlesex hospital where her serious injuries and evidence of malnutrition were found. Nurse Lesley Nelson, part of a three-person retrieval team which picked up Anna from North Middlesex hospital and took her to St Mary's in Paddington, said the condition of the child was "quite horrendous". Her temperature was 27C, nine degrees below normal. Despite extensive efforts by staff, Anna died early in the morning on February 25. At last seeing clear evidence of abuse, police arrested Kouao at the hospital. Manning was taken from the Tottenham flat where he immediately began confessing his role in the torture and eventual death of the child. He admitted manslaughter and cruelty to a child - although he claimed he was responsible for just one third of her injuries - but his girlfriend defiantly denied any knowledge of how Anna came to be in her dreadful condition. While in prison, the unremorseful Kouao told a pastor: "Anna caused trouble for me when she was alive, and now she is dead she is still causing trouble for me." She also said: "Look what Anna has done to me. After making me suffer, she has just died and I have suffered for nothing." Stubborn to the end, Kouao did not tell police that Anna was not her daughter until confronted with DNA test results, and refused to give them details of her real identity. Eventually officers traced Anna's family, who knew nothing of the trauma their little girl had had to live through. They were told that a child was dead and that police were not sure if it was their daughter. A family liaison officer who broke the news to the family and brought them to Britain said: "They were absolutely devastated but they wanted to do the identification. They wanted to be able to have knowledge of the injuries. They were shown post- mortem photographs of her injuries. This was a very difficult time for them. This was the first time they had been on an aeroplane or an escalator. They had no concept of the dangers of traffic." But the horror was not at an end. After they made a positive identification, the family could not take Anna's body home with them - Kouao refused to let them, saying she wanted to bury her herself. It will be some time before Anna's body will be allowed to return home. A coup in Ivory Coast has prevented her parents from coming to the UK to hear the jury's verdict and to take their daughter home. Instead, Anna must wait a while more in a country that failed her terribly, a place which for this child proved less safe than her own trouble-torn country.

fields.headline: Death after false cancer diagnosis
fields.trailText: A man who shot himself after being diagnosed with cancer was free of the disease, an inquest heard.
fields.body:
A man who shot himself after being diagnosed with cancer was free of the disease, an inquest heard.

Anthony Voller, 57, was found dead in the garden shed of his home in Chelmsford, Essex, two days before he was due to undergo surgery to remove a tumour.

At an inquest in Chelmsford last week, coroner Caroline Beasley-Murray heard that the autopsy had found no trace of the disease.

Last May, the retired technical officer was diagnosed with bowel cancer. In June doctors arranged for him to have an operation at Broomfield hospital, Chelmsford. He was found dead by his wife, Hilary, with a shotgun by his side. Police ruled out suspicious circumstances.

Nigel Richardson, Mr Voller's cancer consultant, insisted that there had been clear evidence of cancer when tests and a biopsy were carried out a month before Mr Voller's death. After examining the body during the autopsy, he admitted there was no sign of the disease.

Mr Voller's son Paul told the coroner that his father had never intended to take his own life.

Mrs Voller said yesterday: "He ended it all because he couldn't take it anymore. He was on the understanding that when he went into hospital they would find more things wrong with him and he would lose control of his own body."

A spokesman for Mid Essex Hospitals NHS Trust, responsible for Broomfield hospital, said it was unable to comment.

The inquest recorded an open verdict.

fields.headline: Crawling by in Middle England
fields.standfirst:
Many ticket collectors are too frightened to make their rounds

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The kind of price cuts being offered by Richard Branson's Virgin Rail - 50% on most tickets - are usually only given in two commercial circumstances. The first is when a powerful corporation is seeking to drive smaller rivals out of business: think of the cover-pricing policy of Rupert Murdoch's British newspapers, or the fare-slashing employed by British Airways at various times against Sir Richard's winged division. The second is as a desperation measure: a fire-sale before closing down, or a final attempt to create cash flow before the liquidators are called in.
fields.body:
The kind of price cuts being offered by Richard Branson's Virgin Rail - 50% on most tickets - are usually only given in two commercial circumstances. The first is when a powerful corporation is seeking to drive smaller rivals out of business: think of the cover-pricing policy of Rupert Murdoch's British newspapers, or the fare-slashing employed by British Airways at various times against Sir Richard's winged division. The second is as a desperation measure: a fire-sale before closing down, or a final attempt to create cash flow before the liquidators are called in.

Neither of these models is likely to apply to Virgin Rail. Branson's choo-choo business is in no position to bully rivals, for all railway companies have suffered the same catastrophic loss of customer confidence and income since the post-Hatfield speed limits and repair programme crashed into further trouble brought by the severe weather of the autumn. Nor, even for the gloomiest follower of British transport policy, is it plausible that the rail companies are liquidising their assets before shutting up shop. So what is remarkable about the Virgin bargain offers is that this is an example of a fire-sale of a daily necessity, a product which many of the consumers are forced to buy.

This shows how far the railways are now off-track. Branson, the cleverest businessman of his British generation, has shown typical cunning in suggesting that his price cuts have a moral force: an attempt to reverse the additional deaths on the roads which have resulted from the flight to air and motorway. But what he presents as an ecological rallying cry is a personal yell for help, which will soon have backing harmony from all his rivals.

I live in Middle England in a place served by the Virgin West Coast line, and so my perception of the crisis is far from theoretical. A journey which once took 40 minutes now regularly extends to two hours or even three. At many times, a single hourly service replaces the previous three or four within 60 minutes.

The only bonus for passengers is that carriages are often semi-empty (showing the flight of ticket-buyers to the roads) and that tickets are now infrequently collected, so that those planning to pay on-board travel, in reality, for free. A Virgin employee told me privately that many ticket-collectors are too frightened to make the rounds, because of the level of anger and resentment on these intermittent, late and snail-like trains.

On several days, I have driven to London instead, but the additional traffic has pushed the pre-rush hour lull on the M40 back from 6.30am to around 5am. We must trust Sir Richard when he says that his fare cutting was influenced by events on the roads, but it's possible that his attention was also drawn to the effect on a company's profits when half your passengers disappear and many of the remaining ones don't have to pay.

When supermarkets halved the price of beef at the height of the BSE crisis, the shelves were emptied. Branson and his rivals are hoping for a similar hike in demand for their own damaged goods. The risk, though, is that rail travel is not now price sensitive but experience sensitive.

There must be some sympathy for Virgin Rail and the others because of the irony that the loss of consumer confidence trains was caused not by the Hatfield crash but by the safety measures subsequently introduced. As an airline baron, Richard Branson knows that the public is generally sanguine about the trade-off between travel and safety. The airports were not empty the day after the Lockerbie or Long Island tragedies, nor did the pilots come on the intercom and announce that they would be flying very slowly today just in case. Most travellers just shrugged and played the statistics game, which keeps most of us going through the terrors of life.

There's every suggestion that rail users made the same accommodation with themselves after Hatfield, until Railtrack intervened with a scheme to allow commuters several extra hours to reflect on how unpleasant and potentially deadly trains might be. In a way which psychologists would perhaps understand better than PR companies, the safety measures have had the effect of making rail travel feel dangerous.

From the perspective of a cold, crowded, crawling carriage on the Virgin West Coast line, it seems to me that this daily abuse of the commuting population may yet have an impact on the general election. At the moment, few travellers seem to hold Tony Blair personally responsible for their missed meetings and truncated evenings, although a case can be made that the government contributed to the recent crashes by emphasising punctuality over safety and that the over-reaction of Railtrack in imposing the tortoise timetables was encouraged by the Blair administration's general culture of culprit-hunting.

Even so, the anger building up in the trains each day - the feeling of living in a failing and underfunded economy - must eventually have political impact, especially if the emergency timetables continue up to polling day. Blair's best defence is that William Hague, while looking quite like Mussolini in a certain light, would not be trusted by many to have Il Duce's fabled effect on the trains.

fields.headline: Community service for selling drug
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: A Rastafarian was yesterday sentenced to 150 hours of community service for possession of herbal cannabis with intent to supply, after a judge expressed "respect for the sincerity of his beliefs".
fields.body:
A Rastafarian was yesterday sentenced to 150 hours of community service for possession of herbal cannabis with intent to supply, after a judge expressed "respect for the sincerity of his beliefs".

Admitting that he was passing a lenient sentence at Inner London crown court, Judge Charles Gibson warned it was not a precedent.

Rasta Brown, 37, was arrested in June last year after selling herbal cannabis to an undercover police officer in Brixton, south London. He pleaded guilty to two counts of possession of the drug with intent to supply and one of possession.

But when he appeared for sentencing, Brown, of Stockwell, south London, applied to change his plea under the new Human Rights Act, which states everyone has the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion.

Judge Gibson dismissed the application, but said Brown believed cannabis ought not to be classified as a drug and was not a "regular, let alone professional dealer".

webTitle: Woman died after 9 hours on trolley

fields.headline: Woman died after 9 hours on trolley
fields.trailText: A woman died from pneumonia after nine hours on a hospital trolley because no beds were available, her mother said yesterday.
fields.body:
A woman died from pneumonia after nine hours on a hospital trolley because no beds were available, her mother said yesterday.

Brenda Marshall, 52, who was born with Down's syndrome and a hole in the heart, was taken by ambulance to the Medway Maritime hospital in Kent after losing consciousness last Friday.

Miss Marshall, who had been taking antibiotics for a chest infection, was not given treatment for 2 hours, her parents claim.

Her mother Bertha Limacher, 76, said they had arrived at the hospital at 6.45am. "It was 9am before we ended up in a cubicle. They took some of her blood and gave her oxygen. They then said they needed to take x-rays before they took us back to the accident and emergency department."

Mrs Limacher, from Minster, Kent, said her daughter had to endure a further 6 hours on a trolley before staff found her a bed. She died the next day.

"I think it is disgraceful - it is not really the hospital's fault, but the fault of the system," Mrs Limacher said.

The Medway NHS Trust's medical director, Alaisdair Stewart, said Miss Marshall's death was not the result of a delay in getting her a ward bed.

"The hospital was very busy with emergency admissions on Friday January 5. Unfortunately, this meant that Brenda had to be nursed in the A&E department until a bed could be allocated for her. The lady was very poorly. While in A&E Brenda received all the nursing and medical care that she would have received on a medical ward."

He said that in line with the hospital's practice, staff offered to transfer Miss Marshall to a bed in A&E but "her family expressly said they wanted her to remain on a trolley and we respected their wishes".

fields.headline: Farewell to a master craftsman
fields.standfirst: Michael Williams dies at 64
fields.trailText: The actor Michael Williams, a graceful and self-effacing master craftsman and "national treasure", has died aged 64.
fields.body:
The actor Michael Williams, a graceful and self-effacing master craftsman and "national treasure", has died aged 64.

Williams, husband for 30 years of the actor Dame Judi Dench, had lung cancer. He died at their home in Surrey 24 hours after receiving the Order of St Gregory, the Roman Catholic equivalent of a knighthood.

Dame Judi, who was at his bedside with their daughter Finty, said that after celebrating the honour he said: "It was one of the best days I've ever had - and could I have a match replay?"

It was the only official honour Williams received in his 42 years in the theatre. But he was admired as a pre-eminent light comedian and speaker of Shakespearean verse. Two cameo performances from the 1990s - as a soldier in Kenneth Branagh's film of Henry V, and as Horatio in the audio version of Branagh's Hamlet - are regarded as models of their kind.

"I never feel inferior to Judi," he once said. "My range is equal to hers - sometimes." His greatest regret was not having played Lear, but he blamed no one for this. "There are too many other bloody good actors around," he said.

He was best known for the TV sitcom A Fine Romance, with Dame Judi, along with September Song and Conjugal Rights.

His stage success began in the 1960s at the Royal Shakespeare Company. Its artistic director, Adrian Noble, said he was "one of the most gifted and versatile actors of his generation. He will be sadly missed by everyone with whom he worked - and by the public who, I think, held him in their affection as something of a national treasure."

In 1998 critics praised Williams as "a master craftsman" for his London stage performance as the diarist John Aubrey in Brief Lives. His final role was in last year's Radio 4 series, Bristow.

He sent his wife a red rose every Friday. When their home in Hampstead, north London, burned down in 1994, Dame Judi's sorrow was, he said, "somewhat assuaged when, picking over the debris, she came across my old love letters to her".

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Blair tomato charge dropped
fields.body:
Blair tomato charge dropped

The woman who hit Tony Blair with a tomato had a charge of causing criminal damage to his suit dropped when she appeared at Bristol magistrates yesterday.

Lynn-Marie Coles, 25, now faces a reduced charge of using threatening, abusive or insulting words when Mr Blair was pelted with fruit in Bristol on Tuesday.

Unhappy landing

An investigation was under way yesterday after a light aircraft made an unauthorised landing on the second runway at Manchester airport, which is not due to open until next month.

The Ravenair PA 34 Seneca air taxi had no passengers when it landed on Thursday. A Ravenair spokesman said the pilot had made a mistake.

Lecturer cleared of rape

A lecturer at Salford University accused of raping a trainee teacher after a night out to celebrate his birthday, was yesterday found not guilty at Manchester crown court.

Order placed on bullies

Two boys who strung up a boy of nine and set him alight in a bullying frenzy were yesterday given two-year supervision orders at Bristol crown court after they admitted causing actual bodily harm.

  • This article was amended on 17 June 2019 to remove some personal information.

webTitle: Papers start taking up poll positions

fields.headline: Papers start taking up poll positions
fields.standfirst:
Europe and the media
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Forget the fact that poor David Frost was photographed on the beach in his swimming trunks looking, well, a little paunchy. Doubtless he did not summon the photographers.
fields.body:
Forget the fact that poor David Frost was photographed on the beach in his swimming trunks looking, well, a little paunchy. Doubtless he did not summon the photographers.

But he was still the major influence on the political week. The prime minister was talking to Frost as though the poll was just around the corner. The election had begun. And every day feels like just another in what will be, by my calculations, a 116-day campaign.

So in our regular consideration of how the newspapers are reflecting the debate over Europe, we have to start asking whether Europe is a central election issue, and, if so, how it is being treated in the press. The press cannot be blamed for the politicians wanting to play it down, and this week they have set an agenda of, variously, tax, crime (or mobile phone theft!) and hospital waiting lists. But Europe, too, has been there.

The Mail and its Eurosceptic ally the Daily Telegraph were the only papers to give prominent treatment to the view of Sir John Weston, former British ambassador to Nato, that the proposed European rapid reaction force could lead to the break-up of Nato.

But the Telegraph demonstrated its desire to present both sides of the debate by running an article by the TUC general secretary, John Monks.

He accepted that some Labour strategists wanted as low a profile as possible for the euro during the election, while the Conservatives wanted it to feature strongly as a vote-winner. Monks thought both were wrong. Eurosceptics were already committed to the Tories and most convinced Europeans had already decided to vote Labour or Lib Dem. For the remainder it would "not be much of an issue among the voters who will decide the election".

The Daily Mirror, dedicated supporter of New Labour, told us baldly that "the euro's on its way". What was needed, said the Mirror editorial, was a sensible campaign to explain the benefits of being in the single currency. And it needed to come from the government and business.

According the the Independent, but no one else, Tony Blair had been cuddling up to the owner of the Mirror's great rival, the Sun. The prime minister had "assured Rupert Murdoch that he would not call a snap referendum on the single currency shortly after the general election". The intention, said the Independent, was to persuade Murdoch to ensure the Sun told its readers to vote Labour at the election, as it did last time.

The Guardian reported that a Treasury report on Britain's position on meeting the criteria for joining the euro showed the UK was strongly on course. But it noted that the Treasury had not publicised the report, fuelling the belief that Gordon Brown was "intent on suppressing a debate about the prospects of British entry".

One columnist does not want an election this year at all. Peter Preston, writing in the Guardian, thought the spring election would mean Europe was not much discussed.

"Could we have an election where, willy-nilly, there had to be a hard-edged debate about the single currency? Absolutely: in April 2002, when the euro is coins and notes, not a paper calculation, when every voter going to Spain for Easter week has to pay for tapas with euros changed at Thomas Cook's."

By my calculation that would mean a 475-day election campaign.

Peter Cole is professor of journalism at Sheffield University

webTitle: Election countdown: Bruno claims blue corner against Bell

fields.headline: Bruno claims blue corner against Bell
fields.trailText: In publicity terms, it looks set to be a heavyweight contest, with an ex-boxing world champion pitted against a sleaze-fighting, sniper-dodging former war correspondent.
fields.body:
In publicity terms, it looks set to be a heavyweight contest, with an ex-boxing world champion pitted against a sleaze-fighting, sniper-dodging former war correspondent.

Yesterday, the bookies were already giving odds as Frank Bruno, the one-time world heavyweight boxer-turned-pantomime-favourite, announced he would stand as a Tory candidate against Martin Bell, the BBC hero-turned-independent MP, in the fight for Brentwood and Ongar.

His claim, made to reporters before he appeared in Goldilocks at the Milton Keynes Theatre, came after he told BBC Radio Essex he was considering standing, and was something of a surprise to Conservative central office, which has its own candidate for its sixth safest seat - Eric Pickles, the incumbent MP.

Last night, Mr Pickles - whose nomination paper was signed by the boxer in a flurry of publicity before the last election - was bemused by the apparent back-stabbing, which local Tories assigned to the MP's failure to ensure a local building was bought by a charity Bruno supports. Instead it was sold by the local party chairman to an evangelical church in a move which has riven the association.

"I've absolutely no idea why he's doing this but there's a world of distance between getting applause at the pantomime and at the hustings," Mr Pickles said.

A Tory party spokesman said the former WBC world heavyweight champion would have to stand as an independent, a move which could split the disillusioned Tory vote further. Mr Bell, who rode to victory in Tatton in 1997 on an anti-sleaze ticket after beating the Tory former minister Neil Hamilton, decided to stand for the Essex constituency only after pleas from a breakaway Tory group concerned by their local association's links with the Peniel Pentecostal Church.

The white-suited Mr Bell, who has admitted he is addicted to politics, insisted he was "relaxed" about the new competition. "I have a great admiration for Frank and if he wants to stand that's up to him," he said. "I think politics needs more people in it who have had careers in other things."

While Bruno's sense of political protocol may be somewhat shaky, the 39-year-old - who has forged a successful career in showbusiness after retiring from boxing four years ago - already has three qualities that could help in Westminster: a love of performing, a certain wit, and aggression.

But, though he came out in support of John Major for the last election, he is likely to be dismissed as a joke candidate. As he admitted, when attending a Tory winter ball two years ago, politics is not really a passion. "I'm not into party politics," he confessed. "I'm here for a good night and the free drinks."

webTitle: The village next to the DU test range

fields.headline: The village next to the DU test range
fields.standfirst:
After 17-year campaign, Scottish community demands public inquiry and health screening

Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: After 17-year campaign, Scottish community demands public inquiry and health screening.
fields.body:
When Dan Kenny sneaked a look inside the military truck that stopped in the small Dumfriesshire village of Dundrennan in November 1983 he had no idea the contents would change his life.

The vehicle carried radiation warning signs and was filled with containers marked "wartime use only". Concerned, Mr Kenny contacted his MP and discovered that what he had seen were depleted uranium munitions bound for the nearby Dundrennan military testing range.

Since 1982 more than 6,000 DU shells have been fired from the range at the south-western tip of Scotland into the Solway Firth. Most of the shells, some 20 tonnes worth, are still lying on the seabed. Only one has been retrieved.

The testing is carried out by the defence evaluation and research agency and is due to stop this October. The agency says it is done under strictly controlled conditions and a comprehensive monitoring programme launched in 1983 has shown only very low levels of DU contamination at the base, well below anything that could be considered a health hazard.

But local people tell a different story. They say there have been misfirings on the remote 4,500-acre range. Some claim the site is littered with unexploded ordnance; that there has been a strange red dust on the road that borders the base; that a quartermaster died of leukaemia.

There are reports of traces of beryllium, a component of depleted uranium, being found 30 miles away from Dundrennan; and in 1995 an independent report recommended that special monitors were set up outside the base, something locals say has not been done.

Mr Kenny is 80. A wartime bomb disposal officer and retired oil executive, he now devotes his time to discovering the truth about DU and its effect on the community.

"The local people have always believed me, but the rest saw me as an eccentric old man with a particularly irritating bee in his bonnet," he said.

"It has taken 17 years out of my retirement and I was intending to go fishing every day. Now my study is full of documents and I rarely have time to do anything else."

Mr Kenny wants a full public inquiry into the DU testing and a comprehensive independent health screening programme for local people.

Local politicians have called for the testing to stop, and on Thursday, Malcolm Hooper, of the Gulf war illnesses inter-parliamentary group, said he was concerned about the impact of the manufacture and testing of the DU munitions.

"I don't want to scaremonger but I think there is a real risk - it's unquantifiable and if I lived in such an area where there was production or firing, I would be worried," Professor Hooper said.

Officials at the Military Toxics Project, an American environmental pressure group that monitors sites across the US where DU weapons are manufactured and tested, say Mr Kenny is right to be worried.

"The local community should be concerned," said MTP national organiser, Tara Thornton. "There are areas here in the US where we work with communities that live around the proving grounds and the manufacturing sites and we have seen increased rates of cancer in these areas. The big problem is that the proper health studies have not been done. There needs to be much more in-depth health studies done in these areas."

Mr Kenny claims to know of a cluster of cancers in the area around Dundrennan, but local health officials who have checked leukaemia rates say there is nothing of statistical significance.

David Breen, consultant in public medicine for Dumfries and Galloway health board, said statistics from 1980 to 1997 showed no evidence of a high risk of leukaemia in children living near the range. Dr Breen has asked the Scottish cancer surveillance unit to update the figures to include 1998, and they will be made public in the next few days. "If there is an excess I would be worried, but at the moment there isn't," he said.

Meanwhile, environmentalists say efforts must be made to recover the DU shells littering the seabed in the Solway Firth. The area is rich in shellfish and there have been reports of fishermen picking up DU shells in their nets.

"If there are particles of DU floating about then the shellfish will ingest them and there is a clear route by which people could be affected," said Dr Richard Dixon of Friends of the Earth. "We now have a strong suspicion that our service people have been affected by this stuff. That is as close as you get to a smoking gun.

"Our view is that in the end the MoD will have to admit defeat and retrieve as much of this stuff as possible. We are only going to get more concerned about DU."

Mr Kenny has always been worried. But he feels no vindication that others now share his fears.

"I'm just very angry it has taken so long. I don't give a damn about people my age. It's the future generations that concern me. We need to get this sorted out for their sake."

fields.headline: Alternative to MMR jab 'not safe'
fields.trailText: Separate doses of measles, mumps and rubella vaccines are not a safe alternative to the combined MMR jab, which some parents have shunned because of scares over alleged links to autism and bowel disease, government and independent scientists said yesterday.
fields.body:
Separate doses of measles, mumps and rubella vaccines are not a safe alternative to the combined MMR jab, which some parents have shunned because of scares over alleged links to autism and bowel disease, government and independent scientists said yesterday.

The heads of the independent Joint Committee on Immunisation and Vaccination (JCVI) and the Committee on the Safety of Medicines, as well as the government's head of immunisation, came together to warn that obtaining individual vaccinations for the three diseases involves delay, which exposes children to the real and increasing risk of infection. Last week the government said that low rates of immunisation could shortly lead to a fatal measles outbreak, as it did last year in Ireland, where there were two deaths, and the Netherlands, where there were three.

Michael Langman, head of the JCVI, said there were also worries about some of the individual vaccines available in other European countries. Some parents in Britain have gone abroad for supplies of separate vaccines because of the MMR scare.

"The mumps vaccine in France is the Urabe vaccine, which is one we have abandoned in the UK because of a distinct, though small, risk of meningitis," he said. He added that there were doubts about the efficacy of the measles vaccine used in Switzerland and that high potency measles vaccines used in the past had been withdrawn by the World Health Organisation. The main measles vaccine used in Europe is, however, the same one used in the MMR jab.

The government has banned individual vaccines from the NHS, but some private clinics have imported supplies.

The scientists cited Japan as proof that single vaccinations do not protect the population as well as the combined MMR. In Japan, which has single measles and rubella injections, there were 79 deaths from measles between 1992 and 1997. There have been no deaths in Britain since 1990.

The two committees had again reviewed the safety data for the MMR vaccination, the scientists said, and concluded that the combined jab was the safest way to protect children.

They cited a 14-year follow-up study of children immunised with MMR in Finland, released last month, which found only 173 potentially serious reactions in 1.8m children vaccinated. Nearly half those reactions were probably caused by other things. The most serious were cases of encephalitis, of which there were three.

The authors of the study say they found "no cases of inflammatory bowel disease or autism" linked to MMR.

"This finding is important because were there an association with MMR vaccination after such a short interval as suggested, this prospective study design would undoubtedly have disclosed at least some cases," they write in the Paediatric Infectious Diseases Journal.

The scientists were mounting a pre-emptive strike ahead of a further study to be published by Andrew Wakefield of the Royal Free hospital in London. Dr Wakefield first suggested a link between MMR, bowel disease and autism in a paper which caused uproar when it was published in the Lancet in February 1998.

Dr Wakefield's next paper is expected to question the clinical trials that were carried out to ensure the safety and efficacy of the combined MMR before it was licensed in 1972. He is expected to claim that the trials were inadequate, the follow-up data was collected over too short a period and that the vaccines can interact.

Alasdair Breckenridge, chairman of the Committee on the Safety of Medicines, insisted there was sufficient evidence of MMR's safety available in 1972, and that there was far more evidence now that more than 500m doses have been given to children worldwide.

David Salisbury, head of immunisation at the Department of Health, said officials were concerned about further scare stories. "This would be a really unfortunate time to have coverage go down when we really need to be working our hardest to get coverage up," he said.

"This finding is important because were there an association with MMR vaccination after such a short interval as suggested, this prospective study design would undoubtedly have disclosed at least some cases," they write in the Paediatric Infectious Diseases Journal. The scientists were mounting a pre-emptive strike ahead of a further study to be published by Andrew Wakefield of the Royal Free hospital in London. Dr Wakefield first suggested a link between MMR, bowel disease and autism in a paper which caused uproar when it was published in the Lancet in February 1998. Dr Wakefield's next paper is expected to question the clinical trials that were carried out to ensure the safety and efficacy of the combined MMR before it was licensed in 1972. He is expected to claim that the trials were inadequate, the follow-up data was collected over too short a period and that the vaccines can interact. Alasdair Breckenridge, chairman of the Committee on the Safety of Medicines, insisted there was sufficient evidence of MMR's safety available in 1972, and that there was far more evidence now that more than 500m doses have been given to children worldwide. David Salisbury, head of immunisation at the Department of Health, said officials were concerned about further scare stories. "This would be a really unfortunate time to have coverage go down when we really need to be working our hardest to get coverage up," he said.

fields.headline: Risks 'hard to avoid in battle'
fields.standfirst: Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: Exposure to depleted uranium used in anti-tank shells could pose an increased risk of cancer which would be difficult to protect against in battlefield conditions, according to an internal US army document seen by the Guardian.
fields.body:
Exposure to depleted uranium used in anti-tank shells could pose an increased risk of cancer which would be difficult to protect against in battlefield conditions, according to an internal US army document seen by the Guardian.

The document, drawn up by the US army surgeon general's office in 1993, two years after the Gulf war, raises questions about assurances given by the Ministry of Defence this week.

"When soldiers inhale or ingest DU dust, they incur a potential increase in cancer risk," the US document says. After referring to recommended limits for exposure in peacetime, it adds: "There are no comparable limits for wartime."

It says that "expected physiological effects from exposure to DU dust include possible increased risk of cancer (lung and bone) and kidney damage". The author of the report, a US medical corps colonel, goes on: "I expect the latter to be highly unlikely for most battlefield scenarios."

The report - which called for further research - conflicts with advice now given by the MoD. The MoD has repeatedly focused on contami nation from soluble DU which, it says, could easily be excreted through the kidneys, while playing down the risk of cancer from insoluble DU dust.

An MoD report dated 1997 and leaked this week stated that exposure to uranium dust "has been shown to increase the risks of developing lung, lymph and brain cancers".

The ministry said that while that report was mainly accurate, it contained significant errors, including the references to cancer risks. It initially said it was the work of a "trainee", but later admitted it had been drawn up by an "experienced military officer".

Shaun Rusling, of the Gulf War Veterans and Families Association, yesterday called on the MoD to release the full report on which the leaked ministry document was based.

webTitle: Bush's choice linked to 'guns for pupils' group

fields.headline: Bush's choice linked to 'guns for pupils' group
fields.standfirst:
Special report: George W Bush's America
Special report: gun violence in America
fields.trailText: George W Bush's nominee to be the next US attorney general has been linked to an extremist pro-gun lobbying group which believes that the answer to America's school shootings is to allow pupils to be armed in the classroom.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle in Washington and Jane Martinson in New York
fields.body:
George W Bush's nominee to be the next US attorney general has been linked to an extremist pro-gun lobbying group which believes that the answer to America's school shootings is to allow pupils to be armed in the classroom.

The revelation that former senator John Ashcroft has recent links with the militant Gun Owners of America (GOA) group is the latest twist in an increasingly impassioned partisan battle over a nomination which has become a major trial of political strength for Mr Bush.

Even many conservatives consider the GOA to be extremist. After a shooting at an Oregon school in May 1998 in which two pupils were killed by a fellow student, it issued a press release headed: "Lesson of school shootings: More guns needed at schools".

Its director, Larry Pratt, was forced to resign as co-chairman of Pat Buchanan's 1996 presidential bid after news leaked of his links with the Ku Klux Klan, the Aryan Nations and rightwing militia groups. Mr Pratt is also head of an anti-immigrant organisation called English First.

It emerged yesterday that Mr Ashcroft wrote a friendly handwritten letter in March 1998 to Mr Pratt, thanking him for drawing his attention to provisions in a juvenile justice bill which imposed increased penalties for gun law offences. As a result of the GOA's lobbying, Mr Ashcroft, who had originally been a sponsor of the bill, withdrew his support for the legislation.

The letter was sent on Senate notepaper and was addressed "Dear Larry" and signed "Thanks! John".

This is not the only known link between Mr Ashcroft and Mr Pratt. The two men know each another from a secretive but highly influential rightwing religious group called the Council for National Policy, of which Mr Pratt is a member and whose meetings Mr Ashcroft has attended. The CNP's membership is almost a who's who of US conservatism and includes the Republican congressional leaders Senator Trent Lott and Congressman Tom DeLay.

The revelation of the link with Mr Pratt came as two other allegations about Mr Ashcroft's extreme rightwing links also surfaced.

In the first, it was confirmed that Mr Ashcroft took time off from his bitter senatorial contest last September to meet Thomas Bugel, the president of the St Louis chapter of the Council of Conservative Citizens, to discuss the case of a CCC member, Charles Sell, jailed by federal authorities on charges of conspiring to murder an FBI agent.

The CCC is the successor organisation of the Citizens Council, which led the fight against integration in the South in the 1950s and 60s. The CCC, whose supporters also include Senator Lott and Senator Jesse Helms, opposes interracial marriage and non-white immigration, and believes black people are genetically less intelligent than whites. It is currently mobilising to try to defeat a statewide referendum in Mississippi in April to remove the Confederate flag from the state flag.

Meanwhile, the ultra-conservative Bob Jones University in South Carolina confirmed that it possessed a transcript of reportedly inflammatory remarks made by Mr Ashcroft in a May 1999 speech there. The Senate judiciary committee, where Mr Ashcroft faces confirmation hearings next week, had asked the university to supply a transcript, after rumours surfaced about the speech.

Bob Jones University, whose graduates include the Rev Ian Paisley, was at the centre of a political storm last year when Mr Bush made a speech there to rally conservative support for his presidential bid after he lost the New Hampshire primary to John McCain. The university had a ban on inter-racial dating and supports a doctrinaire anti-Catholic view of the world.

Mr Ashcroft's nomination has become the latest flashpoint of America's political culture wars, with both sides preparing for a major confrontation next week. On Thursday, Mr Bush urged Mr Ashcroft's opponents to "tone down their rhetoric".

Mr Ashcroft spent yesterday trying to shore up support among moderate Republican senators who support abortion rights, an issue he strongly opposes.

fields.headline: Monkeying about
fields.trailText: If the rhesus monkey really is "so similar" to human beings (ANDi, first GM primate. Will humans be next? January 12), then shouldn't we resist experimenting on it for the same reasons we resist experimenting on human beings?
fields.body:
If the rhesus monkey really is "so similar" to human beings (ANDi, first GM primate. Will humans be next? January 12), then shouldn't we resist experimenting on it for the same reasons we resist experimenting on human beings? And if it's dissimilar enough for us not to have such ethical qualms, then why are we experimenting on it at all?
Prof Andrew Dobson
Keele University

 So "we are only a few steps away from testing on monkeys" (Protein find raises hopes for HIV drugs, January 12). What an evil and arrogant species we humans are.
Derek Gillard
Oxford

 I note that the rebranded Post Office logo (Letters, January 12) looks like nothing so much as the water disappearing down the plug hole. Perhaps that is the image that they want to project.
RW Hyde
New Romney, Kent

 Mrs Jones and the rest of her village neighbours will need some reassuring from "Consignia Pat" on his next delivery.
Eddie Connery
Dawlish, Devon

 So Julie Burchill has made it into Who's Who (Diary January 11) and list's her interests as sex and shopping. Is this the same Julie Burchill who writes (Never mind the gap, G2, January 11) that "the final straw that put me off both my husbands was that they wanted to have sex with me, night and day". I bet she's better at shopping.
David Stewart
Mansfield, Notts

 Araucaria may be the Tiger Woods of crossword-writing, but has he ever produced a better clue (January 11) than "Poetical scene with surprisingly chaste Lord Archer vegetating (3,3,8,12)"? (Answer: The Old Vicarage, Grantchester)
Dr Nicholas Smith
Oxford

fields.headline: Ben's line
fields.trailText: Twice last week you reported that I was to attend George W Bush's inaugural gala (About turn as Ben Elton sings a welcome to Bush, January 10). I have not accepted any invitation to attend the gala nor has one been offered to be me.
fields.body:
Twice last week you reported that I was to attend George W Bush's inaugural gala (About turn as Ben Elton sings a welcome to Bush, January 10). I have not accepted any invitation to attend the gala nor has one been offered to be me. Andrew Lloyd Webber has been asked to contribute a song from The Beautiful Game, the new musical that he and I wrote together.

My sole involvement with the event is that I have agreed for my lyric to be used. I am extremely proud that this all-British musical has been selected for inclusion in such a uniquely American event but that does not make me a Republican supporter. The theme of The Beautiful Game is that of peace and reconciliation, sentiments which people of all political persuasions should be encouraged to consider.
Ben Elton

fields.headline: Senior nurses defend HIV trainees
fields.trailText: The Royal College of Nursing has criticised the government for planning to revise admission procedures for foreign trainee nurses after a health authority said some African trainees were HIV positive.
fields.body:
The Royal College of Nursing has criticised the government for planning to revise admission procedures for foreign trainee nurses after a health authority said some African trainees were HIV positive.

The Department of Health stressed there was no risk to the public from Wolverhampton's decision to employ five to 10 men and women nurses infected with HIV. But a spokesman suggested tests for HIV should come at the earliest possible stage of the admission process.

The Royal College of Nursing said the government was treading difficult ground as it was illegal in Britain to test for HIV unless an individual consented.

The trainees, from sub-Saharan Africa, including Zimbabwe, are working at the city's New Cross hospital or completing a three-year nursing course at Wolverhampton University. After training they will work in British hospitals and are not obliged to tell patients or colleagues they have the virus.

Jane Eminson, chief executive of Wolverhampton health authority, said the nurses conformed to NHS guidelines on the employment of HIV staff, and were part of a number of NHS staff with the virus across Britain. They did not take part in procedures where there was a risk of patient tissue being exposed to their blood.

Ms Eminson said Wolverhampton's intake of HIV positive nurses from Africa had increased in the past three months.

A Department of Health spokeswoman said: "We must be clear that this is not part of the NHS's international recruitment campaign. The NHS is not actively recruiting from developing countries such as Zimbabwe."

She added: "It is unusual to have such a group of HIV positive students from one country at one school of nursing, and the government will be reviewing the way in which nursing schools admit overseas student nurses."

The spokeswoman said trainee nurses from countries with a high prevalence of tuberculosis were screened for TB in a test which indicated whether they should also be screened for HIV. The department suggested HIV tests should come at the earliest stage.

A RCN spokeswoman said: "Foreign trainee nurses receive the same occupational health testing as UK trainees and we would like to see that continued. If admission procedures for foreign trainees are reviewed, we would want to know why one set of standards is being set for foreign trainees and another for British."

Derek Bodell, chief executive of the National Aids Trust, said: "Given everything we know about how difficult it is for HIV to be transmitted, the public does not have a right to know if someone is HIV positive except under the most unusual circumstances."

fields.headline: No website, no worries
fields.trailText: Paul Burstow MP proudly observes (Letters, January 12) that 23 out of 47 Liberal Democrat MPs have web sites. I am pleased to add to this survey that Martin Bell MP, whom I serve as adviser, has no website
fields.body:
Paul Burstow MP proudly observes (Letters, January 12) that 23 out of 47 Liberal Democrat MPs have web sites. I am pleased to add to this survey that Martin Bell MP, whom I serve as adviser, has no website, never will have a website and is indeed the only party represented at Westminster to be in this position. When asked for his opinions he either utters them or writes them down.

As his hero G K Chesterton observed of an earlier time of technological enthusiasms, "Certainly we would sacrifice all our wires, wheels systems, specialities, physical science and frenzied finance for one half-hour of happiness such as has often come to us with comrades in a common tavern" (What's Wrong With the World, 1910).
Oliver Kamm
London

 I couldn't help noticing that Paul Burstow's website is to be found under the URL "www.paulburstow.com". Isn't "com" short for "commercial"?
Marcel Marre
Southampton M.Marre@maths.soton.ac.uk

 I note that 23 out of 47 Lib Dem MPs and 40% of the UK's MEPs have websites. Does this not merely confirm the view that these two groups have nothing very important to do with their time?
Irene Noble
Edinburgh

 Guardian Online's estimate of only one in six MPs with websites is wrong - in addition to personal websites, over 300 MPs have signed up for websites with www.epolitix.com (The House Magazine Webminster project) most of which also offer email contact to MPs
Monica Masson
MASSONM@parliament.uk
