webTitle: Letters: Trustees still at war over aid charity

fields.headline: Trustees still at war over aid charity
fields.trailText: Your reference to me in the War Child story is misleading (Stars quit charity in corruption scandal, January 10).
fields.body:
Your reference to me in the War Child story is misleading (Stars quit charity in corruption scandal, January 10). I am not director of music at the Pavarotti Centre. This is a post I held for a year from September 1997. Otherwise I have worked as an unpaid volunteer. Your "quote" is lifted from one of several letters I wrote in the strictest confidence to the directors and trustees of War Child in early 1997.

I indeed demanded the strongest action to deal with financial "gift" from the Hidrogradnja construction company. But in the same letter I defended Bill Leeson, whom you use my words to malign. I continued to collaborate with War Child, because the work with children was essential and effective, and because the money was paid back to the company.

Your readership should not jump to hasty conclusions about "missing money" owed to the Pavarotti Centre. I shall be delighted if it exists, but we should wait for a proper audit from the charity commissioners. My fear is that the Guardian, Channel 4 and the "stars" may be more the innocent stooges of internecine warfare than champions of truth and the public interest.
Prof Nigel Osborne
Edinburgh

 Chief charity commissioner, John Stoker, says (Letters, January 11) that the commission has worked with trustees to resolve War Child's difficulties without a statutory inquiry.

When the then trustees in June 1996 sought the commission's help over similar difficulties, they did so in vain. It is therefore totally inaccurate of John Stoker to claim that the commission's involvement was "intensive from the start". With the admission of the present trustees that money has gone astray, is John Stoker really satisfied that all that has transpired can he set aside without a statutory inquiry?
Liz Huhne, Berry Ritchie
Ex-trustees, War Child

 The issue in the War Child case has been the suggestion that funds were spent on activities other than those which the patrons who helped to raise them would have wished. Neither the charity nor the commission has evidence indicating that funds went astray in any other sense than this, particularly in the sense that they were unlawfully applied or remained unaccounted for.

As for the commission's capacity to give advice (MPs call for law change over charity cash scandal, January 11), last year NOP carried out our first customer survey, based on a sample of 600 charities which had dealings with us (including some we investigated). Overall, 83% considered that the commission had done a fairly or very good job.
John Stoker
Chief charity commissioner

fields.headline: Junior brief
fields.body:
For two years John Spellar, the armed forces minister, supported my prosecution under the Official Secrets Act. It failed. In that case the evidence was provided by what he calls two junior officers. Now he has dismissed the letter written in 1997 warning of the hazards of depleted uranium as being by a junior officer and not reliable (MoD knew shells were cancer risk, January 11). Can we believe anything he says, or is he a marionette for the civil servants in the MoD who want to keep accountability out of their department?
Nigel Wylde
Esher, Surrey Nigel.Wylde@btinternet.com

webTitle: Letters: The shady side of Eminem

fields.headline: The shady side of Eminem
fields.trailText: Many of Joan Smith's comments on Eminem (Outpourings of rage, January 10) are well taken.
fields.body:
Many of Joan Smith's comments on Eminem (Outpourings of rage, January 10) are well taken. True his authenticity comes from the presumption that his lyrics and exploits represent the anger of America's white underclass.

Like Smith I have been dismayed by his overt homophobia, racism and misogyny. Yet how are we to account for his success amongst young people? Is it really, as Smith suggests, that his fame is the product of middle-class voyeurism enjoying the turmoils of working-class angst? I would suggest not.

In a society that remains deeply divided by race, class and sex, Eminem is a more contradictory phenomenon. The single, Stan, which topped the charts at Christmas ends with the suggestion that the letter writer learns to "treat his girlfriend better". The previous single, The Way I Am, deals with the complex relationship between the media, image construction and the public. It is Eminem's reflexivity about the projection of his own image rather than his championing of misogyny that best accounts for his success.

It is not that we are asked to celebrate Eminem's destructiveness, rather we are being asked to try and understand it. Eminem's success comes from his undoubted intelligence and his ability to embody some of the contradictions of contemporary culture in a way that is often missing from the suburban niceness of the All Saints and the Spice Girls.

Eminem is allowing young people to explore a dangerous and sometimes poisonous urban culture.
Dr Nick Stevenson
University of Sheffield

 In her middle-aged rant, Joan Smith says "liberal critics throw up their hands in horror when black men produce this stuff but roll over when a white kid gets in on the act". Surely the whole point is that liberal critics have traditionally let black American rappers off the hook because what they're saying is authentic, while Eminem only achieved respectability among the palefaced cognoscenti through his association with a respected black producer, Dr Dre.

The hip hop that's coming out of the US (Eminem included) makes British pop music look bloodless indeed. It's better to say something real, no matter how unpalatable to the likes of Ms Smith, than say nothing at all.
Andrew Collins
London acol@dial.pipex.com

 Charlotte Raven (On why Britney should be banned, not Eminem, G2, January 9) missed an important point in her comparison. Although there may be much unjustified "moral outrage" at the wit of Eminem's lyrics, there has been little of the same about Ms Spears's video and musical pantheon. Whatever argument can be made about Eminem's so-called misogyny pales into insignificance compared to the image of Ms Spears, at the tender age of 17, dressed provocatively in fantasy schoolgirl outfit, pleading that her boyfriend "hit me baby one more time".
Andy Hunter
Hull

 I have long been wondering why Eminem garners so much unworthy praise in the media. I even borrowed Eminem's CD, just to give it a fair go. It is the worst, juvenile garbage I've heard in years, if not ever. Eminem's success is derives from old-fashioned shock value, and that is where any similarity with punk ends.

As for Britney Spears, vacuous fluff as she may be, she does not pretend to be a politically aware, critic of society. All 15-year-olds girl would like to have big breasts; that someone gets them surgically is hardly a reason for drawing Britney as the devil.
Eleanor Deakin
Newcastle-upon-Tyne
mailto:edeakin@mac.com

webTitle: Fear of attack triggers arms build-up

fields.headline: Fear of attack triggers arms build-up
fields.standfirst:
Rogue states and terrorist threats identified in attempt to boost spending

Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: Rogue states and terrorist threats identified in attempt to boost spending.
fields.body:
The US has invoked the spectre of a devastating chemical weapons attack by the international terrorist Osama bin Laden to help justify a massive expansion of America's military forces, including the deployment of a "Star Wars" National Missile Defence (NMD) system.

The threat posed by the spread of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons of mass destruction to "rogue" states and terrorists is identified by a Pentagon report, as the biggest challenge to American and global security since the end of the Cold War.

This assessment, strongly supported by President-elect George W Bush's nominee as defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, Vice President-elect Dick Cheney, and by Republican hawks in Congress, now looks certain to be the springboard for a big new defence build-up under the Bush administration that takes office a week from today (jan 20).

"At least 25 countries now possess - or are in the process of acquiring and developing - capabilities to inflict mass casualties and destruction," said William Cohen, the current US defence secretary and former Republican senator, in a foreword to the Pentagon report.

"Our unrivalled supremacy in the conventional military arena is prompting adversaries to seek unconventional, asymmetric means to strike what they perceive as our Achilles heel," Mr Cohen said.

He singled out North Korea, Iran, Iraq and Libya as countries whose missile-building programmes and attempts to acquire nuclear, chemical or biological weapons posed the most pressing threats to US and international security.

"Also looming on the horizon is the prospect that terror weapons will increasingly find their way into the hands of individuals and groups of fanatical terrorists or self-proclaimed apocalyptic prophets. The followers of Osama bin Laden have in fact already trained with toxic chemicals," Mr Cohen claimed.

President-elect George W Bush pledged during last year's election campaign to boost Pentagon spending by $45bn over the next decade and spend up to $70bn on space and submarine-based defensive missiles.

But Mr Cohen's comments, this week's Pentagon report, and assessments made by a commission on space weapons convened by President Bill Clinton and by a panel chaired by former senator Howard Baker all make clear that a big push in now under way in Republican-controlled Washington to gain much bigger spending increases.

The money is intended to fund anti-proliferation efforts, missile defences, and new generations of "big ticket" delivery platforms such as "stealth" destroyers and submarines.

Mr Rumsfeld warned Congress this week that after a decade of static or declining post-Soviet military spending, a big effort was required to counter what he characterised as growing threats to the US and its allies, and in particular to space satellites, from "rogue" states and terrorist groups.

"Forces in world politics have created a more diverse and less predictable set of potential adversaries," Mr Rumsfeld told the Senate armed services committee. "I look forward_ to bringing the American military successfully into the 21st century. We must work together if we're to be able to address the problems of inadequate funding... We're going to have to find new dollars in non-trivial amounts."

Mr Rumsfeld said that his first action as defence secretary would be to launch a comprehensive review of defence policy to assess budgetary needs and priorities. The US currently spends approximately $300bn annually on defence (compared for example with China's estimated $60bn).

The new administration's fast-evolving defence plans will pose political problems for Mr Bush who, while pledging to increase military spending, has also promised to deliver large-scale tax cuts. Democrats in Congress like Senator Joe Lieberman are already publicly asking where the money will be found at a time of economic slowdown.

But given the mounting pressure from Republican hawks and from within his own Cabinet, Mr Bush is considered unlikely to back away from his vow to deploy an expanded version of NMD as soon as technical problems have been resolved. The repeated failure of NMD test firings last year persuaded Mr Clinton to leave a decision to his successor. NMD technology remains unproven.

The NMD element of America's counter-proliferation offensive is also certain to cause problems with US allies and potential adversaries alike.

Labour is divided over the project which would involve the enhancement of US radar tracking facilities at Fylingdales in North Yorkshire. But William Hague pledged yesterday(fri) that a Conservative government would back the US project, which, he said, was necessary, as the world entered a "second nuclear age".

Russia and China, as well as some of America's European Nato allies, are opposed to NMD which they say will breach existing treaties, bring to a halt 25 years of largely successful offensive arms control negotiations, and provoke a new global arms race.

Among the concerns fuelling the new military build-up is the perceived failure to protect American space satellites.

The space weaponry commission set up by Mr Clinton and until recently chaired by Mr Rumsfeld warned that the US potentially faced "a space Pearl Harbor" It pointed to relatively cheap micro-satellites that could be used by US enemies to disrupt or destroy orbiting satellites considered vital for military surveillance, intelligence-gathering, and information systems.

The separate inquiry led by Howard Baker has meanwhile warned that Russia's large nuclear, chemical and biological weapons stockpiles are dangerously insecure and vulner able to theft and smuggling by terrorist groups and Russian mafia syndicates.

The Pentagon report entitled Proliferation: Threat and Response focuses on several key areas of concern:

Transnational: "The increased availability of dual-use technologies, coupled with the relative ease of producing some chemical and biological agents, has increased concern that use of chemical or biological weapons may become attractive to terrorist groups intent on causing panic or inflicting large numbers of casualties." It singles out the terrorist network headed by the Afghanistan-based Saudi millionaire Osama Bin Laden as a particular threat, linking it to terrorist activity in Bosnia, Chechnya, Sudan, Yemen, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Libya, Pakistan and the Philippines.

States of Concern: The report provides a detailed breakdown of attempts by Iran, Iraq, Libya, North Korea and others, including Pakistan, Sudan and Syria, to enhance either their missile capability or acquire or augment weapons of mass destruction (WMD). It predicts, for example, that should sanctions be lifted against Iraq, Saddam Hussein could have an operational offensive nuclear weapon within five years. The report says that nuclear-armed India and Pakistan are engaged in a regional arms race that could have catastrophic consequences reaching far beyond the subcontinent. It accuses Iran of being dedicated to obtaining nuclear weapons and pursuing "offensive biological warfare capabilities".

Graphics published in the report put Western European countries including Britain well within range of missile systems in Middle Eastern states of concern.

Proliferators: The report says that while Russia and China have taken steps to curb the export of WMD-related technology, the activities of "entities" within both countries remain problematic. It links Russia and North Korea to Iran's nuclear and missile programmes and China to that of Pakistan. It expresses particular concern about the safety of Russia's WMD stockpiles and the defection of unemployed Russian scientists to states of concern or terrorist groups.

Response: The report outlines an escalating American response to WMD proliferation ranging from improved training and protective equipment for US forces based abroad and the arming of allies like Israel and Taiwan to ballistic missile defence (BMD).

BMD involves a bewildering array of weapons systems, either already deployed, in production, or on the Pentagon's wish-list,including airborne lasers, and National Missile Defence.

"The NMD program is tasked to develop, demonstrate and if ordered to do so, deploy an NMD system to defend all 50 states against limited strategic ballistic missile attacks from a country of proliferation concern," the report states. "Should a decision be made to deploy the NMD system, the department of defense(correct) expects to achieve Initial Operating Capability (IOC) shortly after 2005."

fields.headline: French connections
fields.standfirst: Torrid times for the Mitterrand family
fields.trailText: When our neighbours across the Channel in France have a political scandal, they do it in style. Their latest involves gun-running, the mysterious death of an ex-security service chief, an illegally backdated search warrant and a suddenly-remembered legal doctrine dating from 1939. All that and a mother who loves her son enough to find £500,000 bail. "He slowly turned to me and asked 'father's first name?'. My lawyer intervened telling him "60m French people know his father's first name." Jean-Christophe Mitterrand's account yesterday of his interrogation makes gripping reading - recall Mitterrand  père 's energetic extra-marital love life and feel the sharpness of that inquiry about whose  fils he might actually be.
fields.body:
When our neighbours across the Channel in France have a political scandal, they do it in style. Their latest involves gun-running, the mysterious death of an ex-security service chief, an illegally backdated search warrant and a suddenly-remembered legal doctrine dating from 1939. All that and a mother who loves her son enough to find £500,000 bail. "He slowly turned to me and asked 'father's first name?'. My lawyer intervened telling him "60m French people know his father's first name." Jean-Christophe Mitterrand's account yesterday of his interrogation makes gripping reading - recall Mitterrand père 's energetic extra-marital love life and feel the sharpness of that inquiry about whose fils he might actually be.

The latest affaire Mitterrand has several of the Scott inquiry's ingredients, plus that mesmerising political name. Now Jean-Christophe, in jail since before Christmas, has laid into the probity of the examining magistrate, that quintessential figure of the French judicial system, half-Maigret, half-Solomon. His accusation that the judge was politically motivated has secured the tacit support of the French left, except for the left-leaning Magistrates' Union. It is as if the Tories accused Sir Richard Scott of political animus; which come to think of it, some of them did.

Mr Mitterrand jr now been bailed, courtesy of mum, the formidable Mme Danielle. The legal question around the higher courts is whether a new inquiry has to be opened on the arms dealer Pierre Falcone. It was on a floppy disk found in his lawyer's office that Mr Mitterrand's name first appeared. This tale will run and run - but without, it seems, wider political fall-out. The French right have sleaze problems too. President Chirac is alleged to know of illicit party funding. As for premier Lionel Jospin, he, like so many on the non-Communist left, was a former pal of Mr Mitterrand - and one of the president's victims.

webTitle: Letters: Hague in the firing line

fields.headline: Hague in the firing line
fields.trailText: You report that William Hague is to express active support for the American nuclear missile defence system, known as "son of star wars" (Hague to back US upgrading of missile warning system, January 12). As a loyal follower of Margaret Thatcher, he should have been told of her opposition to the strategic defence initiative (SDI) launched by Ronald Reagan.
fields.body:
You report that William Hague is to express active support for the American nuclear missile defence system, known as "son of star wars" (Hague to back US upgrading of missile warning system, January 12). As a loyal follower of Margaret Thatcher, he should have been told of her opposition to the strategic defence initiative (SDI) launched by Ronald Reagan.

In particular, he should ask her for briefing on her meeting with Caspar Weinberger, then US secretary for defence, on March 27 1986, when he came to apologise for actions by Pentagon agents who used SDI as a cover for industrial espionage.

In 1985 the computer science and laser physics communities united in opposition to the construction of the proposed "peace shield", a task which was agreed not to be feasible. There was an underlying threat to leading technology, such as the programmes in artificial intelligence and parallel computing which I was managing for the DTI Alvey programme in advanced information technology. Scientists demonstrated that they were not for sale.
Richard Ennals
Former research manager, DTI Alvey programme
ennals@kingston.ac.uk

 Hague wants to sign up to NMD (New Maginot Disaster), a system that does not work, is guaranteed to upset Russia and China, will destroy the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty and could be interpreted by any "rogue state" as a challenge to find another way to hurt the US.

Even if NMD does work and a "rogue state" decides to launch a nuclear missile at the US, how to do it? Simple - knock out Fylingdales. So Hague wants to put his beloved Yorkshire in the firing line for nuclear attack. Genius!
Jeremy Barraud
London

fields.headline: Apocalypse tomorrow
fields.standfirst:
The message: spend more on US defence

Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: In the world according to the Pentagon, apocalypse is always just around the corner. In its latest survey of global menaces, Proliferation: Threat and Response, the US defence department presents a scary picture of multiplying offensive missile systems, accelerating regional nuclear arms races, ever more easily obtained (and murderous) chemical and biological weapons, and stateless fanatics dedicated to worldwide mayhem.
fields.body:
In the world according to the Pentagon, apocalypse is always just around the corner. In its latest survey of global menaces, Proliferation: Threat and Response, the US defence department presents a scary picture of multiplying offensive missile systems, accelerating regional nuclear arms races, ever more easily obtained (and murderous) chemical and biological weapons, and stateless fanatics dedicated to worldwide mayhem.

Military men never feel totally secure. If they did, they would lose their raison d'etre. Thus while the success of efforts to reduce the Soviet warhead arsenal is acknowledged, this achievement is tempered by gloom about clandestine transfers of hardware and expertise from present-day Russia to rogue "states of concern". And while China is praised, for example, for curbing nuclear cooperation with Iran and tightening its chemical weapons export controls, the Pentagon still warns sombrely that Beijing "remains one of the world's key sources for missile-related technologies" and will continue to use arms sales "to advance its strategic and economic interests". That the US, the world leader in missile technology, never ceases to do precisely this at every opportunity is an irony apparently lost on America's analysts. Unnoticed, too, when it comes to Iraq's destabilising "pursuit of regional hegemony", is the contradiction inherent in America's uncritical attitude to Israel's unmatched nuclear weapons programme. The report notes elsewhere that roguish Syria spends about $1bn annually on defence. But it does not publicise the equivalent US total: about $300bn.

Despite these blindspots, the Pentagon report has to be taken very seriously on two counts. One is the light it sheds on the undoubted dangers posed by the spread of weapons of mass destruction. It argues, for example, that North Korea, despite the thaw with the South, continues to deploy large, "offensively-oriented" forces along the common border, has the capacity to make at least one nuclear bomb, and is increasing its missile capabilities at a steady pace. Pyongyang, says the report, has also assembled a large stockpile of chemical precursors and chemical warfare agents. Iran, aided by North Korea and Russia, is said to be moving aggressively towards nuclear weapons and biological warfare capabilities; Sudan and Libya give rise to similar worries. When it comes to India and Pakistan, the report detects a "nuclear and missiles arms race ... with consequences that are difficult to predict and (with) potential for spillover beyond the subcontinent". When the activities of freelance terrorist groups like that led by Osama bin Laden are factored in, all this adds up to what that report calls a daunting worldwide challenge.

Which brings us to the second reason why this Pentagon analysis has to be taken very seriously. Just as the cold war gave rise to new generations of offensive missiles, the threat posed by the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction - accurately assessed or not - is now the principal justification for the next big US military expansion: into the multi-layered realm of defensive missiles and expensive new launch platforms like "stealth" destroyers and submarines and space-based vehicles. US National Missile Defence plans, rashly endorsed yesterday by William Hague, get only a small mention here. But they are an integral, and in the Pentagon view, clearly an essential part of the massive, many-pronged counter-proliferation programme now gathering pace in Washington. The military machine is already rolling. It will be very hard to stop.

The report notes elsewhere that roguish Syria spends about $1bn annually on defence. But it does not publicise the equivalent US total: about $300bn. Despite these blindspots, the Pentagon report has to be taken very seriously on two counts. One is the light it sheds on the undoubted dangers posed by the spread of weapons of mass destruction. It argues, for example, that North Korea, despite the thaw with the South, continues to deploy large, "offensively-oriented" forces along the common border, has the capacity to make at least one nuclear bomb, and is increasing its missile capabilities at a steady pace. Pyongyang, says the report, has also assembled a large stockpile of chemical precursors and chemical warfare agents. Iran, aided by North Korea and Russia, is said to be moving aggressively towards nuclear weapons and biological warfare capabilities; Sudan and Libya give rise to similar worries. When it comes to India and Pakistan, the report detects a "nuclear and missiles arms race ... with consequences that are difficult to predict and (with) potential for spillover beyond the subcontinent". When the activities of freelance terrorist groups like that led by Osama bin Laden are factored in, all this adds up to what that report calls a daunting worldwide challenge. Which brings us to the second reason why this Pentagon analysis has to be taken very seriously. Just as the cold war gave rise to new generations of offensive missiles, the threat posed by the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction - accurately assessed or not - is now the principal justification for the next big US military expansion: into the multi-layered realm of defensive missiles and expensive new launch platforms like "stealth" destroyers and submarines and space-based vehicles. US National Missile Defence plans, rashly endorsed yesterday by William Hague, get only a small mention here. But they are an integral, and in the Pentagon view, clearly an essential part of the massive, many-pronged counter-proliferation programme now gathering pace in Washington. The military machine is already rolling. It will be very hard to stop.

webTitle: RUC chief says reforms on track

fields.headline: RUC chief says reforms on track
fields.standfirst:
Significant changes will go ahead whether or not political battle is settled, Sir Ronnie Flanagan insists

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Significant changes will go ahead whether or not political battle is settled, Sir Ronnie Flanagan insists.
fields.body:
Many substantial reforms of the RUC will go ahead in the next few months, whether the political battle over nationalist support for the new police board is settled or not, according to the chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan.

Special Branch and CID will be merged on April 1, the force will be reorganised into district divisions, and Sir Ronnie intends to advertise soon for around 200 recruits to start training in September and be fully fledged officers in the new Police Service of Northern Ireland by early next year.

Nationalists view policing changes as a central part of the Good Friday agreement and the SDLP welcomed Chris Patten's plan for a radical overhaul of the overwhelmingly male-dominated force, which is more than 90% Protestant and many Catholics believe is biased towards unionists.

But they have accused the government of drastically watering down the Patten plan and say they do not have enough confidence in the current legislation to recommend young Catholics to join the new service. Nor have they agreed to nominate political representatives to the overseeing police board, which is supposed to be in place by the end of January.

The SDLP will face intense pressure in the general election from Sinn Fein, which wants the RUC disbanded and the police bill ripped up because it claims it is so far from the new beginning Sinn Fein argues is necessary.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, has warned that nationalist failure to support the reforms could wreck the entire peace process. But while Sir Ronnie acknowledged that the heart of the reforms was partnership between the police and the community, he said the wheels were already in motion for massive change.

"Patten was not just about policing but about how the police fit within the community and I genuinely respect the sincerity of all the political parties and am working with them to achieve that," he said.

"But we as police have a responsibility to the community and we are determined to move ahead rigorously to fulfil our responsibility. We are absolutely committed to change."

One of the SDLP's key demands is the Special Branch/CID merger, about which unionists are dubious, but Sir Ronnie pledged that this would go ahead on April 1 and he believed it would greatly benefit police work.

"Much closer coordination between those who gather intelligence and those who have to present evidence before the courts is a good thing," he said.

The SDLP also wants the Gough barracks interrogation centre in Armagh to be shut, and Sir Ronnie said he was working toward this in the near future although it was a matter of getting alternative accommodation sorted out.

He also pointed out that a new UK-wide law, the Regulation of Investigative Powers Act, passed in October meant undercover policing and surveillance activities were already subject to much greater external scrutiny than before.

The police bill's requirement that recruitment be on a 50/50 Protestant/Catholic basis could prove extremely problematic without widespread nationalist support.

But Sir Ronnie said it was imperative to start advertising for new officers as soon as possible because of the large numbers already leaving the force as a result of the downsizing plan outlined in the reforms, which aims to eventually cut the 13,500-strong force to about 7,500.

"Non-recruitment is not an option," he said. "We are on the point of selecting an independent recruitment agency and just because there is no police board doesn't mean we can't advertise. A total of 497 officers will have left by April. There is provision for another 700 to go in the next financial year and that is not including natural wastage of around 30 a month."

The SDLP also wants guarantees that the 2,500 full-time reserve will be phased out as soon as possible but the chief constable said this was not an option at present. "Almost 700 have already gone from the reserve and as things stand, we cannot lose any more," he said. "This is an indispensable body of men and women."

fields.headline: They all failed Anna
fields.standfirst:
She had 128 injuries. She was eight

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: No system is stronger than its weakest link. In the wake of earlier child abuse tragedies stretching back three decades, enormous investment has been made in our child protection system. The emphasis has been on earlier intervention, better agency coordination and much faster response to signs of abuse. As even the NSPCC conceded yesterday, real progress has been made in reducing abuse and the numbers of children who die. Even so, another sad name was added yesterday to the grim list of child victims who have been tortured and murdered by their carers. In the words of John Hutton, the health minister who announced a statutory inquiry into Anna Climbie's murder: "On three separate occasions she knocked on the door, but the door was slammed in her face."
fields.body:
No system is stronger than its weakest link. In the wake of earlier child abuse tragedies stretching back three decades, enormous investment has been made in our child protection system. The emphasis has been on earlier intervention, better agency coordination and much faster response to signs of abuse. As even the NSPCC conceded yesterday, real progress has been made in reducing abuse and the numbers of children who die. Even so, another sad name was added yesterday to the grim list of child victims who have been tortured and murdered by their carers. In the words of John Hutton, the health minister who announced a statutory inquiry into Anna Climbie's murder: "On three separate occasions she knocked on the door, but the door was slammed in her face."

The injuries which eight year old Anna suffered were described by a home office pathologist as the worst he had seen. There were 128 separate injuries to her body, including cigarette burns, weals from being beaten with bicycle chains, belt and buckle and coathangers, and hammer blows to the toes. As on earlier occasions when the system has failed, the mistakes were multiple and spread among several agencies: a consultant paediatrician who misdiagnosed cigarette burns as scabies; social services ignoring separate warnings by a relative and a childminder about serious signs of abuse; and an almost unbelievable decision by a police officer and social worker to return Anna from a hospital where doctors had identified abuse to her carer. It is not just individual mistakes but the lack of effective supervision that must be rigorously examined.

Lord Laming, former chief social service inspector, who will head the inquiry has a daunting task. He will need to review the record of nine public agencies and that of the evangelical churches to which the murderers took the child seeking an exorcism. There is an even more delicate racial dimension. The key social worker and police officer were female and black. The highly disciplined relationship between child and carer that worried hospital staff was described by the social worker as "normal within the context of their Afro-Caribbean background". We need to know why both female officers backed off. Was it fear of assault that delayed them from visiting the home? The danger faced by female officers, in many other contexts beside this one, has not been been fully addressed.

fields.headline: Manning 'Nerd' besotted with older woman turned into child killer
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Carl Manning, 28, was described by his counsel as "a bit of a nerd", a man who led a lonely, boring life, "had no luck with the ladies", paid for prostitutes and watched pornography on his home computer.
fields.body:
Carl Manning, 28, was described by his counsel as "a bit of a nerd", a man who led a lonely, boring life, "had no luck with the ladies", paid for prostitutes and watched pornography on his home computer.

A Tottenham Hotspur fan, Manning lived in a studio flat in Tottenham which he had bought. Even though he worked as a bus driver, he spent a lot of his spare time riding on buses and noting down bus numbers. It was while driving a number 18 in Wembley that he met Marie Therese Kouao.

Manning quickly became besotted with the older Kouao, allowing her to move into his flat a month after they had met. He wrote in his diary: "It is great to be in the arms of one you love." He was still writing her love letters in prison.

Manning believed Kouao when she said Anna's incontinence was due to witchcraft and evil spirits. He admitted in court that he hated the child and called her "satan Anna" in his diary.

In a chilling confession, he told police: "You could beat her [Anna] and she would not cry at all. She could take the beatings and pain like anything."

Manning's counsel claimed he had been brutalised by his actions. A psychologist's report said his crime was a folie à deux , meaning it is unlikely Anna would have been killed had Kouao and Manning never met.

His defence said: "Meeting her [Kouao] was the single worst thing that ever happened to him. What transformed him from a harmless nerd to a child killer nine months on was a process of gradual brutalisation that blinded him to the horror of what he was doing until it was too late."

Manning began to confess to his part in Anna's death as soon as officers came to arrest him, but denied murder.

webTitle: Church said it would pray for girl's 'spiritual problem'

fields.headline: Church said it would pray for girl's 'spiritual problem'
fields.standfirst:
The sect
Special report: child protection
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Marie Therese Kouao, who clutched a Bible as she was taken from the dock to begin her prison sentence, appeared to believe that Anna was possessed by evil spirits.
fields.body:
Marie Therese Kouao, who clutched a Bible as she was taken from the dock to begin her prison sentence, appeared to believe that Anna was possessed by evil spirits.

This belief, which served as an excuse for the girl's brutalised condition, was allowed to flourish by a series of evangelical churches Anna was taken to by her abuser.

Anna was made to repeat the story that she was possessed by demons and that Satan was making her injure herself.

The church that played a crucial role in this was the Universal Church of the Kingdom of God, a global Christian sect which tells its followers that diseases are caused by demons.

The sect, which last year bought the London-based Liberty Radio from Mohamed Al Fayed, is surrounded by controversy; its Brazilian founder is at the centre of corruption allegations.

Founded by shop assistant Edir Macedo in 1977, the Protestant evangelical movement has grown to acquire millions of followers.

It claims 4,500 regular members in Britain and has established a headquarters at the Rainbow Theatre in Finsbury Park, north London.

A week before her death last February Anna was brought to the theatre where the church advertises a "deliverance service" offering exorcism for those troubled by spirits.

Anna's frail body was completely covered in black clothing and she interrupted the service to say she was possessed.

Kouao told the assistant pastor, Alvero Lima, 21, that witchcraft had followed Anna from Ivory Coast. Mr Lima told Kouao the girl had a "spiritual problem" and said he would fast for her. They should return for a Friday service, the pastor said, at which they would try to cast out the evil spirits.

But the day before the service Kouao drove Anna, who was barely conscious, to the church. Mr Lima realised Anna was ill and advised Kouao to take her to hospital. She died the next day.

Kouao told doctors that when she had called the church earlier she was told Anna had a "bad spirit" and she should leave her alone. She had lost faith in modern medicine and had taken Anna to a church to rid her of "itchiness" through prayer.

A spokeswoman for the Universal Church said that medical studies had acknowledged the positive effects of prayer on health.

The Evangelical Alliance described Anna's death as tragic and warned churches to take great care in dealing with people who believe they are possessed.

webTitle: The cunning liar and the lonely bus driver

fields.headline: The cunning liar and the lonely bus driver
fields.standfirst:
Kouao Evil and devious woman who cared only for herself

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Kouao Evil and devious woman who cared only for herself.
fields.body:
Marie Therese Kouao was a cunning, manipulative liar. She was totally self-seeking, and cared only for herself. The Old Bailey was told that Kouao would do whatever was necessary to keep herself out of trouble and achieve her ends. She "cared nothing for Anna".

The 44-year-old was "devious" and "evil", the prosecution said. Kouao told many lies and refused to admit to police that she was not Anna's mother. Until the end she said she knew nothing of Anna's injuries and claimed that her lover, Carl Manning, was lying when he said they abused the child and left her in a bin bag in the bath.

The police found it difficult to get information about Kouao. She had worked in the aviation industry in Paris but she had been different things to different people. She had said she was an air traffic investigator, a press officer and a medical student, and she wrote on a CV that she had studied at the university of Oxford Street.

Kouao was from a large family in Ivory Coast but had lived most of her life in France. She has three sons and an adopted daughter and at various times she told various people that one of her sons was studying medicine and another was in prison. The jury was told: "She can't keep up with the lies she's told."

In court, she would often make outbursts and even called the prosecutor, Linda Stern, a liar. Kouao had to be taken down a number of times when the judge, Richard Hawkins, lost patience with her.

Kouao's own counsel said Kouao had led "a bit of a Walter Mitty life". Ultimately, though, it was not lies that Kouao was found guilty of. She took Anna away from her home in Ivory Coast and killed her. Kouao denied any part in Anna's death but yesterday the jury saw through another of her lies.

webTitle: Army double agent was 'at the very top of IRA'

fields.headline: Army double agent was 'at the very top of IRA'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Detectives looking into alleged collusion between loyalist paramilitaries and security forces in Ulster have for the first time acknowledged the existence of an army double agent.
fields.body:
Detectives looking into alleged collusion between loyalist paramilitaries and security forces in Ulster have for the first time acknowledged the existence of an army double agent, codenamed Stakeknife, who was working in the top echelons of the IRA.

Hugh Orde, the Scotland Yard commander leading the inquiry, will almost certainly have to broaden the scope of his investigation to include Stakeknife - a move which will horrify the Ministry of Defence.

The MoD's sensitivity about the agent has already led to injunctions being served on two national newspapers.

It has never previously admitted having such a highly placed informer in the IRA.

To the RUC's concern, it has emerged that the army was running its own network of informants to protect soldiers who, they argued, were as vulnerable to attack as the police.

The Stevens inquiry was set up to re-investigate the murders of Pat Finucane, a defence solicitor shot by the Ulster Defence Association in February 1989, and 19-year-old Adam Lambert, who was shot the day after the IRA blew up 11 people at Enniskillen in November 1987.

The terms of the inquiry are vague - it orders an investigation into "collusion" - which means Cdr Orde has the scope to look into allegations involving republicans and loyalists.

Last month he spoke to relatives of Francisco Notarantonio, who was shot dead on October 9, 1987, at his home in west Belfast.

It is thought Notarantonio, 66, was suggested as a target by the army to deflect the UDA from shooting Stakeknife.

The loyalists had unwittingly put the agent on a list of senior republican targets without knowing his importance.

Cdr Orde told the family he believed Stakeknife exists, saying he had uncovered details of a "high-level informant which would fit the description of Stakeknife".

Last night Cdr Orde confirmed he has spoken with the Notarantonio family, and added: "I have been on the record to say I believe the agent exists."

fields.headline: The last word on Miracles
fields.standfirst: Men talk about Bible miracles because there is no miracle in their lives. Stop gnawing that crust. There is ripe fruit over      your head. - Henry Thoreau
fields.trailText: Men talk about Bible miracles because there is no miracle in their lives. Stop gnawing that crust. There is ripe fruit over your head. - Henry Thoreau
fields.body:
Hinduism's grand festival of Kumbh Mela, which began this week and runs into February, is the largest religious event in the world. Millions of pilgrims gather at the confluence of the Ganges and Yamuna rivers for the 12-yearly opportunity to wash away their sins and diseases, and to gain salvation.

The festival is an impressive display of the power of faith, with its absolute certainties and unshakeable hopes - such a contrast to the cautious, sceptical, thoughtful attitude of science, which seeks evidence and weighs it, and changes its mind when presented with good counter-evidence. The place where the holy rivers join at Allahabad is called the "sangam".

Its miraculous power to cleanse spiritually and physically is, it seems, the accidental result of a squabble among the gods over a pitcher containing nectar that confers immortality. Vishnu won, and gave the pitcher to his winged horse Garuda to take to heaven. Demons stopped Garuda at four places on his journey, one of them being the Ganges-Yamuna confluence. Whenever Garuda put the pitcher down, he spilled some of the nectar.

Every 12 years these holy drops, which somehow the great rivers never wash away, become active again, and have their miraculous effect on whoever bathes there. Given that the Ganges is used both as a cemetery for human burial and as an open sewer for the many populous cities along its banks, bathing in it is itself a spectacular act of faith. But faith is not in short supply there, least of all faith in the promised miracles of salvation and healing.

The happy fact about miracles is that they require no support in the way of evidence or rational evaluation. Indeed, they do better without them. Mark Twain illustrates this by relating how an enquirer asked a celebrated professor whether recently received reports (it was then 1909) claiming that Dr Frederick Cook had discovered the north pole were true.

"The answer, yes or no," replied the professor, "depends entirely upon the answer to this question: Is it claimed that Dr Cook's achievement is a Fact, or a Miracle? If it is a Miracle, any sort of evidence will answer, but if it is a Fact, proof is necessary." "Is that the law?" asked the enquirer.

"Yes," said the professor, "it is absolute. Modifications of it are not permissible. A very pertinent remark has been quoted from the Westminster Gazette, which points out that the golfer, when he puts in a record round, has to have his card signed, and that there is nobody to sign Dr Cook's card; there are two Eskimos to vouch for his feat, to be sure, but they were his caddies, and at golf their evidence would not be accepted. In any event they are extremely non- standard events. Obviously, the concept of the miraculous is very useful because it can be invoked to explain anything whatever.

But therein also lies its weakness; as David Hume pointed out, when one weighs the evidence supporting the regular functioning of natural laws with evidence supporting claims that there has been a singular violation of them, the former must always so far outweigh the latter as to render the latter nugatory. And he added that it is infinitely more likely that a person who claims to have witnessed a miracle is mistaken, or deluded, or lying, than that the relevant laws of nature should in fact have been abolished temporarily for some local purpose.

There is another and better sense of "miracle," a colloquial one, denoting what is wonderful in both nature and human nature at their best. No gods are needed to explain them, and the only faith required is in the world's own capacity for good - a capacity which, in its variety and extent, is itself miraculous.

webTitle: McAlpine opts out of dome bid

fields.headline: McAlpine opts out of dome bid
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: One of the four companies expected to be part of the Legacy group close to buying the millennium dome for £125m has not joined the consortium.
fields.body:
One of the four companies expected to be part of the Legacy group close to buying the millennium dome for £125m has not joined the consortium.

Construction giant Sir Robert McAlpine unexpectedly declined to take up a proposed stake in the company, forcing multimillionaire property developer Robert Bourne to increase his own holding.

McAlpine's move will fuel fears over the viability of Legacy's plans to develop the site as a hi-tech "knowledge city" business park.

Under an agreement signed yesterday to transform Legacy from a shelf company into a £50m development corporation, Mr Bourne holds 15% of the shares, Bank of Scotland 5% and Dublin-based Treasury Holdings a controlling 80%.

Legacy intends to borrow £150m to fund a three-year redevelopment programme, but bankers believe only a third has so far been committed by the Bank of Scotland.

The Guardian has also learned the dome will still be owned by the government until June, leaving it in public hands if as expected Tony Blair goes to the polls on May 3.

Legacy is scheduled to sign the deal on February 14, but is not required to make an initial £50m payment until it takes possession in June.

Legacy will get 63 acres of land and will be barred from knocking down the dome for 15 years. Any profits in the first 10 years would be shared with the government. Mr Bourne said he hoped McAlpine would take a holding later and said the decision was insignificant.

The Tories last night urged the government to open talks with other interested parties, including Frenchman Pierre-Yves Gerbeau who wants to retain it as a visitor attraction.

fields.headline: Must do better
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on.. a report that makes uncomfortable reading
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on.. a report that makes uncomfortable reading
fields.body:
We have just completed a rough numerical analysis of entries in our daily Corrections and Clarifications column through one entire year, from November 1999 to the beginning of that month last year. By the time you read this a copy of the results will have been posted on the paper's electronic noticeboard for the examination of all Guardian journalists. I shall tell you about some of the results in a minute, but a few qualifying remarks are necessary.

It is not a league table and there are no gold stars or penalty points. The purpose of the exercise is to provide at least something against which any improvement may be roughly measured in future. The paper is actively seeking to improve its system of checks and to cut down the number of mistakes. Perhaps the figures will stimulate this process, if only because they will stand as a caution against complacency - not that I see much sign of that.

They are, as I say, only a rough guide because, in the first place, not all mistakes come to my notice and not all of those that do are corrected. As a general rule, grammatical errors have been dealt with in clusters in this column on Saturdays rather than in the daily corrections column, although increasingly under pressure from readers to do so, I have been including some of them in the corrections column.

Some of the other, factual, errors escape correction simply because something more important occurs to push them too far down the constantly changing list of priorities. It does not mean that nothing was done: in almost all cases the matter is brought to the attention of the journalist.

Here is one, for example, that did not get into the corrections column. In a front page report of the appalling fire in Holland on New Year's Eve we referred to the "inland Ijsselmeer sea". A reader sent an email from the Hague saying that it is actually a man-made freshwater lake and that it is not spelled Ijsselmeer but IJsselmeer.

The Encarta Online Encyclopedia confirms all this and helpfully points out that one of the rivers from which it receives fresh waters is the IJssel. The reporter was sent a copy of the email; he, in turn, sent an email to the reader pointing out that he had spelled it IJsselmeer but that its double capital letters (representing a single Dutch character) had not survived to reach the printed page (or website). One does not wish to sound like Lady Bracknell, but to have two initial caps must have looked to someone like carelessness.

It is not a matter of huge consequence, although interesting, and of course it is important to get things right. Readers, I have found, do not hesitate to point out this kind of mistake in reports, such as the one in question, of quite horrifying events.

We must keep a sense of proportion, however. Here are the thoughts of Dr Johnson, a familiar figure in this part of London 250 years ago, writing about his friend Richard Savage:

"A superstitious Regard to the Correction of his Sheets was one of Mr Savage's Peculiarities; he often altered, revised, recurred to his first Reading or Punctuation, and again adopted the Alteration; he was dubious and irresolute without End, as on a Question of the last Importance, and at last was seldom satisfied; the Intrusion or Omission of a Comma was sufficient to discompose him, and he would lament an Error of a single Letter as a heavy Calamity." Johnson, the historian Richard Holmes tells us, "noted this Quixotic desire for perfect type-setting with shrewd amusement".

We work in haste and do not, no matter how fretful we may get, have time for that degree of fastidiousness. The figures we have compiled lump all categories of error together and do not differentiate the serious and the less consequential (you may say trivial).

During the year there were almost 1,500 entries in the corrections column, nearly half arising from four main areas. These are pages 1,2 and 3, which are treated as a unit with their own production team (124 corrections); the home news pages, the biggest part of the paper (267); the foreign pages (121); and G2, the tabloid second section (245), excluding the arts pages, the women's, style and parents pages and the Guide pages with the television programmes, which were all counted separately.

The G2 total, considering it was produced largely by its general feature pages and columns (8,000 to 10,000 words a day), could not be considered good. Not surprisingly the months of August and September, last year, when G2 was understaffed, showed a sharp rise.

Here are the figures for some of the other high-profile sections: the comment and analysis pages, excluding letters, 70; letters, 25; obituaries and birthdays, 79; City 51; sport 74. And yes, sorry, mistakes in corrections: 8.

 The analysis of the year's corrections was made by Mary Fitzgerald. The quotation from Dr Johnson comes from his Life of Savage and is quoted in Richard Holmes's Dr Johnson & Mr Savage (Flamingo paperback). Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020-7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday. Mail to Readers' editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Fax 020-7239 9897. Email: reader@theguardian.com

fields.headline: On female flan flinging
fields.trailText: The tomato that splattered over Tony Blair's suit in Bristol could be the first of many. Smallweed fears we may be on the verge of a projectile election. The tomato follows the chocolate éclair that burst over Nick Brown at a farmers' meeting last February, and the more traditional custard pie that scored a direct hit on Ann Widdecombe when she visited Oxford. Instructively, all seem to have been hurled by women.
fields.body:
The tomato that splattered over Tony Blair's suit in Bristol could be the first of many. Smallweed fears we may be on the verge of a projectile election. The tomato follows the chocolate éclair that burst over Nick Brown at a farmers' meeting last February, and the more traditional custard pie that scored a direct hit on Ann Widdecombe when she visited Oxford. Instructively, all seem to have been hurled by women.

I worry about this development, since it may be used by politicians as an excuse to duck out of traditional meetings at which opponents are present and to shelter instead within hand-picked congregations. Others, however, glory in it. "I cannot believe I am alone", Boris Johnson wrote in the Daily Bigot, "in my exultation in reimagining the moment of impact: the splat of the squidgy red projectile, the explosion of seeds, the sudden soaking of the Armani, the momentary clouding of that maddening grin and its replacement by a wondering frown."

This Johnson, I understand, will himself be standing in the coming election, as the Conservative candidate for Henley. Henley, I understand, is particularly well equipped with greengrocer's shops stocking squidgy projectiles. There are also several excellent pastry cooks.

The editor of the Times, returning after illness, lost no time in disposing of Stephen Pollard, recruited from the Express, after Pollard had smuggled a message expressing his hatred of its new proprietor into that newspaper. How long, then, I wonder, is he going to tolerate the paper's new diarist, Giles Coren, who on January 2 concluded his contribution with the following thought: "Did you think the diary was a bit ropey today? Yes, well, did you go to work yesterday? No? Shut up, then."

On Thursday this week, he had each of his items assessed by a visiting reader called Tripp, who scored each one out of 10. The marks he awarded were three, two and one, which in my view was madly generous. Giles is the son of the veteran Times columnist Alan Coren, which just goes to show how right the Guardian is in its distrust of the hereditary principle. Still worse, though, was a column this week by the paper's teenage prodigy and former fawner-in-chief over Michael Portillo, Michael Gove, who, holding forth on the decline (as he sees it) in social and legal attitudes to the sanctity of life, wrote: "When we face the enormity of Harold Shipman's dispatch of his frail and vulnerable victims, our capacity to condemn appropriately is limited."

Let him speak for himself. Smallweed's imagination is haunted by a picture of all Shipman's victims, some very aged, others who might have expected many good years before them, arrayed in their serried ranks in some kind of field with, behind them, the even more numerous congregation of those deprived of loved parents and grandparents. What does Gove expect me to do to express my condemnation? Organise a lynch mob and march on the jail?

And now - it cannot be avoided, given the number of issues that readers have raised - back to the London suburb of Acton. Did I know that Acton had seven railway stations, including ones for all four points of the compass? Well, sort of; though East Acton station is not in Acton. Did I know that at least one laundry survives in the area known as Soapsuds Island, and possibly two? No, but I'm glad to hear it. Did I know that Acton used to be big in ice-cream? No, but ditto. Is the 94 bus a product of Smallweed's fevered imagination? (This from one who waits regularly at a bus stop which proclaims the existence of such a bus, but claims that none ever comes.) Why did I describe Prince Kropotkin as a nihilist, instead of an optimistic anarchist? Was I led astray by Chambers Biographical Dictionary? (Yes.) Why did I woundingly fail to distinguish between Acton W3, which is mere Acton, and Acton W4, which claims the right to call itself Chiswick? And so on.

I'm intrigued, by the way, that the woman (name unknown) who was married to the son of Osama bin Laden at a fun-packed ceremony in Kandahar was not herself present for the occasion. Could she, perhaps, like the new bride of Syria's president, be an Acton girl? Maybe she missed out on Kandahar because she was stuck at a bus stop, waiting for the elusive 94.

I am also rebuked for having, in my assessment of Acton, failed to mention the great historian John Emerich Edward Dalberg, first baron Acton of Aldenham. I omitted him on the wimpish grounds that as far as I know he had nothing to do with Acton W3 or, for that matter, W4. He is best known today for his teaching that power corrupts and absolute power corrupts absolutely, though what he actually said was a shade more cautious: power tends to corrupt and absolute power corrupts absolutely. This is probably the most famous line ever written in a letter dispatched to a bishop, the bishop being Mandell Creighton of London.

He also wrote in this letter: "Great men are almost always bad men, even when they exercise influence and not authority." Which deserves to be famous, too, though note again that qualification: almost. Though by nature rather remote, he was MP for Carlow from 1859 to 1865, when he switched to the splendid Shropshire town of Bridgnorth, which he won by one vote, only to be disqualified. In his time at Westminster he made just one speech and asked only two questions.

I have space to mention only one other aspect of Acton: his beard. This was one of the most imposing beards in late Victorian politics, a match, I would guess, even for the Marquess of Salisbury's - capacious enough, statisticians tell me, to conceal a small laundry or even a 94 bus. The Acton Institute for the study of religion and liberty, in Grand Rapids, Michigan, celebrates him on its website, though whether or not he'd approve of them is another matter.

They market a book by Marvin Olansky, who is said to have brought George W Bush round to compassionate conservatism, through something they call the Acton Book Shoppe. That doesn't sound very John Emerich Edward Dalberg to me.

Smallweed@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Cloned bison dies after 2 days
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The world's first clone of an endangered animal, Noah, a gaur or Indian bison, died just 48 hours after being born, scientists announced yesterday.
fields.body:
The world's first clone of an endangered animal, Noah, a gaur or Indian bison, died just 48 hours after being born, scientists announced yesterday.

Researchers from the US firm trying to clone endangered and extinct species, Advanced Cell Technology, said the bull calf had died from a common infection.

"We are all deeply saddened by this loss," said Robert Lanza, ACT's vice-president for medical and scientific development. "He was born alive and healthy. He was adorable."

Noah was created using DNA from an adult gaur's skin cells, which was then inserted into a cow's egg which had its own genes removed. The gaur embryo was brought to term in a surrogate mother, a domestic cow called Bessie.

Noah was born in Iowa on Monday evening and died 48 hours later. Bessie remains healthy.

Dr Lanza said ACT still intended to collaborate with Spanish scientists to clone an extinct animal, a Pyrenean mountain goat called the bucardo. The last bucardo was killed by a falling tree last January but frozen tissue samples are expected to yield good enough DNA for cloning to take place.

"The data collected [from Noah] clearly indicate that cross-species cloning worked and, as a scientist, I am pleased," said an ACT researcher, Philip Damiani. "As a person, however, I am saddened that an animal died.

"Noah is the first individual of an endangered species to be cloned and then brought successfully to term by a surrogate mother - his birth brightens the prospect that we can apply this technology to many species on the verge of extinction."
fields.bodyText: The world's first clone of an endangered animal, Noah, a gaur or Indian bison, died just 48 hours after being born, scientists announced yesterday. Researchers from the US firm trying to clone endangered and extinct species, Advanced Cell Technology, said the bull calf had died from a common infection. "We are all deeply saddened by this loss," said Robert Lanza, ACT's vice-president for medical and scientific development. "He was born alive and healthy. He was adorable." Noah was created using DNA from an adult gaur's skin cells, which was then inserted into a cow's egg which had its own genes removed. The gaur embryo was brought to term in a surrogate mother, a domestic cow called Bessie. Noah was born in Iowa on Monday evening and died 48 hours later. Bessie remains healthy. fields.headline: End of the line for the entrepreneur in a sweater
fields.trailText: I had to go to Oxford one evening this week. On the train I saw a newspaper picture of the dejected Sir Richard Branson, who has decided not to go to law in a last attempt to win the national lottery franchise. As I stepped off, the station PA system was announcing that a Virgin train to Manchester, due in five minutes, had been not merely delayed, but cancelled. There, I reflected, are a dozen or so people who won't get to Manchester tonight, and who will now curse the name of Branson - to say nothing of hundreds of others along the route.
fields.body:
I had to go to Oxford one evening this week. On the train I saw a newspaper picture of the dejected Sir Richard Branson, who has decided not to go to law in a last attempt to win the national lottery franchise. As I stepped off, the station PA system was announcing that a Virgin train to Manchester, due in five minutes, had been not merely delayed, but cancelled. There, I reflected, are a dozen or so people who won't get to Manchester tonight, and who will now curse the name of Branson - to say nothing of hundreds of others along the route.

I suspect that the Branson story will be taught as a case study to future generations of business students, warning them how easy it is to destroy an excellent brand image. Five years ago Branson was seen as an amiable entrepreneur in a sweater who had the novel idea of offering innovation and good value on a wide range of services - not so much a fat cat as a cuddly pussy. Then he bought a train company. Since then many of his enterprises, Virgin Cola, record shops and clothing, have flopped, and he's had to sell half of his one great acknowledged success, Virgin Atlantic Airways, to pay off his debts.

Last year the author Tom Bower brought out a critical biography, in spite of the worst that Branson's multitudinous lawyers could do; none of whom has yet managed to land a glove on the book. I was not surprised to learn that all the lottery commissioners had read this book before giving the franchise straight back to Camelot.

I suppose the message of this tale is rather cheerful. A cunningly cultivated image might work for a while, but it won't last unless it reflects reality. The reality is that Branson is just another grasping, ambitious businessman. By now the public realises it too. I doubt that his temporary half-price ticket offer will do much to restore matters.

 The desperate view that it doesn't matter what you do provided you have an exciting new name is behind the Post Office holding company deciding to name itself Consignia. This has caused great derision, though businesses have been doing it for hundreds of years. Even a pleasant sounding title like Sabena actually stands for something horribly complicated, beginning "Société Anonyme Belge..." Qantas sounds vaguely crisp and go-ahead, but stands for Queensland and Northern Territories Air Service. My guess is that now Consignia has brought so much ridicule, the next trend will be back to long, descriptive and somehow reassuring titles.

At the time that Cunard were looking for a name for its new luxury liner the Royal Shakespeare Company (shortly to be renamed Bardco) was presenting The Persecution and Assassination of Marat, as Performed by the Inmates of the Charenton Lunatic Asylum, under the Direction of the Marquis de Sade, or the Marat/Sade as it came to be known. Michael Frayn suggested the new ship should be called The Exploitation and Navigation of the Atlantic Ocean as Performed by the Employees of the Cunard Shipping Company under the Direction of their Chairman, Sir Basil Smallpiece, or "Basil" at it would have been called.

If he has any sense, Sir Richard Branson could give his appalling train service a new image by renaming it something long and comforting, such as: The West Country, English Midlands, North-West and Scottish Electrical Traction Company.

 Being a sceptic contemplating the onrushing tide of paranormal nonsense can be pretty depressing. Poltergeists, haunted houses, astrology and crop circles are like moles: however hard you whack them on the head, they always come back. But now and again you get a slight consolation. This week I saw in one of those shops that deal in remaindered books a stack of boxes labelled Uri Geller's Mind Power Kit. The great spoon bender gazed out over a lump of rock which was set into the front of the pack: "I have personally empowered this crystal for you. Use its energy and the rest of my kit to explore the potential of your own mind."

You'd imagine that a crystal empowered by Geller would be worth a tremendous amount of money. You could use it, as Geller claims to do, to find deposits of rare minerals, or at least restart broken watches. Sadly though, the kit had been marked down from £19.99 to £4.99. Astonishingly, it had not sold even at that price and the shop had had to offer the thing for sale at £2.99. Perhaps all is not lost.

 Peter Best writes from north London to tell me that the letter "L" added by Bristolians to words ending in vowel sounds is called "the lateral approximant", as in the example he heard locally: "He bought himself a villal in Austrial." He adds: "In my annals ['Annal' being the first name of the tennis player Kournikoval] pride of place goes to this story. While working at Bristol Temple Meads station, I enquired about an absent colleague and was told he suffered from recurrences of a disease he'd picked up in the tropics. I was told, 'It's the malarial he caught in Africal.' Another colleague instantly contradicted him, 'No, it bain't! It's the choleral he caught in Indial.' "

Bob Gough writes from Walton-on-Thames: "A friend of mine, Welsh-born but resident in Bristol, tells of hearing a kitchen described as having 'terralcottal tiles'. He was in higher education and had to attend a conference in Warsaw. The travel agent asked him, 'Do you mean Walsall in Poland, or Walsall in the Midlands?' "

 Thank you for all your many letters and emails about hats. I shall return to this topic, and why it is that every hat sends a message about its user, usually that he is a total dork. Since last week I have bought a black-and-white check cap from a charity shop, which makes me look like a bookie at a point to point, and a Ralph Lauren Polo sailor-type thing marked down from £35 to £11, which is still roughly four times what it is worth. My quest continues.

fields.headline: State defends Microsoft trial judge
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of Microsoft
NetNews
fields.trailText: The US government yesterday staunchly defended the trial judge in the Microsoft antitrust case against accusations from the software company that he was biased and should play no part in any further proceedings.
fields.body:
The US government yesterday staunchly defended the trial judge in the Microsoft antitrust case against accusations from the software company that he was biased and should play no part in any further proceedings.

In its filing to the US court of appeals, the justice department and 18 states are taking issue with Microsoft's attempt to overturn the ruling that it broke the law and should be split up.

In its own filing, Microsoft used post-trial comments by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson to reporters and in public lectures as evidence that he was biased against the firm.

Judge Jackson has continued to make incendiary remarks in print, not least in the book on the trial written by Ken Auletta, serialised in the Guardian this week.

In World War 3.0: Microsoft and its Enemies, Judge Jackson accuses Bill Gates of being Napoleon-like in his arrogance and like other criminals in his inability to see any wrongdoing. He is scathing about the company's behaviour during the 73-day trial.

The justice department yesterday argued against each of Microsoft's complaints and urged the appeals court not to take "the extraordinary step of invalidating the judgment".

Not only were many of Judge Jackson's comments justified by Microsoft's behaviour, it said, but he had also said some positive things in print about it - such as that he was "full of admiration" for its products.

Judge Jackson's public statements have raised eyebrows in legal circles. Bill Kovacic, a professor of law at the George Washington University who has applauded Judge Jackson's handling of the trial, called his subsequent comments "a ghastly display of bad judgment" this week. "It's clearly the behaviour of a man who expects to have no further role in this matter," he added.

Both sides appear before the court of appeals next month.

fields.headline: 'Naive' Hague backs Bush
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday highlighted a potentially grave diplomatic dispute between Tony Blair and the incoming US president, George W Bush, when he said Britain must give immediate unqualified backing for America's planned national missile defence system.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour and Richard Norton Taylor
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday highlighted a potentially grave diplomatic dispute between Tony Blair and the incoming US president, George W Bush, when he said Britain must give immediate unqualified backing for America's planned national missile defence system.

His call was broadly echoed by senior aides to the incoming Bush administration, who warned that Britain must accept the upgrade of the Fylingdales early warning tracking station in North Yorkshire.

Bruce Jackson, a key Bush defence policy aide, described an upgrade of Fylingdales as essential to the development of the shield. Lack of British cooperation would create a serious diplomatic fissure and materially degrade the security of Europe, he said.

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, attacked Mr Hague for "blundering around regardless of sensitivities and showing no judgment or sense of responsibility". He said a British response would be premature, explaining: "Our defence interests are closely interlinked with America's. But we cannot come to a view ourselves until US thinking has moved further forward."

The government is desperate to avoid an open disagreement with the US administration, and has been working as a bridge between the US and some EU states openly hostile to the plan.

Labour would prefer to see the issue shelved until after the general election, but the shadow defence secretary, Iain Duncan-Smith, and shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, are to visit Washington in advance of a pre-election meeting between Mr Hague and Mr Bush. They hope to show that the Tories are now the protectors of the US special relationship.

Senior Labour select committee chairmen said Britain had no need to state its position for some time since the preliminary missile tests had failed and the precise extent of the shield not yet disclosed.

Menzies Campbell, Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman, also savaged Mr Hague. He said: "It takes a particular kind of naivity to endorse a system which has so far failed every test," he said.

"Too much of the Tory language is reminiscent of the cold war as they try to prove they are Thatcher's children."

In a speech on Anglo-US relations in London, Mr Hague denied that the NMD shield would trigger a new arms race. "Current vulnerability to missile attack is an invitation to build offensive weapons. To choose to remain vulnerable in a world of multiple threats would be absurd as well as dangerous," the Tory leader said.

Mr Hague also in effect ditched the ABM treaty, saying: "I cannot accept that an agreement designed for a different time in world politics should stop us from taking steps that will improve the chances of peace and security in this very different age." He said if the UK did not give consent for changes at Fylingdales, "the relationship between Britain and America will have suffered a most serious blow".

Though the Tories believe there are serious divisions in the government, with Foreign Office ministers strongly opposed to the NMD project and defence ministers in favour, the reality is that there is widespread opposition to it in both ministries, including among senior military officers.

They believe US enthusiasts for the project have not properly considered the consequences, not least for arms control agreements and relations with America's allies, many of whom - notably France and Germany - are fiercely opposed to it, as are Russia and China. They also say NMD will undermine the traditional Nato concept of "shared risks" among the allies.

Most European governments, including Britain, believe Mr Bush and his advisers are exaggerating the threat posed by so-called "states of concern", including North Korea, Iraq and Iran.

fields.headline: Take-off boost
fields.standfirst:
Priceline wins an extra $25m

More net news
fields.trailText: Priceline wins an extra $25m
fields.body:
The European offshoot of Priceline.com, the troubled US "name your own price" air travel e-tailer, has received a $25m (£17m) injection of cash three days before its official launch.

General Atlantic Partners has ignored growing concerns about the long-term financial viability of pan-European e-commerce firms and a 97% slump in Priceline's share price to double its commitment to the firm.

Chief executive Dennis Malamatinas (pictured), who quit as boss of Burger King to join Priceline, said he was unconcerned by the collapse of other e-tailers which had looked to build pan-European brands.

"We have everything in place to move forward and maximise the potential of our unique and compelling business model. Our team is ready, our website is up and the money from GAP will enable us to build on this solid foundation across Europe."

Mr Malamatinas admitted Priceline Europe would need to raise more money to reach profitability but it would keep a tight rein on costs. "We have the money to do what we need to do at the moment and we don't have a significant burn rate."
