fields.headline: Urgent inquiry into repeated failures
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The government yesterday ordered an urgent statutory inquiry into lessons to be learned from the murder of eight-year-old Anna Climbie after months of "truly unimaginable" abuse went unheeded by the child protection authorities.
fields.body:
The government yesterday ordered an urgent statutory inquiry into lessons to be learned from the murder of eight-year-old Anna Climbie after months of "truly unimaginable" abuse went unheeded by the child protection authorities.

The move came after an Old Bailey jury convicted the child's aunt, Marie Therese Kouao, 44, and her lover Carl Manning, 28, of murder and cruelty to a child.

Sentencing them to life, Judge Richard Hawkins told the pair that Anna had "died at both your hands a lonely drawn-out death". He added: "Lessons must be learnt about the failures of social services and police."

Anna died in February 1999 after months of abuse. The Home Office pathologist who examined her body found 128 marks and said it was the worst case of child abuse he had seen.

She was brought to the attention of social services on three occasions and twice discharged from hospital.

The judge said Anna had been repeatedly assaulted "by hand and implement", "covered from head to toe in injuries and open sores", "bound by ankle and wrist in packing tape" and "placed overnight naked in a bag in the bath, sometimes for 24 hours". He said: "What she endured was truly unimaginable."

The officer in charge of the murder investigation, Detective Inspector Keith Niven, said: "It beggars belief how these two could have inflicted such suffering on this defenceless child."

Anna's parents, Francis Climbie and Berthe Ehoura, were prevented from coming to London for the verdict because of the recent coup in Ivory Coast. In a statement they said: "We entrusted our daughter to an aunt because we are poor and she would have had the opportunity to live well and receive a good education. Unfortunately, she was the victim of a tragedy."

After the verdict, Alan Milburn, the health secretary, led a wave of anguished reaction by all the organisations involved in the case. "She was undoubtedly failed repeatedly by the child protection system," he said.

An inquiry under Lord Laming will examine the conduct of professionals in the NHS, social services, housing departments and police across four London boroughs. Eight London police officers are facing a police complaints authority inquiry and a social worker has been suspended pending disciplinary procedures while four others are being investigated. Three councils, Haringey, Brent and Ealing, will be conducting their own inquiries.

webTitle: Look for the wheat among the chaff

fields.headline: Look for the wheat among the chaff
fields.standfirst:
The underperformance of tech stocks will force many investment bankers to look at alternative careers

More net news
fields.trailText: The underperformance of tech stocks will force many investment bankers to look at alternative careers.
fields.body:
Before I begin, let me tell you that you do not have to feel sorry for him. But I would like to relay the story of an investment banker smart enough to realise that he is staring down the barrel of that big gun called redundancy.

This week I met said banker to discuss his career options. He works for one of the bulge bracket firms in their technology team. He is one of 60 frontline team members in London alone, and his own narrow focus is on B2C - the dot.coms.

Looking at the pipeline of work in progress for his department in general, and his own practice in particular, is like a view from the heart of the Gobi desert, with nary an oasis in sight. No flotations, no secondary fundraisings, no mergers nor acquisitions.

No sensible corporate financier builds a career solely expecting a buoyant market for new issues. Stock markets are cyclical and a new issue market can freeze up entirely. It is no surprise that there is currently no appetite among investors for tech company flotations.

But our banker is screwed because there is little prospect of any other type of corporate work for tech stocks. Investors appear unwilling to risk throwing good money after bad by subscribing for second or third round fundraisings by existing quoted companies. And any M&A work is unlikely to have big advisory fees attached because the companies concerned just cannot afford to pay them.

Our banker is no mug. He may or may not deserve to beat the cut when his American parent wields the axe, but he recognises that redundancy programmes are notoriously fickle processes. Better to engineer a career change now than have one forced upon him at a time when the City is likely to be awash with underemployed and unemployed tech specialists.

The City excels in gallows humour. You have heard the new definition of B2C? Back-to-consultancy, of course. B2B? Back-to-banking. The bad news for the tech starlets with an eye on a bit of back-to-banking is that the investment banks are likely to sweep away many of the workstations in the great game of musical chairs.

Early year portents for the new issue, or initial public offering (IPO), market are not good. Two weeks into the year and there is barely a newcomer in sight. In Germany the first anticipated IPO on the hi-tech Neuer Markt, software company Ubis, cancelled its plans. In the UK a mighty fundraising for Orange is just grinding into gear, but the mobile telecom company is returning to the market and as such is hardly an unknown quantity to investors.

It is doubtless frustrating for wannabe listed companies to find the IPO market's shutters down - particularly for those with good prospects and genuine reasons to raise cash from equity investors. But they have to accept that the risks attached to companies without a track record of public scrutiny on the stock market are greater than for those that have.

The response of investment bankers who sponsor new issues and handle the attendant fundraisings is to price IPOs at a discount to comparable companies already listed on stock exchanges. However, the statistics show that this discount is instantly corrected in the first few days of dealing and is then followed by prolonged underperformance - justifying fears of higher risks for unknown entities.

A recent study by one of my colleagues revealed that over the past 10 years UK IPOs averaged a 28% gain on the first day of dealings, but subsequently underperformed their relevant peers by an average 15% over the next three years. International experience has been similar. The average US new issue has lost 20% relative ground in the three-year, post-float period.

It is too early to assess the aftermarket performance of last year's IPOs. But the vast majority are well on their way to posting even greater long-term underperformance. In the US only four investment banks saw the new issues they sponsored close the year at a premium to flotation prices. The various TMT sectors averaged IPO price falls by year-end of 34-56%.

Last year had been shaping up to be a bumper year for new issues. The finely honed abacus wielded by KPMG totted up 138 IPOs on the main market in the UK last year - a record number raising a record £10.6bn. However, this does not include admissions to the Alternative Investment Market, which totalled 275 raising £1.7bn. This represents more than the entire amount raised in AIM's previous history since its launch in 1995.

If the main market and AIM flotations are combined last year represented the high water mark in London's modern new issue history. If history proceeds to repeat itself, then there is a lot of pent-up disappointment to be dumped on investors over the next couple of years.

This need not necessarily imply that the new issue will be stone dead over this period. But, with luck, the opportunity for half-baked schemes to come to market masquerading as "proper" companies is behind us. Few have been left unscarred by the madness of last year's tech market. The scars will act as a reminder to investors to focus on reality when assessing prospects for prospective new issues.

So, back to our nervy banker. Short of reincarnation as an insolvency lawyer, his best bet might be to apply his skills to stock selection among those tech companies that have already made it to market. There must be some premium quality wheat among all the chaff.

Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities

edmondw@omsecurities.co.uk

webTitle: Vista expands for Bill's window on the world

fields.headline: Vista expands for Bill's window on the world
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of Microsoft
More net news
fields.trailText: • During the first nine months of 2000, Microsoft invested in or acquired 42 companies; at this rate, they will exceed the number of deals they made in 1999. Everywhere one looked in mid-2000, Microsoft was positioned to pounce, with a $17.8bn portfolio of equity investments in a variety of companies and $23.8bn in ready cash and marketable securities to enter new ventures.
fields.body:
 During the first nine months of 2000, Microsoft invested in or acquired 42 companies; at this rate, they will exceed the number of deals they made in 1999. Everywhere one looked in mid-2000, Microsoft was positioned to pounce, with a $17.8bn portfolio of equity investments in a variety of companies and $23.8bn in ready cash and marketable securities to enter new ventures.

 The company previewed its Xbox, a new video-game console that could be linked to the PC or to a television and aimed at supplanting Sony's PlayStation2.

 Microsoft pursued Rob Glaser's RealNetworks by integrating for free its Media Player software into Windows both for the desktop and for servers.

 Mr Gates chased Palm and its more than 80% market share by introducing a new version of its Pocket PC software for hardware manufacturers such as Casio, now offering such enticing features as colour, a web browser and the ability to play music or video clips.

 For the first time in years Microsoft saw MSN's subscribers grow at a faster pace than AOL's - doubling in 2000 - although by the autumn of 2000 AOL had 25m subscribers to MSN's mere 3m.

 In June, the company undertook a radical companywide restructuring during the course of the trial, shifting the company toward what it called "next generation Windows services", aiming to promote a seamless Windows platform on any device connected to the internet, integrating all services and applications.

 Microsoft continued its spending spree -spending more than $2bn on joint wireless ventures worldwide, billions on new wireless devices, and hundreds of millions on web-hosting companies that deliver software online.

 Microsoft made big bets on cable. In concert with John Malone's Liberty Media, Microsoft set out to construct a global cable empire. Overall, by September 2000, Microsoft had made more than $11bn in broadband investments worldwide - including a $3bn stake in Britain's Telewest and a $500m stake in NTL, England's third-largest cable operation and an 8% stake in UPC, Europe's largest cable broadband company, whose reach stretched over 12 countries.

webTitle: Russian Orthodoxy brings Grandfather Frost in from the cold

fields.headline: Russian Orthodoxy brings Grandfather Frost in from the cold
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: It's been a stirring if theologically challenging week for the bearded bigwigs of Russian Orthodoxy. The second most important date in the Orthodox calendar fell last weekend.
fields.body:
It's been a stirring if theologically challenging week for the bearded bigwigs of Russian Orthodoxy. The second most important date in the Orthodox calendar fell last weekend; the churches and cathedrals of Moscow were bursting at the seams with people celebrating a very white Orthodox Christmas.

Round the corner from where I live, the newly built Cathedral of Christ the Saviour, the jewel in the crown of contemporary Orthodoxy looming imperiously on the Moscow skyline, was packed with 6,000 of the faithful, including Vladimir Putin and a couple of high-profile visitors from Berlin, Gerhard and Doris Schröder.

There was incense and candles, and the cathedral was decked out in sprigs of fir.

The Russians are very good at pomp, mystery and awe-inspiring devotion. But there was also something strangely unorthodox about the presence of Grandfather Frost and his Snowmaiden partner at Jesus Christ's birthday party in the cathedral.

Like all things western, Santa Claus has recently been flooding Russia with his gospel of unbridled consumerism and shop-till-you-drop doctrine. But you couldn't catch Santa at any of the Russian church festivities.

Jealously guarding its restoration to the centre of Russian life, the church's hierarchy is a bastion of anti-westernism, suspicious of the Vatican, and contemptuous of Hollywood. Santa Claus, therefore, is persona non grata.

Which is where Grandfather Frost, an unreconstructed pagan and perhaps a communist to boot, comes in. He and Snowmaiden are the traditional Russian equivalents of Santa, essentially the spirits of the winter solstice. The trouble is they are decidedly unChristian; they were originally pagan, appropriated by Stalin, the destroyer of the Russian church, as a secular substitute for the New Year holiday.

In 16th-century rural Russia, Frost was the pagan winter wood sprite; Snowmaiden was his offspring who perished every spring when the thaw set in. By the 19th century, Frost had acquired grandfather status and Snowmaiden had transformed into his granddaughter, not least thanks to the playwright Alexander Ostrovsky, who devoted a theatre piece to the girl.

In 1917 the killjoy Bolsheviks summarily turned both fairy-tale figures into non-persons and banned fir trees as the symbol of the New Year. Stalin, however, relented in the 1930s, mobilising the trees and the pagan spirits for the secular festival, while smashing the church and abolishing Christmas.

So when the church hierarchy allowed granddad and the girl into the children's Orthodox Christmas party in the basement of the grand cathedral on Tuesday, eyebrows were raised and questions asked.

There was a large fir tree illuminated by laser angels and saints; the Ten Commandments played a central role in the kids' party.

But in a bow to all things Russian ancient and superstitious as well as modern and secular, the wood sprites were also allowed to take part. Patriarch Aleksy II himself had given his blessing to their participation.

Up in the north of Russia, Vyacheslav Pozgalov, the governor of the Vologda region, rails at the west and argues that Grandfather Frost is a key to Russia rediscovering its soul.

"Today we see the intellectual degradation of the nation. The intellect and the spirituality of our people are collapsing rapidly on a mass scale. Western ideology is deliberately washing it away. For us, Grandfather Frost is not a commercial, but an ideological project." This is a view to which the bearded bigwigs fully subscribe. Which is why you can now talk to ancient pagan spirits of the forest in the biggest church in Moscow.

As for the Christmas trees, the church hierarchy has less qualms about accepting gifts from the west. Moscow has been invaded by forests of Danish fir, costing more than £40 for a spindly sapling.

Not surprisingly, more than 90% have gone unsold, so they were donated to the patriarchate to decorate Moscow's churches for the Orthodox Christmas.

fields.headline: The people behind Legacy
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Robert Bourne
fields.body:
Robert Bourne

Trademark navy blue Armani suits and all-year suntan are very much an in-your-face testament to Robert Bourne's wealth.

The champagne parties at his house in Cheyne Walk, Chelsea, are legendary, with Tina Brown, Richard Attenborough and Melvyn Bragg among those who have enjoyed his hospitality. So has Peter Mandelson, the former dome minister, warranting a suprise birthday party thrown by the property developer.

Companies House lists Mr Bourne as a director of 54 companies, including one named after his wife, theatre impresario and society hostess Sally Greene.

Together they form one of New Labour's most glamorous couples, though Mr Bourne maintains that the glitz is hers as he presents himself as little more than a guest at some of the soirees.

Mr Bourne, 50, is a successful operator in the dog-eat-dog world of property development and colleagues talk of a hard man behind the smiles and warm handshakes. The son of a Polish Jew who escaped to Britain before the Holocaust, he was privately educated and started making his fortune in the 1970s by refurbishing old offices.

Shrewd and hard-nosed, he switched his support and donations totalling £40,000 from Margaret Thatcher's Tories to Tony Blair's entrepreneur-friendly brand of New Labour, investing £100,000 over three years in the people's party.

Richard Barrett and John Ronan

The two Irish property developers will effectively own the dome through their company, Treasury Holdings, which has 80% of Legacy.

Together they hold 89 directorships and have donated considerable sums to Irish political parties, including £10,000 to the Labour leader, Ruairi Quinn, in 1997 and £1,000 to the minister for foreign affairs, David Andrews.

Mr Barrett, 46, a tall and well groomed figure, is from a wealthy west of Ireland family. After training as a barrister he worked in the family grain and farming businesses before teaming up with Mr Ronan in the late 1980s. Mr Barrett, a bachelor, is known as a ruthless businessman with a fiery temper.

Mr Ronan, 47, the son of a Tipperary pig farmer who turned to property development, is instantly recognisable, with his bushy black beard, shoulder-length hair, a taste for erotic sculpture and a penchant for powerful four wheel drive vehicles, including a metallic blue Humvee, the US army jeep favoured by film stars and gangsta rappers.

Married with three children, he trained as a chartered accountant and his first major property venture was the Treasury building on Dublin's Lower Canal Street, from which the company takes its name.

Bank of Scotland

Established in 1695, the Bank of Scotland is a familar sight on Scottish high streets. But it was eclipsed by its arch rival, the Royal Bank of Scotland, last year when the Royal Bank snatched NatWest from its clutches.

The Bank of Scotland has a reputation for funding start-up companies and high-profile entrepreneurs such as Trevor Hemmings who runs the Blackpool Tower. But it ran into controversy 18 months ago when it tried to set up a US deal with evangelist Pat Robertson, who described Scotland as a land of homosexuals.

The bank is inextricably linked to the dome, since it backs not just Legacy but Treasury Holdings, and is the banker to Quintain Estates and Development, which owns the land adjacent to the dome.

Valentine's Day harbours painful memories for the Bank of Scotland. Last year, it marked the failure of its attemped marriage with NatWest. Now, it is trying to get to the altar again, but this time its courtship with Abbey National is being scuppered by Lloyds TSB.

The figures in full

The cost

 £845m to build and run, attracting little more than half the target 12m visitors

The sale

 £125m for the dome and 63 acres, in staggered cash payments for three years

Plus government to share in any profits for 10 years

 Developers claim an estimated £685m in taxes will be generated by business buying space

 Contents of the dome to raise an unspecified amount after auction

The funding

 Dome buyer Legacy is owned 80% by Dublin-based Treasury Holdings, 15% Robert Bourne and 5% Bank of Scotland who will pay £50m between them

 The £50m forms June's downpayment with the £75m remainder to be handed over in phased, unquantified sums

 Redevelopment of the dome is estimated to cost £150m, which is eventually expected to be paid for through a 20-year bond. Bank of Scotland is committed to backing the first phase of the development with £50m

The deal

 A 999-year lease and a promise to keep the Dome in place for 15 years

 Legacy will pay a share of the profits for 10 years, on a sliding scale under which all the profits will go to the public purse in the first year

 Planning permission for houses, shops, pubs, cafes, restaurants to earn extra cash for the public purse

 The roof may be need to replaced after 10 years

webTitle: Rising cost of restoring train service

fields.headline: Rising cost of restoring train service
fields.standfirst: More about transport
fields.trailText: The cost of the rail industry's recovery programme has risen from £300m to £600m, much of which will have to come from government, industry sources admitted last night.
fields.body:
The cost of the rail industry's recovery programme has risen from £300m to £600m, much of which will have to come from government, industry sources admitted last night.

This includes the cost of new rails and compensation for lost business, which Railtrack will have to pay to the 25 train companies. It shows that rising sums are required just to restore the industry to normal service.

Railtrack said 250 miles of new track had been laid, leaving a further 200 to be completed by Easter, although it has admitted that the full programme could continue until May.

It dismissed as "utter rubbish" claims by the leader of Aslef, the train drivers' union, that 50% of new track laid since the Hatfield train derailment will have to be torn up and replaced, delaying Railtrack's recovery programme until the summer.

Mick Rix, Aslef's general secretary, said new track around the Hatfield crash site had already been replaced because its width was several millimetres short.

Railtrack said the Hatfield site had been reopened at the earliest possible time using short lengths of rail which were quickly available. These were replaced after a few weeks with longer rail normally used on inter-city lines.

Railtrack rejected Aslef's claim that there were doubts about the quality of the replacement rails at Hatfield.

It said it had received one batch of sub-standard rail from its Italian supplier. This was installed at only one site and replaced when the problem was identified.

Yesterday also saw the launch of a trade union campaign aimed at persuading the government to renationalise Railtrack.

This includes the cost of new rails and compensation for lost business, which Railtrack will have to pay to the 25 train companies. It shows that rising sums are required just to restore the industry to normal service. Railtrack said 250 miles of new track had been laid, leaving a further 200 to be completed by Easter, although it has admitted that the full programme could continue until May. It dismissed as "utter rubbish" claims by the leader of Aslef, the train drivers' union, that 50% of new track laid since the Hatfield train derailment will have to be torn up and replaced, delaying Railtrack's recovery programme until the summer. Mick Rix, Aslef's general secretary, said new track around the Hatfield crash site had already been replaced because its width was several millimetres short. Railtrack said the Hatfield site had been reopened at the earliest possible time using short lengths of rail which were quickly available. These were replaced after a few weeks with longer rail normally used on inter-city lines. Railtrack rejected Aslef's claim that there were doubts about the quality of the replacement rails at Hatfield. It said it had received one batch of sub-standard rail from its Italian supplier. This was installed at only one site and replaced when the problem was identified. Yesterday also saw the launch of a trade union campaign aimed at persuading the government to renationalise Railtrack.

fields.headline: At this price? Morrison
fields.trailText: Sales at Morrison, the northern based supermarket chain, are rising and every piece of good news helps lift its share price.
fields.body:
Sales at Morrison, the northern based supermarket chain, are rising and every piece of good news helps lift its share price.

This week, the company again cheered up the market with the announcement of buoyant like for like sales, which have risen by 8% over the past 22 weeks.

The news forced the stock price up 4.5% to 180.75p on Thursday and it crawled up to just over 181p as the London markets closed last night.

But executives at Britain's fifth largest grocery chain are coming to the conclusion that their company is unlikely ever to become an investor's darling.

Analysts view Morrison as a gritty, stable and dependable debt-free group which can be relied on to produce solid results but is unlikely to do anything dramatic.

The chain is headed by Ken Morrison, its chairman and major shareholder, who has repeatedly shrugged off speculation about how long he is likely to stay in the role.

With more than 100 stores, observers insist there would be no shortage of interest should Mr Morrison decide to hoist the For Sale sign.

It is perhaps reasonable to assume that he will eventually make his exit and, with the succession looking far from obvious, a bid battle could well ensue.

The plain talking Yorkshireman may be dismissive of takeover talk, but he is not reticent when it comes to the planning laws which he insists are strangling the development of his business.

The food sector has benefited greatly from the recent swing away from technology companies, but the sector is notoriously competitive because most of the growth is generated by persuading your competitors' customers to switch sides.

That aside, Morrison looks like a strong performer, but anyone thinking of opening their wallet should do so in the knowledge that the company probably will not ever generate bumper profits. But regular, gradually increasing returns can be expected.

fields.headline: Navan goes for gold
fields.trailText: Traders are struggling to keep up with the recent performance of Navan Mining. The share price of the Irish exploration group has risen in an almost straight line since the start of the year and breached 100p for the first time yesterday after advancing 10%.
fields.body:
Traders are struggling to keep up with the recent performance of Navan Mining. The share price of the Irish exploration group has risen in an almost straight line since the start of the year and breached 100p for the first time yesterday after advancing 10%.

The move came on the back of speculation that Navan has found a world-class gold deposit at a site in southern Bulgaria.

Although an official announcement on results of test drilling at the site on the Bulgarian/Greek border is not expected until the end of the month, market gossips reckon Navan is sitting on a deposit that has at least 4m ounces of gold.

In a recent note SG Securities, Navan's house broker, set a 151p target price for the stock, based on the site yielding 1m ounces of gold. If yesterday's gossip proves accurate, traders expect Navan shares to trade north of 200p.

fields.headline: Arcadia boss dresses up
fields.standfirst: Market forces Neil Hume
fields.trailText: Charles Wilson has held the post of "executive director-designate" at clothing retailer Arcadia for less than a week and already he is turning heads in the Square Mile. He bought 331,000 shares in the owner of the Top Shop and Dorothy Perkins chains on Tuesday, when he joined, and yesterday there was news that he topped this up with the purchase of a further 92,000 shares at 94.6p a piece on Thursday.
fields.body:
Charles Wilson has held the post of "executive director-designate" at clothing retailer Arcadia for less than a week and already he is turning heads in the Square Mile. He bought 331,000 shares in the owner of the Top Shop and Dorothy Perkins chains on Tuesday, when he joined, and yesterday there was news that he topped this up with the purchase of a further 92,000 shares at 94.6p a piece on Thursday.

It is commonplace for new directors to make maiden investments in their new companies. But these are very chunky purchases and, more importantly, Arcadia is due to update the City on its Christmas trading next week.

We must assume Mr Wilson has not looked at the figures, but the new man looks to be in double danger of being seriously embarrassed: if the trading figures are good, everyone will query his advance knowledge; and if the figures are bad, everyone will assume he is a bit dim. Why did he not wait until after the statement, people will ask. On the day, City traders decided to run with the "up" red-face scenario, pushing the market price 6.5p higher to 101p. After all, company directors, like all investors, normally buy shares if they believe they are going up.

The FTSE 100 index ended a gloomy week on a bright note, rising 50.6 points to 6,165.5, after strong performance from tech and telecom stocks like Vodafone, 9.25p higher at 236p, CMG, up 83p at 845p, and Logica, 100p better at £16. Over the week, however, the blue-chip index lost 74.1 points.

Market turnover breached the 2bn mark, as institutional investors, taking comfort from the performance of the Nasdaq, which continues to move higher even in the face of gloomy corporate and economic news, dipped into the market.

Yesterday, for example, Nasdaq was higher as London traders headed home for the weekend, even after profits warnings from PC makers Dell and Hewlett-Packard and strong US economic data that brought in question how much the Fed will be able to cut rates.

The feeling that Nasdaq may have bottomed out helped the FTSE Techmark 100 close 112.96 points higher at 2,583.14, with traders keeping a close eye on the performance of telecoms group Fibernet, up 12.5p at 752.5p.

According to the gossips, European rival KPNQwest is running the slide rule over the company. It seems that KPN, owner of a 4,100-mile fibre-optic cable network in Europe, wants to expand and views Fibernet, which specialises in building local and metropolitan networks, as the one way to do it. Another might be to buy Telewest, up 4.5p at 136p, but that appears unlikely given its massive debt burden.

Media planning and buying company Aegis, 11p better at 123p, ended a dreadful week on a bright note. The shares, down 25.5p before yesterday's rise, were lifted by speculation that the company has won its battle to retain a £130m contract with US drugs company Pfizer. News that chief executive Douglas Flynn bought 25,000 shares yesterday at 121p also helped.

Chatter that Banco Santander is planning to offload a large chunk of its 9.6% stake through a convertible bond issue unsettled Royal Bank of Scotland, 4p lower at £16.06.

The rumours, though, appear wide of the mark, given the two bank's close connections. More likely is that the Spanish bank is looking to use its own shares as collateral for a fund raising exercise to satisfy its ambitious growth targets.

E-commerce software company QSP advanced 4.5p, or 16.67%, to 31.5p on takeover hopes. It seems that QSP met its biggest shareholder, Schroder Investment Management, on Thursday and was told that it was seeking a strategic buyer, possibly Sage, up 20p at 340p, for its 24% stake.

Consolidation hopes lifted Premier Oil, 1.5p better at 18.75p. Amerada Hess, which recently tried to buy Lasmo, up 0.75p at 199.75p, owns a 25% stake in Premier.

webTitle: Innocent victim of Ulster's dirty war

fields.headline: Innocent victim of Ulster's dirty war
fields.standfirst:
Stevens inquiry: Family's quest for truth may lift lid on secret army unit

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Stevens inquiry: Family's quest for truth may lift lid on secret army unit.
fields.body:
Francisco Notarantonio was having a lie-in the day he died. At 7.30, he would normally have been up and about, but the 66-year-old grandfather had retired eight weeks earlier and probably thought another few minutes in bed was as much as he deserved.

When there was a crash downstairs, he barely stirred. His wife, Edith, assumed one of their children was up to no good and put on a gown to investigate. She only got as far as the bedroom door. It burst open. A hooded man carrying a long-barrelled gun and wearing a blue boiler suit pushed past her.

Another man in a balaclava stood behind him. "I shouted, 'What's wrong, what's the matter?'" said Edith, now 73.

"Francisco jumped up, half out of bed with his hands up and open. He was shot in the chest. He fell forward on the bed, and was shot twice in the back." The couple had been married for 39 years and had 11 children.

"I thought they were going to kill me too. But they went into another room and shot my grandson in the hand. Then they walked downstairs - walked - and left."

The murder of Notarantonio on October 9 1987, at the family home in Whitecliff Parade, a staunchly republican estate in Ballymurphy, west Belfast, was horrific, but depressingly, it was hardly extraordinary in a period when sectarian shootings were commonplace.

RUC officers told Mrs Notarantonio they hoped to catch the killers within a fortnight. Nobody has been arrested.

Her husband's death would probably have been forgotten if it had not been for the suspicions of the family, and revelations from former security force personnel which has put the case at the centre of one of the most intriguing and potentially explosive stories of the Troubles.

To begin with, it was assumed Mr Notarantonio had been killed by the loyalist paramilitary outfit, the Ulster Freedom Fighters, who were engaged in a tit-for-tat campaign with republican terrorists. The family thought there was more.

"For days before the shooting, the army was everywhere," said Charlotte Notarantonio, Francisco's daughter. "Just before my father died, the soldiers, the helicopters and the barricades disappeared. It was as if they were clearing the way. And just after the shooting, we also found an army map in the hallway. It must have been dropped by one of the gunman."

Rumours the military was involved were apparently substantiated last year when a former soldier confirmed that Notarantonio was the innocent victim of a complex conspiracy designed to protect a top double agent.

The allegation is that a secret army intelligence squad working in Northern Ireland, the force research unit, infiltrated the Ulster Defence Association using an agent, Brian Nelson, who became the UDA's senior intelligence officer. When Nelson discovered loyalist terrorists were intending to assassinate a senior member of the Provisional IRA, it caused panic in the FRU.

Intended victim

The intended victim was the army's "primary source" spy within the movement, codenamed Stakeknife. To protect Stakeknife, the army allegedly fed false details of Notarantonio to the UDA through Nelson, which suggested the former taxi driver, who had given up work to look after his wife, was an IRA godfather.

In fact, Notarantonio had not been actively involved in politics for more than 40 years. The details were passed to the UDA's gunmen, the UFF, who carried out the killing. "When we heard about Stakeknife, we realised we hadn't just been paranoid about thinking there was collusion," said Ms Notarantonio.

"In some ways, it was a relief to think we were getting closer to the truth. But it made us want to fight all the harder. We want to know who ordered my father's death, and how many other people were executed in this way."

Sir John Stevens, the commissioner of the Metropolitan police, was asked to conduct an inquiry into collusion almost two years ago - his third investigation in Northern Ireland - focusing on the murder of Patrick Finucane, a Belfast solicitor shot in front of his wife and children in 1989. Commander Hugh Orde, who is in charge of the day-to-day running of the inquiry, has inevitably been drawn into allegations of collusion in other deaths.

He saw the Notarantonio family last month to discuss their case. He told them he has not uncovered any firm evidence - yet - to confirm the claims about the death. But he did say he thought Stakeknife exists, the first acceptance by the police that the army was running a spy at the highest levels of the IRA. Some republicans have questioned whether Stakeknife might be a figment of loyalist imagination, a myth designed to unsettle the movement.

This is dismissed by a former member of FRU, a whistleblower who uses the pseudonym Martin Ingram. Until recently, Ingram was a key witness to the Stevens inquiry, but he withdrew his statement because he felt the police were not doing nearly enough to protect him and his family.

Last year, his house was burgled in mysterious circumstances, and in recent months he has received threatening phone calls warning him not to give further information about the covert activities of FRU.

"The circumstances of the Notarantonio murder are 100% true," said Ingram yesterday. "I was working in the FRU at the time, though I wasn't involved.

"I knew there was targeting of Stakeknife, and yes, there was panic. The aim was to switch attention to another individual.

"This was the ethos between 1986 and 1989... to try to refine the targeting of loyalist gunmen, which would add to the weaponry of the British army and raise some panic within the republican movement." Ingram believes Stakeknife is still operating.

His statement to the Stevens inquiry concentrated solely on what he knew about the double agent, none of which has been reported in the newspapers.

"I have been extremely responsible in what I have said about Stakeknife. It's such a major problem for the army. They are running an agent who is working against the interests of one section of society."

Ingram believes the setting up of the Stevens inquiry was the very least that should have been done to unravel what was going on in Ulster at that time.

"A public inquiry would be better, or some form of truth and reconciliation commission."

He has also been dismissive of leaks to the Guardian suggesting the Stevens team will finish its investigation by concluding FRU was acting "on its own", "or in a maverick fashion".

To blame FRU for breaking the rules, would be a nonsense, he says, because there were no rules.

"The army is a bureaucratic organisation which needs funding. There is structure and there is accountability. You cannot finance an organisation like that without people knowing exactly what FRU was doing."

Although the withdrawal of Ingram's statement and cooperation was a blow, Scotland Yard sources insist the inquiry is still progressing.

"Ingram was just one strand. We've not lost all hope we'll get him back."

The next three months, however, are likely to be critical for the Stevens team.

In the spring, Billy Stobie, from Glencairn in Belfast, will go to court to face charges of aiding and abetting others to murder Pat Finucane and a teenager, Adam Lambert. Stobie will claim he was an RUC special branch agent when Finucane was killed, and warned his handlers Finucane was a target.

If the case gets before a jury - there is likely to be furious debate over abuse of process - it could give an extraordinary insight into the murky world of counter-intelligence.

Mr Orde is also working his way through a list of 25 former FRU soldiers, summoning them for interviews to discuss their duties.

Last, and most importantly, he will question the former commander of the unit, Brigadier Gordon Kerr - known as "Colonel J" - who is currently the military attache to the British embassy in Beijing.

Then, Mr Orde will set about writing his report.

"We're getting there," said a Scotland Yard source. "Things are just beginning to hot up."

Undercover operators

The Force Research Unit was one of three army-sponsored undercover intelligence squads in Northern Ireland. The others were 22 squadron SAS, and 14 Company. They are at the heart of claims that the army was involved in organising state-sponsored assassinations.

The FRU, set up in Northern Ireland in 1980, dealt with recruiting and handling agents in paramilitary organisations. 14 Company specialised in surveillance while 22 SAS undertook "executive actions".

FRU was divided into detachments - north, south, east and west. Headquarters FRU dealt only with material supplied by Stakeknife. Overall, FRU had a complement of about 100 soldiers. Stakeknife was said to have been paid £75,000 a year via an account in Gibraltar

webTitle: Challengers to the crown gather strength

fields.headline: Challengers to the crown gather strength
fields.standfirst:
NetNews
Special report on the future of Microsoft: www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/microsoft
fields.trailText: Bill Gates is particularly concerned about Linux, an operating system pioneered by a Finnish engineer, Linus Torvalds. Linux proclaimed itself open to all, and was converting users and provoking considerable buzz.
fields.body:
Linux

Bill Gates is particularly concerned about Linux, an operating system pioneered by a Finnish engineer, Linus Torvalds. Linux proclaimed itself open to all, and was converting users and provoking considerable buzz.

In full-page newspaper ads in May 2000, IBM hailed the free and open Linux operating system as "the fastest growing operating system in the world". Windows' market share in early 2000 dropped to 82%, with Linux and Apple each claiming 9%. With PC sales slowing, America Online and Gateway agreed in April 2000 to accelerate the move to the post-PC era by producing low cost internet appliances that will use Linux.

RealNetworks

Rob Glaser joined Microsoft in 1983, and had been close to Gates before leaving to start streaming expert RealNetworks. In June 2000, Glaser and Apple's Steve Jobs announced that they would align their streaming media efforts and would jointly attack the number three streaming media provider, Microsoft. Later that summer, AOL agreed to broadcast RealNetworks audio and video software to its members.

AOL

AOL announced that it had purchased a stake in a voice recognition company, hoping to go head to head against Microsoft. DoCoMo agreed to assume a 43% stake in AOL Japan and to run the enterprise, and together they would provide wireless web access.

Although the browser wars now appear to be over - with Microsoft's market share surging to 86% and Netscape's plummeting to just under 14% - America Online announced in the spring of 2000 the debut of the new Netscape 6 browser, which Steve Case insisted was superior to Microsoft's.

Should America Online replace Microsoft's browser when their contract lapses in January 2001, Netscape's share of the browser market would jump to 40%.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Jospin under fire
fields.body:
Jospin under fire

The French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, unveiled a controversial tax credit scheme yesterday to boost the spending power of low earners.

The plan, which gives annual rebates to nearly 9m workers who earn less than Fr10,000 (£1,000) a month, was criticised by opposition politicians and members of his ruling socialist coalition. Stuart Jeffries, Paris

Woman executed

A 41-year-old convicted killer has become the first black woman to be executed in the US since 1954. Wanda Allen received a lethal dose of drugs at Oklahoma state penitentiary on Thursday night.

In 1981, she fatally shot a childhood friend and seven years later killed her lesbian lover. Before Thursday, 44 women had been executed in the US since 1900. AP, Oklahoma

Artist's last work

An Estonian artist known for using pyrotechnics in his artwork died after he apparently doused himself in petrol and set himself alight in front of Tallinn art university.

Hours before his death, Lauri Tiidemann, 26, and other artists, had turned discarded Christmas trees into sculptures and set them on fire on a nearby beach. AP, Tallinn

webTitle: Police check link to two other children

fields.headline: Police check link to two other children
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Police are investigating the cases of two other children from Ivory Coast after they found paperwork in Carl Manning's flat to suggest that they had been adopted by Marie Therese Kouao.
fields.body:
Police are investigating the cases of two other children from Ivory Coast after they found paperwork in Carl Manning's flat to suggest that they had been adopted by Marie Therese Kouao.

The officer who led the investigation into Anna's death, Det Insp Keith Niven, said he was carrying out inquiries with the French authorities with regard to two children who he believed may have suffered at the hands of Kouao. He said: "I just want to talk to them to check upon their welfare in the light of what Marie Therese has done in relation to Anna.

"Knowing this woman's capabilities, we are very concerned for the other children. We need to know they are safe and are making inquiries."

While trying to find paperwork that would lead them to Anna's real identity - Kouao was adamant after her arrest that she was her daughter - police discovered documents from the minor supervision department of Vanves magistrates court in France, dated April 28 1993, which show that Kouao applied for guardianship of a girl named Christelle Koula, age not stated, at a time when she was living at 27 Rue Phileas Lebesque in Amiens.

During her trial at the Old Bailey, Kouao claimed that Christelle was her sister's daughter and that she was still living in France.

Paperwork from Abidjan magistrates court shows that Kouao also applied for custody of a boy named Aime Constant Allo, 15, on September 5 1996. When asked in court about him, Kouao claimed she never took the boy to France and he remained with his parents.

Kouao has an adopted daughter, Claudine, who is living in France.

Police said they were interested in speaking to another person with regard to Kouao's actions.

fields.headline: Papon seeks freedom
fields.trailText: Lawyers have asked for the release of Maurice Papon, the Vichy official jailed nearly three years ago for his role in deporting Jews to Nazi death camps, on the grounds that his continued incarceration is "inhuman and degrading".
fields.body:
Lawyers have asked for the release of Maurice Papon, the Vichy official jailed nearly three years ago for his role in deporting Jews to Nazi death camps, on the grounds that his continued incarceration is "inhuman and degrading".

"The imprisonment of a man aged 90 in these conditions is contrary to article three of the European convention of human rights," their 20-page submission to the European court in Strasbourg says.

They are also claiming 1m francs (about £120,000) as compensation for the moral and physical damage to Papon "as a result of the inhuman treatment inflicted upon him".

They say he suffered ill health in Fresnes prison, in suburban Paris. He has since been transferred to La Santé prison, where conditions are "better adapted", but, they add, French prisons are "absolutely ill-adapted to receive people as old as our client".

A former justice minister, Robert Badinter, supported the plea yesterday, saying: "People say 'crimes against humanity', but I would say that there is a moment at which humanity must prevail over the crime."

Papon was a senior official in Bordeaux of the Vichy government who subsequently made a respected name for himself, serving as prefect of police for Paris under President Valéry Giscard d'Estaing.

In 1998 he was found guilty of having helped to transfer 1,560 Bordeaux Jews to death camps and jailed for 10 years for "complicity in crimes against humanity".

Serge Klarsfeld, president of the Association of Sons and Daughters of Jews deported from France, said Papon had to serve his term, pointing out that the Vichy head of state, Marshal Pétain, was kept in jail until he was over 95.

webTitle: EU asked for money to raise Kursk

fields.headline: EU asked for money to raise Kursk
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: European Union countries are being asked to pay millions of dollars to raise the Kursk, the Russian nuclear-powered submarine which sank with all hands in the Barents Sea last summer.
fields.body:
European Union countries are being asked to pay millions of dollars to raise the Kursk, the Russian nuclear-powered submarine which sank with all hands in the Barents Sea last summer.

According to detailed plans unveiled in Brussels yesterday, it will cost some $70m (£47m) to lift the stricken vessel, in which 118 sailors lost their lives.

Salvage work is to begin in April and, weather permitting, should be completed by August, said officials of the Kursk Foundation, marshalling unique maritime heavy-lifting and towing equipment for the complex project.

The submarine's shattered nose cone will be cut off and left 108 metres below the surface. Russian experts will deal with the 24 cruise missiles on board, which Moscow insists are not carrying nuclear warheads.

"There is no question that the boat should not be left alone on the bottom of the sea," said the former Soviet foreign minister Alexander Bessmertnykh, who chairs the international foundation with a former Dutch defence minister, Willem van Eekelen.

Russia has reassured the international community that the two nuclear reactors on board were automatically shut down when the vessel exploded and sank. But there are fears that the environment will suffer after radioactive leakage is caused by corrosive seawater and strong currents if the submarine is left untouched for too long.

The foundation is after funding support from the US, Japan and Canada for the operation. But Brussels is a special target, with high-level talks between the EU and Russia due in Moscow next week.

"The EU and the Swedish presidency have indicated that relations with Russia are a high priority," said foundation spokesman David Webber. "Now they have a chance to show their commitment."

American, Russian and Dutch companies will be involved in the three-stage recovery operation, in which the Kursk will be raised, secured and towed to Murmansk. Divers will attach cables to the top of the submarine and a giant barge, specially fitted to tow the 14,000-tonne boat, will make the the three-day voyage.

Environmental groups have warned that lifting the Kursk could be too dangerous, risking a breakup which would rupture the reactors' protective casings, endangering fish stocks and local wildlife.

Work by a Russian commission investigating the disaster has still not determined what happened. Officials have repeatedly suggested that the Kursk collided with a foreign submarine, but say an internal explosion could also have been the cause.

webTitle: Wallenberg: the riddle that will not unravel

fields.headline: Wallenberg: the riddle that will not unravel
fields.standfirst: Fate of 'Swedish Schindler' is still uncertain
fields.trailText: Fate of 'Swedish Schindler' is still uncertain.
fields.body:
Shrouded in mystery and mendacity for more than half a century, the fate of Raoul Wallenberg, Sweden's war hero and Stalin's victim, was left unresolved yesterday when nine years of joint Swedish-Russian investigation ended with both sides agreeing to disagree as to whether Wallenberg was alive or dead.

Arrested by Stalin's secret police as the Red Army fought the Nazis for Budapest in January 1945, Wallenberg, a "Swedish Schindler" who singlehandedly saved thousands of Hungarian Jews from the gas chambers, was spirited away into the Gulag and never heard from again.

Ever since, his ghost has haunted Russia and Sweden and his mystery has gnawed at the consciences of Moscow and Stockholm. His story has been a long and sad tale of Russian cruelty, lying, and cynicism, buttressed by official Swedish complicity with Stalin's henchmen.

Both countries have spent nine long years poring over the archives, seeking out contemporary witnesses, prising open secrets to try, once and for all, to draw a line under the Wallenberg case. The riddle refuses to unravel.

Accentuating their lack of consensus, Moscow and Stockholm issued separate reports on the Wallenberg case yesterday, unable to agree on a common version.

Fundamentally, the Russians now insist that Stalin's executioners shot Wallenberg dead at the secret police headquarters, the Lubyanka, in Moscow on July 17 1947.

Not necessarily so, say the Swedes. The jury is still out. There is no death certificate and no documents proving the killing. "It does not seem possible to draw any definite conclusion about the real fate of Raoul Wallenberg," said the Swedish side. Born in 1912, Wallenberg would be 88 years old if he were alive today.

The Swedish prime minister, Goran Persson, said: "As long as there is no unequivocal evidence of what happened to Wallenberg, and this is still the case, it cannot be said that Raoul Wallenberg is dead."

By contrast, Vyacheslav Tuchnin, the head of the Russian side of the joint commission told the Guardian there was no doubt that Wallenberg was killed in July 1947 at the age of 34.

In November, Alexander Yakovlev, the head of a Russian commission for the rehabilitation of Stalin's victims, also delivered the same verdict and among other evidence said that Vladimir Kryuchkov, the former KGB chief and leading coup plotter against Mikhail Gorbachev in 1991, had told him so.

The Russian authorities then rehabilitated Wallenberg as "a victim of the political repressions", referring to the alleged fact that he had "perished".

Independent Swedish researchers and Wallenberg's relatives refuse to accept this version and are convinced that the Swede was alive somewhere in the Soviet prison system well into the 1970s and maybe the 1980s. They note that it was only in 1989 that Moscow turned over Wallenberg's passport and other personal effects and take that as a sign that he had just died.

Mr Tuchnin said it was only last year, eight years into the work of the researchers, that Russia finally opened up the Kremlin archives and made available fresh documents on the case.

Secret mission

The Wallenberg saga of heroism and tragedy starts in early 1944 when Europe's Jews were perishing en masse in the Holocaust. Budapest was still home to the biggest surviving Jewish community on the continent, around 700,000.

Adolf Eichmann was overseeing their mass deportation to Auschwitz and other death camps. By July when Wallenberg, 32, arrived in Budapest on a secret mission as secretary of the Swedish legation, only 230,000 Jews remained in the city.

Within months he had saved at least 20,000 from certain death by doling out Swedish passports on trains, in the streets and among columns of prisoners being marched off. By January 1945 the Russians were encroaching and the Red Army had taken the eastern half of Budapest.

According to the Russian account disclosed yesterday, a Red Army intelligence officer reported to his superiors on January 14 1945 that Wallenberg was living in a street under Soviet control. Nikolai Bulganin, the deputy defence minister and later prime minister, ordered Wallenberg's arrest.

A Soviet counter-intelligence team seized him on January 17 and by February 6 he was jailed in Moscow as a prisoner of war. Moscow officials variously branded him a British, American or German spy, though there is no record of him having been tried or condemned.

It was in the war's immediate aftermath that the lying and cover-ups began, prompting a ringing apology yesterday from Mr Persson for Sweden's "mistakes". But the Russians, while now admitting criminal conduct, have yet to issue a formal apology to Wallenberg's relatives.

'Heart attack'

When the Swedes inquired about Wallenberg, Moscow first answered that he was under Soviet protection, then that he had fallen in the battle for Budapest.

Then in an infamous memorandum in 1957, the Soviet Union's longest serving foreign minister, Andrei Gromyko, announced, on the basis of an alleged doctor's certificate, that Wallenberg had died of a heart attack on July 17 1947 in the Lubyanka, the time and place the Russians now say he was shot.

But yesterday's revelations also exposed Swedish complicity with the Soviet lies, and the inadequate pressure put on Moscow by Stockholm. The Swedish ambassador in Moscow met Stalin in June 1946 and did not press the case because he believed Wallenberg was dead when he clearly was still alive.

And despite the Soviet falsehoods, Moscow also secretly offered to trade Wallenberg for Soviet defectors in Sweden but the overtures were rebuffed.

"It is now clear that more energetic and purposeful action on the part of Sweden during the 1940s could have led to a more successful outcome for Raoul Wallenberg and his relatives," Mr Persson said. "I should like today, on my own behalf and on behalf of the Swedish government, to extend our deepest regrets to his relatives for these mistakes."

Although there has been no saying sorry from the Russians, a joint Swedish-Russian statement resonated with strong condemnation of Moscow's conduct.

"The trials that befell [Wallenberg] from January 1945 arouse deep bitterness and compassion," the statement said. "His illegal arrest and imprisonment and the subsequent actions of the Soviet authorities are a great tragedy. Irrespective of the fact that the concrete circumstances surrounding these events are still not exactly known, the actions of the authorities at the time must be regarded both in Russia and in Sweden as criminal."

Unresolved since 1945

The Amber Room The glory of imperial St Petersburg, dubbed the eighth wonder of the world, this highly ornate study, clad in intricately carved Baltic amber, was presented by Prussia to Peter the Great in the early 18th century and installed at the Catherine Palace outside St Petersburg. The Nazis dismantled it and took it to German Königsberg, now Russian Kaliningrad, during the siege of Leningrad. It disappeared in 1945

Reparations It is only now that the hundreds of thousands of surviving slave labourers or their relatives, mainly in eastern Europe, are beginning to obtain some compensation from German firms and institutions that profited from their toil

War crimes In Britain, Germany, central Europe and the Baltic, allegations of surviving Nazi war criminals still regularly surface

Trophy art The issue of art and cultural objects looted by the Nazis and then by the Red Army is still very much alive and was discussed last week in Moscow by President Vladimir Putin and the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder. Ian Traynor

webTitle: Puzzled Swedes fail to get the pictures

fields.headline: Puzzled Swedes fail to get the pictures
fields.trailText: Empty white space marks the spot in Sweden's national museum where the two Renoirs used to hang, though a Rembrandt snatched from the next room has already been replaced - temporarily - by another 17th century Dutch work.
fields.body:
Empty white space marks the spot in Sweden's national museum where the two Renoirs used to hang, though a Rembrandt snatched from the next room has already been replaced - temporarily - by another 17th century Dutch work.

It was late on the Friday before Christmas when something like a bank heist shattered the cultured hush of the Italian-style palazzo on Stockholm's Hanseatic waterfront, opposite parliament andthe royal palace.

Masked men held off unarmed guards at gunpoint and cut down the three pictures, while accomplices burned cars to create a diversion and scattered nails to ease their getaway.

Three weeks after one of the boldest crimes Sweden has ever seen, five suspects are in custody. But the motives of the thieves and, crucially, the whereabouts of these priceless works of art, remain a mystery.

Swedes, stunned by the museum theft, are asking uneasy questions about security and violence, much as they did when the prime minister Olaf Palme was murdered outside a Stockholm cinema in 1986.

"It's embarrassing," the minister of justice, Thomas Borstrom said. "It was a shock for many people," said Hans-Henrik Brummer, the acting director of the fine arts gallery. "Things like that just don't happen here."

In extraordinary scenes, terrified visitors were held back in the lobby by one gunman while two others deployed on the second floor, where guard Dan Andersen - equipped only with a radio - was on duty in the old masters room.

"He was wearing a mask with holes for the eyes so I never saw his face," Mr Andersen (not his real name) recalled this week. "I went up and said: 'What the hell are you doing?' Then he pointed a gun at me and told me to lie down. He was very controlled."

The Rembrandt was a 20x30cm self-portrait painted in 1630 on copper plate. Seven larger works by the Dutch master were untouched.

In the next room, where a dazzling array of French impressionists are housed, the second thief used wire-cutters to quickly remove Renoir's Conversation and Young Parisian, both small and easily portable works.

Sprinting down the marble stairs to the museum lobby, they joined the third robber, left via the front door and jumped into a speedboat. By the time police arrived, six minutes later, it was all over.

Initially, Stockholm CID believed the crime had been commissioned by a wealthy collector willing to pay to keep the pictures for their private pleasure: clearly such famous works could never be sold or displayed openly.

But then came a new twist: police received a photograph of the pictures juxtaposed with a recent edition of a popular tabloid, along with a demand for several million kronor.

Police and the museum insist that paying a ransom is out of the question.

By last week, five men already in custody were joined by a Stockholm criminal lawyer accused of being an intermediary. But he was released after protesting his innocence.

webTitle: AOL Time Warner merger loses its gloss

fields.headline: AOL Time Warner merger loses its gloss
fields.standfirst:
Notebook Value creation evaporates
NetNews
fields.trailText: A lot has changed in the 367 days since America Online and Time Warner smacked every new economy gob in sight with their plan to create the biggest media and internet services company on the planet. Just look at it from the paper wealth perspective: on announcement day, the combined businesses were worth $160bn; yesterday, as trading in the new entity - AOL Time Warner, logically - finally got under way, its market value had shrunk to below $110bn. So much for value creation.
fields.body:
A lot has changed in the 367 days since America Online and Time Warner smacked every new economy gob in sight with their plan to create the biggest media and internet services company on the planet. Just look at it from the paper wealth perspective: on announcement day, the combined businesses were worth $160bn; yesterday, as trading in the new entity - AOL Time Warner, logically - finally got under way, its market value had shrunk to below $110bn. So much for value creation.

Of course, the evaporation of investor confidence in the internet revolution and the rapid deceleration of the US economic growth has played a substantial part in taking the gloss off this deal. But so too have doubts over how these two heavyweights of the old and new economies are going to integrate their businesses - and make real money.

Predictably chief executive Gerald Levin, chief executive of the new monster, tried to dispel such doubts, stating bluntly: "When you have the number one position in so many different areas, there are a lot of different levers you can pull from a revenue perspective."

The betting now, however, is that the first lever to be yanked will be that big old fashioned one, labelled "job cuts". Staff at CNN, the cable news network owned by Time Warner, are already bracing themselves for up to 1,000 job cuts to be announced next week and others are expected. And, as Mr Levin conceded yesterday: "When you put two companies together, there are a number of cost opportunities."

Being the number one in any market also brings important responsibilities, as its rival, Microsoft, has belatedly learned. The AOL Time deal took more than a year to complete because of continued consumer and government fears about the enormous market power wielded by the combined group.

In agreeing to the merger, regulators have forced a string of restrictions which will, inevitably, restrain growth.

In particular, the combined group must open up its cable network and future instant messaging services to competitors.

Consumers are divided about how this will change the company's behaviour, however. The Ralph Nader-backed Consumer Project on Technology was continuing to insist yesterday that the merger should have been blocked, as it will simply "expose the internet to greater risks of monopolistic control". But it is more difficult than ever to peer into the cyber-future and say now, with any certainty, what would constitute an unfair alliance as far as consumers - and also other corporate competitors - are concerned.

The reality today is that this sector is full of companies, big and small, which are struggling to maintain the momentum and raw excitement which, to date, has been their life blood.

They are trying to hold themselves together, rather than hatching dastardly plots. The threat of world domination once presented by AOL Time Warner has seriously faded.

Abbey woe

Any hopes of quick result on the future ownership of Abbey National bank seem to be fading fast. The office of fair trading yesterday admitted it would need more time to consider the implications of its planned merger with Bank of Scotland. The new deadline - February 8 - is even later than the initial target date for advice to Stephen Byers, the secretary of state, on the rather trickier potential bid for Abbey by Lloyds TSB, which at present is set for February 3.

Nobody expects much action from any of the factions involved until some of the competition mist clears. So the prospect of a longer consideration period for the bid - allowed under the rules - leaves the door open for a round of lobbying by those who are more concerned about the fate of consumers than the value which might be delivered to shareholders.

Yesterday, Vincent Cable, the vocal liberal democrat shadow trade and industry secretary, popped up with a letter to "Stephen", to "suggest you should consider referring the proposed merger of Lloyds TSB and Abbey National to the competition commission to investigate the threats to competition, particularly in the current account market".

We can expect the Consumers' Association to follow with its a submission, after holding its own meeting with Abbey National on Monday, apparently to get behind the facts in the event of a Lloyds TSB takeover.

In the short run, this will stack a little higher the odds against Lloyds' success, since a merger with Abbey National would give it more than 25% of the current account market and avoid the creation of a so-called fifth force in high street banking which the alternative merger with Bank of Scotland would create.

But in the meantime Ian Harley, Abbey National's strangely quiet chief executive, must feel very uneasy about having his defence documentation written by such left-leaning lobbyists.

webTitle: Friend or foe? Police ready for allcomers on Bush's big day

fields.headline: Friend or foe? Police ready for allcomers on Bush's big day
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the US elections
Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: A presidential inauguration is normally the closest the United States gets to a coronation. But with one week to go before George W Bush takes the oath of office on January 20, authorities in Washington are preparing both for celebrations and for a possible riot.
fields.body:
A presidential inauguration is normally the closest the United States gets to a coronation. But with one week to go before George W Bush takes the oath of office on January 20, authorities in Washington are preparing both for celebrations and for a possible riot.

The unprecedented levels of security reflect the political turmoil which surrounded Mr Bush's defeat of Al Gore after 36 days of disputes over the results of the election in Florida.

The traditional four-day whirl of celebrations and kill-for-a-ticket social events kicks off on Thursday with a concert featuring Ricky Martin and Van Morrison and including a tribute to US sporting heroes, including Muhammad Ali and Marion Jones. But it is the inauguration ceremony next Saturday which is the real focus.

About 750,000 people are expected to throng the centre of Washington when Mr Bush is sworn in on Capitol Hill before the traditional parade along Pennsylvania Avenue to the White House.

Police say they are expecting the largest number of inauguration day demonstrators since Richard Nixon's second inaugural in 1973, during the Vietnam war. They anticipate more than 5,000 "rowdy" protesters, some of whom are veterans of the anti-globalisation demonstrations in Seattle in 1999 and at the Washington IMF meetings last year. Some protesters are expected to fly in from Europe.

"As George Bush goes up Pennsylvania Avenue he's going to be met by demonstrators throughout the inaugural parade," said Brian Becker of the International Action Centre, one of the groups mobilising.

"There is intelligence information that a lot of people are disgruntled and a lot of demonstrators are coming," said Michael Radzilowski, commander of the District of Columbia police special operations division. "We are trying to err on the side of everybody's safety."

The law enforcement presence is expected to go far beyond anything Washington has seen for an inauguration.

As many as 10,000 police, secret service and other security forces are expected to be deployed. Officers will stand at 6ft intervals along the entire mile and a half route from the Capitol to the White House. Much of the national Mall, the open grassy area in the centre of the city which has seen some of the most important public rallies in US history, will be roped off and closed.

Access to the parade route will be through police checkpoints only. Anyone carrying a placard - "Hail to the Thief" has replaced "Hail to the Chief" as Washington's slogan of the moment - will have it confiscated unless it is handheld on a wooden stake no more than three-quarters of an inch square.

"People are upset. They have concerns and they wish to tell this President George Bush what they view as wrong with this country, where they see injustices," said Mara Verheyden-Hilliard, a lawyer with the Partnership for Civil Justice. "He is not entitled to privatise the parade route. He is not entitled to use the power of the state to stop people from saying things that are in opposition to his policies."

"We are not policing their message," said Mr Radzilowski. "We are looking at any type of weapons that can be used against us or the crowd. We don't want pro-Bush crowds taking sticks out of their backpacks and hitting the demonstrators over the head.

"The last thing we want is 50 pro-Bush guys jumping one of these poor demonstrators."

webTitle: NSPCC calls for overhaul of child protection procedures

fields.headline: NSPCC calls for complete overhaul of child protection procedures
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The NSPCC said the inquiry into Anna Climbie's murder should lead to a complete overhaul of child protection procedures.
fields.body:
The NSPCC said the inquiry into Anna Climbie's murder should lead to a complete overhaul of child protection procedures.

Mary Marsh, the society's director, said the rate of child murders in England and Wales had not dropped in the past 25 years. "In each generation of children more than 1,000 will be killed before reaching adulthood. Most will die at the hands of violent or neglectful parents and carers.

"This country has made great strides in reducing the number of children who die from accidents or illness. Child protection agencies protect tens of thousands of children from harm every year, often under extremely difficult circumstances. Yet nationally we have failed to cut the overall number of children who die from abuse or neglect."

She said a new national strategy should include child wellbeing indicators, to monitor cases of maltreatment, and national targets to reduce deaths from child abuse and neglect. Child death review teams should look at the circumstances of all unexpected or suspicious deaths.

Alison Murphy, director of children's services at the charity Childline, said lessons should be learned from the case.

"Child death inquiries point to a number of factors in protecting children, including the importance of communication. Child protection is everyone's responsibility and we must all look for early warning signs and listen carefully to children. Childline receives many calls from children who are suffering in dangerous situations and feel they have nowhere else to turn. It is important that children can access help when they are in trouble or danger."

David Lammy, Labour MP for Tottenham where Anna endured the torture, said: "One cannot account for the wickedness of individuals. However, it is our collective responsibility to intervene in such wickedness and ensure that no harm comes to innocent people, particularly our children. There were distinct opportunities for intervention that were missed. Anna had been in the country for two years, yet she wasn't registered with a GP or a school.

"People in deprived communities deserve and require the best from public services. Too often they receive the worst."

Taki Suleiman, lead member for housing and social security at Haringey council, said the authority accepted full responsibility for the part it played as the leading child protection agency in the case.

Social workers and managers had been suspended and a disciplinary inquiry set up. Procedures had been changed to tighten supervision and an independent reviewer was examining the way social workers carried out their jobs, he told BBC Radio 4's The World at One.

"I feel very strongly that there may have been some cultural value judgments that were made which need to be unpacked and examined in greater detail through an inquiry," she said.

"African families have a lot of respect for their elders. Therefore, the fear displayed by Anna, as spotted by numerous professionals, was [interpreted] as a result of the respect needed in African families."
