fields.headline: Inquiries, suspensions and disciplinary action as authorities pick up the pieces
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Anna Climbie was failed at every turn by authorities who could have taken simple measures to prevent her murder. Now, detailed investigations are to look at what went wrong in the slow, tormented months that led to the child's death in February 1999.
fields.body:
Anna Climbie was failed at every turn by authorities who could have taken simple measures to prevent her murder. Now, detailed investigations are to look at what went wrong in the slow, tormented months that led to the child's death in February 1999.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, said yesterday that a statutory inquiry would look at every aspect of the case, including health, housing, social services, local authority and police involvement across four London boroughs.

In the meantime, a social worker has been suspended and four other social workers and eight police officers have been served with disciplinary papers. All are being investigated over their involvement in the case. Their failings were underlined at the Old Bailey by Nigel Rumfitt, the defence QC. "Those people exhibited a blinding degree of incompetence. If you came across a child in need, you would do more good calling the RAC than those people," he said.

Yesterday, the trial judge, Richard Hawkins, said that "lessons must be learned about failures of social services and the police inquiry following Anna's release from the North Middlesex hospital". He added: "I would like to be kept informed of the result of any inquiry."

Mr Milburn has asked for an early report "to determine what action should be taken to enhance the protection of vulnerable children". All agencies will be required to cooperate and the report will be published in full. The inquiry will be by Lord Laming, a former chief inspector of social services who had been due to chair a private inquiry into Harold Shipman, the killer GP, before relatives of the victims forced a public inquiry.

Anna's death was an appalling tragedy, Mr Milburn said. "She was murdered by her 'carers', but was undoubtedly failed repeatedly by the child protection system. We will take all necessary steps to ensure wherever possible such failures cannothappen again."

The government placed the Haringey social services department, the main child protection agency in the case, under special measures requiring close supervision by the inspectorate.

A review undertaken when a child has died and abuse is suspected was suspended pending the trial. However, it had already concluded that "a catalogue of errors and poor judgment led to the failure to protect this girl. Anna came to the agencies... on three separate occasions with signs and symptoms of abuse. Intervention on any one of these could have saved her life."

It recommended a thorough review of the way police and social services work together, and clear and comprehensive child protection guidelines in every local authority.

Apart from the government inquiry, the agencies that failed Anna have all launched internal investigations. Two other councils - Brent and Ealing - whose social services departments had had concerns about Anna lodged with them, will cooperate with the government inquiry.

Yesterday, the Metropolitan police's child protection team admitted that its procedures were "inadequate". Its child protection teams have been restructured and eight officers are being investigated by the police complaints authority.

Commander Carole Howlett, who has special responsibility for the teams, said she would ensure "as far as possible that such an appalling tragedy cannot happen again".

Haringey's director of housing and social services, Anne Bristow, admitted that the council should have prevented the tragedy. She said officers should have checked on the fact that Anna had never been to school in this country.

"Clearly visits should have been made and action taken when the allegations were made," she said. "The system failed Anna - and we are part of the system."

She said Lisa Arthurworrey, the social worker who refused to visit Manning's flat in Tottenham for fear of catching scabies, had been suspended pending the inquiry outcome.

John Riordan, medical director for the North-West London hospital NHS trust, responsible for North Middlesex hospital from where Anna was discharged back to Kouao, said they would not be carrying out disciplinary procedures against their staff, but would help with Mr Milburn's inquiry as much as possible.

Moira Gibb, president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, said it was premature to call for a fundamental overhaul of a child protec tion service that was "probably the most sophisticated in Europe, and which many professionals from other countries envy and admire".

She acknowledged "serious, inexcusable professional failures in this case", but said they did not seem to stem from a lack of collaboration between agencies. "The system we have is pretty good, but it obviously depends on the individuals working in it," she said.

The association said the inquiry should look particularly hard at protection arrangements for vulnerable children coming from abroad.

Missed chances

July 15 Anna is returned from Central Middlesex hospital to Kouao because the consultant paediatrician is persuaded that her injuries - cuts, bruises and red eyes - were self-inflicted as a result of scratching because of itchiness from scabies.

August 6 After two weeks in North Middlesex hospital having allegedly poured boiling water over her head Anna is returned again. She had told social worker Lisa Arthurworrey and PC Karen Jones that she caused her own injuries.

November 1 Anna makes an unfounded sexual allegation against Manning, withdrawn the next day. Arthurworrey believes Kouao put the child up to it in order to get housing. The social worker's police partner on the child protection team is assigned to find out why the false allegation was made. Her letter to Kouao is ignored. No further action is taken.

The government placed the Haringey social services department, the main child protection agency in the case, under special measures requiring close supervision by the inspectorate. A review undertaken when a child has died and abuse is suspected was suspended pending the trial. However, it had already concluded that "a catalogue of errors and poor judgment led to the failure to protect this girl. Anna came to the agencies... on three separate occasions with signs and symptoms of abuse. Intervention on any one of these could have saved her life." It recommended a thorough review of the way police and social services work together, and clear and comprehensive child protection guidelines in every local authority. Apart from the government inquiry, the agencies that failed Anna have all launched internal investigations. Two other councils - Brent and Ealing - whose social services departments had had concerns about Anna lodged with them, will cooperate with the government inquiry. Yesterday, the Metropolitan police's child protection team admitted that its procedures were "inadequate". Its child protection teams have been restructured and eight officers are being investigated by the police complaints authority. Commander Carole Howlett, who has special responsibility for the teams, said she would ensure "as far as possible that such an appalling tragedy cannot happen again". Haringey's director of housing and social services, Anne Bristow, admitted that the council should have prevented the tragedy. She said officers should have checked on the fact that Anna had never been to school in this country. "Clearly visits should have been made and action taken when the allegations were made," she said. "The system failed Anna - and we are part of the system." She said Lisa Arthurworrey, the social worker who refused to visit Manning's flat in Tottenham for fear of catching scabies, had been suspended pending the inquiry outcome. John Riordan, medical director for the North-West London hospital NHS trust, responsible for North Middlesex hospital from where Anna was discharged back to Kouao, said they would not be carrying out disciplinary procedures against their staff, but would help with Mr Milburn's inquiry as much as possible. Moira Gibb, president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, said it was premature to call for a fundamental overhaul of a child protec tion service that was "probably the most sophisticated in Europe, and which many professionals from other countries envy and admire". She acknowledged "serious, inexcusable professional failures in this case", but said they did not seem to stem from a lack of collaboration between agencies. "The system we have is pretty good, but it obviously depends on the individuals working in it," she said. Missed chances July 15 Anna is returned from Central Middlesex hospital to Kouao because the consultant paediatrician is persuaded that her injuries - cuts, bruises and red eyes - were self-inflicted as a result of scratching because of itchiness from scabies. August 6 After two weeks in North Middlesex hospital having allegedly poured boiling water over her head Anna is returned again. She had told social worker Lisa Arthurworrey and PC Karen Jones that she caused her own injuries. November 1 Anna makes an unfounded sexual allegation against Manning, withdrawn the next day. Arthurworrey believes Kouao put the child up to it in order to get housing. The social worker's police partner on the child protection team is assigned to find out why the false allegation was made. Her letter to Kouao is ignored. No further action is taken.

webTitle: Bourne digs deeper for his dream

fields.headline: Bourne digs deeper for his dream
fields.standfirst:
Dome's future: Consortium's front man seals £125m three-year, interest-free, hire-purchase deal

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Dome's future: Consortium's front man seals £125m three-year, interest-free, hire-purchase deal.
fields.byline: Kevin Maguire, Jill Treanor, Terry Macalister and Jamie Wilson
fields.body:
Robert Bourne is an old romantic with a taste for candlelit dinners and a passion for sending flowers to his wife, the theatre impresario Sally Greene. So the property developer must be tickled pink that ministers have chosen St Valentine's Day, February 14, as the date on which his Legacy consortium finally signs to buy the Millennium Dome for £125m.

"I went to see the structure of the dome going up... I thought, this is absolutely unbelievable, an icon building," said the Tory-turned-Labour donor.

The deal will be the commercial equivalent of a householder, in this case the Cabinet Office minister Lord Falconer, exchanging contracts with the prospective buyer, Mr Bourne and the Legacy consortium. But completion has been delayed until June, leaving Lord Falconer still holding the keys to the dome on May 3, when Tony Blair is expected to go to the country.

Perhaps it is fitting that the dome will still be in public hands, since the prime minister intended to make Greenwich's huge upturned wok the first paragraph of his manifesto, if it had lived up its billing as the greatest show on earth, rather than one of the most embarrassing episodes of the Labour government in swallowing large doses of money and failing to attract the anticipated 12m visitors.

Yet Mr Bourne, runner-up when the dome was first up for sale and the only bidder when the Japanese bank Nomura pulled out, is happy to wait a little longer as the contents are removed and site cleared. During a break in negotiations with the solicitors representing the government, he revealed that he did not have to put the initial £50m down until June, with the remaining £75m due over three years in what must be one of the biggest ever interest-free hire-purchase agreements.

He is getting the dome and 25.5 hectares (63 acres) of prime land for £125m after last year offering £150m for only 19.5 hectares. Given that £845m was pumped into the site by the public sector, he has driven a hard bargain.

Serious doubts are growing, however, over Legacy's plans to turn what is seen as a white elephant in the public sector into the successful hi-tech Knowledge City presented in Mr Bourne's flip charts and artists' impressions.

He himself has had to plough another £2.5m of his own fortune into the project after a main backer, the construction company Sir Robert McAlpine, pulled out. This increases his Legacy stake to 15% at a personal cost of £7.5m.

Legacy was set up as a shell company by Mr Bourne in January 1999. The Irish developers Richard Barrett and John Ronan, through their controversial group Treasury Holdings, hold an 80% stake. In fiendishly complicated financing deal, the remaining 5% is held by Bank of Scotland, which is committed to lending Legacy £50m in the first year of a three-year redevelopment. Eventually, the £150m total cost of refitting the dome as a "high-technology campus" will be turned into a 20-year loan from the bank, leaving the consortium heavily in debt.

Lord Falconer, anxious to get Mr Bourne's signature, is playing down Legacy's failure to get Sir Robert McAlpine aboard, while Mr Bourne shrugged it off, claiming that McAlpine would take a stake "in due course". That company was not so certain, as a spokesman declared: "We are interested in the construction side [of Knowledge City] but we are not a shareholder, and as far as I am concerned this has not been discussed."

Mr Bourne, listed at Companies House as a director of 54 companies, boasts that he can turn in a profit by the third year when the development phase ends.

Ministers, fearful of fresh charges that a public asset was sold on the cheap, have insisted on a 10-year profit-sharing clause. The government will share in any profit made in the first 10 years on a descending scale, taking all profit in the unlikely event of surplus in the first 12 months and then nothing from year 11.

The £125m price tag on the dome is also conditional on certain planning permissions being granted, particularly for a housing development.

"By the end of year three, we want the operation in the dome to be profitable," said Mr Bourne. "We deserve no less. We are a business. We're investing £150m for transforming the inside and £125m for the dome."

The idea of Knowledge City is to build inside the "wind and watertight" dome with skylights. Space age capsules along boulevards with mature trees is the idea, renting out desks through flexible charging structures starting at, say, £50 a week in buildings of 10 floors.

Mr Bourne claims that many companies are interested in taking space, with phase one "pretty much spoken for" as he brandishes Legacy brochures listing universities and companies such as Sun Microsystems. Not so, said Ian Merritt, Sun's manager responsible for these negotiations. "We do need more physical space for training and sales staff because of natural growth in the company," he said. "We are in negotiation but we have not signed anything."

He suggested that any future agreement would be dependent on Sun selling Legacy a lot of information technology infrastructure.

The original plans for Knowledge City envisaged it as a business park for telecoms and dot.com-type start-ups, but as these sectors went into decline on the stock market Legacy changed its pitch towards the controversial but temporarily booming biotech sector.

Mr Bourne, who started out in property development in the 1970s, doing up and renting clapped-out offices, talks of transforming the dome and its surrounding area into a "vibrant" place.

Scores of shops, pubs, cafes and restaurants are part of his plans and so are houses, though he turns coy when pressed on details. Surrounded by water on three sides, flats would sell at a premium because of views of the Thames. Mr Bourne has said he has made no planning applications.

The front man for the consortium, Mr Bourne - who has given the Labour party £100,000 over three years, the final £33,000 during negotiations to buy the dome - has presented himself as the businessman who will transform one of the government's worst failures into a shining success.

Legacy in fact is controlled by the two highly ambitious Irish tycoons, whose Treasury Holdings has thrived more than most in the murky waters of the Dublin property market and has an £800m portfolio on both sides of the Irish sea. Richard Barrett and Johnny Ronan's rise to the top has not been without incident, with their company making its fair share of enemies both in business and political circles.

Accusations of sharp practices, including an apparent admission of trying to fix an auction for an office block and trying to run another property developer out of town by bombarding him with lawsuits, have been ranged against the pair, while a row in the Irish parliament led to the company's being branded "purveyors of untruths".

Their public relations adviser, Sean O'Riordain, said the accusations were unfair and old hat. "It is a tough business, and to achieve the success that Johnny and Richard have achieved they are obviously tough businessmen," he said. "But they are also fair people, and they command the respect of the business community not just nationally but internationally. The sort of backing they have got does not come to a pair of shysters."

Not everybody in Dublin agrees, including Michael Smith of An Taisce, the Irish National Trust conservation agency, who sees the pair as buccaneers with cutlasses in their mohair suits.

"Court documentation reveals Treasury as 'cavalier, litigious and gratu itously truculent'," hesaid. "Their failure to observe the prevailing ethic has attracted comprehensive and virulent antagonism across every sector, from community to environmental to government and most interestingly to the commercial and construction sectors."

Some claims are backed up by court documents. In a letter to Paul Clinton, a property developer with whom Mr Ronan and Mr Barrett have had numerous run-ins over a Dublin city centre shopping mall, Mr Barrett wrote: "Certain opponents of ours have underestimated our ability to cause legal chaos to their detriment."

Treasury Holdings is seeking a low public profile within Legacy, despite owning four-fifths of the consortium and the fact Mr Barrett and Maurice Harte, the chief executive, will be on the board of the dome's new owner.

"The dome is very much a Legacy vision, a vision we support, and I do not want to take anything out of their enthusiasm and drive on it," Mr Harte said. "We are there as investors, and our aim is to help them to drive the project through to a success."

Going under the hammer for four days from February 27 will be the contents of the dome, including acrobatic props and rigging, golf buggies and battery powered scooters, and parts of the giant body with its pubic lice.

Mr Bourne is not so gauche as to claim that he has already got the biggest bargain, but the winners from the sorry saga of the dome are certainly not lottery ticket buying members of the public, whose cash has been squandered on the project.

Is the government finally getting value for money? "If you are asking, 'Have I ever sold a dome before?' the answer is no," said Lord Falconer, "but I have to make it clear I am being advised by the competition team."

fields.headline: Catalogue of cruelty
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: 1984 Jasmine Beckford is battered to death. The four-year-old had been slowly starved and beaten by her stepfather Maurice Beckford while her mother looked on.
fields.body:
1984 Jasmine Beckford is battered to death. The four-year-old had been slowly starved and beaten by her stepfather Maurice Beckford while her mother looked on.

1984 Tyra Henry dies in local authority care. A report found that central to the case was the families being black and the social workers white. This encouraged social workers to be too trusting towards the parents.

1984 Heidi Koseda dies of starvation in Hayes, west London. Her stepfather Nicholas Price was jailed for life while her mother Rosemary Koseda was sent to a psychiatric hospital.

1986 Kimberley Carlile, four, is killed by her stepfather, Nigel Hall, who frustrated attempts by social workers and health visitors to investigate.

1987 Doreen Mason, 16 months, dies of neglect. She slept on the floor where her parents puts crisps, chips and hamburgers for her to eat. She had been tortured.

1992 Leanne White, three, is beaten to death by her stepfather who made her sleep on floorboards. Doctors found 107 marks on her body.

1993 Rikki Neave, six, is throttled with his coat zipper. A report three years later concluded that social workers failed to protect him and were "scared" of his drug-addict mother Ruth.

1994 Paul, 15 months, dies of neglect in a pool of urine. His grandmother had alerted social services, but no one acted. Paul's father, never named for legal reasons, was jailed for manslaughter.

fields.headline: Barak resorts to negative advertising
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Ehud Barak's desperate campaign staff were pinning the last of their shrinking hopes on a series of aggressive television advertisements yesterday after opinion polls showed the prime minister heading for political oblivion.
fields.body:
Ehud Barak's desperate campaign staff were pinning the last of their shrinking hopes on a series of aggressive television advertisements yesterday after opinion polls showed the prime minister heading for political oblivion.

In the latest polls the the hardline Likud leader, Ariel Sharon, is maintaining a 19-point lead over Mr Barak

But Mr Sharon's popularity is only part of the problem. While the poll in the newspaper Ma'ariv yesterday showed Mr Barak on 25% and Mr Sharon with 44%, it also showed the Nobel peace laureate Shimon Peres - who is not a candidate in the February 6 prime ministerial election - two points ahead of Mr Sharon.

To Eli Goldschmidt, who heads Mr Barak's information campaign, it was confirmation of his greatest fear: Mr Barak, while gaining slightly on his showing last week, has failed to close the gap with Mr Sharon to an acceptable degree.

Mr Peres's continued strong showing was "disastrous", ge said, because it increased the speculation that Mr Barak would step aside for the Mr Peres in the closing days of the campaign.

Yesterday Peres supporters in the Labour party launched an internet petition in support of his candidacy; others began printing campaign badges and posters earlier this week.

Party leaders said they should switch candidates if Mr Barak's team did not produce a significant gain in next week's opinion polls.

"It is very hard stimulating people to work when you have such a margin," Mr Goldschmidt said. "The polls can be a self-fulfiling prediction."

Mr Peres has particular appeal to voters on the left and among Israel's 1m Arab citizens. After months of violence in the West Bank and Gaza, and the collapse of the peace process, many on the Israeli left feel so let down by Mr Barak that they are not even going tovote, handing victory to the hawkish Mr Sharon by default.

The Barak survival strategy now hinges on the television ads, which will begin on Monday, focusing on Mr Sharon's character as a politically reckless warmonger and a "serial refusenik" of peace deals with Egypt, Jordan, and now the Palestinians.

"We have to do some historic milestones of our opponent in Lebanon," Mr Goldschmidt said.

"We must show the public, because many people under the age of 35 do not know what happened there.

"For me, the slogan 'Sharon can bring peace' is like saying that there can be snow in the summer in Tel Aviv." .

The ads are unlikely to use images of the 1,800 corpses left by the Christian militias' massacre of Palestinians in the Shatila and Sabra refugee camps in 1982 after Israel invaded Lebanon: the Barak campaign team has already been censured for a graphic newspaper ad last week.

They will, however, have clips of Mr Sharon's critics, including the late Likud prime minister Menachem Begin, who accused the burly former general of lying to him.

They will also show footage of Israeli tanks trundling into Lebanon in 1982 on Mr Sharon's orders, and rolling back out last May after Mr Barak ordered the army to withdraw.

That was the crowning achievement of Mr Barak's 18 months as prime minister. But it is difficult to fix that foreign-policy success in the Israeli collective memory, given the upheavals of recent months.

In public, at least, Mr Peres has been supportive of Mr Barak, having been promised a greater role as a peacemaker in the next government.

He is expected to hold talks tonight with the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, Israel Radio said, following the renewal of contacts overnight between Israeli and Palestinian negotiators.

 In the West Bank town of Hebron yesterday, a 23-year-old activist in Yasser Arafat's Fatah movement hurled an explosive device and fired shots at Israeli troops.

The soldiers returned fire, killing the assailant and wounding another man.

"For me, the slogan 'Sharon can bring peace' is like saying that there can be snow in the summer in Tel Aviv." . The ads are unlikely to use images of the 1,800 corpses left by the Christian militias' massacre of Palestinians in the Shatila and Sabra refugee camps in 1982 after Israel invaded Lebanon: the Barak campaign team has already been censured for a graphic newspaper ad last week. They will, however, have clips of Mr Sharon's critics, including the late Likud prime minister Menachem Begin, who accused the burly former general of lying to him. They will also show footage of Israeli tanks trundling into Lebanon in 1982 on Mr Sharon's orders, and rolling back out last May after Mr Barak ordered the army to withdraw. That was the crowning achievement of Mr Barak's 18 months as prime minister. But it is difficult to fix that foreign-policy success in the Israeli collective memory, given the upheavals of recent months. In public, at least, Mr Peres has been supportive of Mr Barak, having been promised a greater role as a peacemaker in the next government. He is expected to hold talks tonight with the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, Israel Radio said, following the renewal of contacts overnight between Israeli and Palestinian negotiators.  In the West Bank town of Hebron yesterday, a 23-year-old activist in Yasser Arafat's Fatah movement hurled an explosive device and fired shots at Israeli troops. The soldiers returned fire, killing the assailant and wounding another man.

webTitle: Henlys warns of drop in US sales

fields.headline: Henlys warns of drop in US sales
fields.trailText: Coach and bus builder Henlys yesterday warned that its full-year profits would be below expectations because coach orders in north America had fallen off towards the end of the year.
fields.body:
Coach and bus builder Henlys yesterday warned that its full-year profits would be below expectations because coach orders in north America had fallen off towards the end of the year.

The market, which expected full-year pre-tax profits of about £68m before goodwill, marked the shares down 75.5p to 382.5p.

Henlys' chief executive, Robert Wood, said the market had overreacted. The trading statement had been made in the light of a rising share price in the past month and recent heavy trading in the company's shares. In addition, full-year forecasts by the company's two house brokers had been at the top end of analysts' predictions.

The group said its Quebec-based Prevost subsidiary had missed its targets even though the performance of its main business, making bus shells for conversion to $1m luxury motor homes, was in line with expectations.

Overall uncertainties about the US economy reduced the number of coach sales by Henlys' north American businesses by 12-15%. For tax reasons, most sales are made towards the end of the year.

fields.headline: Lawyer accused of £2m fraud plot
fields.trailText: A City lawyer and a Danish businessman have been charged by the serious fraud office over missing pension funds totalling more than £2m.
fields.body:
A City lawyer and a Danish businessman have been charged by the serious fraud office over missing pension funds totalling more than £2m.

Paul Baxendale-Walker, senior partner of Baxendale Walker solicitors, and Bjorn Stiedl are accused of conspiring to defraud 165 members of the Glascow-based fund.

The charges involve cash invested in the Clarion retirement and benefits scheme which was made up of contributions from Balfron Group, a local engineering company.

Both men are on conditional bail and due to appear before Bow Street magistrates at a hearing scheduled for February 14.

The charges, which are understood to have been brought before Christmas, follow an investigation by the SFO and Surrey police.

Mr Stiedl, 39, is living in London and is on conditional bail of £100,000 security and £100,000 surety.

Conditions were imposed on his residence and he has had to surrender his passport.

Mr Baxendale-Walker, 36, is also on conditional bail, with £50,000 surety, and has surrendered his passport.

webTitle: IMF damps down fears of another Asian crisis

fields.headline: IMF damps down fears of another Asian crisis
fields.trailText: The International Monetary Fund yesterday announced a sharp cut in its forecast for US growth this year but sought to sugar the pill for jittery financial markets by ruling out a repeat of the financial contagion that swept across the globe in 1997 and 1998.
fields.body:
The International Monetary Fund yesterday announced a sharp cut in its forecast for US growth this year but sought to sugar the pill for jittery financial markets by ruling out a repeat of the financial contagion that swept across the globe in 1997 and 1998.

Horst Köhler, the IMF's managing director, said the world's biggest economy was likely to expand 2.5% in 2001, compared with the fund's previous projection of 3.2%, but was "on balance" still on course for a "soft landing" after its recent boom.

While he acknowledged that he was surprised by the pace of the reduction in American growth in recent months, Mr Köhler said it was necessary to avoid swinging from the "exaggerated optimism of a few months ago to an exaggerated pessimism today".

Speaking in Tokyo, he said the signs still suggested that the US would avoid a recession - particularly in the wake of last week's half-point cut in interest rates by the Federal Reserve, the US central bank.

"And, if necessary, there is quite a lot of further room for manoeuvre in both monetary and fiscal policy to maintain growth," Mr Köhler added.

Asia would feel the impact of the slowdown in the US, he said, urging the continent to speed up the pace of its economic reforms.

The IMF now expects growth in Asia - excluding Japan - to slow down to around 5% this year from about 8% in 2000 as exports to the US falter.

"I would consider such a slowdown more as a normalisation than a cause for doom and gloom, and justifying neither panic nor frantic actions," said Mr Köhler, who singled out solid growth in China and India as stabilising factors for Asia's economies.

Fresh figures for the UK's domestic economy yesterday indicated that the strong growth in the world economy last year and the recent modest decline in the value of sterling have boosted output from factories in Britain.

Data from the office for national statistics showed that manufacturing output rose 0.3% between October and November, boosted by hefty jumps in production of 1.35% in the transport industries sector and 0.6% in electrical and optical industries.

Over the three months to November - considered a better guide to the underlying trend - British factories' output was up 0.2%, and was 0.7% higher than in the same period a year earlier.

Despite the slightly better than expected figures for manufacturing, sterling continued to weaken to a 14-month low against the euro, with dealers suggesting that the single currency is in demand because investors believe the eurozone will outperform the UK in the face of a slowdown in the US.

fields.headline: Equitable Life deadline looms
fields.standfirst: GE and Aegon have just days to make bids
fields.trailText: GE Capital and Aegon are expected to receive detailed financial information from Equitable Life early next week, giving them only a few days to decide whether to mount a takeover bid for the troubled mutual insurer.
fields.body:
GE Capital and Aegon are expected to receive detailed financial information from Equitable Life early next week, giving them only a few days to decide whether to mount a takeover bid for the troubled mutual insurer.

Their interest has revived hopes of a better deal for Equitable Life's policyholders, whose financial situation has been uncertain since last month, when Prudential pulled out of bidding for Equitable amid concerns about the size of the "black hole" caused by broken promises over guaranteed annuities.

Amid fresh hopes of finding a way to put a ceiling on the scale of these liabilities, GE Capital and Aegon are likely to decide by the end of January whether to make an offer for Equitable Life.

Both of the foreign-owned companies were rumoured to have been candidates to bid for the insurer the first time around but failed to submit concrete bids.

GE Capital and Aegon both refused to comment on the speculation surrounding Equitable Life last night but were said by City sources to be the front runners among the companiesthat have expressed a new interest in the insurer.

The mutual insurer is expected to send out more detailed financial information next week, assuming an agreement is reached on the scale of the liabilities.

Given the fact that a month has already passed since Equitable Life closed its doors to new business, fresh bids will have to be submitted before the end of the month.

The crisis at Equitable arose after a ruling made during last summer by the Law Lords that it had treated its guaranteed annuity policyholders unfairly.

The insurer - which has promised to find a new chairman - yesterday named Charles Thomson from Scottish Widows as appointed actuary, the position previously held by the new chief executive, Chris Headdon.

Equitable Life said last night: "We are working all hours to get the best possible solution for policyholders".

The National Association of Pension Funds - which represents the major pension fund groups - is to put forward candidates for appointment to the board to make sure the interests of hundreds of thousands of company scheme members are fully taken into account in future.

A large proportion of those who are affected by the crisis are employees of companies paying into top-up pension schemes provided by Equitable Life, and the National Association of Pension Funds said it would be putting forward one or more nominees for appointment to the board.

"Our objective in taking this action is to ensure that the interests of trustees and members of occupational pension schemes are properly taken into account as the board oversees the transition of the society from its current position to one which we hope will ensure a secure future for policyholders," said the organisation, which represents British pension schemes.

fields.headline: Credit card forgers await sentencing
fields.trailText: Undercover police officers have smashed a counterfeit credit card and CD ring which they believe could have led to British banks losing £5m.
fields.body:
Undercover police officers have smashed a counterfeit credit card and CD ring which they believe could have led to British banks losing £5m.

The operation, carried out by the City of London police, found counterfeit CDs and equipment capable of producing forged credit cards.

Investigators also recovered details of 500 credit cards which had been obtained by dishonest workers in restaurants and hotels in London.

As a result of the inquiry, Russian nationals Alexander Tanov, 33, and Vladimir Stroguine, 44, both pleaded guilty to conspiring to commit forgery.

The pair appeared at Southwark crown court yesterday for sentencing but this was postponed until February 2 for medical reports to be prepared. The 30-minute hearing was told that Mr Stroguine suffered from a heart condition.

The conspiracy was exposed after investigators from the IFPI, a trade body representing the recording industry, discovered a global counterfeit CD operation.

City detectives were alerted and discovered associates of Mr Tanov and Mr Stroguine were "skimming" the credit card details and transferring them on to forged credit cards.

The equipment seized by police, when they executed search warrants last January, included a machine imported from Russia which was capable of producing holograms.

webTitle: Sainsbury insists that size does not matter

fields.headline: Sainsbury insists that size does not matter
fields.trailText: The battle between Asda and Sainsbury for the title of Britain's second-largest supermarket chain took an unexpected turn yesterday with the latter saying size was not its priority.
fields.body:
The battle between Asda and Sainsbury for the title of Britain's second-largest supermarket chain took an unexpected turn yesterday with the latter saying size was not its priority.

Last month Sainsbury disputed claims that Asda had overtaken it in the supermarket rankings. But yesterday Sainsbury chief executive Sir Peter Davis said: "Our aim is not to be the biggest but to do things well."

Referring to the reduced market share of the chain that was once Britain's market leader, he added: "We are an oil tanker that needs turning around. And we are beginning to see that happen."

However, Richard Ratner, a retail analyst at Seymour Pierce, said Sainsbury's Christmas trading figures were likely to place it bottom of the league table of big supermarket chains in terms of like-for-like sales growth.

Sainsbury announced yesterday that its like-for-like sales rose 0.7% in the 12 weeks to January 6.

Figures for Asda are to be released next month but yesterday a spokeswoman said Asda had done "much better" than Sainsbury. "We had our best Christmas week ever, with sales up 20% on last year."

Sainsbury recorded a 10% rise in sales for the week to Christmas.

"Like-for-like sales are not everything," Sir Peter said. "We have achieved two major short-term objectives - we are where we said we would be in terms of stopping the decline in profitability and, having lost customers last year, are now gaining customers." The number of Sainsbury shoppers rose 4.4% over the quarter.

fields.headline: Crédit Lyonnais denies cover-up
fields.trailText: French bank Crédit Lyonnais denied yesterday that its chairman, Jean Peyrelevade, had withheld from the American authorities information about alleged breaches of US insurance and banking regulations.
fields.body:
French bank Crédit Lyonnais denied yesterday that its chairman, Jean Peyrelevade, had withheld from the American authorities information about alleged breaches of US insurance and banking regulations.

It said information about possible violations had been reported as soon as they had come to light.

The affair centres on the acquisition by Altus, a Crédit Lyonnais subsidiary, of a $6bn (£4.06bn) junk bond portfolio from failed Californian insurer Executive Life in 1992.

The deal, which is alleged to have breached insurance and banking regulations, took place before Mr Peyrelevade was brought in to Crédit Lyonnais following the near collapse of the bank after a late 1980s lending spree turned sour.

Yesterday the Economist magazine said that although Mr Peyrelevade maintains he knew nothing of any wrongdoing until late 1998 "research by the Economist suggests that his claim is implausible". It said a 17-page fax detailing the Executive Life deal had been sent to Mr Peyrelevade soon after he was appointed chairman in 1993.

Crédit Lyonnais said yesterday: "As soon as the bank was informed, on December 31, 1998, that its former subsidiary Altus might have violated American regulations it reported immediately to the proper American authorities."

Crédit Lyonnais found the fax and, "transmitted it, at its own initiative, to the American authorities as early as spring 1999". Mr Peyrelevade had offered on several occasions to be interviewed by US regulators but so far the offer had not been accepted.

According to the Economist, the Executive Life deal is the subject of court action in California and is being investigated by the justice department and the Federal Reserve.

webTitle: Analysis: When paranoia means big bucks

fields.headline: When paranoia means big bucks
fields.standfirst: Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: Many commentators assumed that George W Bush's narrow election victory would mean a bipartisan stance on a wide range of issues, especially as power is so finely balanced in Congress.
fields.body:
Many commentators assumed that George W Bush's narrow election victory would mean a bipartisan stance on a wide range of issues, especially as power is so finely balanced in Congress.

But no. On most issues, the Bush administration is taking a decidedly hawkish line, most obviously on defence.

The rhetoric coming out of Washington is now that of a powerful giant beset by threats. It is a perception that is very much in line with CIA thinking in the wake of the cold war, summed up memorably by a former CIA director who said: "We have slain the dragon but we now live in a jungle full of snakes."

The Bush administration looks set to boost defence spending for the first time in 10 years, and to do so substantially and over a number of years. It is both a policy and a state of mind, and has a number of components.

One fundamental aspect is the desire of major corporations to boost earnings. The US defence industry is dominated by a few contractors such as Boeing, Lockheed Martin and TRW. All have suffered in recent years but they have immense lobbying power, close links with the Republicans and a persistent vested interest in playing up threats to US interests.

They are helped by many in the military, where career prospects look bright once more, as well as by the numerous thinktanks and the university centres that depend on buoyant defence budgets for funding. There are powerful lobbies based on some of the defence laboratories, not least the nuclear weapons labs at Los Alamos and Lawrence Livermore. They are already designing new weapons for "small nuclear wars in far off places" and looking at micro-nuclear warheads for an evolving national missile defence system (NMD).

There are further unspoken motives, especially in relation to missile defence. Many on the Republican right believe that the only long-term threat to US dominance will come from China if it develops into an economic giant. One way to curb its growth is to force it to commit more money to defence, and NMD is one way of doing this. That may stimulate a dangerous nuclear arms race but, after all, the Soviet giant was successfully "spent into an early grave", so perhaps the same strategy can be applied to China.

Beyond this there is also deep-seated opposition to any form of arms control that might limit US military capability. It may seem a strange attitude for the son of a president who negotiated several key agreements at the end of the cold war, but those were seen as providing stability without limiting US power. Now that we live in an uncertain and volatile world, there must be no such limitations.

In many ways it is this feeling of uncertainty that lies at the heart of US security perceptions. A dominant world view coalescing around the Bush administration is that the US is the true leader of the civilised world, with a historic duty to promote the liberal market and the western way of life.

It is almost impossible for them to comprehend that much of the rest of the world has a different view, of an increasingly divided world with a widening rich-poor gap that is already facing environmental constraints and is dominated by the power of a largely western elite. From this standpoint, the US is a major part of the problem, not the solution.

US thinking simply cannot encompass such a mind-set - instead it sees the absolute necessity of maintaining control and keeping the lid on dissent. The symbol of the Republican party is an elephant, and the analogy is of an elephant that feels threatened to the point of paranoia by lethal mice that must be trampled on by any means available. The trouble is that an awful lot of people could get hurt in the process.

 Paul Rogers is professor of peace studies at Bradford University

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Monti to talk over Interbrew
fields.body:
Monti to talk over Interbrew

Europe's competition commissioner Mario Monti has agreed to meet the Belgian government to discuss the furore surrounding Interbrew, which has been ordered by the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, to sell its £2.3bn Bass brewing business.

The meeting is at the request of Belgium's economics minister, Charles Picque, who questioned whether Mr Byers' decision took into account "the logic of globalisation and the objectives of the single market".

A commission spokesman said no date had been set for the meeting. He said it was "too early to draw any conclusions" on whether Mr Monti would attempt to intervene.

Fight for Abbey faces delay

The outcome of the three-way tussle for control of Abbey National faces a further delay after the competition authorities yesterday extended their review into the regulatory implications of a merger between Abbey and Bank of Scotland.

The office of fair trading, which is also considering a possible bid for Abbey by Lloyds TSB, asked for extra time to review the case. It might not now make a decision until February 8, even later than the February 3 initial deadline for a decision on the Lloyds takeover scenario.

Industry sources do not hold out much hope of any resolution of Abbey's future until the OFT advises Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, whether or not to refer the potential bids for full-scale competition commission investigations.

Cable to cost C&W £300m

Cable & Wireless plans to spend £300m on a 13,000 km transatlantic cable, known as Apollo. It is designed specifically for carrying internet and data traffic and will have 25% more capacity than other systems.

Together with project financing from French equipment maker Alcatel, the cost of the cable will rise to around £800m once it is fully upgraded, said Alan Robinson, a C&W vice-president.

Builder raises Bryant stakes

Britain's fourth-biggest construction firm, Taylor Woodrow, yesterday raised its proposed offer to woo Bryant Group away from a planned merger with Beazer Group but failed to convince the rival housebuilder.

Taylor sweetened an earlier cash and share offer to 55p cash and 0.8 Taylor Woodrow shares for each Bryant Group share. Its previous proposal was for 45p cash and 0.831 shares.

However, Bryant is expected to reject the latest proposal. Bryant announced last month it had agreed with fellow housebuilder Beazer to merge to form a new company called Domus.

Marconi sells factories

Marconi's plan to become a pure hi-tech company moved forward yesterday with the sale of five telecom component factories to Jabil Circuit for $390m (£264m).

A Marconi spokesman said that no involuntary job losses were expected as a result of the sale, and that the employment rights of the 2,900 people involved would be protected.

About 1,200 people are employed at factories in Liverpool and Coventry, with a further 1,000 at Marcianise, Italy, and Offenburg, Germany. The fifth factory is in Bedford, Texas.

Marconi is keeping its optical systems manufacturing operations. It has said it would eventually sell Hotpoint, its consumer appliance business.

webTitle: EU hits back in airliner war

fields.headline: EU hits back in airliner war
fields.trailText: The European Union has accused Washington of exerting unreasonable pressure on the Israeli government in order to ensure that its national flag carrier, El Al, purchases American-made Boeing aircraft instead of cheaper European-made Airbus models, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The European Union has accused Washington of exerting unreasonable pressure on the Israeli government in order to ensure that its national flag carrier, El Al, purchases American-made Boeing aircraft instead of cheaper European-made Airbus models, it emerged yesterday.

In a move that threatens to spark a new transatlantic trade war, EU officials this week told their American counterparts that they believe Washington told Israel that huge amounts of foreign aid might be withheld or even cancelled if El Al bought American. Israel is the largest recipient of US foreign aid in the world.

The unusually frank accusations were made at a meeting in Washington on Thursday, where American officials argued strongly that European government loans to finance the £7.3bn development costs of Airbus' new A380 superjumbo were an illegal state subsidy. The A380 will compete directly with a stretched version of Boeing's 747.

President Clinton has already called for the European loans to be made on commercial grounds only "if we are to head off a serious problem affecting the US-EU relationship".

But EU officials hit back yesterday, and claimed that Washington's own behaviour over the El Al affair meant it was not in a position to complain about loans that Brussels insists are fully repayable.

"When you want something from someone you bring leverage to bear, and that does not constitute fair competition," one EU official explained.

"This is the linking of aid to the purchase of aircraft and the granting of foreign aid to Israel for the purchase of Boeings by El Al," he added, confirming that the subject had been raised with the Americans at this week's meeting.

The A380 will be the world's largest airliner, and is expected to create up to 20,000 jobs in Britain - where the wings will be built - and safeguard another 62,000. Britain is providing £530m towards its launch cost.

El Al's board decided to buy three Boeing 777 aircraft for $400m in October of 1999 as part of a drive to expand its fleet. It resolved to purchase three or four cheaper Airbus jets at the same time, but in February of this year put that order on hold.

US secretary of state Madeleine Albright is on record as saying that if El Al chose European aircraft and engines in preference to their American rivals, Congress would be more reluctant to approve aid for Jerusalem.

A senior Israeli government official also warned El Al at the time that a decision to buy European would imperil American funding for various defence projects and make it more difficult for the Israeli air force to negotiate good terms for the purchase of fighter aircraft from Boeing.

Officials in Brussels suspect that the US government is challenging the legality of government loans to Airbus in a cynical move to shield Boeing from unwanted competition.

"In 1992 Boeing was the only lion in the jungle, but now there's another lion," said one official yesterday, referring to Airbus.

EU officials have already warned the US that Brussels will immediately retaliate if Washington chooses to launch a legal action before the World Trade Organisation over the government loans to Airbus.

The EU has invited officials from Washington to a meeting to discuss the issue in Brussels next July.

webTitle: Roadies to Rio Brazilian rock festival aims for record

fields.headline: Roadies to Rio Brazilian rock festival aims for record
fields.trailText: Sixteen years ago, when Rock in Rio was first staged, it was the biggest paying music festival the world had ever seen, drawing nearly 1.4m people.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos  in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Sixteen years ago, when Rock in Rio was first staged, it was the biggest paying music festival the world had ever seen, drawing nearly 1.4m people. Yesterday the third edition of the event opened with hopes of beating its own record and attracting 1.5m music fans over seven days.

Rock in Rio I is remembered as politically symbolic, coinciding with the end of Brazil's 21-year dictatorship. Rock in Rio III is being run with the slogan "For A Better World" and aims to be remembered for promoting global peace.

Alongside an eclectic lineup of acts, including Oasis, REM, Neil Young, Britney Spears, Sting and NSync, there will be talks by the East Timorese Nobel Peace Prize winner, Jose Ramos Horta, and other international human rights activists.

The festival organiser, Roberto Medina, says his social conscience grew after he was kidnapped in 1991 and held hostage for two weeks in one of Rio's hillside favela shanty towns - although he personally stands to make more than £1m from the event.

fields.headline: Body Shop makeover flops
fields.standfirst: Shares fall after cosmetics company's profits warning  Laura Ashley back on track
fields.trailText: The Body Shop yesterday said that its recent make-over has proven a flop, with profits likely to fall by up to 15% this year because of disappointing sales of new products.
fields.body:
The Body Shop yesterday said that its recent make-over has proven a flop, with profits likely to fall by up to 15% this year because of disappointing sales of new products.

The environmentally- friendly cosmetics company admitted it had moved too quickly in introducing a clutch of ranges such as Palm Shine shampoo. The speed of change alienated some customers, while others stayed away because of poor Christmas weather and transport chaos.

Shares in the Body Shop, which were 210p four years ago, dived 23.5p to 97.5p. Chief executive Patrick Gournay said: "In our rush to get new products on the market, we were probably too radical in eliminating out heritage goods. Customers were not happy when things they liked were not there."

The setback was greeted with gloom by analysts, who were just beginning to believe that the firm was recovering from a slump two years ago, when expansion in the US proved problematic.

This time, the Body Shop said the difficulties were in Britain and Ireland, where like-for-like sales fell 2% over Christmas, compared to a 2% rise for the group as a whole.

Mr Gournay insisted: "All the problems are fixable. The direction we are facing is absolutely right. It is just that we have tried to move too fast, and we have paid the price in efficiency."

Mr Gournay took the helm in 1998, at which point founder Anita Roddick stepped back to become co-chairman, with her husband Gordon.

The Frenchman was brought in to revive the fortunes of the firm, which was struggling to compete with cheaper "green" products introduced by chains such as Boots and Tesco.

He has revamped the shops to make them "less green and less cluttered", sold the firm's manufacturing operation and accelerated the development of new cosmetics.

However, new lines - which include Juice It body milks, Temptation make-up and a Tobacco Flower cosmetics range - are yet to take off.

The changes have meant the company has been holding extra stocks, at a cost of £3m, and the weak euro has cost a further £3m.

Analysts cut their profit forecasts from £39m to £28m.

Mr and Mrs Roddick still hold a 25% stake in the business.

The value of their shares fell by £11m to £47m.

Laura Ashley, best known for its floral designs, failed to attract clothes shoppers over the Christmas period but showed an increase in home furnishing sales.

The company, which narrowly staved off bankruptcy in 1998, reported an increase of 7% in like-for-like sales for the six week Christmas period to January 6. Home furnishings saw a 15% rise over the same period. Clothes sales were flat for the six weeks to January 6.

The group, which bounced back to profit last year after poor sales and management upheavals, said it was on track for recovery, with Christmas and second half sales showing solid growth. Analysts yesterday said the figures were positive and in line with expectations. The shares edged up 0.25p to 18.25p.

webTitle: Why a sheltered life is now the good life

fields.headline: Why a sheltered life is now the good life
fields.standfirst: The property market for the over 60s is booming - and East Anglia is the preferred area. Elizabeth Langton investigates
fields.trailText: The property market for the over 60s is booming - and East Anglia is the preferred area. Elizabeth Langton investigates
fields.body:
Twenty-somethings may be staying away from the property market after three years of spiralling prices but at the other end of the age spectrum the housing market is hotting up. As the number of older people continues to rise, demand for retirement homes has rocketed, according to housing experts.

Property company DTZ Residential claims that there has been a 30% rise in buyers in their 50s and 60s buying new homes in central London. In response to this burst of activity building societies are looking more kindly on loan applications from older people who want to purchase retirement and sheltered housing properties.

This week the Norwich and Peterborough Building Society launched "mortgages without age limits" specifically aimed at the over 60s. The move followed inquiries from older customers who wanted to move house as part of a change in lifestyle. The products are now available to those purchasing a "warden assisted" home. It is well-known that the UK has an ageing population - by the year 2021 there will be 12m people aged over 65 - out of an overall population likely to remain static at 58m.

The boom market is sheltered housing. There are now more than 500,000 people living in sheltered housing -more than the number living in nursing and residential care homes put together. Sheltered housing is the preferred option for older people who want to maintain their independence while having the peace of mind of a warden on call if needed. There is a wide range of both private and affordable rented accommodation on offer from local authorities, housing associations and private developers.

According to David Hollingworth, mortgage broker with London and Country: "Elderly people who want to move are usually looking to downsize and often have enough money from the sale of their existing property to cover the purchase of a new one outright."

But Alison Rolls of the Norwich and Peterborough says this is increasingly not the case. "Very often retirement bungalows are expensive properties in desirable areas. And buyers need to take out a loan to finance the difference between what they're selling and the home they're buying," she explains. "Some older people are keen to hang on to their savings or capital and would rather take out a loan to pay for housing costs."

Lenders will always look at loans in terms of the size of the risk, says Mr Hollingworth. With sheltered housing, one of the lenders' main concerns is the saleability of the property, he explains. "Obviously there is not as great a demand for it as for normal housing or a bungalow. It would need to be sold to another elderly person which limits the number of buyers."

But this is not the case in East Anglia, says Ms Rolls. In a region known for possessing the only remaining affordable homes within commuting distance of London, demand for retirement housing is high, "particularly along the coast, where there is more demand than properties available".

Home loans for older people are available but borrowers may need to use a broker to shop around for a suitable product, says Mr Hollingworth. "Lenders will look at lending to people past retirement age but they pay close attention to whether or not older people have sufficient income, including pension to cover repayments," he says.

He adds that retirement mortgages are available, often on an interest-only basis. "Flexible loans are available although there may be a balance to pay on the loan following the borrower's death."

In Norwich and Peterborough's view, elderly people are not necessarily high-risk borrowers, says Ms Rolls. "An elderly person with a fixed income from a pension or who has a regular income from investments is just as, if not more, stable than someone in employment."

Last year the N&P noticed that increasing numbers of people wanted to take out a mortgage on sheltered or warden-assisted homes - particularly in the building society's East Anglian heartlands. In response the society is offering a repayment loan with a 2% discount for the first 18 months from a standard variable rate of 7.24%, which itself is 0.5% lower than the standard Halifax mortgage rate. The society will lend up to 75% of the purchase price.

Ms Rolls points out that although the population as a whole is living longer, women are racing ahead of men. The result : "more and more older ladies living on their own who would be happier living in a secure environment such as a sheltered flat".

Premier Retirement Services, run by a group of new- home builders, publishes details of developments several times each year. The Elderly Accommodation Counsel, a charity that provides information on all types of accommodation for older people, can advise on sheltered housing. Another avenue is offered by elderly people's charity Help The Aged.

The charity found that many elderly people were purchasing sheltered housing without realising what they had bought. It identified a gap in the market for an agency dealing specifically with sheltered housing properties and set up a housing arm called Retirement Property Services. The service is a national agency which puts house hunters in touch with properties that match their requirements.

"High street agents can lack knowledge of the specialist conditions that can apply to retirement properties," says Catherine Rawes, a Help the Aged spokeswoman.

Some developments are governed by strict rules and regulations and buyers need to pay attention to the small print. Ms Rawes advises buyers to visit several properties to ensure they find a development that suits them and find out whether the estate manager lives in. Membership of the Association of Retirement Housing Managers is another safeguard. Pet lovers will need to find out whether or not animals are allowed and DIY-ers will want to know whether they are allowed to make internal or external alterations.

Buyers should also check out service charges and ask whether they include estate manager costs, emergency alarm call systems, maintenance, building and communal areas.

fields.headline: When flexible  isn't so friendly
fields.standfirst: Bringing together the needs of employers and the wishes of their staff sounds like the recipe for perfect industrial relations. But, as Rachel Spence reports, working arrangements that may sound fine in theory are far from ideal when put into practice
fields.trailText: Bringing together the needs of employers and the wishes of their staff sounds like the recipe for perfect industrial relations. But, as Rachel Spence reports, working arrangements that may sound fine in theory are far from ideal when put into practice
fields.body:
Flexibility may be the mantra of 21st century corporate life, but it seems to mean one thing to employers and another to employees. So is it the key to the holy grail of work/life balance, or simply the demand for a workforce that lives at an employer's beck and call with zero job security?

According to last month's green paper - in which the government proposed increased flexible leave for working parents, including extended maternity leave and paid paternity leave - there's no conflict of interest. The employers' need for a flexible labour force can be met by the employees' need for flexible working arrangements. "There are benefits to individual employers and the economy as a whole if the needs of employers and parents can be brought closer together," the paper declares.

The British Chamber of Commerce doesn't see it like that. "Firms recognise the benefits of family-friendly practices, for employers and employees, but will object to any government attempts to force them to do so in ways which undermine flexibility."

Flexibility was seen at its least family-friendly just before Christmas, as 2,200 Vauxhall workers were laid off, their lack of job security a by-product of market-driven flexibility. If the jobs those workers lost involved working flexible hours, it was not to accommodate their work/life balance. Flexible working, in the form of "banked hours" schemes whereby employers can call on their workers as and when they need them most is the industry standard, says a Transport & General Workers Union spokesman. "But generally this is to accommodate companies' productivity targets, not employees' home life."

Land Rover employees work a 37-hour week but are paid for 36 hours, banking the extra hour. Until the end of last year they could use the extra hours as seven days additional holiday and in return were forced to work longer hours when production schedules demanded. A dispute in November with new owner Ford forced the man agement to give staff the extra hours in the form of extra pay or holiday and resulted in the suspension of the scheme to work long hours pending a review.

The evidence suggests that truly employee-centred flexible working is still the exception. The Workplace Employee Relations Survey revealed that only one-third of UK employees could work flexible hours; a recent Personnel Today survey showed that 69% of companies had no flexible working policies at all and a new DTI survey reveals that one in five employers think flexible working arrangements for parents are of no benefit to the company.

It's true that part-time working is available in 75% of organisations, but it's debatable whether those employees enjoy the same status as full-time workers. A recent parliamentary report revealed that part-time female employees received less training than their full-time peers. And, although there is no research as yet, there appears to be a dearth of part-time employees in senior management/director positions.

This could explain another alarming trend: the extremely low take-up, particularly by men, when flexible working policies are on offer. New research by the Industrial Society reveals that although 84% of male managers thought companies should devise flexible policies, 88% thought it would be a bad career move to take advantage of them. Meanwhile, companies which do offer strong flexible packages, such as Unilever, admit that the majority of takers are working mothers compelled to juggle a job with childcare.

"What this evidence tells us is that women are prepared to risk reduced hours, and with that reduced salary and status, whereas men aren't," says John Knell of the Industrial Society.

And, as Jack O'Sullivan of lobbying organisation Fathers Direct observes: "Many fathers feel they must maintain the security of their income, especially if their partner is not in work or working part-time. If companies are serious about career breaks, for example, you have to see people being promoted when they come back."

Meanwhile the Government Labour Force Survey tells us that UK workers subsidise firms to the tune of £23bn in unpaid overtime. In terms of flexibility, you can have too much of a good thing.

 Part-time personnel officer Karen Maloney, 32, from Leigh, Lancashire, won £18,000 compensation from construction contract consultants James R Knowles after they replaced her with a full-time worker.

Karen, pictured with daughter Charlotte says: "I started at James R Knowles in 1995 in the payroll department. I was ambitious and had done my Institute of Personnel and Development qualification. I had my baby in December 1998 but they asked me to come back early from maternity leave. To help them out, I agreed to return part-time when my baby was just five weeks old. Just before my maternity leave ended, the personnel officer resigned and I was promoted, with the agreement that I would work part-time. I couldn't believe it when, a couple of weeks later, they made me redundant along with another part-time member of staff.

"They said they wanted a full-timer but they wouldn't consider job-sharing. Finally, they said they would give me another part-time job. But they were very vague about it and wouldn't confirm the position, or details of salary and status in writing. I couldn't accept a job which didn't appear to exist so I told them I thought I'd been constructively dismissed.

"With the help of the Equal Opportunities Commission I claimed sex discrimination, indirect sex discrimination and constructive dismissal. I won £18,000 and the right to a reference. It sounds a lot but I'd lost salary and at least one job because they wouldn't give me a reference; also some of that goes towards my MA fees which they had refused to continue funding.

"It's been stressful. It was awful accepting that I was disposable when I thought they valued me. But it had become clear that part-time workers weren't valued there; you got comments such as 'when are you in next, next year?' There's still a stigma attached to part-time workers; the company sees them as performing a function rather than making a valued long-term contribution."

I can't lead a private life

Jim Miles, 42, works as an aircraft dispatcher for a major aviation handler.

He says: "We're responsible for looking after the grounded aircraft. I'm contracted to work 37.5 hours per week but I often do 60. If you don't work longer, you'll suffer in terms of promotion or being given the worst flights to look after.

"The biggest problem is the shifts, which change at a mo ment's notice.There are early shifts (from 6am to 2pm) and lates (2pm to 10pm) but those times alter according to flight patterns. You work two earlys and two lates and then have two days off. So you finish on a late and often start on an early. On your first day off you may get home at 4am, sleep until 2pm and then get up at 4am on your first day back to work. The shifts work on a six-week schedule, but they often change them in mid-rota with about 72 hours notice.

"The toughest thing was making time to see my son. I'm separated and I see him on a Saturday, but for three years I had to work four out of five Saturdays and because we had to take two days off together that meant I couldn't swap my day with him for Sunday. Thanks to my union negotiator, they've given me Saturdays off now. Basically this is a job where you're given no flexibility but expected to give plenty yourself. It's impossible to plan any private life because of the shifts. We're constantly reminded we're expendable. Not surprisingly, the staff turnover is huge. Why do I do it? Well not for money; we get just over £5 per hour. But it's a terrific atmosphere and my workmates are great."

webTitle: Brand new start is best way forward

fields.headline: Brand new start is best way forward
fields.standfirst: The EU is streets behind the US in marketing innovation and excessive red tape is largely to blame. Eileen Sheridan explains
fields.trailText: The EU is streets behind the US in marketing innovation and excessive red tape is largely to blame. Eileen Sheridan explains
fields.body:
The concepts of innovation and marketing as key drivers of successful businesses may be old hat to British executives but European Union policy-makers are just waking up to them, according to management consultants.

In the week before Tony Blair and his European counterparts were hogging the headlines at the Nice summit, a group of 100 economists met to discuss a crucial question which has dogged Europe since the beginning of the century - why is the upstart United States much more successful at engineering economic growth through innovative new products than Europe?

One who took part, Tony Clayton of management consultants PIMS Associates, says: "Two years ago we asked the EU policy-makers what they saw as key success factors in innovation and were surprised to find that the European Commission's Enterprise Directorate, responsible for industrial policy, didn't have anyone who understood marketing.

"And the Innovation Directorate didn't understand the role of customer communication in making innovation successful."

Since then a series of studies to prove the economic value of marketing has led to changes in the EU and appointments in the Enterprise Directorate to deal specifically with the discipline. But there is still a long way to go to create a level marketing playing field in member countries.

What leads to business growth, says Clayton, actually runs counter to the conventional laws of economics and has little to do with costs. "It is mostly driven by new products and service and by doing a better job for customers," he adds.

Companies in the US have been doing this for years, which helps to explain their substantially better productivity record, and only recently have European companies shown signs of following the same strategy.

"This is relevant to the 'productivity initiative' that Gordon Brown launched," explains Mr Clayton. "What is important is that we should not repeat earlier mistakes based on the 'old' analysis that says we can close the gap by piling more capital investment into businesses. What matters is the scope for value adding innovation."

Most innovations require more investment in communication than in the development of technology to support them;

Markets with well developed communications from producers to consumers are much more innovative;

Businesses with good brand development strategies are much more successful than those without;

Really successful brand owners use brand capital to innovate, rather than to milk their customers.

Brands used as examples were Philips Lighting, Dulux paint, Nestle's Chunky single-finger KitKat, Kleenex Balsam tissues and John Rocha's design range for Waterford Crystal. KitKat, Britain's biggest selling chocolate bar, saw a slow decline in the 90s and attempts to boost sales through flavoured versions did nothing to change things.

"Real innovation in chocolate bars is difficult," says Clayton. "New products go up like a rocket and down like a stick." But Nestle's ultimate solution was a redesigned KitKat keeping the chocolate and wafer content but presenting it to younger consumers as a single chunky bar that could be eaten with one hand while on the move. And although resources for advertising were limited, the product has been a phenomenal success.

The case of Philips Lighting demonstrates that speed in bringing an innovation to market is another key to success. Sales were hit in 1997 by cheap low-energy "stick bulbs" imported from China. These drove prices down but created little growth in repeat purchasing by satisfied customers.

Philips reacted quickly, understanding that decorative products like their own "Softone" range were as important to customers as energy efficiency. The normal prod uct development cycle of a new lighting product is up to 24 months, but Philips established a new project under an "innovation to market" team and the Ambiance low-energy bulb with Softone quality went from development to launch in just six months. Early sales success saw it launched across the EU the following year. The company's major European competitor took more than a year to respond and other rivals in its sector took even longer.

"A key conclusion in this work is the vital role of marketing in innovation," says Mr Clayton. "This may seem blindingly obvious but had not occurred to most economists involved in the field until a couple of years ago.

"When it comes to innovation, the old marketing adage 'if you don't tell you won't sell' is true in spades. But for innovation and marketing to flourish across the European Union, the bureaucrats have to take a look at the rules.

"While products can legally move across the single market, rules on marketing, advertising and promotion differ from country to country, " he explains. "It is virtually impossible to design a good marketing package which is legal across all European markets. So innovation is a higher risk in Europe than in the genuine single market of the North American Free Trade Association.

"Europe still has a long way to go to make its single market work effectively and to do so will require individual countries to give up some of their rights to home-grown red tape."
