fields.headline: PCs fall into place
fields.standfirst: Richard Thompson set up Mosaic in response to a huge gap in the home computer market, giving advice to customers unsure of what they wanted. Mi
fields.trailText: Richard Thompson set up Mosaic in response to a huge gap in the home computer market, giving advice to customers unsure of what they wanted. Michael Edmands talked to him
fields.body:
Fancy buying one of these fancy internet-ready PCs in the January sales but don't know which to choose? Your troubles could be over if you bump into one of Richard W Thompson's young employees in one of the larger electronics retail chains.

Usually dressed in a T-shirt boasting the name of the product, the Mosaic technology whiz-kids attempt to make the intricacies of the electronic age a doddle to understand.

Today's business is a direct descendant of Mr Thompson's first. His mum made great cakes, and when he was 14 he begged her to bake some more, took them to school and sold them to hungry classmates at a tidy profit. Another relative, Uncle Frank, became the next link in the Thompson plan. "While school in Sutton was no blackboard jungle, I had grown somewhat street-wise. I was tall and athletic and kept out of trouble, but I was also a budding entrepreneur. Mum's cakes gave me a taste for selling. Luckily I had an uncle, Frank, who took a shine to me and was a source of interest-free loans."

At 14, while attending the Oval with his uncle, young Thompson noticed a stall in the street selling highlighter pens very cheaply. He borrowed the money, bought the stall and sold the lot back in Sutton. "After that my uncle funded me in selling office supplies to the school and other students and by then I was making what to me was real money," he says.

"I left school with some good passes because the old man had promised me £25 an O level," he says. "Dad worked in advertising and knew the score when it came to a little bribery." By 16 he joined a small "one man and a dog" Croydon company selling computer supplies.

The company soon had 50 employees and was growing quickly, but he was set on selling computers, not supplies. He realised he needed a new Uncle Frank in the form of a well-established computer giant. His big break was about to appear; he set up his own company, FirstStop. "I was 19 and it was 1986," he says. "The country was booming in the Thatcher years and I needed a known name to get ahead, so I turned to IBM."

"I was living and working in Croydon, which some people might call a backwater but not me. There were half a million people living there and I was focused. I designed a business plan and took it to IBM; they liked it and took me on. That gave FirstStop identification with Big Blue. Everybody had heard of IBM." Big Blue recognized his potential and of the 5,000 dealers in the UK made him dealer of the year.

"I took concessions in superstores, even Harrods," he says. He trained staff and sent them into the stores dressed in shirts identifying them as employees of IBM, easily recognisable to people shopping for computers. "When customers came in," he says, "they thought they were dealing with IBM." At computer shows IBM liked FirstStop to show the human side of big business, but it soon made him recognise the downside of dealing with a single brand name. It was time to try something else. In the 90s he sold the retailing end, with a turnover of £6m and 38 staff, to an internal management team.

Spotting a niche in the market in 1993 he founded EMS to provide field marketing and training services to electronic retailers in the UK. He sends teams into PC World, Dixons, Currys and Comet to provide training, roadshow demonstrations and mystery shopping exercises. Feeding the huge gap that once existed in the technology sector for outside retail training services and merchandising has seen turnover soar to £30m and staff rise to 3,000 field personnel and 180 office personnel. In 1998 he sold the business to Canadian marketing services group Mosaic.

Now the cricket-loving Thompson, third generation to play for local side Carshalton, and Surrey County Cricket board member, is spreading the word both for the summer game and, as chief executive of Mosaic Technology (formerly EMS Chiara) pushing for growth across Europe. From France to Scandinavia "retail stores can't get enough of our guys," he says. "By aligning with the right people we constantly spot new opportunities. But the real secret of success," he says, "is what I hammer home to the troops: think how you can say yes."

Attitude is everything to this homeboy from south of the river.

webTitle: Czech MPs try to end TV battle by cutting politicians' role

fields.headline: Czech MPs try to end TV battle by cutting politicians' role
fields.standfirst: Parliament in emergency session as director's resignation fails to end news strike
fields.trailText: Parliament in emergency session as director's resignation fails to end news strike.
fields.body:
Czech MPs met in emergency session yesterday to amend the law governing public service television and end the confrontation between news staff and management, unresolved by the resignation of the man at the centre of the row, the station director Jiri Hodac.

News staff took over the station three weeks ago when Mr Hodac was appointed, accusing him of political bias, and have put out their own programmes.

They are refusing to end their strike until the entire management team leaves. Mr Hodac remains in post until a replacement is appointed.

The strikers are supported by the biggest public protest since the communist regime was toppled in 1989. Their supporters include President Vaclav Havel, the playwright and dissident who helped bring down communism.

Almost 200,000 Czechs have signed a petition protesting at Mr Hodac's appointment and each night thousands gather outside the television studios.

The government is asking parliament to enlarge the television council, which appointed Mr Hodac, from nine to 14, and legislate for its members to be nominated by non-government bodies and approved by parliament: one of the journalists' key demands.

It make take several weeks to enact the amendment.

At present the council is appointed by political parties, and dominated by nominees of the government party, the Social Democrats (CSSD) and their coalition partners, the Civic Democrats (ODS). Mr Hodac was accused of favouring the ODS, which he denies.

The council refused to accept parliament's recommendation to sack Mr Hodac. He eventually resigned on Thursday for health reasons, after being admitted to hospital.

"The amendment of the law should allow the depoliticisation of the services provided by public media," the culture minister, Pavel Dostal, who supported the strikers, told MPs yesterday.

Mr Hodac, a former news director at the television station, is widely regarded as close to, and influenced by, the former prime minister Vaclav Klaus.

The controversy has further damaged Mr Klaus, the lightning rod of the Czech political scene since the 1989 revolution, who is blamed by many for his part in the corruption and mismanagement which has soured the republic's post-communism privatisation.

After his government was defeated in the 1998 general election, under strong public criticism from President Vaclav Havel, his longstanding rival, Mr Klaus and his rightwing ODS made an agreement to sustain the incoming centre-left minority Social Democrat government of Milos Zeman.

But public irritation with him has increased, even in Prague, the centre of his support.

The television row has been interpreted by political commentators as a rerun of last year's huge but brief and unsuccessful student-led demonstration, which was aimed at toppling the political old guard.

It was followed by resounding losses for both parties in last summer's senate elections.

State interference with press freedom in central and eastern Europe is not confined to the Czech Republic.

In Slovakia, a change of government gave rise to a fierce struggle in the state television station, and journalists who supported the authoritarian leader Vladimir Meciar were dismissed.

In neighbouring Hungary the government's critics have accused it of packing the board of directors responsible for public broadcasting.

At present the council is appointed by political parties, and dominated by nominees of the government party, the Social Democrats (CSSD) and their coalition partners, the Civic Democrats (ODS). Mr Hodac was accused of favouring the ODS, which he denies. The council refused to accept parliament's recommendation to sack Mr Hodac. He eventually resigned on Thursday for health reasons, after being admitted to hospital. "The amendment of the law should allow the depoliticisation of the services provided by public media," the culture minister, Pavel Dostal, who supported the strikers, told MPs yesterday. Mr Hodac, a former news director at the television station, is widely regarded as close to, and influenced by, the former prime minister Vaclav Klaus. The controversy has further damaged Mr Klaus, the lightning rod of the Czech political scene since the 1989 revolution, who is blamed by many for his part in the corruption and mismanagement which has soured the republic's post-communism privatisation. After his government was defeated in the 1998 general election, under strong public criticism from President Vaclav Havel, his longstanding rival, Mr Klaus and his rightwing ODS made an agreement to sustain the incoming centre-left minority Social Democrat government of Milos Zeman. But public irritation with him has increased, even in Prague, the centre of his support. The television row has been interpreted by political commentators as a rerun of last year's huge but brief and unsuccessful student-led demonstration, which was aimed at toppling the political old guard. It was followed by resounding losses for both parties in last summer's senate elections. State interference with press freedom in central and eastern Europe is not confined to the Czech Republic. In Slovakia, a change of government gave rise to a fierce struggle in the state television station, and journalists who supported the authoritarian leader Vladimir Meciar were dismissed. In neighbouring Hungary the government's critics have accused it of packing the board of directors responsible for public broadcasting.

fields.headline: Why coffee's so frothy
fields.standfirst: The US main-street culture is filtering through to Britain- and the range of blends and blenders is enormous. Eileen Sheridan samples the market
fields.trailText: The US main-street culture is filtering through to Britain- and the range of blends and blenders is enormous. Eileen Sheridan samples the market
fields.body:
Right now coffee is so hot, it's the coolest thing around, challenging wine in the poseur's drink stakes.

Suddenly Brits have switched on to the coffee culture and every high street now boasts at least one outlet of the ever-growing café chains. And passions are also stirring over the drop in cof fee prices worldwide which have not been reflected in the cost of the cup we drink. Coffee is the second most traded commodity after oil and producers also suffer when prices fall. But at least drinkers with a social conscience will welcome the latest pairing between high street chain Costa Coffee and suppliers Fairtrade ,which pays a guaran teed minimum price to producers.

Costa Coffee marketing director Laurie Morgan says the company teamed up with Fairtrade to put something back into the community.

A special blend to fit with the Costa Coffee brand took months to develop and you will pay an extra 10p a cup for it. Costa Coffee charges £1.70 for its own blend medium cappuccino and £1.50 for a small one, while espresso is £1.15 and a mochaccino is £1.80. Chilled versions for the same drink are £1.60 and £1.95.

Mrs Morgan defends the price issue, which is still headline news, by pointing out that coffee beans are only a small percentage of the cost of running a coffee shop.

"Customers don't complain about the price," she says. "The coffee culture is very trendy now. Coffee shops offer value for time, some brain space."

The coffee shop is now the "third place", according to Madison's operational marketing director John Tonks. "Bars are not so family-friendly and restaurants may expect you to order food," he says. "A coffee bar or lounge is the place where you can relax and enjoy yourself."

Madison's charge less than most chains, with an espresso or americano at 95p, latte, cappuccino, and mocha at £1.50 for a tall one and £1.95 for a grande.

Madison's has 42 outlets nationwide and recently acquired Bristol-based Cawar dine's, which was established in 1777. Cawardine's special blends will also become available in Madison's and customers will be able to buy blends to make their own coffee at home.

Starbucks, which bought out the Seattle Coffee Company, is another big player in the market and has an wide range of drinks on offer. You can have a Gingerbread Latte at £2.35 for the small size. It contains a special syrup and is topped with whipped cream. The Eggnog Latte, at the same price, is made with espresso, steamed eggnog and milk and topped with a sprinkle of nutmeg. And 10p from each drink goes to the National Literacy Trust.

Another Christmas line starred Starbucks Christmas Blend of Latin American beans and aged Indonesian beans.

This autumn saw another tooth-trembling drink on sale at Starbucks - the caramel macchiato - a combination of espresso, vanilla and frothy milk topped with caramel sauce costing £2.35 for a medium size. Filter coffee is £1.45, £1.60 or £1.75; caffe latte is £1.75, £2.15 and £2.35; mocha is £1.95, £2.35 and £2.55.

All of these fancy drinks are based on the espresso shot, which is produced from each company's individual blends. The high pressure water system in an espresso machine brings out the coffee oils which you see as the "crema" on the top of the coffee. This is not something you can reproduce in your filter or cafetiere at home, says John Tonks. For that you'll need a home espresso coffee machine and then you can experiment with combination drinks of your own.

Which? Online favours the Dualit 889 at £190, which is on sale in Selfridges and can be ordered from John Lewis. The testers said the Gaggia Espresso at £150 made reasonable coffee, the Krups Novo 2200 Plus at £110 produced good froth but did not keep the coffee hot enough, and neither did the Krups Vivo at £79 which made "disappointing" coffee. The most expensive machine tested at £250 was the LA Pavoni EBR which made good coffee but was difficult to use.

Cafetieres and electric filter machines come in all types and prices. Top of the range at John Lewis is a Siemens filter at £129 and the cheapest is a Morphy Richards at £19.75. A chrome cafetiere making eight cups costs £ 29 and for 12 cups, £33.

And then there's the coffee. These days it's an aspirational drink, says Sainsbury's coffee buyer Matt Spence. His company is the biggest brand seller with the largest in-store range - more than 90 options to choose from. Best-sellers are Sainsbury's own brand, then Lavazza, Taylor's of Harrogate and Douwe Egbert.

The Original blend, a medium roast, is £1.35 for 227grams; the Continental blend is £1.89, Espresso £1.69 and After Dinner also £1.69. French coffee blended with chicory is £ 1.89 and you pay the same price for a Viennese blend with fig seasoning or a straight Italian blend. In the coffees of the world range you can buy Ethiopian, Kenyan, Java, Colombian and Puerto Rico all at £2.09.

Specialist coffees are Australian Skybury, Guatemalan Antiguan and Papua New Guinea, all at £ 2.19.

As for the price issue Spence says: "It takes a while, usually about three months, before prices hit the retail sector. Retail prices cannot fluctuate on a daily basis."

But if there were a long-term low it would be unjustified to keep prices where they were, he added. And we are still inclined to flash the cash for coffee because of its luxury image. If you're into top-quality blends there are scores of specialist retailers to meet your needs. Smith's Coffee Company, which roasts and blends for retailers like Cawardine's, Sally Lunn's in Bath and the Grand Café in Oxford, also has a mail order service. The range covers speciality coffees like Yemeni arabica at £12.90 a kilo, Sumatra Mandheling at £5.51 and Pure Jamaica Blue Mountain at £39.68. More standard coffees range from £6.60 to £8.49.

There is a flavoured coffee range including amaretto, cinnamon, raspberry, rum and famous names like Teacher's whisky, Drambuie and Lamb's Navy Rum as well as Boaters flavoured coffees, offering things like Death by Chocolate, Irish Moccachino. Bannoffie Pie and Hawaiian Delight.

For on-line ordering there is Roast and Post. The company does its own blend of African Arabica with some South American beans as well as After Dinner Continental, Kenya Special, and Morning Reviver all at £9.99 for a 500-gram pack available as beans or in different grinds.

A coffee trial pack selection of Roast and Post Coffees in six 250-gram packs costs £25, Mocha Djimma and Costa Rica Fair Trade. For more information: Smith's Coffee Company, tel 01442 234239; Dualit, tel 0207 639 5271; La Pavoni, tel 0207 722 7646; Krups, tel 0847 231072.

fields.headline: Aladdin's cave in Lancashire
fields.standfirst: Later this month Sotheby's South will auction a treasure trove of Victorian antiques. Stewart Dalby reports
fields.trailText: Later this month Sotheby's South will auction a treasure trove of Victorian antiques. Stewart Dalby reports
fields.body:
It is every auctioneer's dream to be asked to value a house packed with antiques with the possibility of a lucrative sale. So when Tim Wonnacott of Sotheby's South took a call from Joe Marshall, doyen of antique dealers in the north-west of England, inviting him to visit his home he must have thought lightning was striking twice.

In May 1996 Tim sold the contents of antique dealers Alan and Edna Austin's terraced house near Clitheroe in Lancashire. The sale raised £1m. Mr Marshall was an acquaintance of Alan and Edna and when Tim received the call from Mr Marshall he was excited.

Marvin House, a large Victorian former merchant's home on the outskirts of Blackburn, looked promising from the outside, but Mr Marshall had converted the property into flats and was living in the ground floor. The valuation of the contents was completed quickly.

Tim left, only to be called back three months later. They chatted about the trade over tea and biscuits and again Tim left none the wiser. He was called back a third time three months later. On this occasion it was different. Mr Marshall ushered him into the kitchen and moved the dresser, covered with breakfast cereals and marmalade, to reveal a huge vault which Tim described as containing "a staggering array of paintings, ceramics and fine objects of vertu". It was a veritable Aladdin's cave.

Now, four years after the discovery, this trove is to be sold in a series of sales at Sotheby's South in Billing shurst, West Sussex on Monday January 29 to Thursday February 1, 2001.

Joe Marshall, who died last year aged 91, was born in Blackburn. He was the son of Mrs E J Marshall, who built up the family antiques business and joined when he was 14. Apart from a stint in Preston during the Second World War Joe lived in Blackburn all his life and was passionate about antiques. For 25 years he was one of the largest dealers of pottery and porcelain in the north-west and was especially fond of paintings and Royal Worcester porcelain.

Tim Wonnacott points out that Joe Marshall and the Austins were in a very strong position to build up collections. He says: "During the industrial revolution the Victorian middle classes bought paintings and antiques for their homes. When the north-west went into decline from the 1930s onwards, families would sell off pieces perhaps to pay bills, or solicitors would call in dealers to clear houses on deaths. This was before programmes such as the Antiques Road Show when knowledge of antiques was rudimentary. People like Joe Marshall had rich pickings. As with many dealers Joe would often keep back the best for his own collection.

Some 237 lots are to be sold by Sotheby's. The collection is light on furniture, although there is a good French late 19th century mahogany and parquetry gilt mounted vitrine by Henry Dasson, a Parisian known for high quality work. This piece is estimated at £5,000 to £8,000.

There are more than are 100 lots of ceramics and glass. A notable example is a pair of Flight Barr and Barr candlesticks dating from 1820. Each is painted with views of Keswick Lake, Cumberland and Pylle and Priory Pembrokeshire. The pair is estimated at £5,000 to £7,000. So too is a Royal Worcester reticulated vase and cover, dating from 1907, by George Owen. These vases, very fine, have become rare.

There are good examples of glass. A cameo glass scent bottle by Thomas Webb, modelled as a swan, dates from 1884 and is expected fetch £1,500 to £2,000. In the objects of vertu section one of the most appealing pieces is a 20th century gold Freedom box engraved with the arms of the City of Cork, estimated to fetch £8,000 to £12,000. It was presented by the city of Cork in 1882 to His Excellency, the Most Noble Marquis Wellesley, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland.

Highlights of the paintings sale are two oils by Victorian artist Charles Spencelayh's RMS (1865-1958). One, "Mother", depicts an elderly man seated with his spectacles on his forehead, looking at a portrait of his mother. This painting within a painting is typical of Spencelayh's visual style and is estimated to fetch £40,000 to £60,000.

This is not a grandee sale where the contents of a great country estate have been cleared. Many of the items are modestly priced. But it is an interesting and attractive sale of Victoriana and a testament to Joe Marshall's eye and taste over 70 years.

For further information telephone Sotheby's South, 01403 833521 or visit www.sothebys.com.

fields.headline: Could using a mobile be more dangerous than smoking?
fields.standfirst: In March Vodafone will face a test case in a Californian court on whether their use causes tumours. If it loses, consequences for the industry will be disastrous, says Richard Colbey
fields.trailText: In March Vodafone will face a test case in a Californian court on whether their use causes tumours. If it loses, consequences for the industry will be disastrous, says Richard Colbey
fields.body:
Are mobile phones the new cigarettes? Each crosses the boundaries of class, gender, age and nationality. Each has generated a great deal of revenue for governments: cigarettes through high sales taxes, mobile phones through the granting of licences and sales taxes. Each costs most users more money than they want to pay. Each has tremendous potential to annoy those who don't use them.

Whether they have a more important similarity - that they are capable of killing their users - is going to be the subject of an American lawsuit announced at the very end of last year.

Peter Angelos, a Baltimore attorney famous for winning $4.2bn (£2.8bn) for lung cancer sufferers from the tobacco industry, will in March commence the first in a series of test cases in California, against Vodafone. The actions will be brought on behalf of frequent mobile users who have suffered brain tumours and the main issue will be whether a link between mobile use and the condition can be established.

Much will depend upon the views of the experts each side will line up. Doctors, statisticians, physicists and engineers will all have a role to play. So far, the mobile phone industry has fought off all claims against it made on this basis. The fact that Mr Angelos has now put his reputation and his firm's tremendous resources behind the claims adds greatly to the credibility of the arguments.

The case will cost tens of millions of dollars to present and he will only be paid if he wins. Theoretically, findings in American courts have no force in Britain. On a strictly legalistic analysis it could be said that a decision made in any case brought by an individual has no bearing on anyone else's case. The law involved in deciding the issue is not complicated and will not set any formal precedent.

In practice, though, once a respected court, having heard detailed scientific evidence, decided there was a link the impact would be enormous. Thousands of "passive smoking" cases were settled after Australian litigation in the late 80s led to a finding such smoking could lead to lung cancer.

The industry may have done itself no favours by its failure to recognise the risks. In 1999 Orange published an article in its customer magazine asking whether media speculation on the association between mobile phone use and "headaches, dizziness and even cancers" was "fact or fiction". It concluded it was fiction. But no one knows for sure yet. In 10 years' time, if, say, brain tumours are twice as frequent among mobile phone users as among the general population, the consequences for the industry, facing tens of thousands of substantial claims, will be dire.

The tobacco industry was extraordinarily stubborn in its refusal to recognise that cigarettes cause lung cancer. Well into the 80s it was denying that a link had been proved. It was this position that contributed to the willingness of American courts to award massive exemplary damages against cigarette manufacturers: their deliber ate deception of the public was punished as much as its selling of a lethal product.

There may not yet be enough evidence to persuade many mobile users to give up their phones. If a link is proved, the companies with the best prospects of surviving are those which have warned users of possible risks, not those who have dismissed them. The present head-in-the-sand approach may increase short-term sales and profits, but until this issue is resolved it is, perhaps, not an industry into which shrewd investors will be putting their money.

webTitle: Bloodbath fears are cooled by Isa bosses

fields.headline: Bloodbath fears are cooled by Isa bosses
fields.standfirst: Now could be the time to buy bonds despite a rating agency's prediction of doom and gloom. Tony Levene investigates
fields.trailText: Now could be the time to buy bonds despite a rating agency's prediction of doom and gloom. Tony Levene investigates
fields.body:
Forecasts of a US bond bloodbath with defaults hitting record levels leading to a spill-over into UK and European markets have left corporate bond Isa providers and financial advisers largely unmoved.

They reckon that after a poor two years in corporate bond funds, it could be a chance to buy - especially for those fearful of an equity market slide. Other potential buyers are looking for higher than building society or bank income and are prepared to take a risk.

This weekend, fund manager Axa launches a Global High Income Fund which promises a headline 8.9% - a level achieved by investing in junk and other lower grade bonds. And if this is successful, others will follow.

The doom and gloom prediction comes from Standard & Poors, one of the two main agencies which rate bond quality both in the US and here. It sees large numbers of bonds losing cash for holders by "defaulting"- from companies cutting or delaying dividends to going bust.

And that, it reckons, will see buyers in a flight to quality bonds where yields are lower. Either way, income seekers can expect less. "There are liq uidity concerns, credit quality fears and the chance of defaults has never been higher," S&P says. "This follows the havoc wreaked on the US corporate bond market in the last three months of 2000," it adds. Both "investment" grade and junk bonds were hit, leading to spreads - the gap between bonds from companies and those backed by governments - widening. This can lead to falling prices - and a drop in the cash-in values of bond Isas.

"Now, despite the US interest rate cut earlier this month, investment-grade spreads will remain at wider levels in the first half of the year," says Diane Vazza, managing director and head of global fixed income research for S&P.

"Moreover, given the high level of speculative-grade issuance during the years 1997 through 1999 of $373bn, we expect defaults to continue to rise in 2001," Ms Vazza adds. "That is because, coupled with a slowing economy, historically, defaults peak two to three years after high-yield issuance peaks."

But S&P has its critics. "They're far behind the curve, especially on defaults. They're good at history and bad at future forecasting," says one bond fund expert.

"They'll only be right if the landing in the US economy is really hard. They need this to be right to bale out their prediction reputation - and they don't want to be seen as softer than their rivals."

Some argue that while it is impossible to say there will be no defaults, they should be within normal parameters.

"There will be more defaults because there are more corporate bond issuers," says Bernard Abrahamsen, who heads UK Fixed Income at investment bank Schroders.

"Lots of the bad news has already been priced into the bonds in the US, so gloomy predictions are a repeat of what investors already fear. Here, we don't have such a big proportion of companies at the high risk end of the credit rating spectrum," he adds.

Most bond fund investors have sterling or UK portfolios. Those wanting 100% safety can buy baskets of gilts - UK government backed bonds - where the typical pre-tax yield stands at 4.25%.

"That's ridiculously low," says bond manager Paul Reed at Aberdeen Asset Management. "A good enough basket of bonds and a bit of work can produce a big advance, while those prepared to take some risks can double that return, although we are getting some new issues to soak up demand," he adds.

He believes UK bond failures will be balanced by takeovers and recoveries, while dealers cite continuing demand from pension funds, the need to rebalance the £20bn Equitable Life portfolio, and a possible flight from shares.

Over the past 12 months, typical bond funds returned 7.7% including reinvested income - UK growth oriented unit trusts managed just 1%. But one major bond disappointment was the Norwich Union (formerly CU) Monthly Income Fund, where a high risk mix of junk bonds and equity related preference shares went wrong.

IFA Darius McDermott at Chelsea Financial Services sees the bond market picking up after a bad period.

He says: "A lot of money will go after European bond funds where there are hopes of further currency pick-ups. We would look at Invesco, Framlington and the new Axa fund. But Unless you think equities will be dire or that you have an overweening need for income, we would still say that bond funds are not best advice for most investors."

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: The artless lodger
fields.standfirst: ''Story! Story! Story!' Sandy is obviously going to be a newspaper editor'
fields.trailText: ''Story! Story! Story!' Sandy is obviously going to be a newspaper editor'.
fields.body:
Ex-Spouse has taken his aunt off to Scotland. They missed out on Hogmanay, but I expect there's still plenty of atmosphere: a deep, rich Caledonian winter redolent of saturated fat and with an antique patina. Mahogany, perhaps. Henry has gone back to university, wrapped around Claudia. Their off-piste experiences have helped the bonding process, though I expect she'll eventually become piste-off with him, as seems customary in human relations. And Harriet has gone to stay with her friend Kelly for the weekend, leaving her room looking like a rubbish tip outside Nairobi. If only we lived in a tropical rainforest, I could train the bower birds to tidy up. At least the house has emptied nicely. If it weren't for my ex-husband's subsequent ex-wife and her brat, I could wallow in solitude. Yes, Elaine and Sandy are still here, refugees from the flood plain.

"Story! Story! Story!" The kid's obviously going to grow up into a newspaper editor. Elaine looks pleadingly at me most evenings. I made the fatal mistake a week ago of starting to tell him The Adventures Of Sandy - about how his house was surrounded by water, and Noah's ark suddenly appeared and invited him aboard. Ever since, he has had a series of adventures involving different kinds of animal dung. I'm thinking of working them up into a little collection: The House At Poo Corner.

"Dulcie - could you possibly oblige with another of your fabulous stories?" Elaine cringes ingratiatingly. "I'll cook supper and I've bought a few bottles of Nottage Hill. I'm hoping they'll taste like Hugh Grant!" Cheered by the thought of a decent meal and a bottle of plonk, I go upstairs and tell Sandy a story involving aardvark's piss and an anteater who prefers pants. Descend to kitchen full of delicious smells. Slump wearily down and accept first of several glasses of vino. "I bought you some stuff today, Dulcie, I hope you don't mind." It is very hard to be cross with this woman for long, even if she does steal one's husbands. "It's an alternative HRT kit, look: Dong Quai, Black Cohosh, Agnus Castus, Wild Yam and Red Clover."

Feel grateful and intrigued, though it is perhaps tactless of her to draw attention to my menopause. Wonder if it's a cunning plan to demoralise me. But Elaine never seems cunning. Quite the contrary. She often seems completely artless. Though, perhaps, this could be the greatest cunning of all.

Devour delicious foodstuffs and chuck much vintage down my neck. The herbal menopausal products begin to acquire personalities, indeed sitcom potential. Dong Quai, a Hong Kong émigré whizz kid, shacks up with Black Cohosh, a Brixton rapper, and his Buddhist ex-nun girlfriend, Agnus Castus. In the flat next door are Red Clover, a faded Marxist garden designer, and his boyfriend, Wild Yam, a rock-band supremo given to narcotic excess.

Elaine's face suddenly looms down at me. "Dulcie! Whaddaya thinking?" It seems that narcotic excess is more widespread than I thought.

"I'm thinkin'," I roar, "how most people would say I'm mad to be sitting down and, nay, sheltering, and and and being helpful to the woman who norronly stole my husband, but stole my farkin' lover as well!"

Elaine recoils in horror. "Yurright, Dulcie!" she cries. "M'a bitch! Todally ouda orda to dodat! Yur a saint! But, y'know, I've always always admired you dodally, Tulcie. When I used to live across the road, you always seemed so clever'n'intresting'n'you had a career and, like, work, and I wuz just a useless kept woman empty-headed boody blimbo!"

Amazed by the idea that Elaine might have once admired me. "But," I object authoritatively, "you're farkin' beautiful and thassallthat madders."

"Noah," Elaine insists, "you'll always be intressin', but I'm already losing it. Look, I'm growing a bloody goitre!" She waggles her double chin at me. I find it faintly comforting. Shortly afterwards, I lurch off towards the nearest bed - Aunt Elspeth's, as it happens. A few minutes later, someone crashes down beside me. Elaine's arms snake around my waist. "Nothin' shinishter!" she hisses in my ear. "NOT a leshbian! Just bloody cold an' an' miss my Mummy!" She starts to sob. Not sure whether this is a compliment or an insult, but frankly, my dear, I don't give a damn.

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Ally McCoist
fields.trailText: Ally McCoist
fields.body:
Ally McCoist was born in 1962, and brought up in East Kilbride, the son of a fitter who ran the local football team. He made his professional footballing debut at 16 for St Johnstone, and in 1981 he moved to Sunderland, before transferring to Rangers two years later. He stayed with the Glasgow club until 1998 before joining Kilmarnock. He is one of the most prolific goalscorers in the history of Scottish football. McCoist is also a team captain on BBC1's A Question Of Sport, and introduces the programme's video, Ally McCoist's Trial And Errors.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Sunday lunch with the family.

What is your greatest fear?
My middle son, Argyll.

With which historical figure do you most identify?
Robert the Bruce.

Which living person do you most admire?
My youngest son, Mitchell.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
Timekeeping and biting my nails.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
Ignorance and bad manners.

Where would you like to live?
At home more often.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?
Are you serious?

What is your favourite smell?
Fresh air.

What is your favourite word?
Goal.

What is your favourite journey?
Going home.

How did you vote in the last election?
With a pen and paper.

How will you vote in the next election?
See above.

Should the royal family be scrapped?
No.

Do you believe in capital punishment?
No.

For what cause would you die?
My family.

Which words or phrases do you most overuse?
Brilliant.

When and where were you happiest?
On the park, kicking a football.

How do you relax?
Feet up, watching horseracing on TV.

Do you believe in life after death?
Hope so.

How would you like to be remembered?
Good guy, good fun, gave people pleasure.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
Do not take it for granted.

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Rooting for parsnips
fields.trailText: Rooting for parsnips.
fields.body:
The subject
Pastinaca sativa. One of the few reasons to welcome cold weather. 'As much a part of autumn and winter as asparagus is of summer,' if you, like the Knowledge, side with Nigel Slater's 30-Minute Cook.

The basics
Parsnips lead a double life. They're starchy, but they're also sweet. According to Alan Davidson's The Oxford Companion To Food, they were exploited for both reasons before (a) the arrival of spuds in the 16th century and (b) the discovery of cheap forms of sweetness. Nowadays, the double life is merely life-enhancing, not necessary.

The details
Most people roast parsnips with a joint, so they can absorb cooking juices, but the Knowledge casts them in a starring role. Essential prelims: choose smallish 'snips, carrot-sized rather than Cro-Magnon club; scrub well, trim both ends, halve lengthways; cut out the core from each half - this is usually so woody that it never gets much more tender than a tennis racket. All done? Hooray! Now you can cut the core-free halves into chunks, boil them until they're really soft, and then mash them (after ruthless draining) and serve as a soup (by adding chicken stock, say) or a side dish. Really serious parsnip fans go one step further on the path to Parsnip Pleasure: they leave the parsnips in full-length glory and pluck them from the water just short of full doneness (circa five minutes), then cook them again in a pan with plenty of butter or duck fat over moderate heat. The outside goes crunchy-caramelly, while the inside stays soft and sweet. The result is so good that you'll want to eat it all. And it costs Parsnip Peanuts. Parsnip Plea: ignore recipes that tell you to peel them. Passionate Parsnip Pals: pork, game, lamb, Indian spices.

Where to buy
Aw, come on.

The easy way out
That was it.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck adds to this newspaper's long outmoded reputation for typographical curiosities.
fields.body:
I discover, to my irritation, that I have done my bit to maintain this newspaper's long outmoded reputation for typographical curiosities. In my antepenultimate On The Rack column, I gave Mr Clutten's name as Chutten, while writing on the German retailer (now a phenomenon within these shores) Aldi.

Aldi is a cash-and-carry warehouse operation whose 'no-frills' policy prices as low as any. Over Christmas, for example, its house champagne, Prince Laurent Brut (a product of one of France's largest wine companies), was reduced from £9.99 to £7.89. Even so, I could rate it only 11 points out of 20, for it did little to charm my tastebuds and was really only acceptable as a base for a kir royal (or some such cocktail). However, why spend even £7.89 when you can buy cava for half this and achieve exactly the same result?

The rest of Aldi's range made more or less the same impression, I am sorry to say. St Jean Colombard & Ugni Blanc (£2.09) rates 12 points, Liebfraumilch Nahe 1999 (£1.89) rates eight, Riesling Hock (£2.49) rates 12.5 (good base for a summer spritzer, here), Niersteiner Gutes Domtal Spätlese 1998 (£2.49) rates 11 points, Frascati Superiore 1999 (£2.99) notches up 11 points also, Chardonnay Budavar 1999, from Hungary, (£2.49) manages 12.5 points, and Reflets de Bourgogne Chardonnay 1999 (£4.49) struggles to reach 10 points. The only two whites to make 14 points were the Australian Semillon Chardonnay 1999 (£2.99), with its agreeable hints of ripe melon, pear and lemon, and the California Mountain Vineyards Chardonnay 1999 (£3.99), which has some creamy richness to the soft woodiness that gives it some class.

On the red side, the non-vintage Le Rouge France (£1.89) was the cheapest wine I tasted last year, and also the least impactful. There was nothing to loathe except its vacuousness. It rates 10 points. Baron St Jean Vin de Pays de Gard (£2.09) rates 10.5 points, Château Selection Claret Bordeaux 1999 (£2.49) rates 11 points, Montepulciano d'Abruzzo 1999 (£2.99) achieves the same, as does Budavar Merlot 1999 (£2.49). Fleurie Le Challier 1999 (£4.49) rates 12 points, Chilean Cabernet Sauvignon NV (£2.99) rates 11.5 points, but takes the prize as the most spineless Chilean red I've tasted. Australian Shiraz Cabernet Sauvignon 1999 (£2.99) makes nine points and the Californian Mountain Vineyards Zinfandel Shiraz 1999 (£3.99) 10.5 points. The one red I could enthuse about was Vieux Château Saint-Pierre Montagne St-Emilion 1998 (14 points, £4.49), which is an eminently quaffable authentic merlot (with a layering of cabernet franc). There is a nice touch of liquorice to the blackcurrants. Last at Aldi, there is Moscato Spumante from Italy, a sweet £2.99 bubble that rates 10 points.

Aldi needs to add flair to its rock-bottom prices, in much the same way as Somerfield has done. Wine prices there are also risibly low, but the quality is deliciously high. South African Colombard Chardonnay 1999 (15.5 points, £3.99 - although at Kwik Save it is apparently for sale at £3.49) is outstandingly well textured and classy. Bright Brothers Uruguayan Sauvignon/Semillon 2000 (15.5 points, £3.99) is immensely quaffable, with crisp yet softly undertoned fruit, and refreshing to finish. South African Chenin Blanc 1999 (15.5 points, £3.99) offers a superb texture and fascinating gooseberry/melon fruit. Non- vintage Merlot Vin de Pays l'Ardeche (15 points, £3.35 - £2.99 at Kwik Save) is fresh and cherry-fruited. Non-vintage Argentine Red (15 points, £2.99) has spicy plums allied to organised tannins, and is a great quaffing experience for the money.

Sainsbury's offers us a splendid pair of 16.5-point reds at £4.99. Concha y Toro Casillero del Diablo Cabernet Sauvignon 1999, from Chile, develops on the tastebuds from ripe cherries to smoky blackcurrants, with a hint of spice, and a suggestion of gravy. This is a lovely, textured cabernet of great class. Louis Bernard Ctes du Rhne Villages 1999 parades herbs, pleasant earthiness and deep plum fruit. It is gloriously unpretentious.

 Superplonk.com has Malcolm Gluck's email address and the latest wine news.

The one red I could enthuse about was Vieux Château Saint-Pierre Montagne St-Emilion 1998 (14 points, £4.49), which is an eminently quaffable authentic merlot (with a layering of cabernet franc). There is a nice touch of liquorice to the blackcurrants. Last at Aldi, there is Moscato Spumante from Italy, a sweet £2.99 bubble that rates 10 points. Aldi needs to add flair to its rock-bottom prices, in much the same way as Somerfield has done. Wine prices there are also risibly low, but the quality is deliciously high. South African Colombard Chardonnay 1999 (15.5 points, £3.99 - although at Kwik Save it is apparently for sale at £3.49) is outstandingly well textured and classy. Bright Brothers Uruguayan Sauvignon/Semillon 2000 (15.5 points, £3.99) is immensely quaffable, with crisp yet softly undertoned fruit, and refreshing to finish. South African Chenin Blanc 1999 (15.5 points, £3.99) offers a superb texture and fascinating gooseberry/melon fruit. Non- vintage Merlot Vin de Pays l'Ardeche (15 points, £3.35 - £2.99 at Kwik Save) is fresh and cherry-fruited. Non-vintage Argentine Red (15 points, £2.99) has spicy plums allied to organised tannins, and is a great quaffing experience for the money. Sainsbury's offers us a splendid pair of 16.5-point reds at £4.99. Concha y Toro Casillero del Diablo Cabernet Sauvignon 1999, from Chile, develops on the tastebuds from ripe cherries to smoky blackcurrants, with a hint of spice, and a suggestion of gravy. This is a lovely, textured cabernet of great class. Louis Bernard Ctes du Rhne Villages 1999 parades herbs, pleasant earthiness and deep plum fruit. It is gloriously unpretentious.  Superplonk.com has Malcolm Gluck's email address and the latest wine news.

webTitle: Jeremy Lee: Some like it hot

fields.headline: Some like it hot
fields.standfirst: Some spices are so familiar that we take them for granted. Jeremy Lee considers the potent power of the trusty, but misunderstood, peppercorn
fields.trailText: Some spices are so familiar that we take them for granted. Jeremy Lee considers the potent power of the trusty, but misunderstood, peppercorn.
fields.body:
In 1328, the splendidly named Guild Of Pepperers was registered as "Grossarii", from which the term grocer is derived. Not enough people know that. The fact that a spice should have its own guild is an indication of just how important pepper was considered to be in the great scheme of English cooking. And things haven't changed that much. Pepper may be the most common of all the spices, but its worth in cooking is incalculable, and no other spice figures as frequently.

The climbing tree, Piper nigrum , which winds its way up the trunks of mango or betel trees, bears but one fruit, a berry, that is harvested at different stages of ripeness - fully under-ripened to give the green peppercorn; slightly under-ripened to produce the black peppercorn; and fully ripened to give the greatly prized white peppercorns.

Green peppercorns can be dried, but are more generally used in their brined form, with a soft texture that is easy to crush and quite delicious. To produce black peppercorns, the berries are picked when they begin to turn red, and then piled high and allowed to ferment for several days before being spread out on mats to dry, when they turn black. The ripest berries produce white pepper; after harvesting, they are soaked to soften the pericarp, or outer wall, allowing the removal of the seed within.

The tree was native to, most famously, the forests of Malabar. In his book Dangerous Tastes, Andrew Dalby writes of the Greeks' use of Malabar pepper in the 4th century BC and how the Romans, 500 years later, took advantage of the predictable monsoon winds to sail to the ports of south-west India. Cultivation of the tree began in earnest, although the Roman obsession for pepper was not to everyone's taste: a Tamil poet wryly commented on Roman ships arriving with silver and gold and leaving with pepper, and Dalby quotes Pliny bemoaning 100 million sestertia a year being spent on pepper to satisfy Rome's lusty appetite.

As the European passion for spices grew, the lengths to which the Portuguese, Dutch and English went to try to achieve the spice monopolies were truly extraordinary, their methods highly questionable, often downright vicious and most treacherous.

In spite of the huge mercantile interest and adventure it has inspired in the past, it's not often that pepper gets to be the hero in any dish. But there is no doubt that the foods we eat today would often be lacking without it. There is hardly a dish in which it doesn't add its distinctive heat.

Whether to use white or black pepper is a minor debate. White is milder than black, but less aromatic. You can combine equal quantities of white and black peppercorns, then crack them to make migonette pepper, which is a happy vehicle, splendidly flavouring meat and forming a glorious crust while frying gently.

Unground peppercorns will keep indefinitely, and the cunning device that is the efficient pepper mill is an indispensable tool in a kitchen. Once ground, the glory of pepper fades. The rubbish that is sold as ground pepper should be banished, as it is generally made from poor-quality pepper and has little worth. While the tree is now grown throughout the tropics, those of India - Alleppey, Tellicherry and Mangalore - are still among the the most highly prized and are worth seeking out.

All recipes serve six.

Hot and sour soup

This recipe may seem lengthy, but that's only because it has a lot of ingredients - and that means a visit to the nearest Chinese supermarket.

2 large dried mushrooms
6 tree ear mushrooms
4 dried tiger lily stems
1 tbsp peanut oil
50g pork, finely shredded
1 tbsp light soy sauce
1 big handful bamboo shoots, finely shredded
1.2 litres chicken stock
Salt
3 tbsp very good red-wine vinegar
1 tsp dark soy sauce
1 slabs fresh white bean curd
2 eggs, lightly beaten
1 tbsp sesame oil
1 tsp freshly-milled black pepper
8 spring onions
1 big handful fresh coriander, washed and picked

Put the mushrooms, tree ears and tiger lily stems in a mixing bowl, and steep in boiling water. After half an hour, lift out the softened pieces and drain. Cut away the stems of the mushrooms and the harder part of the tree ears. Chop the mushrooms and tree ears into very thin slices. If the tiger lily is very long, shred it with your fingers.

The soup can be cooked in a heavy-based pan, but a wok is better. Place it over a high heat, pour in the peanut oil and fry the pork, stirring and separating the strips. Add the light soy sauce, then the mushrooms, tree ears, tiger lily stems and bamboo shoots. Stir for a minute, then add the stock, a little salt, the vinegar and the dark soy sauce. Bring to the boil.

Finely slice the bean curd. Trim and finely slice the spring onion. Chop the coriander. Drop the curd strips into the broth, return it to the boil, then turn off the heat for 30 seconds. Tip in the sesame oil and pepper, stir, then pour in the beaten egg in a steady stream. Add the spring onion and coriander. Stir again, and serve at once.

Salt and pepper squid

800g squid
1 tbsp plain flour
1 tsp sea salt
1 tsp freshly-ground black pepper
Vegetable oil, for deep frying

To garnish

2 green chillies
8 spring onions
Lemon wedges

Clean and prepare the squid (ie, remove the ink sac and backbone, and clean out the inside of the squid tube), discarding the sideflaps but keeping the tentacles. If the squids are large, cut the flesh into squares; if they're small, cut the body into rounds. Rinse, then pat dry.

Heat the oil, in a deep-fat fryer if you have one, and have a wide dish piled high with kitchen paper to hand. Wash and trim the onions and chillies, then slice both as thinly as possible. Mix together the flour, salt and pepper, pop the dried squid in a bowl and toss in the seasoned flour, coating all the squid pieces. Adjust the seasoning to taste.

Drop a handful of the squid at a time into the oil, and fry for a minute. Tip the cooked squid on to the kitchen paper, and repeat until all the squid is cooked. Pile it on a plate, scatter over the slivers of chilli and spring onion, and serve with lemon wedges.

Fricassee of chicken with green peppers and tarragon

I've suggested two chickens here, as the leftovers make an excellent salad.

2 free-range, organic chickens
Olive oil
Salt and black pepper
8 cloves garlic, peeled
150ml white wine
2 tbsp Armagnac
2 tbsp jarred green peppercorns, plus 1 tsp pepper juice
1 tbsp fresh tarragon, picked
1 tsp Dijon mustard
200ml whipping cream
lemon, juiced

Cut the legs from the chickens, ensuring that the oyster-shaped pieces of dark meat do not remain on the carcass. Remove the backbone, and use this, the leg and wing tips and other bits to make a simple stock. Cut each breast piece into four, then separate the drumsticks and the thighs. Set a large, heavy-bottomed pan over a medium heat. Pour in a little oil, liberally salt and pepper the pieces of chicken, and lay the meat, skin-side down, in the pan and leave to fry gently, undisturbed, along with the cloves of garlic. Cook for 20 minutes until golden, then turn each piece. Cook for a further five to 10 minutes, then remove the breast pieces and keep warm while the legs continue cooking through.

Once done, place all the meat in a dish and keep warm. Raise the heat under the pan, pour in the Armagnac and then the white wine, and as they bubble away, scrape up any bits and pieces of chicken that have stuck to the bottom of the pan. Simmer until the liquid has reduced by one third, then stir in the peppercorns and their juice and whisk in the mustard. Bring the sauce to a boil and tip in the cream. Chop the tarragon and add this to the pan, along with the lemon juice. Stir, simmer for a minute, then pour over the chicken and serve piping hot.

Sauce poivrade

This goes well with meats, game and robust fish such as hake or monkfish.

For the stock

1kg free-range, organic chicken pieces, on the bone
1 carrot
3 onions
1 stick celery
1 leek
1 bayleaf
1 small sprig fresh thyme
6 black peppercorns
100ml white wine
2 pig's trotters

For the sauce

2 onions, chopped
1 small carrot, chopped
1 small stick celery, chopped
1 clove garlic, chopped
5 parsley stalks
1 bayleaf
30ml top-quality red-wine vinegar
1 litre chicken stock
200ml good red wine
15 black peppercorns
30g unsalted butter

First, make the stock. In a heavy-bottomed pan, fry the chicken in a little vegetable oil until golden. Wash and chop the veg, and fry them in the same pot until they, too, take on some colour. Pour in the wine, and add the herbs and pepper. Add the trotters, pour in enough cold water to cover the chicken by a good 5cm, then bring to a simmer and cook for 1 <+>1 / <->2 -2 hours. Pour the resulting liquid through a fine sieve lined with muslin, and return to the pot and raise the heat to high. As the stock comes to the boil, skim off any foam that rises to the surface, then leave to simmer until reduced by a quarter. Cool the stock, and refrigerate or freeze until required (if stored in the fridge, it should be boiled again every day until you use it, which should be within three or four days. Such sauces tend to taste better, and are easier to make, in larger quantities, so freeze any that you do not need.

To make the sauce, fry the chopped veg in a little oil until well coloured. Add the garlic, bayleaf and parsley, then pour in the vinegar and simmer until completely reduced. Pour in the wine, and cook until reduced by half. Pour in the stock, bring up to a simmer and cook gently for 20 minutes. Crack the peppercorns, then drop them in the sauce and simmer for a minute. Pour the sauce through a fine sieve, and return to the boil, skimming away any foam that appears. Taste and adjust the seasoning if required, then whisk in a small knob of butter and a final few grinds of black pepper

 Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, Butlers Wharf, London SE1.

fields.headline: I will survive
fields.standfirst: He was the 70s disco king who launched New York's legendary Studio 54. Then came the downfall - tax evasion and a prison term. Now Ian Schrager is back, still in tune with the times, at the head of a proliferating chain of 'hip' hotels
fields.trailText: He was the 70s disco king who launched New York's legendary Studio 54. Then came the downfall - tax evasion and a prison term. Now Ian Schrager is back, still in tune with the times, at the head of a proliferating chain of 'hip' hotels.
fields.body:
The young man dressed in black appears to be speaking to his wristwatch. Except it's not a watch. It's some kind of minuscule walkie-talkie strapped to his wrist, in the style of a baddy in Mission: Impossible, say, or The Matrix. "Location required for two medium-sized pieces of luggage," he says to his wrist. There's a pause, then the response comes back. Affirmative - location found. Over and out. The young man is a bellhop at New York's Hudson hotel, and we've asked him if he can store our bags for a couple of hours until we leave to catch our flight home.

A bit of a palaver, the stunt with the walkie-talkie - a bit of a performance. But that's the whole point of the Hudson. For Ian Schrager's modish hotels, of which the Hudson is the newest and biggest, are all about performance. The exteriors are unobtrusive, but inside they are designed (by Philippe Starck) like whimsical stage sets, full of skewed proportions and vertiginous angles. The entrance to the Royalton, also in New York, is essentially a catwalk - a raised platform that runs through the bar - an exhibitionist's dream, along which you must walk, or sashay. At the Hudson, a glass-enclosed escalator in a vivid shaft of yellow light transports you up to the 40ft-high, glass-roofed lobby. They, the hotels, are also about atmosphere. "It makes you want to drink," said a teetotal New Yorker friend as he emerged from the futuristic, translucent Hudson bar, where the glass floor literally lights up.

Since its opening, people have been queueing along the street at weekends just to have a drink here. Yet, such is the ingenious sleight of hand that Schrager pulls off, the appeal of his hotels is their exclusivity, or rather the illusion of exclusivity. An eager young Englishman in the Hudson's "library" bar informed us that the previous evening Harrison Ford had been sitting in the very same capacious leather armchair that I was now occupying. Jack Nicholson loves the macaroni cheese, someone else told us in the restaurant. Well, if it's good enough for Jack... The highly profitable Schrager formula - last year, the business is said to have made a $120m profit - is predicated on the whiff of glamour and celebrity that pervades his establishments. Maybe a little of that lustre, that sex appeal will rub off on the rest of us. Ker-ching!

The 54-year-old Schrager, inventor of the "boutique hotel" or "destination hotel", is largely responsible for a sea change in the hotel industry (although, with 900 rooms, the Hudson makes a rather large boutique). You only have to flick through glossy magazines such as Wallpaper* or Condé Nast Traveller, or books such as the best-selling Hip Hotels series, to see that the Schrager game plan extends far beyond his own domain. In modern city travel there is a decisive move away from the sameness summed up by the old Holiday Inn slogan "the best surprise is no surprise".

It was a trend that Schrager kickstarted in 1984 with his first hotel, Morgans, and followed up with the Royalton and Paramount, all in New York. The art of lobby culture was born, or reborn, and these hotels became hot spots for locals and guests alike. Miami's Delano (where Madonna co-owns the restaurant) followed, and the Mondrian in West Hollywood. Schrager has opened in London, too, with St Martins Lane and the Sanderson (with holographic lifts and a stained-glass-windowed billiards room) equally beloved by the jet set and would-be jet set.

If anyone should know about celebrity and glamour - and their sleazy downside - it's Schrager, the man who created the legendary 70s New York nightclub, Studio 54 (and later, in the 80s, Palladium, one of the biggest clubs New York has ever seen). Studio 54 was the mecca of the disco generation, where Bianca Jagger famously once made a grand entrance on a white horse. It is remembered as a hedonistic hang-out, where Warhol sat and watched as Mick, Margaux, Liza and Truman Capote caroused, along with the hosts of extravagantly dressed decadents, druggies and party people who also managed to gain entry. Two films, The Last Days Of Disco and 54, have re-told the story of the club's rise and ultimate fall - a dramatic raid, and the arrest and imprisonment of its owners, Schrager and Steve Rubell, for tax evasion in 1980.

Nightclub entrepreneur was not a career that was mapped out for Schrager, he says, nor even hotelier, when he was growing up in Brooklyn's East Flatbush. His parents brought him up with "middle class, maybe somewhat provincial, values" (rumours of his father's alleged mob connections have always been flatly denied by Schrager). "The entertainment business would have been taboo to them." In any case, as it turned out, his parents would never know of their son's career path - Schrager senior died when his son was just 19, and Ian lost his mother five years after that. By then he had trained at Syracuse University to become an attorney, and it was there that he met fellow Brooklynite Steve Rubell. Schrager practised law for a while, but then the pair "fell into" the nightclub business, "you didn't need much capital".

They were a winning team - Rubell was flamboyant and gay, Schrager reserved and straight. Their friendship and business partnership lasted until Rubell's death of an Aids-related illness in 1989. "I'll never have the kind of friendship I had with Steve, who I loved," says Schrager. "We went to school together and grew up together and had our ups and downs together, and it was a really, y'know, unique and special thing." Nightclubs suited his fancy, he says, encompassing as they did many disciplines in an undisciplined, "freewheeling" way. Schrager always had the more detached approach of the two - Rubell was the front man, working the door and mingling flamboyantly, Schrager tended to stay put in the office at the back of the club, earning the nickname "Greta", after Garbo.

Schrager famously never danced at Studio 54. But it is now widely considered to be his intuitive understanding of detail, of creating an ambience, that was the driving force behind the duo's success. But it was never an intellectual exercise, he insists. "All you have is the atmosphere you create, it's about creating this magic and this excitement and this cachet because you really don't have anything else distinguishable from other nightclubs."

Studio 54 was the paradigm for Schrager's subsequent ventures, but also for much of late 20th-century, urban nightlife. The media frenzy, the celeb clientele, the smart design - all of these became commonplace in urban bars and clubs in the decades that followed. And it was here that the "velvet rope" approach to nightclub access was pioneered - the rope was the barrier between the in-crowd, handpicked by Rubell from the throng who assembled nightly on the pavement outside, and the forlorn rejects. Schrager has always dismissed accusations of elitism. "I used to say it's the most democratic club of them all, because it has nothing to do with wealth or race or religion or creed. It does have to do with a spirit, an attitude." He says he used to see "people in ballgowns dancing with people in jeans", and that is a sensibility that has stayed with him.

The hedonistic mood, too, has since become legendary. It was a different time, "much druggier, not as cerebral or social as now - the time for that kind of thing has come and gone". The wildness can be overplayed, he says: "It wasn't debauchery, as legend has it, it wasn't that bad." Schrager had grown up in New York in the 60s when, he says, it was the black population who had set the cultural agenda. "In the 70s, it was the gay population's time to emerge and set the cultural tone." It was also a time when the Pill and the liberation that came with it had begun to take off. "All of this was hitting its stride," he says. In the States, the 70s were known as the "me decade" (a label more usually attributed to the 80s here), and nothing encapsulated that sensibility more than Studio 54. "Everyone was really self-involved, and that self-involvement necessarily led to a lot of indulgence."

Now, the mood of celebratory sexual permissiveness that Studio 54 was known for seems outdated, a sensibility defined by, and contained within, its era."My memories are really ones of spontaneity and innocence and naivety," says Schrager. "It was pre-Aids, pre all of the things that we've subsequently learned about the price we pay, and about the things that aren't good for you or aren't appropriate or aren't right. It was like, anything goes. But I don't look on it as Sodom and Gomorrah. No, I look on it as, y'know, the Baby Boomers having a real impact on culture and flexing their muscles and experimenting."

But it couldn't last. The club was raided by Internal Revenue Service agents in 1979. They found nearly $1m stashed in bin bags concealed in the ceiling of the office, and it was estimated that another $2.5m had been skimmed. How did they think they could get away with it? Did their success and the mood of the time make them feel invincible? "Invincible - I'm not sure. Intoxicated with the whole thing, yes. It was like a lightning bolt, like holding on to a lightning bolt."

The club closed in 1980, and Schrager and Rubell were sentenced to three years in jail. They served one year at the Maxwell Federal Prison Camp in Montgomery, Alabama. It was a reflective time for Schrager, and a "completely humbling" one. But it didn't quash the pair's enthusiasm or passion, and it was during their time inside that they decided to go into the hotel business. fields.headline: Get fresh
fields.standfirst: Carmine classic
fields.trailText: Carmine classic.
fields.body:
If you've got some fresh cranberries lurking in the fridge, why not juice them? True, cranberries in the raw aren't exactly overburdened with flavour - the juice is at best clean-tasting, with a bitter background note - but it does have a wonderfully vivid red hue. The other main attraction is the cranberry's health-giving properties: a good source of vitamin C and an anti-fungal, anti-viral action which earmarks it for those suffering from urinary tract infections and thrush.

Our shelves are laden with off-the-peg cranberry drinks, trading on the fruit's healthy image, but they tend to be sugary. Make your own by teaming cranberries with the freshly-pressed juice of sweet apples (go for Cox's or Braeburns) or perfumed William pears and some intense, marmaladey clementines, if you can find good ones, or sweet oranges. Hey presto: cranberry sauce in a glass. To make one glass, put 100g cranberries in the juicer (or blender) with any of the following: four clementines, one orange, one sweet apple, two pears.

fields.headline: Happy vending
fields.standfirst: Getting the best price for your home is a sophisticated business - that's if you believe estate agents and their 'house doctor' cousins. So what hot advice do they offer to the seller? Andrew Purvis reports
fields.trailText: Getting the best price for your home is a sophisticated business - that's if you believe estate agents and their 'house doctor' cousins. So what hot advice do they offer to the seller? Andrew Purvis reports.
fields.body:
In his 30 years of showing prospective buyers around properties, estate agent Hugh Dunsmore-Hardy has never once smelled the aroma of fresh coffee nor the warm, comforting whiff of hastily-baked bread. It's a shocking revelation from a man who has had the voyeuristic pleasure of stepping inside thousands of homes, especially to the halfwits among us who actually believed the myths.

"Few people have the competence to bake bread," says the chief executive of the National Association of Estate Agents, "and I've never really bought the one about coffee. I don't think people will spend £500,000 on a house because it smells like a cafe. Offering a coffee, on the other hand, goes down a bundle in creating goodwill."

It's a refreshing thought that straightforward fawning can work where the complex science of aromatherapy can't - but you'd expect an estate agent to think of that. What troubles me is the way you will be judged when you start offering hospitality to strangers. Will potential buyers sneer and go elsewhere when they realise your coffee is instant? Will they shave a few grand off the price if you run out of Fair Trade Mocha Java or Ethiopian Sidamo and offer them Douwe Egberts instead? What if they only drink tea?

It may sound paranoid, but when people view a property they are viewing the owners as well. Daphne Leck, a "house doctor" with Property Presentation Services - a US-style consultancy that helps vendors "dress" their homes for sale - believes the seller's image and possessions are almost as important as the building itself. "Potential buyers do have an idea of the kind of lifestyle they will have in that property, so they will be put off by white melamine furniture but encouraged by the right kind of kitchen appliance or tasteful antiques. That is particularly the case in London, where prices are so aspirationally high." Perhaps the old trick of displaying a music stand in the front room, beaming out an impression of cultured bohemianism and classical erudition, really does work.

The truth is, homebuyers are a lot more savvy than they were - and TV programmes such as Changing Rooms and Home Front have given people a false sense of aesthetic superiority. If Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen is an "expert", interior design can't be that difficult. "In the 80s, it was cookery programmes," says Leck, "but now the obsession is with homes and gardens. Everyone wants to do what Laurence says." I ask whether the old advice about baking bread is a culinary 80s thing as well, but Leck thinks it goes back further: "That was doing the rounds in the 70s - and it still is. Estate agents just haven't grown up."

As she points out, there are practical reasons why making your kitchen smell like a patisserie doesn't work. "It just makes people feel hungry," she says, "so they'll go dashing off to McDonald's instead of taking a good look at your home."

So what are the house doctor's tips for making a home sell - if not smell - like a hot, organic wholemeal bloomer? "Smell is important," says Leck, "but we've come a long way since the 70s when people sprayed chemical room fresheners all over the place. Now, the move is towards more natural, subtle smells - like scented candles. Good old fresh air is making a comeback, too, so open the windows for half an hour before the viewers arrive."

Another trend is feng shui - though Leck warns that banishing spiky plants, sawing the corners off tables and preventing positive "qi" from escaping down the lavatory may not pay the dividends you think. "It's a bit of a fad, and buyers simply won't notice unless they are of that mindset themselves. But it's true that the loo seat does look better down rather than up."

Then there are all those other old chestnuts, like the one about a nice fitted kitchen from Ikea adding thousands to the value of your home. "Free-standing kitchen units are much more popular these days," says Leck, "and it's more the look of the kitchen that counts. The problem is, it is so subjective. The acme of style to you may just look like a waste of money to the viewer who walks in through your door."

Paul Williams, managing director of Holden Matthews estate agents, in north London, is doubtful that even the ultimate bourgeois accessory - a stainless-steel Smeg cooker with a rotisserie big enough to chargrill eight chickens - will necessarily shift a home. "Most of the properties we're selling in Islington are worth half a million pounds," he says. "Anyone with that kind of money will have pretty strong views about what they want. They'll see straight through a Smeg cooker."

Perhaps the most dubious of accessories is children. With three or four of those romping round the house, you will never persuade anyone to buy. That is the view of another agent at Holden Matthews, who described having children around during a viewing as "a complete waste of time". The company's leaflet for vendors puts it more subtly ("Keep children and pets at bay..."), but most property professionals agree that the patter of tiny feet is a turn-off for buyers. "Ask a neighbour to babysit," urges Pamela Hadaway, a house doctor with The Wow Factor, "ideally elsewhere. Then you can give your undivided attention to the visitor." Only Daphne Leck seems to have latched on to the contentious millennial view that children are humans, and a part of your home, rather than things to be tidied away. "Estate agents send out videos," she says, "showing houses before and after being prepared for sale. They are completely desolate places. Moving house is a hard time for kids, and making them invisible will not make you the best of friends." Nevertheless, she suggests arranging viewings only when the children are out at school.

Most of the advice on offer is mind-numbingly obvious (throw away clutter, tend the garden, mend the leaking tap) but there are a few unexpected gems. "Mode of dress is important," says Pamela Hadaway. "Look well-off when selling, and slightly less well-off when buying." She also suggests sending pets to the beauty parlour, brushing spiders' webs from bushes, and placing "big bold plants about 4ft high" in bathrooms to divert attention from "mouldy old taps". Her advice on estate agents' photographs is: "Avoid snow, which proves it's been on the market since last winter - and try not to show the estate agent's car parked in the drive."

"Trim hedges, hide dustbins, paint the front door and polish the door furniture," urges the Holden Matthews brochure - houseproud gestures that might invite instant burglary in the less salubrious areas of some inner cities. Sometimes it is more sensible to leave your house looking like a squat.

There is, of course, a complacent inertia that can prevent a property from realising its market potential. When you've lived in a dump for a while, you become blind to the depravity of your circumstances. But sometimes that doesn't matter. In one house he was selling in Cambridge, Stewart Chipchase, of agents FPD Savills, found "16,000 books on the upper floors, and every inch cluttered with grass cuttings, broken lawn mowers, supermarket baskets full of unopened tins and food packets - and dog poo!" The house sold within three weeks.

All this begs the question of whether house doctors are worth their fee. When I cast my mind back to why we chose our property, the thing I remember most is the stench of rotting fish. Mind you, there was a log fire blazing and classical music playing - so the guy had read the right leaflets. The thing that really swayed us, though, was that our children fell in love with the place. I'm sure Pamela Hadaway of The Wow Factor would have something to say about that. She refers to children as "disposable assets" and says they shouldn't really be allowed to view properties. Not only are they a distraction, but ornaments can vanish "into little pockets". "I don't know about you," she says, "but I've got lots of porcelain, crystal and silver in my house which I'd very much like to keep intact." As the house doctors say, taste is very subjective

Selling your home: What the experts say

Tip: Offer a coffee. The generous version of the old 'aroma' myth.
Theory: Three out of 10 people buy because they like the owner (source: estate agents Holden Matthews).
Downside: Seven out of 10 people don't.

Tip: Dress well.
Theory: If you look affluent, people will make a higher offer.
Downside: You can't afford to because of the mortgage.

Tip: Fitted units are better than freestanding.
Theory: Bolted-down £2,000 kitchen Ikea units add £20,000 in value to your home.
Downside: You haven't been reading Elle Decoration.

Tip: Take pets to the beauty parlour.
Theory: They won't stink.
Downside: The sofa still does.

Tip: Polish the door furniture.
Theory: It's the first thing potential buyers see.
Downside: It's the first thing burglars nick.

Tip: Home improvements really do help.
Theory: 'Good bathrooms and kitchens help sell a property' (National Association of Estate Agents leaflet).
Downside: Good bathrooms and kitchens highlight the bad state of the rest of the place.

Tip: Tidy up.
Theory: 'In a flat, ensure common parts are clean and tidy. Remove all old post' (source: Holden Matthews).
Downside: All old post came from Holden Matthews.

Tip: Consult a house doctor.
Theory: Professional advice can add 10% to the value of your home.
Downside: And 50% to your outgoings.

Tip: Think feng shui when arranging ornaments and furniture (also, close the loo seat).
Theory: It harmonises the 'qi' energy, making buyers feel good about your home.
Downside: How many people understand what 'qi' is about?

Tip: Light a scented candle.
Theory: More natural than the air fresheners of the 70s.
Downside: Now you've given away your age.

Tip: Light a fire.
Theory: Glowing embers and a smell of woodsmoke create a pleasant ambience.
Downside: Your chimney hasn't been swept in years and the place fills with smoke.
