fields.bodyText: In his 30 years of showing prospective buyers around properties, estate agent Hugh Dunsmore-Hardy has never once smelled the aroma of fresh coffee nor the warm, comforting whiff of hastily-baked bread. It's a shocking revelation from a man who has had the voyeuristic pleasure of stepping inside thousands of homes, especially to the halfwits among us who actually believed the myths. "Few people have the competence to bake bread," says the chief executive of the National Association of Estate Agents, "and I've never really bought the one about coffee. I don't think people will spend £500,000 on a house because it smells like a cafe. Offering a coffee, on the other hand, goes down a bundle in creating goodwill." It's a refreshing thought that straightforward fawning can work where the complex science of aromatherapy can't - but you'd expect an estate agent to think of that. What troubles me is the way you will be judged when you start offering hospitality to strangers. Will potential buyers sneer and go elsewhere when they realise your coffee is instant? Will they shave a few grand off the price if you run out of Fair Trade Mocha Java or Ethiopian Sidamo and offer them Douwe Egberts instead? What if they only drink tea? It may sound paranoid, but when people view a property they are viewing the owners as well. Daphne Leck, a "house doctor" with Property Presentation Services - a US-style consultancy that helps vendors "dress" their homes for sale - believes the seller's image and possessions are almost as important as the building itself. "Potential buyers do have an idea of the kind of lifestyle they will have in that property, so they will be put off by white melamine furniture but encouraged by the right kind of kitchen appliance or tasteful antiques. That is particularly the case in London, where prices are so aspirationally high." Perhaps the old trick of displaying a music stand in the front room, beaming out an impression of cultured bohemianism and classical erudition, really does work. The truth is, homebuyers are a lot more savvy than they were - and TV programmes such as Changing Rooms and Home Front have given people a false sense of aesthetic superiority. If Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen is an "expert", interior design can't be that difficult. "In the 80s, it was cookery programmes," says Leck, "but now the obsession is with homes and gardens. Everyone wants to do what Laurence says." I ask whether the old advice about baking bread is a culinary 80s thing as well, but Leck thinks it goes back further: "That was doing the rounds in the 70s - and it still is. Estate agents just haven't grown up." As she points out, there are practical reasons why making your kitchen smell like a patisserie doesn't work. "It just makes people feel hungry," she says, "so they'll go dashing off to McDonald's instead of taking a good look at your home." So what are the house doctor's tips for making a home sell - if not smell - like a hot, organic wholemeal bloomer? "Smell is important," says Leck, "but we've come a long way since the 70s when people sprayed chemical room fresheners all over the place. Now, the move is towards more natural, subtle smells - like scented candles. Good old fresh air is making a comeback, too, so open the windows for half an hour before the viewers arrive." Another trend is feng shui - though Leck warns that banishing spiky plants, sawing the corners off tables and preventing positive "qi" from escaping down the lavatory may not pay the dividends you think. "It's a bit of a fad, and buyers simply won't notice unless they are of that mindset themselves. But it's true that the loo seat does look better down rather than up." Then there are all those other old chestnuts, like the one about a nice fitted kitchen from Ikea adding thousands to the value of your home. "Free-standing kitchen units are much more popular these days," says Leck, "and it's more the look of the kitchen that counts. The problem is, it is so subjective. The acme of style to you may just look like a waste of money to the viewer who walks in through your door." Paul Williams, managing director of Holden Matthews estate agents, in north London, is doubtful that even the ultimate bourgeois accessory - a stainless-steel Smeg cooker with a rotisserie big enough to chargrill eight chickens - will necessarily shift a home. "Most of the properties we're selling in Islington are worth half a million pounds," he says. "Anyone with that kind of money will have pretty strong views about what they want. They'll see straight through a Smeg cooker." Perhaps the most dubious of accessories is children. With three or four of those romping round the house, you will never persuade anyone to buy. That is the view of another agent at Holden Matthews, who described having children around during a viewing as "a complete waste of time". The company's leaflet for vendors puts it more subtly ("Keep children and pets at bay..."), but most property professionals agree that the patter of tiny feet is a turn-off for buyers. "Estate agents send out videos," she says, "showing houses before and after being prepared for sale. They are completely desolate places. Moving house is a hard time for kids, and making them invisible will not make you the best of friends." Nevertheless, she suggests arranging viewings only when the children are out at school. Most of the advice on offer is mind-numbingly obvious (throw away clutter, tend the garden, mend the leaking tap) but there are a few unexpected gems. She also suggests sending pets to the beauty parlour, brushing spiders' webs from bushes, and placing "big bold plants about 4ft high" in bathrooms to divert attention from "mouldy old taps". Her advice on estate agents' photographs is: "Avoid snow, which proves it's been on the market since last winter - and try not to show the estate agent's car parked in the drive." fields.headline: The People's Pessimism
fields.standfirst: 'Blair would have a think and probably end up appointing a Depression Tsar, who would be half Redcoat, half Robin Williams in Patch Adams'
fields.trailText: 'Blair would have a think and probably end up appointing a Depression Tsar, who would be half Redcoat, half Robin Williams in Patch Adams'.
fields.body:
One in three Britons is currently depressed, according to those party people at the Mental Health Foundation. This figure has found disfavour with the Pollyannas at the health department, who had it pegged at 20% of women and 14% of men. Then there's the suicide rate, of course, which has trebled over the past 30 years to the extent that it is now the third greatest cause of death of men aged 25 to 34. Job insecurity, the divorce rate and drug and alcohol abuse are all blamed and, says the foundation, depression is rising so rapidly among teenagers that if we don't "recognise" it as a major disease, in 20 years we're going to have an "epidemic" on our hands. This strikes me as a good bit of pretzel logic - recognise something and it'll go away; "Yes! You're right; I shouldn't be here - it's a fair cop, byee!" - but for reasons that can't all be to do with my spiteful and malign personality, I found these figures vaguely cheering.

I suppose it's the idea of Blair, sitting at his desk reading those figures, the initial sneer of disbelief chased from his lovely face by that petulant half-laugh we've all come to know and loathe: "Well, thanks a bundle!" he'd ejaculate. "After everything I've done for you ungrateful shower!" (Even alone he wouldn't cuss.) Then he'd have a think and probably end up appointing a Depression Tsar, who would be half Redcoat, half Robin Williams in Patch Adams.

I've never liked the idea of depression much - it often seems to happen to people with too much time on their hands rather than real sorrows - but I do approve of this new survey. And I think what it indicates isn't actually clinical depression, but simply profound dismay. We spent the last century marching up to the top of the hill, and now we're there the vertigo is shocking. Life was always a bit of a vale of tears - getting used to the idea that everything nice ends and everyone you love dies was always going to be a downer, no matter how you slice it - with the odd nice outing thrown in, but during the last century there was always the feeling, in this country anyway, that things were definitely getting better.

The welfare state, the NHS, nationalisation, the marvel of mobility - now eclipsed by filthy hospitals, creeping trains and the spectre of TB stalking the cities again. Young people actually look back to the 70s and 80s as decades of fun and freedom; in the sad, sour soundtrack of Eminem and his brothers in rap, we see an unprecedented turnaround in youth music's treatment of sex, even, always the ultimate treat. Whereas pop and rock was always about the pleasure and transcendence of sex, in rap it is a joyless compulsion. In a twist on the old line about opera - that that which is too ridiculous to be spoken can be redeemed by the addition of music - we now have the spectacle of deeply reactionary views about homosexuals (perverts) and sexually active women (sluts) being hailed as radical art, whereas if a Tory MP was to come out with something half as strong they'd be dismissed as an ignorant bigot. Why?

The one thing Eminem has to recommend him, though, is his flagrant dismay at everything fame has to throw at him. Depression privatises discontent; dismay unites it, hopefully. I only hope I get there; I don't do depression myself, but I have in recent months recognised a new feeling in my personal repertoire - a cold, detached feeling towards anything to do with politics, politicians or, more shamefully, international affairs. I, who spent a good 15 years bursting into tears on buses because of all that stuff that was happening in Chile and South Africa, now scoot through the Guardian's international news pages like a dirty scab skipping across a picket line, bound for the sanctuary of G2's soft cell. The final straw for me was the Arabs and Israelis - at it again, after all these years! At first I felt bad about it, and then - conveniently, admittedly - this started to seem like a terrible conceit, even less morally acceptable than callousness. Who the hell cares if I care?

I know loads of people who feel like this, some of them with colossal records of political engagement. It's the dead leg of the soul. And it doesn't stop there, either. In my personal life, I find myself unable to sustain any interest in either my old friends or my potential new ones, no matter how attractive, smart or famous; I can talk at length to no one but my boyfriend and my cleaner. "You've just grown out of them," my boyfriend soothes. "You want to get some new ones. Perhaps you could advertise." Oh, really? What would it say, this advert? "Wanted: companion for tepid disdain and wild indifference. Don't call me and I won't call you." (And then, embarrassingly, when you finally do get around to calling the people you've been avoiding to apologise, they didn't notice because they were avoiding you, too. That's a real booster.)

I think all of us, to some extent, are the Arabs and Israelis now; we've all heard it too many times, be it the blandishments of beautiful strangers or the bragging of politicians. There comes a time when fatalism actually comes to seem more peaceful, more honest, than going through the motions of idealism one more time; kinder than raising people's hopes and then inevitably dashing them on the rocks of reality. And just as a bloody-minded, best-foot-forward utilitarian optimism seemed the natural response to the 20th century for anyone with half a heart, so a clear-eyed, bouncy pessimism seems the wise choice for this one. Then, if they do ever get the hospitals clean and the trains running and Aids cured, it'll be a lovely surprise, won't it?

With surreal, almost League-Of-Gentlemenish humour, as always, Monday's Daily Mail summed up the national mood; the People's Pessimism, if you will. Pages of new year diets and self-improvement were followed by the concluding chunk of a forthcoming book called Prophets Of The Apocalypse - COUNTDOWN TO ARMAGEDDON! the headline screamed - THE END OF THE WORLD IS FORECAST IN ASTONISHING DETAIL IN THE BIBLE. AND A TERRIFYING NEW BOOK SAYS IT WILL COME FAR SOONER THAN WE THINK. That's the way it is these days, then; life's a diet, and then you die.

fields.headline: Deadly fantasist
fields.standfirst: Jean-Claude Romand claimed to be a leading doctor with the World Health Organisation. In fact, he'd never even qualified. He claimed to be an international jet-setter. In fact, he spent his days in cafes and service stations. How did he construct an entire life out of lies? And why, when threatened with discovery, did he murder his family? Emmanuel Carrére on a story that obsessed France
fields.trailText: Jean-Claude Romand claimed to be a leading doctor with the World Health Organisation. In fact, he'd never even qualified. He claimed to be an international jet-setter. In fact, he spent his days in cafes and service stations. How did he construct an entire life out of lies? And why, when threatened with discovery, did he murder his family? Emmanuel Carrére on a story that obsessed France
fields.body:
Luc Ladmiral was awakened shortly after 4am on the morning of Monday, January 11, 1993, by a telephone call. His friends the Romands' house was on fire; he should come. When Luc arrived, the firefighters were bringing out the bodies. All his life he will remember the sealed grey plastic bags into which they had put the children: too horrible to look at. Florence, Mrs Romand, had simply been covered with a coat. Her face, blackened by the smoke, was unmarked. Smoothing her hair in a desolate gesture of farewell, Luc's fingers encountered something strange. He felt around, carefully tilting the young woman's head to one side, then called over a firefighter to show him, at the base of the skull, an open wound. It must have been from a beam that fell on her, the firefighter said; part of the attic had collapsed. Luc then clambered into the red vehicle where the rescuers had placed Jean-Claude, Florence's husband, the only one of the family who was still alive. His pulse was weak. He was in pyjamas, unconscious, burned yet already as cold as a corpse.

Luc and Jean-Claude had been friends ever since medical school in Lyon. They'd got married almost at the same time; their children had grown up together. Each knew everything about the other's life - the public image, but also the secrets, the secrets of honest, reliable men who were all the more vulnerable to temptation. When Jean-Claude had confided in him about an affair, talked about chucking everything in, Luc had made him listen to reason. Their lives were very similar, even if they hadn't succeeded in the same way. Jean-Claude had become a leading figure in the world of medical research, hobnobbing with government ministers, always off at international conferences, while Luc was a GP in Ferney-Voltaire, a town on the French side of the Swiss border, just a few miles north of Geneva. The Romands lived in the nearby village of Prévessin.

Later that Monday morning, Luc phoned the casualty department in Geneva: Jean-Claude, who was 38, had been placed in a hyperbaric oxygen chamber; the prognosis was guarded. Luc prayed with his wife Cécile and the children that he would never regain consciousness.

When Luc went to his office, two policemen were waiting for him. Their questions seemed odd. They wanted to know if the Romands had any enemies, if they'd been involved in any suspicious activities... Seeing Luc's astonishment, the police told him the truth. An initial examination of the bodies revealed that the victims had died before the fire, Florence from head injuries inflicted by a blunt instrument, the children - five-year-old Antoine and seven-year-old Caroline - from bullet wounds.

That wasn't all. In Clairvaux-les-Lacs, in the Jura Mountains some 50 miles to the north-west of Ferney, Jean-Claude's uncle had been delegated to break the tragic news to the injured man's parents, a frail elderly couple. Accompanied by their doctor, he had found the house locked, the dog mysteriously silent. Worried, the uncle had broken open the door to discover his brother, his sister-in-law and the dog lying in their own blood. They, too, had been shot.

Murdered. The Romands had been murdered. The word echoed through Luc's brain, stunning him. "Was it a robbery?" he asked, as if that word might somehow reduce the horror. The officers asked again about possible enemies, and Luc, at a loss, shook his head. Enemies? The Romands? Everyone loved them. The police needed to find out exactly what Jean-Claude did for a living. A doctor, the neighbours had said, but he didn't have a surgery. Luc explained that he was a researcher at the World Health Organisation (WHO), in Geneva. One of the officers telephoned, asking to speak to someone who worked with Dr Romand. The receptionist did not know any Dr Romand. She connected the officer to the personnel director, who consulted his files and confirmed: there was no Dr Romand at WHO.

In the course of that day, reality became even more nightmarish. Summoned to the police station in the afternoon, Luc learned that a note in Jean-Claude's handwriting confessing to the crimes had been found in his car and that everything people thought they knew about his career and professional activities was a sham. The WHO? No one there had ever heard of him. The national registry of physicians? He wasn't listed. The hospitals in Paris where he was said to be on the medical staff? He was not accredited there, nor was he a graduate of the medical school in Lyon where Luc himself, and several others, swore nevertheless to have been students with him. He had begun his studies, yes, but had stopped taking his exams at the end of the second year; from then on, it was all false. Latterly, Jean-Claude had confessed to Luc that he was suffering from cancer, for which he said he was being treated in Paris by the eminent oncologist Léon Schwartzenberg. Also false. Dr Schwartzenberg had no record of Jean-Claude Romand, nor had the oncology department of any other hospital in France.

At first, Luc simply refused to believe this. When someone tells you that your best friend, your daughter's godfather, the most respectable man you know has killed his wife, his children, his parents, and that in addition he has been lying to you about everything for years, isn't it normal to go on believing in him, even in the face of overwhelming proof?

It soon came out that Jean-Claude had an on-off relationship with a woman called Corinne Hourtin - a child psychologist, now divorced, who had once lived in Ferney with her husband Rémi. She had handed over to Jean-Claude 900,000 francs (about £90,000) in savings that he was to have invested for her in Switzerland. He had embezzled it instead. Other revelations came from Florence's family, the Crolets. They, too, had entrusted money to Jean-Claude: first the father's retirement bonus, and then, after his death, a million francs netted from the sale of his house. Their grief was compounded by an agonising suspicion: M Crolet had died in a fall on a staircase when he was alone with Jean-Claude. Had he been yet another victim of his son-in-law?

Everyone was wondering: how could we have lived beside this man for so long without suspecting a thing? Everyone tried to remember a moment when some suspicion had crossed their minds. Luc himself remembered that he'd been struck by something a few months earlier, after learning from Florence that Jean-Claude had ranked fifth in all of Paris in his finals. Yet Luc had felt vaguely that there was something not quite right in what Jean-Claude said about his career. He'd considered calling WHO to discover exactly what it was he did there - but had decided the whole thing was absurd. And now he kept telling himself that if he'd gone through with it, maybe things would have turned out differently.

"Perhaps," said Cécile when he told her of his remorse, "... perhaps he would have killed you as well."

Three days after the fire, the Ladmirals learned that Jean-Claude was going to live.

Jean-Claude Romand's early childhood was spent in a small village in the Jura where his father ran a farm. Neighbours, cousins, schoolteachers all remember a well-behaved little boy, quiet and sweet, whom some are tempted to describe as too well-behaved, too quiet, too sweet. An only child, perhaps somewhat overprotected by his mother. A child who never got up to any mischief, more respectable - if one can say that about a child - than truly lovable, but even so a child whom no one imagined to be unhappy. He says that his mother worried all the time and that he learned early on to mislead her so that she wouldn't worry even more. He admired his father for never showing his feelings and tried to imitate him. It was better to conceal them. On the one hand, he had been taught not to lie, and that was absolute dogma: a Romand was as good as his word, a Romand told the truth and shamed the Devil. On the other hand, there were certain things you shouldn't say, even if they were true. You had to avoid upsetting anyone, or boasting about your success or your good qualities.

Romand achieves good grades at school. He originally plans to become a forester, but then changes his mind and decides to study medicine instead at Lyon. At the end of his second year, in 1975, he needs to resit one exam. He fails to turn up, but he tells no one, and no one notices.

Three weeks went by between the day of the examination and the posting of the results. There was still time for him to admit that he had lied. It would have been hard for him, naturally. To this serious young man, it must have seemed impossibly painful to admit a whopping error, a childish blunder like that of Antoine Doinel in Les Quatre-Cent Coups, who extricates himself from a sticky situation at school by blurting out that his mother has just died, and who then must deal with the inevitable consequences of his lies and the certainty that the truth will come out. The most baffling thing, in Romand's case, is that he committed his folly in two stages, like the computer user who, having accidentally typed the command for erasing a valuable file, when asked by the program whether he's sure he wants to delete the file, carefully considers the pros and cons - then goes ahead and destroys it anyway. Rationally speaking, anything would have been better than what Jean-Claude did: he waited for the day the results were posted and then announced that he had passed, that he'd been accepted as a third-year medical student.

How could he have foreseen that there was something worse than being quickly unmasked, which was not to be unmasked; how could he have suspected that this childish lie would lead him 18 years later to murder his parents, Florence, and the children he did not yet have?

While still ostensibly studying medicine, Jean-Claude marries Florence Crolet, a fellow student at Lyon. He supposedly passes his medical board exam and becomes first a research assistant in a medical research institution and then a research scientist at the World Health Organisation in Geneva.

Romand was always, as Florence put it, "very compartmentalised", strictly separating his personal and professional relations, never inviting colleagues from WHO to his house, refusing to allow himself to be disturbed at home by anyone from his office, or at work by any of his family or friends. Moreover, nobody had his office phone number, not even his wife, who contacted him through an answering service: you left a message in a voice mailbox, which sent him a signal on the bleeper he always carried with him, and then he quickly called back. Neither his wife nor anyone else found the arrangement strange. It was one of his personality traits, like his gruffness, which she often joked about: "One of these days, I'm going to find out my husband's a communist spy."

In the mornings, he was the one who drove the children to the Ecole Saint-Vincent. He would accompany them into the courtyard, exchange a few words with the teachers or the pupils' mothers, then drive off towards Geneva. More often than not he ended up in the car park of WHO. Entering with a visitor's badge, carrying a briefcase, he followed a familiar orbit, going from the ground-floor library to the conference rooms and the publications office, where he systematically swept up anything printed and free: his house and car overflowed with papers bearing the letterhead or stamp of WHO. He used all the services offered by the organisation - a post office where he sent his mail, a bank where he made most of his withdrawals, a travel agency through which he planned the family holidays - but did not risk going upstairs, where security guards might have asked him what he was looking for. His mother-in-law remembers that one Sunday when the whole family had gone to Switzerland, the children had wanted to see Papa's office, so Papa had agreed to the detour. They'd pulled into the car park, he'd pointed out the window. And that's all.

At first he went to WHO every day, later less regularly. He'd stop at a news-stand to buy an armful of papers: dailies, magazines, scientific journals. Then he'd go and read them, either in a cafe - he was careful to change cafes often and to choose them far enough from home - or in his car. He would park in a car park or at a service station and stay there for hours, reading, taking notes, dozing. He'd have a sandwich for lunch and continue reading throughout the afternoon in a different cafe, at a different service station. Other days, he needed open air and nature, and would drive into the Jura Mountains.

Lastly, there were the trips - conferences, seminars, symposiums, all over the world. He would buy a guide to the country; Florence would pack his suitcase. He'd drive off in his car, which he would supposedly leave in the long-term car park at Geneva airport. In a comfortable hotel room, often near the airport, he would take off his shoes, stretch out on the bed, spend three or four days watching television and the planes taking off and landing outside his window. He studied the guide books so he wouldn't make any mistakes in his stories when he got home. He telephoned his family every day to tell them what time it was and what the weather was like in Sao Paulo or Tokyo. He'd tell his wife, his children, his parents that he missed them, was thinking of them, sent them a big kiss. After a few days, he went home with presents bought in an airport gift shop. Everyone made a fuss of him. He was tired from jet lag.

Indirectly it was WHO that provided Jean-Claude with a source of income. He said or let it be understood that as an international civil servant he was in a position to make extremely advantageous investments at a rate of 18%, an opportunity he could share with his family. Jean-Claude's parents were not the kind of people to cheat on their taxes by putting their savings into Swiss banks, but as it was their son's idea that was enough for them. Romand lived on their nest egg at the beginning of his marriage. Florence declared to the income tax authorities the very modest salary she earned by temporarily filling in for pharmacists in the area, and he declared no income because, since he worked in Switzerland, he had - he said - no taxes to pay.

The year Antoine was born, Florence's father retired from his job in Annecy. A disguised redundancy, his retirement brought him a bonus of 400,000 francs. Jean-Claude agreed to do his father-in-law a favour by investing 378,000 francs for him at a Geneva bank. This sum was deposited in an account in Jean-Claude's name, since he was the one whose position entitled him to make such an investment. But one day Jean-Claude's father-in-law told him he wanted to withdraw part of his capital to buy a Mercedes. A few weeks later, on October 23, 1988, Pierre Crolet fell on the stairs of his home where he was alone with his son-in-law and died just before the arrival of the paramedics.

After the fire, a new investigation was ordered at the request of the Crolet family. Of course, it uncovered nothing. At the end of the proceedings, Jean-Claude insisted on telling the Crolet family, as God was his witness, that he had had no hand in his father-in-law's death. Short of a confession on his part some day, we will never learn any more.

What is indisputable is that the death of his father-in-law was providential for Romand. There was no longer any question of touching the money in the Swiss account. Then Mme Crolet decided to sell the house, now too large for her on her own, and handed over to her son-in-law the proceeds of the sale, which amounted to 1.3million francs.

Romand had become enraptured with Corinne Hourtin and they begin an affair when she moves to Paris. But she soon decides that she could never love him. He confides in her, as he he did to Luc Ladmiral, that he is suffering from cancer. They remain friends, and she turns to him when she had money to invest, handing over 900,000 francs in cash. He flies from Paris with a small suitcase stuffed with notes. Soon after, Corinne decides she wants some of her money back, but finds Romand evasive.

Just before the 1992 Christmas holidays, the president of the school board wanted to talk to Jean-Claude on the subject of a demoted head. The president did not know Jean-Claude well enough to be aware that one didn't call him at his office, and he had his secretary look up Jean-Claude's number in the WHO directory. Puzzled at not finding him anywhere, he imagined there must be some explanation, and he didn't think about it again until one day after the holiday when he ran into Florence in the main street of Ferney and told her about it. His tone wasn't that of a man who had suspicions but that of someone who was curious to find out the real story behind an odd mystery, and Florence reacted equally mildly. It was strange, yes, there was obviously a reason, and she'd speak to her husband about it. Florence and the man did not see each other again. One week later she was dead, and no one will ever know if she brought it up with Jean-Claude. He says she didn't.

Although he was unsure where the first blow would come from, he knew that the hounds were closing in. His various bank accounts would soon be overdrawn, and he had no means of replenishing them. People were talking about him, and talking about coming after him. Hands were flipping through directories. The look in Florence's eyes had changed. He was scared.

In the run-up to Christmas, he flew to Paris and took Corinne to dinner at the Restaurant Michel Rostang. Corinne told him that she had made up her mind and she wanted all of her money back. Instead of trying to wriggle out of it, he opened his diary to set up a meeting when he would hand over the funds. Turning the pages, he had an idea: he had agreed to have dinner at the start of the new year with his friend Bernard Kouchner, illustrious co-founder of Médecins Sans Frontières. Would Corinne like to join them? Of course Corinne would like that. Before then, though, he would be dead.

On the flight home, he continued to study his diary. Christmas wasn't a good day, that would be too cruel for the children. Caroline was going to play Mary and Antoine one of the shepherds in the Nativity play at the church. So, right after New Year?

Jean-Claude did not go to work on the Tuesday after the New Year. Florence and he ran errands in Ferney. She insisted that he buy a new suit; he let himself be tempted by a parka for 3,200 francs. The saleswoman thought they seemed a couple who were at leisure, well-off, and getting along fine.

Jean-Claude had spent the morning studying books such as the Vidal pharmacological dictionary; he rejected drugs that caused instantaneous death in favour of barbiturates with a rapid serum peak for a comfortable lapse into unconsciousness. Everything would be ready by Friday, January 8, said the pharmacist, would that do? It would do.

That evening, Romand read a story to the children. He left for Lyon on Wednesday morning. At 2.08pm he obtained 1,000 francs from the cashpoint, and another 1,000 francs at 2.45pm. Between the two withdrawals, he says, he gave a 500-franc note to a homeless person. Then, in a gun shop, he bought a stun wand, two tear gas canisters, a box of cartridges and a silencer for a .22 calibre rifle.

"So," the judge pointed out, "you weren't thinking only of killing yourself. You were living with your wife and children while you were planning to kill them."

"That idea did surface... but it was immediately masked by other false plans, other false ideas. It was as though the idea didn't exist... I pretended... I told myself I was doing something else, that it was for a different reason, and at the same time... at the same time I was buying the bullets that would pierce my children's hearts."

He sobbed.

On the Thursday, Jean-Claude went to visit his parents in Clairvaux. The next day, after the children had gone to bed, Florence had a long phone conversation with her mother. Mme Crolet complained bitterly about being a widow, about growing old, about being neglected by her children. Her unhappiness affected Florence, who began crying after she hung up. Jean-Claude joined her on the sofa. That is the last image he has. He is sitting next to her, he has taken her in his arms, he is trying to comfort her.

"I don't remember her last words." He went on: "I am unable to say what happened between the time when I was consoling Florence on the sofa and the moment I woke up holding the rolling pin stained with blood."

Early that Saturday morning, the telephone rang, which woke the children. They were always quicker to bounce out of bed on days when they didn't have school. Jean-Claude told them that Mama was still sleeping, and the three of them went downstairs to the living room. He put a tape of The Three Little Pigs in the video, prepared bowls of Coco Pops with milk. With him in the middle, they settled themselves on the sofa to watch the cartoon while they ate their cereal.

"I knew after having killed Florence that I was also going to kill Antoine and Caroline and that those moments in front of the television were the last that we would spend together. I cuddled them. I must have said sweet things to them, like, 'I love you.' "

"We stayed like that for perhaps an hour... Caroline saw that I was cold, she wanted to go upstairs to get my dressing gown... I said that I thought they seemed rather hot, that perhaps they had a fever and I was going to take their temperature. Caroline went upstairs with me, I had her lie down on her bed... I went to get the rifle ..."

"What did you say to Caroline?" asked the judge.

"I don't know any more... She'd lain down on her stomach... That's when I shot her."

"Go on..."

He sobbed. "I shot Caroline the first time... She had a pillow over her head... I must have been pretending it was a game." Here he moaned, his eyes closed. "I pulled the trigger... I put the rifle somewhere in the room... I called Antoine... and I did it again."

"Perhaps I should help you a bit, because the jury needs details and you're not being specific enough."

"Caroline, when she was born, it was the most wonderful day of my life... She was beautiful" - he moaned - "in my arms... for her first bath." A spasm shook his body. "I'm the one who killed her... I'm the one who killed her."

The policemen, appalled, held him gently by the arms.

"Don't you think Antoine could have heard the gunshots? Had you attached the silencer? Did you call him upstairs on the same pretext? To take his temperature? He didn't find that strange?"

"I don't have an image of that precise moment. It was still them, but it couldn't be Caroline... it couldn't be Antoine..."

The prosecutor spoke up. Afterwards, he said, Romand went out to buy the local paper and a sports daily, L'Equipe, and the newspaper seller thought he looked completely normal.

"Were you trying to behave as if nothing had happened, as if life was going on as usual?"

"I couldn't have bought L'Equipe. I never read it."

"Neighbours saw you cross the street to check your postbox."

"Did I do it to deny reality, to pretend?"

"Why did you wrap up the rifle and carefully put it away before you left for Clairvaux?"

"In reality, to kill them, of course, but I must have told myself that it was to return it to my father."

Jean-Claude does not remember the drive to his parents' home later on the Saturday morning. We know the three of them had lunch together. Dishes were still on the table when Uncle Claude entered the house two days later, and the postmortem examination revealed that the stomachs of Aimé and Anne-Marie Romand were full. Did Jean-Claude eat anything? Did his mother urge him to have something? What did they talk about?

First he lured his father upstairs with the excuse of examining a malodorous air vent the old man had complained about. The old man, who couldn't bend over because of back trouble, must have knelt down to point out the defective vent, which was set into the skirting-board. That was when he received two bullets in the back. His son covered him with a wine-coloured corduroy bedspread that had been in the room since Jean-Claude's childhood. Then he went to get his mother. She hadn't heard the gunshots, fired with a silencer. He made her go into the sitting room, which they never used. She was the only one who was shot from the front.

He carefully closed up the house and drove off at around two o'clock. He was heading for Paris where he was to meet Corinne.

Smoothing her hair in a desolate gesture of farewell, Luc's fingers encountered something strange. He felt around, carefully tilting the young woman's head to one side, then called over a firefighter to show him, at the base of the skull, an open wound. It must have been from a beam that fell on her, the firefighter said; part of the attic had collapsed. They'd got married almost at the same time; their children had grown up together. Each knew everything about the other's life - the public image, but also the secrets, the secrets of honest, reliable men who were all the more vulnerable to temptation. Their lives were very similar, even if they hadn't succeeded in the same way. But one day Jean-Claude's father-in-law told him he wanted to withdraw part of his capital to buy a Mercedes. A few weeks later, on October 23, 1988, Pierre Crolet fell on the stairs of his home where he was alone with his son-in-law and died just before the arrival of the paramedics. After the fire, a new investigation was ordered at the request of the Crolet family. Of course, it uncovered nothing. At the end of the proceedings, Jean-Claude insisted on telling the Crolet family, as God was his witness, that he had had no hand in his father-in-law's death. Short of a confession on his part some day, we will never learn any more. What is indisputable is that the death of his father-in-law was providential for Romand. There was no longer any question of touching the money in the Swiss account. Then Mme Crolet decided to sell the house, now too large for her on her own, and handed over to her son-in-law the proceeds of the sale, which amounted to 1.3million francs. Romand had become enraptured with Corinne Hourtin and they begin an affair when she moves to Paris. But she soon decides that she could never love him. He confides in her, as he he did to Luc Ladmiral, that he is suffering from cancer. They remain friends, and she turns to him when she had money to invest, handing over 900,000 francs in cash. He flies from Paris with a small suitcase stuffed with notes. Soon after, Corinne decides she wants some of her money back, but finds Romand evasive. Just before the 1992 Christmas holidays, the president of the school board wanted to talk to Jean-Claude on the subject of a demoted head. The president did not know Jean-Claude well enough to be aware that one didn't call him at his office, and he had his secretary look up Jean-Claude's number in the WHO directory. Puzzled at not finding him anywhere, he imagined there must be some explanation, and he didn't think about it again until one day after the holiday when he ran into Florence in the main street of Ferney and told her about it. His tone wasn't that of a man who had suspicions but that of someone who was curious to find out the real story behind an odd mystery, and Florence reacted equally mildly. It was strange, yes, there was obviously a reason, and she'd speak to her husband about it. Florence and the man did not see each other again. One week later she was dead, and no one will ever know if she brought it up with Jean-Claude. He says she didn't. Although he was unsure where the first blow would come from, he knew that the hounds were closing in. His various bank accounts would soon be overdrawn, and he had no means of replenishing them. People were talking about him, and talking about coming after him. Hands were flipping through directories. The look in Florence's eyes had changed. He was scared. In the run-up to Christmas, he flew to Paris and took Corinne to dinner at the Restaurant Michel Rostang. Corinne told him that she had made up her mind and she wanted all of her money back. Instead of trying to wriggle out of it, he opened his diary to set up a meeting when he would hand over the funds. Turning the pages, he had an idea: he had agreed to have dinner at the start of the new year with his friend Bernard Kouchner, illustrious co-founder of Médecins Sans Frontières. Would Corinne like to join them? Of course Corinne would like that. Before then, though, he would be dead. On the flight home, he continued to study his diary. Christmas wasn't a good day, that would be too cruel for the children. Caroline was going to play Mary and Antoine one of the shepherds in the Nativity play at the church. So, right after New Year? Jean-Claude did not go to work on the Tuesday after the New Year. Florence and he ran errands in Ferney. She insisted that he buy a new suit; he let himself be tempted by a parka for 3,200 francs. The saleswoman thought they seemed a couple who were at leisure, well-off, and getting along fine. Jean-Claude had spent the morning studying books such as the Vidal pharmacological dictionary; he rejected drugs that caused instantaneous death in favour of barbiturates with a rapid serum peak for a comfortable lapse into unconsciousness. Everything would be ready by Friday, January 8, said the pharmacist, would that do? It would do. That evening, Romand read a story to the children. He left for Lyon on Wednesday morning. At 2.08pm he obtained 1,000 francs from the cashpoint, and another 1,000 francs at 2.45pm. Between the two withdrawals, he says, he gave a 500-franc note to a homeless person. Then, in a gun shop, he bought a stun wand, two tear gas canisters, a box of cartridges and a silencer for a .22 calibre rifle. "So," the judge pointed out, "you weren't thinking only of killing yourself. You were living with your wife and children while you were planning to kill them." "That idea did surface... but it was immediately masked by other false plans, other false ideas. It was as though the idea didn't exist... I pretended... I told myself I was doing something else, that it was for a different reason, and at the same time... at the same time I was buying the bullets that would pierce my children's hearts." He sobbed. On the Thursday, Jean-Claude went to visit his parents in Clairvaux. The next day, after the children had gone to bed, Florence had a long phone conversation with her mother. Mme Crolet complained bitterly about being a widow, about growing old, about being neglected by her children. Her unhappiness affected Florence, who began crying after she hung up. Jean-Claude joined her on the sofa. That is the last image he has. He is sitting next to her, he has taken her in his arms, he is trying to comfort her. "I don't remember her last words." He went on: "I am unable to say what happened between the time when I was consoling Florence on the sofa and the moment I woke up holding the rolling pin stained with blood." Early that Saturday morning, the telephone rang, which woke the children. They were always quicker to bounce out of bed on days when they didn't have school. Jean-Claude told them that Mama was still sleeping, and the three of them went downstairs to the living room. He put a tape of The Three Little Pigs in the video, prepared bowls of Coco Pops with milk. With him in the middle, they settled themselves on the sofa to watch the cartoon while they ate their cereal. "I knew after having killed Florence that I was also going to kill Antoine and Caroline and that those moments in front of the television were the last that we would spend together. I cuddled them. I must have said sweet things to them, like, 'I love you.' " "We stayed like that for perhaps an hour... Caroline saw that I was cold, she wanted to go upstairs to get my dressing gown... I said that I thought they seemed rather hot, that perhaps they had a fever and I was going to take their temperature. Caroline went upstairs with me, I had her lie down on her bed... I went to get the rifle ..." "What did you say to Caroline?" asked the judge. "I don't know any more... She'd lain down on her stomach... That's when I shot her." "Go on..." He sobbed. "I shot Caroline the first time... She had a pillow over her head... I must have been pretending it was a game." Here he moaned, his eyes closed. "I pulled the trigger... I put the rifle somewhere in the room... I called Antoine... and I did it again." "Perhaps I should help you a bit, because the jury needs details and you're not being specific enough." "Caroline, when she was born, it was the most wonderful day of my life... She was beautiful" - he moaned - "in my arms... for her first bath." A spasm shook his body. "I'm the one who killed her... I'm the one who killed her." The policemen, appalled, held him gently by the arms. "Don't you think Antoine could have heard the gunshots? Had you attached the silencer? Did you call him upstairs on the same pretext? To take his temperature? He didn't find that strange?" "I don't have an image of that precise moment. It was still them, but it couldn't be Caroline... it couldn't be Antoine..." The prosecutor spoke up. Afterwards, he said, Romand went out to buy the local paper and a sports daily, L'Equipe, and the newspaper seller thought he looked completely normal. "Were you trying to behave as if nothing had happened, as if life was going on as usual?" "I couldn't have bought L'Equipe. I never read it." "Neighbours saw you cross the street to check your postbox." "Did I do it to deny reality, to pretend?" "Why did you wrap up the rifle and carefully put it away before you left for Clairvaux?" "In reality, to kill them, of course, but I must have told myself that it was to return it to my father." Jean-Claude does not remember the drive to his parents' home later on the Saturday morning. We know the three of them had lunch together. Dishes were still on the table when Uncle Claude entered the house two days later, and the postmortem examination revealed that the stomachs of Aimé and Anne-Marie Romand were full. Did Jean-Claude eat anything? Did his mother urge him to have something? What did they talk about? First he lured his father upstairs with the excuse of examining a malodorous air vent the old man had complained about. The old man, who couldn't bend over because of back trouble, must have knelt down to point out the defective vent, which was set into the skirting-board. That was when he received two bullets in the back. His son covered him with a wine-coloured corduroy bedspread that had been in the room since Jean-Claude's childhood. Then he went to get his mother. She hadn't heard the gunshots, fired with a silencer. He made her go into the sitting room, which they never used. She was the only one who was shot from the front. He carefully closed up the house and drove off at around two o'clock. He was heading for Paris where he was to meet Corinne.  Read the second part of the story here.  Taken from the book The Adversary by Emmanuel Carrére and translated by Linda Coverdale to be published by Bloomsbury on 22 January 2001 at 14.99

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText: In The Year In Words And Pictures (December 30), you wrote that my parents, Stephan and Edith Korner, 'died in each other's arms, a double suicide'. The perpetuation of this myth is a deception. My parents did indeed die on August 17, 2000, but they died of asphyxia with two bin bags tied over their heads, and my dear father, far from being in my mother's arms, was lying on the floor with his face covered in black vomit.
fields.body:
In The Year In Words And Pictures (December 30), you wrote that my parents, Stephan and Edith Korner, 'died in each other's arms, a double suicide'. The perpetuation of this myth is a deception. My parents did indeed die on August 17, 2000, but they died of asphyxia with two bin bags tied over their heads, and my dear father, far from being in my mother's arms, was lying on the floor with his face covered in black vomit.

If people continue to believe that my parents' deaths were simple, romantic and laudable, they might be tempted to emulate such a selfish, deeply hurtful act. The truth might be sufficiently shocking to deter other elderly couples from following in my parents' footsteps and causing unspeakable pain to at least some of the family members left behind.
Ann M Altman (née Korner)
Hamden, Connecticut, US

As leader of the ruling Labour group in Brighton & Hove, I take exception to the idea that our city bid was about politicians' egos (Julie Burchill, January 6). It was backed by organisations from Age Concern to the Zap Club, schools and universities, the health authority, football club, bus company, dozens of businesses and 23 tenants' associations.

Also, to claim that our politicians have no interest in getting extra cash for local schools, jobs and hospitals is close to libel. We have attracted the largest amount of government regeneration money in the south-east; we have set up an education action zone, plus a 10-year new deal for communities programme serving our most deprived areas; and the main hospital is part-way through a multimillion-pound redevelopment.

I wouldn't dream of claiming credit for all these developments - but they are all part of a vision for Brighton & Hove about which local resident, Julie Burchill, is spectacularly unaware.
Lynette Gwyn-Jones
Leader, Brighton & Hove council

Julie Burchill is mistaken. The problem was not that 'We held [politicians'] heads down the toilets a beat too long'. It was for nowhere near long enough.
Iain Climie
Whitchurch, Hants

Julie Burchill's article is the talk of the town. We all ring each other and read sentences aloud. I've seen people hooting with joy in cafes. Thank heaven for reason. None of us wanted to be a city.
Charles Goode
Hove, East Sussex

When I feel negative, I go for a long walk along the seafront. I feel much better. Julie should try it. Otherwise, what is the point of living in such a great city?
Linda Wren
Brighton, East Sussex

Can sex in the weightlessness of space be such a problem (2001, January 6)? Why else do we have love handles?
David Jordan
Senni, Brecon

What did I learn last weekend? Julie Burchill is dead clever, Stanley Kubrick and Arthur C Clarke are dead clever, Alexander Chancellor is dead clever, Guy Browning is dead clever. You're all dead clever. So how come, when I finish reading Weekend and went for a bike ride with my children, we all got flat tyres? I don't care that Brighton has gone from urbane to urban, that the 2001 piece was a brilliantly perceptive view of the future, or that shoes benefit from care and attention. I just want to know why, now that we've got to two thousand and bloody one, we still get punctures?
Kevin Bell
Poynton, Cheshire

fields.headline: Grey is back in fashion
fields.standfirst: 'The young dot.com hotshots in their 20s are now having to turn to oldies for advice on how to make their businesses work in the real world'
fields.trailText: 'The young dot.com hotshots in their 20s are now having to turn to oldies for advice on how to make their businesses work in the real world'.
fields.body:
The news from the world of high technology is alarming. Shares in the companies listed on the Nasdaq stock market in New York fell by 54% last year. At least 210 dot.com companies went out of business in the US, 41,000 dot.com jobs were cut, and the value of Bill Gates's shares in Microsoft fell by an estimated $40bn - more than twice the gross national product of Luxembourg. All this was reported this week in the Guardian, which said that the trend was expected not merely to continue but to accelerate this year. But the bursting of the internet bubble, frightening though it is and deeply depressing for those immediately involved, has had one positive consequence for people such as myself who have passed the age of 60.

Until recently, we were pitied for our failing energies and mental powers. There was to be no place for us in a world dependent on high-speed innovation and business drive. The ageism that had been growing both here and in the US over the past few decades had hardened and become entrenched. But young dot.com hotshots in their 20s are now a good deal less cocksure than they used to be, as they watch their instant fortunes crumble. They have started turning to oldies for advice on how to make their businesses work in the real world. As one writer put it in the New York Times the other day, "Suddenly maturity and experience are something to be worn in public, a silver badge of what's been gathered and gained, not just a crumpled record of what's been lost."

We also have George W Bush to thank for this trend. Insecure because of his own lack of experience, he has called on the grand viziers of his father's presidential court to help him out in his daunting new role. During the Florida election nightmare, it was James Baker, the 75-year-old chief of staff in the last Bush administration, who steered him through the courts to victory. And as his vice-president he chose Dick Cheney, his father's defence secretary during the Gulf war - 60 this month and suffering from heart disease. As the former Republican senator, Alan Simpson, has put it, it is people "with grey hair" who must lead the country's post-election healing process (though Mr Simpson, at 67, has almost no hair at all).

I can't say that I have noticed any greater show of deference to my grey (well, white, actually) hair in recent months, but these are reassuring developments all the same. I am no longer tempted to resort to Grecian 2000 or to cosmetic surgery, as there now seems to be a sporting chance of survival without them. The smart new thing for American internet publishers is to revert to being old-fashioned print media companies, which are businesses that oldies generally know more about than the young. The new technology is bound to dominate everything in the end, but in the short term oldies have been offered a new lease of life.

Our purpose is not, of course, to thwart the young, but to reverse the trend towards increasing age segregation. We all need each other - whatever age we may be - and we should not be artificially compartmentalised as young, middle-aged or old. This is not to say that there isn't a certain emotional satisfaction to be found in the current tribulations of arrogant young dot.com millionaires. There is, and it would be hypocritical not to admit it. But the greater satisfaction for oldies is the feeling that they may be needed still.

The disasters visited upon many dot.com high-flyers is of particular comfort to traditional billionaires, such as Rupert Murdoch, who found that the fortunes they spent lifetimes amassing had been overtaken in a few months by mere kids doing incomprehensible things that broke all the old economic laws. After all the grief and confusion this has caused them, they are delighted to discover that the old rules still pertain. For people to get rich too quickly and too young undermines the long-established order of things, and it is nice for old plutocrats to see that order is being restored. Look at the ages of those, such as Lord Hamlyn, who have been pouring millions of pounds into the Labour party recently. These are reassuring as well.

The internet revolution cannot be stopped or held back, and nobody would want it to be. But it can be, and is being, brought within the traditional capitalist system and forced to abide by the same rules that have applied to businesses throughout history. This has to be a good thing, because it restores common ground and understanding to people of all ages who thought that it was forcing them apart. Now we can all soldier on together again.

webTitle: Can I take a wifelet, Sue?

fields.headline: Can I take a wifelet, Sue?
fields.trailText: A week in radio
fields.body:
The Marquis of Bath is writing his autobiography. Only up to 1982 so far, he is already at 4m words. "It will be 6m by the time I've finished," he told Sue Lawley on Desert Island Discs (Radio 4) this week. It was fun wondering what he'd got stuck at in the early 1980s, listening to his very virile weirdness. Wham! songs, perhaps? I can see "Alexander", as Sue fondly called him, poshing it up, entranced by them: "Wham! Bam! I am! A man!" Or maybe ra-ra skirts; I think he'd have liked ra-ra skirts.

For the marquis, apart from running Longleat, Britain's second most-visited stately home (he almost hissed at a mention of Chatsworth, the most visited), has something of the saucy devil about him. On a quiet night in his "penthouse suite" at the house, he likes nothing better than to knock up a couple of murals for his "Kamasutra room" before settling down for the evening with one of his 74 "wifelets". Sue asked him, fondly, poshly, why he called them that. "I felt it would be running them down to call them things like concubines, mistresses," he answered, thinking he sounded every inch the modern man. In fact, he just sounded like an antique, blue-blooded Stringfellow.

It was hard not to warm to him, though. He had a way of introducing his records as if ordering a sandwich in a terribly well-to-do deli: "I think something wonderfully rrrrrrrhythmical"; "Ooh, something wonderfully wild, bestial, fierce"; "I'd rather like some clear flute music." Mostly he chose stirring classical stuff - Wagner, Stravinsky and a Beethoven choral symphony that he promised would "thoroughly arouse" him - but his non-classical choices were the true joys.

There was one of his own compositions, Love Words, for his long-suffering wife, Anna (which didn't mention the word wifelet, despite the many words that rhyme with it), and a children's favourite, which he referred to as Put di Lime in dee Cooking. His two or three - he seemed unsure - children love it, apparently. There may be hundreds more, he teased, but he didn't want to go into that. Mostly he sounded grumpy at his ladies' lack of productivity.

But he got excited by his first musical choice, a thumping samba concoction that made you think of carnival, Gisele on the beach, caipirinhas cocktails. The marquis plans to let it all hang out to this song on the desert island, "being fully alive to rrrrrhythm". As he rolled his Rs flamboyantly once more, that image of Gisele was swiftly replaced by one of him, alabaster white, veiny and naked, limbo-dancing under a chain of wifelets, starkers except for their 74 standard-issue ra-ra skirts. It'll fade, the doctors tell me, in time.

Compared with the marquis, the strange folk in Don Howarth's fine series of four plays, Oddballs (Radio 4), aren't very odd at all. Gently surreal and sweetly comic, these are endearing fantasies set in rural Cumbria. In last week's opener, Radio RIP, "the People's Radio" was caught in a maelstrom of jumble-sale announcements, radical feminist saboteurs and bomb threats, all presided over by DJ Sid Rappaport, graduate of the Alan Partridge school of broadcasting. "Local radio isn't for listening to," he tells a bewildered villager. "It's for performing on." It's always good to get one of life's big ponders cleared up in a half-hour drama. Next week, Stan Rooker, a hospital receptionist, has to deal with a very strange unconscious man, brought in with a knight's helmet stuck on his head. Try saying Chatsworth, Stan. See if he hisses.

The marquis plans to let it all hang out to this song on the desert island, "being fully alive to rrrrrhythm". As he rolled his Rs flamboyantly once more, that image of Gisele was swiftly replaced by one of him, alabaster white, veiny and naked, limbo-dancing under a chain of wifelets, starkers except for their 74 standard-issue ra-ra skirts. It'll fade, the doctors tell me, in time. Compared with the marquis, the strange folk in Don Howarth's fine series of four plays, Oddballs (Radio 4), aren't very odd at all. Gently surreal and sweetly comic, these are endearing fantasies set in rural Cumbria. In last week's opener, Radio RIP, "the People's Radio" was caught in a maelstrom of jumble-sale announcements, radical feminist saboteurs and bomb threats, all presided over by DJ Sid Rappaport, graduate of the Alan Partridge school of broadcasting. "Local radio isn't for listening to," he tells a bewildered villager. "It's for performing on." It's always good to get one of life's big ponders cleared up in a half-hour drama. Next week, Stan Rooker, a hospital receptionist, has to deal with a very strange unconscious man, brought in with a knight's helmet stuck on his head. Try saying Chatsworth, Stan. See if he hisses.

webTitle: Shouldn't you be in the pub?

fields.headline: Shouldn't you be in the pub?
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
'It's Friday night and you're watching Channel 4. How sad is that?" That joke - from The Armstrong and Miller Show (Channel 4) - might elicit a cheeky little grin, but there is a certain danger in popping such a self-deprecating jest into one's material. The audience might agree.

Not that Armstrong and Miller's new series is all that bad. There are some moments of extremely funny, clever comedy. The team of men placing porn in the woods for children to find, the male prostitute stall at the graduate recruitment fair, and the deathbed columnist all coax a chuckle. Other material, however, seems dated and predictable - Nude Practice, for instance. Instead of finding the strategic positioning of milk jugs funny or inventive, thoughts like "What bushy pubic hair Xander Armstrong has" occupy your mind.

Having won the Golden Rose of Montreux, The Mole (Channel 5) arrived in the UK fronted, rather bizarrely, by Fiona from Coronation Street's ex-boyfriend, Alan the policeman. Doing his best to be all mean, moody and mysterious, Glenn Hugill took nine "ordinary people" and one saboteur hired by the producers through a number of tasks, for the chance to win £200,000. These tasks, for this week at least, took place on Jersey; disappointingly, none were remotely Bergerac-related ("Find Charlie Hungerford's favourite restaurant" was not among them). Instead, the contestants had to parachute from 10,000ft and find a kidnapped member of the group.

Initially overwhelming - 10 people are a lot to get to know - The Mole quickly develops into an addictive, ingenious reality-TV show. Is the mole, you find yourself wondering, Ollie the trainee lawyer? With such a career in mind, he evidently has no problem with telling lies. Is it David from London? He has curly hair, after all. Personally, my money's on Jo-anna the artist from the Isle of Man. People with hyphens in their name are not to be trusted, and once I almost choked to death on a fruit Polo on the Isle of Man.

With the possibilities of travel, in-built deception and contestants ranging in age from 22 to 51, The Mole is a lot more rewarding to watch than much of its ilk. Big Brother crossed with The Weakest Link - every week, someone gets eliminated from the group and leaves - it is must-see TV. Alas, languishing on Channel 5, it may well be forgotten when ITV's Survivor hits our screens.

If, as in Streetmate (Channel 4), Davina McCall came up to you in the street and asked you to go out with someone, you'd hope it was her, wouldn't you? Anyone else would be a disappointment. It wouldn't be the first disappointment for those on whom Davina pounces. Maybe she should pop round to Brookside (Channel 4) and sort out Shelley. Davina could take the Sapphic scouse lover for a night on the town, far away from the allure of the Corkhill women and their blue sweatshirts.

Buffy the Vampire Slayer (Sky One) continues its fifth season rockily. After squandering the story potential of Dracula by dispatching him in just one episode, the appearance of Dawn, Buffy's sister, remains unexplained. Buffy even says, "It's not like Dawn didn't live in this house", which precludes her earlier residence at Buffy's dad's place. Was the poor girl locked in a closet for the past four years? We should be told. And the Scooby Gang still don't possess mobile phones. Buffy calls itself a youth show, too. Lk, whtvr.

fields.headline: The old master
fields.standfirst: West Yorkshire Playhouse has turned Coward into a museum piece, says  Alfred Hickling
fields.trailText: West Yorkshire Playhouse has turned Coward into a museum piece, says Alfred Hickling
fields.body:
Not for the first time, Noël Coward's reputation is on slippery grounds. Either he's going to make it into the 21st century as the master of theatrical menace: a snapping termagant beneath the fragile veneer, whose cocktail of linguistic virtuosity and psychological torture taught Harold Pinter a thing or two. Or else he's destined to be put out with the rest of the post-millennial rubbish: a sackful of aphorisms and blatant self-regard, which the British once cultivated as a curious habit, like dressing for dinner.

Even when writing Blithe Spirit in 1942, Coward knew he was fighting a rearguard action against obsolescence. Nonetheless, fashionable London clambered over heaps of rubble to see it. Blithe Spirit's run lasted longer than the war. It's still running, of course - or rather tottering like a heavily decorated west London pensioner, exhausted but fondly indulged wherever it goes. The fact that it's a virtual rewrite of the superior Private Lives has not hindered it; nor the fact that its comedic value is thinly spun across a single resource - that one character can see a ghost and the others can't, as if Banquo had strolled in waving a cigarette holder.

There's nothing wrong with David Giles's note-perfect production at the West Yorkshire Playhouse in Leeds, except that, rather than putting forth a case for Coward's continued relevance, it makes theatregoing seem a quaint example of British social custom from the last century. Thelma Barlow flutters through the part of Madame Arcati in a flurry of marmalade chiffon, without suggesting that the spurious spiritualist is potentially dangerous. Coward has bite. It's a disservice to leave his teeth in a glass by the bed.

 At the West Yorkshire Playhouse, Leeds (0113-213 7700), until February 3.

fields.headline: North Pembrokeshire
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
The rain stopped. We could walk out with shoulders back, arms swinging, singing. Among the first destinations was Foel Eryr, one of the tops in the Preselis.

It's an easy, quick climb, but rewarding. Standing there you can see the sun glistening off the sea around Fishguard. Beyond lies St Davids, hidden, but the sea sparkles off Ramsey Island. Further round you catch St Bride's Bay. Everywhere there is sunshine and sungleam. The hills are simply wet.

Then came the snow and ice. We could walk over the moor without fear of sinking. It was holiday time, so we met neighbours sharing our pleasure: we could breathe cold, dry air before trotting back quickly to one house or another for something hot or hotter. The frost changed the colour of winter trees. Grey ash moved to a pale yellow hue where ice had formed on the branches. As the thaw came, the alders stood in an almost purple haze created by long male catkins and the swelling buds of spring.

The alders have been on these islands for thousands of years, cherished, among other things, for the effectiveness of their roots at holding riverbanks together. They enjoy wetness, but this winter is putting a strain on them.

Birch trees contributed to the purple woodland haze, yet now it was not purple. It was red. A wren rushed off in the sunshine - red. Our eyes gobbled it all up because we could at last see beyond rain and mountain mist.

The birds' responses varied. One blue tit became so excited over a bird box that it had to pop inside for an inspection. Male chaffinches, consumed by a need to keep everything they thought they owned, attacked any bird approaching the bird table - particularly if it was a female chaffinch. Fieldfares jostled in the holly.

Suiddenly, a redwing had me gasping in disbelief: I did not know that they can turn their heads around 180 degrees, like owls. I was looking at a head face on and a back; I thought I had discovered a new bird. Thank goodness for binoculars!

webTitle: Outlook's cool in the hot spots

fields.headline: Outlook's cool in the hot spots
fields.standfirst: What your home is worth after a rollercoaster year depends on where you live. Rupert Jones reports
fields.trailText: What your home is worth after a rollercoaster year depends on where you live. Rupert Jones, reports
fields.body:
East Anglia and south-west England left London standing when it came to how the housing market fared last year, according to new figures published by the Halifax this week.

Homeowners in the west midlands and Northern Ireland also enjoyed a good year, but Scotland and the north of England ended 2000 with lower average house prices than they started it with.

That said, the good news for these two regions is that they look set for a boost this year, as improving economic conditions are expected to help push prices upwards. That's something that will be welcomed by people who own a property, but probably not by those planning to buy a home this year.

In its review of 2000 the Halifax, the country's biggest mortgage lender, says the price of the average UK home is now £86,196 - 5.7% up on a year ago, when the figure was £81,668.

However, it may be argued this figure doesn't mean a great deal when you consider the huge variations in property prices around the country. While a typical semi-detached home in Greater London now costs £226,050, that amount of money would buy almost five similar properties in South Humberside, where the average price-tag is £46,600. Aside from London, there are now 15 counties where a typical semi will set you back more than £100,000 - Surrey (£188,850) and Hertfordshire (£176,950) to Gloucestershire (£103,700) and Bedfordshire (£108,050).

Meanwhile, those counties where the same sort of home may well cost less than £60,000 include Lincolnshire (£54,750), Nottinghamshire (£54,650) and south Yorkshire (£51,700). The Halifax says average house prices rose in all the UK regions during 2000 except for Scotland, where they fell by 4.3% to £61,061, and the north of England, which suffered a 2.2% fall to £55,089.

Its figures show just how much of a rollercoaster ride the London property market went on last year. During the first three months of 2000, house prices in the capital were shooting up at an annual rate of 29.5%. Then things went into reverse for a few months, and by year end the annual rate of price growth had fallen back to 8.3%.

The biggest winners overall last year were East Anglia and the south-west, which saw prices increase by an impressive 13.7% and 12.1% respectively. A typical home in these two areas costs £87,984 and £99,491 respectively. Prices in Northern Ireland ended the year 11.2% up (typical price-tag: £71,749), while there was some good news for west midlands homeowners in the form of an average 10% increase over the year (typical price: £82,128).

Yorkshire and Humberside ended the year little changed, with an annual increase of just 1.1% (£56,197), while Wales saw prices rise 2.7% (£63,619). Martin Ellis at the Halifax says all the evidence suggests the housing market has improved during the last few months, and the omens are pretty good for this year. Signs that manufacturing is recovering bode well for the industrial heartlands away from the south of England, he adds. "We expect improving economic conditions in these regions to increase housing demand and therefore drive up prices more quickly."

At the same time, the high prices in much of the south of England limit the possibilities for further growth there this year. "In light of these trends, the north-south divide in prices should narrow to some degree between now and the end of 2001," says the Halifax.

The bank's figures came hot on the heels of data from Nationwide building society, which says the average UK home increased in value by 9.3% during 2000, and is currently worth £82,188.

Nationwide says the top 10 property hot spots last year were: North Down and Castlereagh, both near Belfast (annual house price growth of 33.9% and 33.3% respectively); Epping Forest, north-east London (32.8%); Rother, East Sussex (28.8%); Crawley, West Sussex (27.2%); Eastleigh, Hants (27.2%); the Suffolk coastal region (26.7%); Gosport, Hants (25%); Test Valley, Hants (23.6%); Weymouth & Portland, Dorset (23.2%).

The areas it reckons will be hot spots during the next few years include Windsor and Maidenhead, Woking in Surrey, Wycombe in Buckinghamshire, Cherwell in North Oxfordshire, Wellingborough and Kettering in Northamptonshire, Stratford-upon-Avon, and Winchester and the New Forest in Hampshire.

"Areas in and around Warwick with good road links, de sirable rural location and proximity to Birmingham are also ones to watch," adds a Nationwide spokesman.

Meanwhile, another survey highlighted just how expensive London is when it comes to renting. In order to live in an average three-bedroom apartment in South Kensington or Mayfair you would probably need to be earning at least £290,000 a year, says online property site GlobalResident.

Even a decent one-bed flat in South Hampstead/Kilburn would require its tenant to have a salary of more than £63,000.
