fields.headline: Green at heart? What a load of old rubbish
fields.standfirst: Whether it's recycling, insulation or alternative fuels, the goverment is generally seen as failing to deliver on energy issues - which, in turn have slid down the youth agenda. Phillip Inman reports
fields.trailText: Whether it's recycling, insulation or alternative fuels, the goverment is generally seen as failing to deliver on energy issues - which, in turn have slid down the youth agenda. Phillip Inman reports
fields.body:
Wine drinkers who put their empties in a bottle bank or recycling box are wasting their time. It's a measure of the chaotic system we have for saving the environment - and, we hope, saving money - that every green bottle used in the UK, most of which contain wine, is dumped in a landfill site once their contents have been enjoyed. Put simply: there is no demand for green glass in the UK and shipping the stuff back to wine producing countries like France, Australia or Chile costs too much money.

A quirk of the recycling system also means that in many areas bottle banks for brown, green and clear glass are tipped into landfill sites if people put the wrong bottles in the wrong container. None of them are recycled. Sorting out the rogue bottles in large bottle banks is not cost effective, say firms that collect rubbish for recycling. There have also been reports of recycling companies dropping newspapers and other waste collected into landfill sites when the price paid for recycled products drops or the capacity to produce goods with recycled materials reaches capacity.

The government wants more people to stop throwing rubbish away and to save energy. But what is it doing, four years after coming to power, to turn into reality the commitments it has made to cut the amount of greenhouse gas emissions?

While much is being done to persuade businesses that cutting emissions can be financially advantageous, little is being done to shift the majority of households over to using energy-saving products like condenser boilers, cars that run on gas and solar panels.

This week a Labour-dominated parliamentary committee said the government had "a long way to go to satisfy the expectations it has raised on the environment and sustainable development". The committee wants an environmental auditor to oversee the government's work and check on its claims that tangible improvements have taken place.

For instance, John Prescott's department of the environment, transport and the regions says it inherited 4m households that could not properly heat their homes. In response, it has brought in many 100% grants targeting people on benefits. The number of people with cold houses has been cut to 3m, it insists - though it cannot say if these households have saved energy using cavity wall insulation, loft insulation or more modern controls on their boilers.

The problem for the government is that households, which account for 44% of all carbon dioxide emissions, are guzzling more gas and electricity every year. The electronic revolution, supported by Tony Blair, is all about having a myriad of electronic appliances on standby, ready to do your bidding at the touch of a remote control, keyboard, or mobile phone handset. General affluence and rising benefit levels are also likely to make matters worse. So the government needs to offer substantial grants, subsidies and tax breaks to minimise the rise in energy use, let alone cut it back to help the planet.

California, some way ahead of us in the e-revolution, has seen its electricity system collapse under the strain. Power cuts are a regular occurrence and power companies have begun to raise the cost of electricity dramatically to drive down demand.

According to a survey for the Co-op Bank this week, the government also has an uphill struggle persuading young homeowners to buy energy saving products and services. The under-25s, once the most environmentally concerned generation, are almost the least concerned today. The survey found that 25% of under-25s and under-35s "are not concerned about the environment at all". Only 9% of the younger group were very concerned.

A government survey published last October found that only 3% consider the environmental impact of an appliance as the most important consideration when shopping, and only 8% considered its energy efficiency to be the key factor.

The main government agency pushing energy efficiency is the Energy Savings Trust. It publicises handy tips for saving energy and will inform callers or visitors to its website which grants are available - something that varies widely from one area to another. Some of the grants are offered by local councils, others by gas and electricity suppliers. Utilities suppliers are forced to devise energy-saving schemes by the government's Easop scheme. Among other things, it demands that suppliers spend £1.20 per customer on emission saving schemes.

Northern Electric, which operates mainly in the north-east and has 2m customers, offers 40% off cavity wall and loft insulation unless applicants are on benefits, in which case the discount is 100%. It also offers discounts of between £20 and £60 on A-rated fridges, freezers and fridge/freezers in its 45 shops. The scheme is open to anyone, but is only marketed to existing customers.

British Gas prefers to promote savings of up to £570 on the installation of a condenser boiler. The boiler has a second fan that recycles heat that would other wise be expelled by the machine.

Until early last year there was a government scheme that gave £200 cash back on the purchase of a condenser boiler, but the fund ran dry and some utility companies have picked up the baton. A British Gas offer can give more in cash terms than the government scheme, but you must choose your machine from a range supplied by British Gas and use the company's installers.

Some councils have taken the issue seriously. The new city of Brighton and Hove and its neighbours in East Sussex complement the obligatory cavity and loft insulation offers with discounts on solar panel installation totalling £250, which sounds great until you find out from Enact, the agency set up to handle in quiries, that installing one panel can cost up to £2,500.

Privately owned cars are also a target. Sales of small cars jumped by over 100,000 last year following the move to cut vehicle excise duty on anything with an engine size under 1100cc (from next year 1200cc cars will be included). Car industry experts reckon the jump had more to do with the arrival of features like ABS brakes and airbags which until recently were the preserve of executive cars, though the tax cut must have helped.

Government attempts to switch cars over to liquid gas (LPG) from petrol is more limited. The Energy Savings Trust has been given £5m pounds to kick-start the changeover and readily confesses that private households are not really in the picture. Only owners of cars which are less than 12 months old receive a grant, which means that the trust mainly talks to fleet car managers about switching their new cars.

Critics say the government has a long way to go before it begins to make an impact on individual consumers. Environmental groups argue that more of Gordon Brown's tax receipts from petrol consumption should be directed into green energy such as burning waste and wind power. It should also subsidise markets for recycled goods to promote their use.

John Prescott's team say they are looking into it, but four years after Labour took power and they seem no nearer getting large numbers of people to switch over.

How you can cut use and save money

The government is keen that we should all fill our kettles with less water and switch off the standby buttons on our televisions to save energy. fields.headline: A Polish Bohème that's as subtle as a brick
fields.standfirst:
La Bohème
Royal Festival Hall, London
*
fields.trailText:
La Bohème
Royal Festival Hall, London
*
fields.body:
The Royal Festival Hall has an unforgiving acoustic at the best of times. But for the staging of one of the world's most famously sensual operas, Puccini's La Bohème, it is one of Britain's least flattering arenas. A transcendent performance would be needed to surmount these architectural difficulties. Sadly, the production by the Polish State Opera of Wroclaws scarcely manages to register in the hall.

The key culprits in this uncommunicative staging are conductor Ewa Michnik and director Waldemar Zawodzinski. The Wroclaw orchestra may not be the Vienna Philharmonic, but they are at least musically committed and technically proficient. Yet Michnik uses them as if they were a military band. The melodic flow of the music is barely recognisable, and Michnik's four-square phrasing subdues the subtlety of Puccini's orchestration. The vivid emotional charge of one of the composer's most intimate and ravishing scores is reduced to a monochrome backdrop, a mere accompaniment to the drama on stage.

Not that Zawodzinski gives the cast much of a chance to express any real dramatic flair. Staid and prop-like, even in the boisterous Act 2 (usually a gift to any production), the singers are ill at ease in the unimaginative set pieces.

The singing in the production does not deserve the mean-spirited approach of conductor and director. Tatiana Pavlovskaya's Mimi and Yevgenny Akimov's Rodolfo have the potential to be a secure, vocally attractive, lead couple; however, there are only flickers of their real gifts. Their farewell in Act 4, as Mimi finally gives in to her consumption, is affecting, but for the most part the pair are without dramatic motivation, seeming to recite rather than relish their roles. And while Maciek Krzysztyniak's Marcello is a suitably love-sick artist, the object of his affections, Jolanta Zmurko's Musetta, lacks the vocal presence to balance his characterisation.

This production turns La Bohème into a muddy reflection of its true brilliance. Yet there is an evergreen audience for Puccini's masterpiece and, for the moment at least, the Polish State Opera of Wroclaw fills an opportunistic gap in London's opera market. But this is a half-baked, poorly realised show.

* Until tomorrow (box office: 020-7960 4242), and then tours in May.

webTitle: Don't go to the dogs in  your old age

fields.headline: Don't go to the dogs in  your old age
fields.standfirst: The government is urging us all to pile into stakeholder schemes to underpin the miserly state provision. Patrick Collinson reports
fields.trailText: The government is urging us all to pile into stakeholder schemes to underpin the miserly state provision. Patrick Collinson reports
fields.body:
You have to be barking mad to rely just on the state pension for your retirement. That's the message from the talking dogs in the government's £6.5m television advertising campaign that began this week, designed to encourage us to stash away more money for our retirement.

Two out of five people in work today - largely the young and the low-paid - do not have anything set aside for their retirement other than the state pension and social security secretary Alistair Darling wants them to do something about it.

This week Mr Darling was at pains to underline that the government's policy is to keep the state pension as the foundation for income at retirement, but is using the adverts to advance another key plank of government policy: stakeholder pensions. These become available on April 6 and the government promises they will be the cheap and simple way for people on lower pay to put aside extra for retirement.

The lure of stakeholders is that they start at just £20 per month, have ultra-low charges and can be stopped or started at any time. But figures prepared by Prudential for Jobs & Money reveal that the £20 per month saver, even after salting away the money for 30 years, will see little in the way of extra income at retirement.

A man aged 65 retiring after 30 years of saving £20 per month will receive a stakeholder pension of £1,770 a year - hardly enough to finance a retirement lifestyle much above the poverty line. What's more, the annual income figure is based on the man taking out an annuity just for himself. If he wanted to have an annuity which benefits his wife on his death, the income figure would be considerably less.

Prudential's figues underline how much people must save to enjoy a decent income on retirement. As the table above shows, £80 per month for 30 years will give you around £7,000 a year on retirement, while even £160 a month will produce an income of little more than £14,000.

If people delay making pension provision until they are in their 40s or 50s the cost of providing a decent pension becomes nearly impossible. Prudential marketing director Sean Tompkins says: "Unless people start saving more for their retirement, over one-third of the population will have to carry on working beyond 65."

But the real reason why people don't put enough aside for pensions is that they are broke. A survey last year by investment company M&G revealed that 67% of families in social classes DE spend every penny of their income on household bills. In total, 46% of the UK's population spend all they have in order to make ends meet.

But the government is not just using advertising. From next year everybody below retirement age in the UK will receive an annual individual pension forecast which will add together the state pension plus company or stakeholder pension forecasts to show how much you will have in retirement.

For many, the forecast will make chilling reading, and may prompt them to start saving more. Everybody connected with pensions knows that the subject is either too difficult, or too boring for most people, especially the young, to take any action.

The lack of interest prompted the DSS to develop the talking dogs advert - using Oscar-winning techniques from the Babe film series - as a way to interest people who find pensions too boring or complex. The DSS believes once people are told about the benefits of stakeholder pensions, take-up will be strong, with around 40% of the target group of low-paid people taking them up.

Accompanying the adverts is a guide to retirement options, available at www.pensionguide.gov.uk or by calling 0845 7313233. Callers will get a free 34-page guide to the options they face and can order any of seven other guides, including occupational pensions, pensions for women, for the self-employed, contracted-out and stakeholder pensions.

What you need to know

What is a stakeholder pension?

Stakeholders are cheap and simple pension plans with government-imposed maximum charges and minimum standards. They go on sale on April 6, with charges capped at 1% per annum and no initial charges. You can make payments from just £20 per month and stop and start them at will. You can transfer between providers at no cost.

Are they a better deal than personal pensions?

You bet. Personal pensions had initial charges of 5-10% plus annual charges of 1-3%, enough to pay big commissions to salesmen and big profits for providers.

Should I take one out?

Only if your employer does not already offer a company pension. Stakeholders are aimed at the 40% of workers who earn between £10,000-£20,000 a year but because they are on contract or self-employed, or work in small companies, are not offered a company scheme.

Why don't I buy an ISA or invest in property instead for my retirement?

Because of the tax relief on stakeholder pensions. You can make payments of up to £3,600 a year (£300 per month) into a stakeholder and earn full tax relief on all the money. This means the government is giving you a 22% or 40% bonus depending on your tax band.

Do I have to be in work to take one out?

No. One of the big innovations in stakeholder is that you can earn tax relief on the money you put in even if you are not working. This means that for the first time people without employment will be able to contribute to a pension and obtain tax relief.

I already have a company pension. Should I switch to a stakeholder?

Almost certainly not. The contributions that an employer makes into your pension far outweigh any benefits that an individual stakeholder pension will give you.

I already have a personal pension. Should I switch to a stakeholder?

You should look into doing so; stakeholders are cheaper and more flexible than personal pensions. Your decision should rest on the size of exit penalty you might face and the length of time you have contributed to a personal pension. The longer you have saved, the less worthwhile it will be to switch.

If my employer offers a stakeholder, should I take it?

It depends on whether your employer is offering to pay any contributions into the plan. Above all, oppose any move by your employer to close down its company pension scheme and offer a stakeholder instead.

Will I still get the state pension?

Yes. The aim of stakeholder is to give a top-up pension to people on low incomes.

Will I pay tax on the income from my stakeholder pension, and will it hit my benefits?

Yes and yes. The income from your stakeholder will be treated like any other income (and any other pension) and will be taxable. A much thornier issue is the benefits problem. For poorer people, the income earned from the stakeholder pension may simply mean that other income, such as housing benefit, will be reduced pound-for-pound.

Will all stakeholder pensions be the same?

Not quite. The rules mean they all charge under 1% a year, but the final pension pot you receive will depend on how successful they are at investing your money.

fields.headline: Hallé Orchestra/ Lu Jia
fields.standfirst:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
***
fields.trailText:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
***
fields.body:
At the age of 18, the Chinese-born pianist Lang Lang already has a considerable reputation and an exclusive recording contract with Telarc, so it should be no surprise that his UK debut was a stunning success. But then teenage virtuosos who can whizz through Rachmaninov's 2nd Piano Concerto are almost too easy to find - there are plenty in Manchester alone. What really distinguished Lang Lang's playing was not so much his flawless technique and his ability to draw a massive range of dynamics and colours from the piano as the sheer joyfulness of his musicianship.

He is one of those rare musicians who can show a sense of absolute delight in every sound they produce. This never gets in the way of the seriousness or the passion of Rachmaninov's music; it is just an added factor that helps turn the performance of even so over-performed a work into a life-enhancing experience. In two encores he showed further dimensions of this sound-loving quality - a Chinese salon piece turned with miraculous charm and some glitteringly technical but still serious Rachmaninov.

fields.headline: Sizer Barker's little big success
fields.standfirst:
Sizer Barker
Fibbers, York
****
fields.trailText:
Sizer Barker
Fibbers, York
****
fields.body:
If pop success had anything to do with the scale of a band's equipment, Sizer Barker wouldn't make it past the garage stage. Their technical support includes the tiniest drum kit in pop history, a keyboard small enough to throw inside a rucksack and "amplifiers" that remind me of an aunt's old tea trolleys. However, the band's expansive sound is the opposite of small-minded.

Hailing from Liverpool and named after a gravestone inscription, the Barkers scored an unlikely (ie, it's not Steps) Radio 1 hit in December with their mesmerising Day by Day, a delicate song about memories and the passage of time. A superb 40-minute set proves Day by Day to be no one-off.

After a year of processed pop, Sizer Barker's sound is a wonderful, idiosyncratic thing. At various times you'll hear fractured samples (their array of electronic FX all emanate from a typically tiny box), spaghetti western atmospheres and one-note, female punk bass lines. However, they settle for a cinematic pop thrill somewhere between Beck, Shack and the late 1980s incarnation of Père Ubu, topped off by Carl Brown's superb McCulloch-does-Dylan voice.

The band could have stepped out of One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (and this is a compliment), and Brown has a leading man's charisma. Bald, stocky and moustached, he is the Lee Van Cleef of Scousepop, but a move into acting would be songwriting's loss. Not a note is wasted, nor an opportunity for self-deprecating humour missed. Brown's barmy banter is often completely at odds with the mood of the songs - Day by Day is so sad it makes Jeff Buckley sound like the Wombles - but that's why it works, terrible jokes about Scouse omelettes ("First you rob three eggs...") and all.

Hardly a moment goes by without a surprise. At one point the drummer plays with a brush and shaker, at another the FX man shocks everybody by producing a flute. Most gloriously, the thoroughly peculiar but irresistible Indian ragga chant of Hotel Juicy Parlour (don't ask), sung in deranged high voices, could be a whopping summer hit. If an audience of fewer than 20 can emit "riotous" applause, Sizer Barker receive it. William Sizer Barker, whose tombstone provides their monicker, is probably dancing in his grave.

* At L2, Liverpool (0151-707 9977) on Friday, then tours.

fields.headline: Poor turnout for 'perfect' Pelléas
fields.standfirst:
Pelléas and Mélisande
Grand Theatre, Leeds
***
fields.trailText:
Pelléas and Mélisande
Grand Theatre, Leeds
***
fields.body:
For many people, Pelléas and Mélisande is the most perfect opera of all. Every note has its importance. Every instrumental texture has its meaning. Every character has a solid place in the drama. And the music generates a world of haunting, ambiguous colours that stays with you for life.

More than that, the Leeds revival by Opera North has what you could call a dream cast for a performance in English, using Hugh Macdonald's old but still marvellously idiomatic translation. Joan Rodgers sings like an angel and has the skill to flip from insecurity to skittishness that the role of Mélisande needs. Robert Hayward makes every note for Golaud sound as though it were written for him, exploiting his astonishing range of sound quality and clarity of diction. William Dazeley is superb as Pélleas, while Frances McCafferty gives a true dignity to the smaller part of Genevieve. And if Clive Bayley is incapable of making Arkel look or sound old and wise, he sings the notes with a richness you rarely hear.

What's more, Paul Daniel returned to the orchestra he had conducted for eight years, and they played as though he had never been away, showing the delicacy and control that can make them sound as good as any opera orchestra in the world. Daniel has a superb ability to keep the energy constantly moving in a score that can easily meander. If he occasionally overpowered the voices that was because of stage business: to expect Pelléas to sing his biggest climax while pulling off his boots is asking for trouble.

So why so many empty seats? Presumably because people knew it was a revival of the 1995 production by Richard Jones, a production that does everything it can to coarsen the delicacy and hide the ambiguities of the work. Any director who can cover the last notes of the score with slamming doors and then suddenly jam down the lights is surely in the wrong business. To play the whole opera in a lunatic asylum and portray all the characters as crackers casts a garish gloss on the work. To turn the aged Arkel's relationship with Mélisande into something so intensely physical and sexual seems crass; and it spoils the impact of the final scene.

Certainly, Antony McDonald's designs are pretty, but all those little boxes now look like the oldest cliche in theatre. Just occasionally, as in the last confrontation of Pelléas and Mélisande, the magic worked theatrically. But rarely has opera production been so ghastly and anti-musical.

* Tonight, then in rep. Box office: 0113-222 6222.

fields.headline: Don't jump while deal hopes last
fields.standfirst: As the stricken firm makes a last-ditch bid to plug the black hole in its finances, policyholders are urged to sit tight. Rupert Jones reports
fields.trailText: As the stricken firm makes a last-ditch bid to plug the black hole in its finances, policyholders are urged to sit tight.Rupert Jones reports
fields.body:
A frantic round of meetings and talks this week raised hopes that a solution to the Equitable Life crisis might just be in sight, so the message to policyholders is: sit tight and think very, very carefully before pulling out any of your money.

Last-ditch proposals that could help to secure a brighter future for the troubled insurer gathered momentum this week. It emerged that a deal may be struck to plug the so-called black hole in its finances, and also that discussions are proceeding apace about the sale of parts or even the whole of the business.

If either or both come to fruition, this could improve the fortunes of the 1m with-profits policyholders, who have been warned they will face lower investment returns in future, yet will be hit with a 10% penalty if they have the temerity to transfer their funds to another company.

An action group representing some of the people with so-called guaranteed annuities has indicated they may be willing to cut their losses and go for a compromise. The Equitable Life Guaranteed Annuity Rate Action Group - whose members brought the court case that led to the company's current predicament - met with Equitable this week and put forward proposals aimed at setting a maximum limit on the cost of meeting the guarantees.

At the moment there doesn't seem to be anything stopping these costs spiralling upwards and hitting several billion pounds, and it is this uncertainty that frightened off the companies that considered buying Equitable late last year. The failure to find a buyer, combined with a House of Lords ruling that Equitable must meet the guarantees in full, led to the company shutting its doors to new business and imposing tough new conditions on its policyholders. Precise details of the deal have been kept under wraps, but it is understood the action group is suggesting that Equitable gives the 90,000 people with guaranteed annuities a one-off payment into their fund. In return for this, they would give up their rights to full payouts. The action group is thought unlikely to accept a total payout of less than £1.5bn.

Equitable is now giving this proposal a lot of thought and, while there has been speculation that a deal might be imminent, the company says it is a complicated issue and a lot of work still needs to be done. "We have got 90,000 people, all of whom have individual contracts. In practical terms it's not simple."

If a deal is struck, it would almost certainly have to be voted on by all the company's policyholders at a special meeting, and it would require the approval of a majority of members. In other words, there is some way to go before any deal of this sort could be put into practice.

Meanwhile, the company said on Thursday that it hopes to announce the sale of part(s) or possibly all of the business by the end of this month. It said it was in talks with several companies which should lead to offers being made for the various parts of its business, either "as a whole or separately". These words raised hopes that the sale of the company as a going concern was still a possibility. Many people would argue this would be the best news of all for the with-profits policyholders as it would put much more money in the kitty for delivering better investment returns in future, and might mean the company is able to reduce or even scrap the 10% penalty for withdrawing your money.

While policyholders might well want to stop making new contributions to an Equitable policy, the best advice would appear to be to keep any money already paid in where it is while we wait and see how things develop.

You'll kick yourself if you paid the 10% penalty for withdrawing your funds and then this charge is reduced or abolished in a few weeks' time. Looking on the bleak side, however, Equitable could decide to increase the penalty further to prevent a mass exodus of policyholders if things goes pear-shaped.

fields.headline: Counting the cost of a little Xtra you missed
fields.standfirst: The Halifax has some £170m in unclaimed shares: vast sums still await their owners. Rupert Jones on the cash that time forgot
fields.trailText: The Halifax has some £170m in unclaimed shares: vast sums still await their owners. Rupert Jones on the cash that time forgot
fields.body:
Time is running out for 145,000 former members of the Halifax who have still not claimed the free shares they are entitled to more than three years after it converted from a building society into a bank.

The Halifax said this week it was giving three months' notice of its plans to sell the £170m worth of shares languishing unclaimed in its vaults. At the same time it will set up a charity, the Halifax Foundation, and plans to use money raised from the sale to fund a £3m-a-year programme for good causes.

It's not too late to claim Halifax shares if you think you're owed some, but you'll need to get your skates on. Claims must be received by the bank by April 7. After that date you won't be able to get your shares, but you will still be entitled to receive the sale proceeds together with any dividends that would have been paid prior to the sale.

This £170m represents just a tiny proportion of the multi-billion pound mountain of forgotten loot just waiting to be claimed by its rightful owners. Here we look at what you should do if you think you're owed a windfall by one of the building societies that converted in the last few years, or if you're wondering whether you may have unknowingly won a premium bond prize.

Around 7.6m people shared in the jackpot when the Halifax made its stock market splash in June 1997, but around 145,000 of them have never come forward. In most cases it is thought these people have moved home without informing the Halifax of their new address, and may have forgotten about the shares they were allocated. The Halifax says it also can't rule out the possibility that a very small number of people may have deliberately not claimed their shares because they were vehemently opposed to it abandoning building society status.

The average Halifax handout awaiting collection by its owner is worth £1,500. Harry Baines, company secretary, says: "There has been a great deal of publicity over the past three years about the Halifax's conversion but the message still does not seem to have reached all those entitled to shares."

A dedicated customer helpline has been set up by the Halifax to handle enquiries about unclaimed shares: call 0870 240 0717, 9am-5pm Mon-Fri. To qualify for shares, a saver must have been the sole or first-named joint holder of a qualifying account which must have been continuously in credit between November 25, 1994 and June 2, 1997, and must have contained at least £100 on the first of these two dates and December 31, 1996. Similar rules apply to mortgage-holders.

The other three building societies which converted into banks in 1997 also have thousands of former members who still haven't come forward to collect what's rightfully theirs:

Alliance & Leicester has 68,000 missing shareholders who between them are owed around £106m. A&L sold their shares on September 27 last year, and if you think you're due a windfall you can claim the proceeds - a tidy £1,560 each, including dividends - by writing in, giving as much information as possible, to: Shareholder Services, Alliance & Leicester, Carlton Park, Narborough, Leicester LE9 5XX.

The Woolwich , which has been bought by Barclays, sold 21m unclaimed shares worth more than £50m on October 11 last year. This money has now been ring-fenced and if you're one of the 38,400 people entitled to a payout you should call the Barclays shareholder line on 0870 702 0196.

Northern Rock seems to have been more successful than the others in tracing its lost shareholders. Of the 885,000 people who qualified for free shares following its October 1997 flotation, only 5,000 have still not come for ward to claim their entitlement. It placed adverts in the papers towards the end of last year informing people it intended to sell these shares, possibly this year. If you think you're owed a windfall, you must get your claim in by the end of this month - otherwise, you'll only be able to claim the cash. Call its shareholder relations helpline on 0191 279 4877.

Bradford & Bingley floated on the stock market on December 4, resulting in windfalls for just under 2.7m people. B&B says that fewer than 5% of the eligible former members have yet to claim their free shares. If you're one of them, ring Computershare Services (the firm handling the share issue) on 0870 703 003 and ask for a B&B shares claim pack.

Meanwhile National Savings has millions of pounds worth of unclaimed premium bond prizes sitting in its vaults, and there is quite a bit more cash languishing in savings accounts that have not been touched for years.

While 99.5% of premium bond winners have been traced, one in every 200 prizes won is never collected and there are currently 324,000 unclaimed prizes worth £19.2m.

The largest outstanding prize is £25,000, which National Savings reckons belongs to someone who has since moved to Canada. "Despite persistent efforts, we have so far been unable to trace this winner," it says. "We contacted the British Embassy in Canada. They put out notices in Canada saying this money was outstanding." There are also two £10,000 unclaimed prizes and 18 £5,000 prizes.

Unlike the National Lottery, there is no time limit on claiming your prize. There are three ways of checking if you're owed anything. You can write to: Premium Bonds, National Savings, Blackpool FY3 9YP, and it will make a free check. Or log on to the website, which has a database of unclaimed prizes. You will need to key in your holder's number.

Alternatively, check the annual supplement to the London Gazette, available at main post offices, which lists all the unclaimed prizes.

There are companies out there which will check to see if you are due an unclaimed payout from a financial services company, but you usually have to pay a fee. One which may be worth a look is the unclaimed assets register, run by insurance broker Aon (www.uar.co.uk tel 0870 241 1713).

fields.body:
Only truly great plays survive their time. Alexander Gelman's two-hander - about a family destroyed by the pressures of the Soviet system and its unrealistic five-year plans - may seem rather dated, but it still has something to tell us.

Andrei Gladkov's cry of "I don't get paid for being a husband and a father, you know" has probably echoed around plenty of British family homes in recent decades as jobs have become less secure and more demanding, and the urge to consume more, bigger and better becomes greater. The British, after all, work the longest hours in Europe.

Gelman's play is set in the early 1980s. Gladkov, the manager of a large Soviet industrial building project, is doing well: he has a three-bedroom flat, a phone and a car. But the strain of keeping the books balanced in an inefficient set-up riddled with corruption and cronyism is great. Yet Gladkov is a man with connections and the smug smile never leaves his face - until his wife, Natasha, accuses him of having been responsible for the industrial accident in which their teenage son lost his hands.

Other plays - most notably Franz Xaver Kroetz's The Nest, in which the pressures of capitalism cause a lorry driver to damage the people he loves most - have dealt with this kind of scenario more effectively, and the way the play is constructed means that the revelation about the son comes as no surprise. But from here on in the drama becomes infinitely more interesting as the slippery Gladkov becomes like a fish speared on the hook of his wife's anger and looking for a way to escape.

As both manoeuvre to seize the moral high ground and gain a psychological advantage, it soon becomes clear that the corruption of Gladkov's workplace has infiltrated their marriage and is symptomatic of a wider infection in a society in which backhanders and personal connections are the only way to get on. Nobody is innocent.

Inevitably, events in the former USSR have superseded the play and it might well have greater impact in a new translation that dared to move it rather closer to home - say to Docklands or Surrey. But Steven James-Little's production fits neatly into the claustrophobic Finborough space, and Andrew McDonald and Fiz Marcus deliver as the mendacious Gladkov and his equally culpable wife, Natasha.

* Until February 3 (box office: 020-7373 3842) then transfers to The Arches (0141-221 4001), Glasgow, from February 8-10.
